Description: A document prepared by experts working for Russian Human Rights Commissioner Sergei Kovalyov says 24,350 civilians from the Chechen capital Grozny have been killed in fighting.  The document said the toll, in the two months up to January 25, 1995 included children, women and men.  Moscow has given no death toll for the number of Chechen civilians killed.

Russian jets twice bombed a northern Afghan district, killing eight people and wounding eight, according to Afghanistan's official Kabul Radio.  The jets bombed Darwaz district in Badakhshan province on January 2 and 3.  Russian troops are deployed in areas bordering Tajikistan to help fight Islamic rebels.

Russian air raids destroyed part of the hospital in the Chechen town of Chali, the international medical organization Doctors Without Borders said.  Bombs hit the hospital and market place, killing 30 people and wounding 150.  The hospital's maternity and pediatric department were destroyed.  Water, electricity and heating were cut off.

Rwanda's government army said on Monday its troops attacked a camp in the southwest where 12 homeless people were slaughtered and more than 30 were wounded. A spokesman for the Rwanda Patriotic Army (RPA) said two officers were arrested in connection with Saturday's attack on Busanze camp near the border with Burundi in which he said 11 people were killed. Aid workers who visited Busanze on Sunday found a trench filled with 12 corpses, five of them children, with limbs broken by machete blows and executed with a bullet to the back of the head. Thirty-six wounded were taken from the camp to the Medical Emergency Relief International health centre at Runyombyi. U.N. officials confirmed that 12 people were killed in the attack. Some aid workers on Sunday said they suspected gunmen loyal to the ousted Hutu regime in Rwanda were behind the brutal raid.

Russian jets bombed a border village in the northern Afghan province of Badakhshan, killing 15 people and wounding more than 30.  The broadcast from the official Kabul Radio said the bombing in Badakhshan's Darwaz district also caused extensive damage.

Six adults died and five children were injured when a Russian artillery shell slammed into their refuge in the Chechen capital Grozny.  Those killed were among a group trying to escape the battle zone.  Their truck had been damaged by shrapnel and the group, none of then injured by the initial blast, had taken refuge in a nearby building.

The Denpasar military court had earlier heard how on January 12 in Fabo village near Liquisa in East Timor, Private First Class Rusdin Maumere shot the six civilians after a member of his patrol had been injured in a skirmish with a suspected guerrilla.
Comments: The report by the Indonesian government originally stated that the six killed were members or a rebel group.  This was contested by international groups prompting the government to launch an investigation into the incident.  The government later found that the six killed were civilians and tried the individual military personnel responsible accordingly.

Description: Monrovia exploded in frustration at the news and an angry crowd thronged the airport and stoned cars. Protests grew in size and intensity on Saturday, when security sources said at least eight people died in riots.  They did not give further details but security sources said some of the dead may have been shot by ECOMOG troops trying to control enraged crowds attacking politicians' homes.

U.S. Ambassador to Burundi Robert Kruger says at least 67 people, including a number of children, have been killed by armed men in a new outbreak of ethnic killing north of Bujumbura, the Burundi capital. In a telephone interview broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation on Sunday, Kruger said he saw 67 corpses during a tour of the rural areas last week, and the total number killed was probably much higher. He said the victims appeared to be members of the Hutu majority, and local sources blamed the Burundi army, which is still dominated by the Tutsi ethnic minority, for some of the killings -- apparently in revenge for attacks on Tutsis. Burundi officials said hundreds of people, both Hutus and Tutsis, had died in sporadic outbursts of violence in the last few months.
Secondary.Source: U.S. Ambassador To Burundi Robert Kruger

Perp.State.Other: Non-State, No State Sanction, otherwise unclear
Description: Reuters reports on 02/05/1995 that gunmen in western Karachi opened fire on a mosque where victims were praying.  Eight were killed, and 25 injured in the attack.  "But it was not immediately clear whether the shooting was related to the [general] strike or to the political and ethnic violence that has plagued Pakistan's commercial capital for years."
Comments: No evidence or claims in report that relate this incident or the "gunmen" to any other attack, simply that they occurred on the same day in Karachi.

Perp.State.Other: Non-State, No State Sanction, otherwise unclear
Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: Fund-raising centre for militant group, no mention if victims were workers, militants, or civilians.
Description: Reuters reported on 02/05/1995 that gunmen fired upon a Harkutal Ansar fund-raising centre in Karachi, killing 10 and injuring 15.  The centre supports military training for guerrillas who fight in India-controlled Kashmir.
Comments: The report did not indicate what the victims' roles were at the centre.  It supports and trains militants, but it is unclear whether the 10 victims were civilian workers or militants.  However, nothing reported indicates that fire was returned or that the victims were armed in any way.

Description: Reuters reported on 02/11/1995 that Indian Paramilitary Border Patrol Forces fired on and killed 5 civilian shopkeepers in retaliation for the earlier killing of two of their force by Kashmiri separatists.
Comments: The Indian troops were angry at the earlier attack and chose to avenge their comrades' deaths by opening fire at shops near their bunker, killing 5 and injuring 37.  However, most of the injuries were from the ensuing panic and stampede to evacuate the area.

Description: Police and striking factory workers clashed at Ghorasal, about 25 miles from Dakar, during a wage protest.  Labor leaders claim the protests have claimed five lives in Ghorasal and left nearly 300 people injured.  Hospitals reported two dead since the protests began on Sunday, while the Home Ministry said one worker had been killed so far when police fired on a rampaging mob at Ghorasal.
Secondary.Source: Abul Bashar, leader of the Worker's Action Committee

Scorched.Earth.Tactics: destroyed or damaged dozens of buildings
Description: Russian jets bombed a village in the northern Afghan province of Badakhshan, killing 10 people and wounding 24, the official Kabul Radio said.  The bombing on the Maymay village in Badakhshan's Darwaz district also destroyed or damaged dozens of buildings, including a high school.

Residents of Zaire's South Kivu province have urged their government to launch an inquiry into recent massacres in neighbouring Burundi. 
In a statement faxed to Reuters from Bukavu, eastern Zaire, on Sunday, the residents blamed the Burundi government and its army for the deaths of more than 200 Zaireans in Burundi. The statement, signed by a seven-member committee headed by Professor Modeste Wasso Mbilizi, called on Zaire's government to launch an international inquiry into the causes of the recent massacres in Burundi. They said the latest killings were not the first time such acts have been committed against Zaireans in Burundi. The statement by the Zaireans followed the recent outbreak of fighting in the Burundi capital Bujumbura, which sparked an exodus of Zaireans across the nearby border into eastern Zaire. The violence in Bujumbura was mainly between the local Tutsi and Hutu ethnic groups. But an unknown number of the large Zairean community in the city were among those killed last month.
Secondary.Source: Residents Of Zaire's South Kivu Province

Perp.State.Military: Sarajevo Romanija Corps (a unit of the Bosnian Serb army (VRS))
Description: Bosnian Serb forces of the Sarajevo Romanija Corps carried out a prolonged campaign of shelling civilians in Sarajevo, killing 59 and injuring 162 between April and August 1995. The Sarajevo shelling campaign was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs, who sought to control parts of Bosnian and who wanted to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions, and non-Serbs, who supported independence for the region. The conflict became militarized about 1992 and included a campaign of ethnic cleansing to organized by Bosnian Serbs.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: Leaders of Turkey's Moslem Alawite minority said on Saturday that 30 people died in the four days of rioting during which witnesses say police opened fire on demonstrators.  Previously leaders had said 34 were killed. Turkish officials have said that 17 people died in the clashes in two Istanbul neighbourhoods sparked on Sunday by unknown gunmen's attack on Alawite coffee shops in the city's Gazi neighbourhood. The protests were brought under control after police were withdrawn from riot-hit areas and soldiers moved in. Officials from the Alawite Haci Bektasi Veli Association in the Gazi neighbourhood, where the protests started, said another 45 people were still unaccounted for and 296 were wounded. The demonstrations -- which spread to Ankara where police used water cannons and batons to scatter protesters -- were the fiercest to hit western Turkey since the 1980 military coup.
Secondary.Source: Officials from the Alawite Haci Bektasi Veli Association in the Gazi neighbourhood

Description: Angola's rebel UNITA movement said on Saturday government troops killed 30 people in the northern Bengo province and warned that heavy fighting would follow if U.N. peacekeepers did not resolve the situation.  UNITA radio, monitored in the nearby West African state of Sao Tome and Principe, said a government offensive which began on Thursday around Bula Atumba had left 30 dead, including one UNITA soldier.

Burundi's president, giving the first official tally of deaths in Friday's ethnic clashes in Burundi's capital, said on Sunday that at least 150 people had been killed. "There have been around 150 killings at least," President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya told Radio France Info in a telephone interview from Burundi. The figure was much lower than the 500 deaths, predominantly of members of the Hutu tribe, reported on the basis of eyewitnesses accounts after last Friday's night of rampage in Bujumbura by Tutsi militiamen. Ntibantunganya, a Hutu, blamed young Tutsis for what he called "acts of ethnic purification, of Balkanisation" -- a reference to alleged killings of Moslems by Serbs in the former Yugoslav republic of Bosnia. "The population is feeling helpless. When you see the way violence and massacres tend to spread, the population can only be worried," he said.

Locality: between Benguela city and Calongo village
Description: UNITA radio also said Angolan troops pulled six people from a vehicle en route from Benguela city, held by the government, to Calongo village, which is under rebel control, on March 25 and shot them dead. There was no independent confirmation.

"They started killing on a nearby hill and then worked through the village, killing people mostly with guns." Accounts the massacre by residents of Kizi village largely substantiated reports from aid workers and diplomats that more than 400 Hutus were slaughtered. They conflicted with a Burundian military spokesman saying he was aware of only some 20 dead in the Gasorwe region and that the reports of 400 dead were greatly exaggerated. "The operation started on March 29 with a combined force of Burundian military and Tutsi Burundi, displaced from nearby camps...people recognised some of the Tutsi displaced," said Bayuga. "They killed men, women and children...just because they are Hutus." Diplomats and aid workers said more than 400 Hutus were killed by troops of the Tutsi-dominated army and Tutsi gunmen in more than five locations in Gasorwe region, including Kisi. Military spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Jean-Bosco Daradangwe said he knew of only about 20 deaths among what he called Hutu guerrillas and civilians taken hostage by them in Gasorwe region last week. He said reports of 400 were exaggerated but the army did not have a definitive toll. He said the army had been hunting Hutu gunmen of the Palipehutu Movement in the region for days.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) or Abu Sayyaf (both were blamed by the government)
Description: Moslem rebels in the Philippines swooped on a town on Tuesday in a well-planned raid by land and sea that left at least 26 people dead and 30 wounded, four banks pillaged and the town centre ablaze.  Northern Mindanao Police director Colonel Orville Gabuna told reporters most of the casualties were civilians who might have been killed in crossfire between rebels and troops.
Citation: 04 April 1995        Reuters news    lba0000020011103dr4408wod    and    03 April 1996     Reuters news   lba0000020011018ds4309pxy
Comments: It was unclear who did most of the killings of the civilians, but since the report said most were killed in cross fire I used both the military and the rebel troops as the perpetrators.  The government officials said the attackers were either members of the Moro National Liberation Front of Abu Sayyaf.

Description: A protest over high utility prices exploded into violence today near Teheran, and opposition groups say more than 100 people were killed when security forces moved in to subdue rioters.  Iran's state-run news organizations said the unrest was minor, and did not report casualties. But sources reached by telephone in Tehran, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the protest had turned deadly.  The official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, said protesters gathered in Islamshahr, a township about 22 miles southwest of Tehran, and smashed bank windows. However, an opposition group based in Paris, the Organization for Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms for Iran, reported 144 demonstrators killed and hundreds injured when helicopter gunships attacked a peaceful crowd. The group said about 100,000 Iranians were protesting the doubling of utility and fuel bills and high rates for drinking water.
Secondary.Source: Organization for Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms for Iran

Description: Five hostages and six guerrillas were killed on Friday in a running series of firefights between troops and Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines.
Comments: The Philippine troops attacked the fleeing Abu Sayyef rebels using military helicopters and ground forces.  A soldier just returning from the operation said the rebels were using the hostages as "human shields" killing five of them.  Reuters photographer Enrique de Castro was present at the scene.

Description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said that Russian troops had killed at least 250 people, mostly civilians, while taking the Chechen town of Samashki.  A Red Cross official accused Russia of using "disproportionate" force to capture the town, which Moscow has said was a Chechen rebel stronghold.  The death toll had been estimated the ICRC delegates who admit it's hard to be precise on such a count and they could have missed some in the count.
Secondary.Source: International Committee of the Red Cross
Comments: Not all of the 250 dead were civilians but the report doesn't clarify how many of the deaths involved combatants.  Instead, the report just says that most of the casualties were civilians

Description: The shooting deaths of 14 suspected drug traffickers and bank robbers by Brazilian police appear to be a massacre and not legitimate police action, an international human rights group charged on Friday.
Citation:
Reuters News 08 May 1995 lba0000020011103dr58081ob 
Reuters News 12 May 1995 lba0000020011103dr5c07q79
Comments: Perps identified as police.  Victims listed as suspected drug traffickers/bank robbers.  Police claim justified raid but a number of children were killed/injured and later reports indicate suspicion of deliberate massacre.  Firearms indicated.

Description: Russian jets bombed an Afghan town close to the border with Tajikistan, killing at least five people, the official Kabul Radio said on Tuesday.  The jets dropped 19 bombs in the attack on the town of Madessa in Badakhshan province.
Afghan officials and witnesses have said Russian jets based in Tajikistan killed 125 civilians and wounded 250 in a raid on the northern town of Taloqan and a border district.

Locality: The Banks Of The Rubyiro River
Description: Rwandan government troops killed 16 civilian men in southwest Rwanda last Friday in retaliation for an attack by unidentified gunmen, a U.N. spokesman said on Wednesday. The spokesman, Ismail Diallo, said the 16 were shot and killed and one wounded on the banks of the Rubyiro river in the southwest on Friday after unidentified gunmen attacked Rwanda Patriotic Army (RPA) troops, killing one and wounding one. He said 20 RPA soldiers later rounded up 17 local men, all civilians, and took them to the banks of the Rubyiro river, 22 km (14 miles) southeast of the border town of Cyangugu, and gunned them down. Sixteen were killed and one who was wounded pretended to be dead and later reached Mashesha hospital, where he was treated.

Russian air raids in the Maymay village in the Darwaz district of Badakhshan in Afghanistan killed 12 civilians.  The event was reported by government-controlled Kabul radio and there was no independent confirmation.

Rebels said government planes bombed southern Sudan on Wednesday, killing five civilians and violating a ceasefire mediated by former U.S. president Jimmy Carter. The South Sudan Independence Army (SSIA) led by Riek Machar said the five civilians including women and children were killed and three people were seriously wounded in the hour-long raid. It said the raid was the 14th violation by Khartoum's forces in SSIA-controlled areas of the two-month ceasefire brokered by Carter at the end of last month to allow aid agencies time to launch a campaign to eradicate Guinea worm and river blindness.

An international inquiry into the April 22 massacre of Hutu refugees at Kihebo camp in Rwanda failed to answer many of the questions left swirling following the gruesome bloodbath.  For instance, the government has claimed 338 dead, Australian U.N. peacekeepers said they and Zambian troops counted 4,050 bodies, and finally the United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda gave a "scientific count" of 2,000 dead. The government denies its troops were responsible for the killings but says 300 people died after Hutu gunmen among the refugees opened fire on troops trying to close the camp.  UNAMIR said virtually no arms were found there, contrary to the Rwandan government's assertion that Hutu hardliners had an arsenal inside the IDP camps. Quoting eye-witness accounts, the human rights groups said at least one rocket propelled grenade was fired directly into crowds of people at Kibeho on Saturday. In another incident soldiers had fired for two hours continuously. "The team also collected numerous eyewitness accounts of similar actions by RPA soldiers the previous day (Saturday) and of soldiers shooting or throwing grenades at women and children who were either already effectively in custody or otherwise posed no threat whatsoever to RPA soldiers," the statement said.
Comments: Multiple numbers were given for the death count, the highest one was recorded; the others can be found in the description.

Description: 195 people were killed when Bosnian Serb separatists shelled the town of Tuzla. The attack on the UN designated "safe area" was apparently in retaliation for NATO bombings of Bosnian Serb targets earlier in the day. Most of the deaths and injuries occurred when a shell hit a crowded city center. The attack was a part of an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs. Bosnian Serbs sought to control parts of the region and also wanted to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions. Non-Serbs supported a separate Bosnian state.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia
Citation: ICTFY Indictment of Karadzic & Mladic (in Cigar & Williams, p. 263)
Comments: News wires reported death counts of 71 and injury counts of 150 or more; the ICTFY Indictment noted 195 killed in this incident, presumable this count includes the number of injured persons who later died. Eyewitness account was reported in Reuters 25 May 95 lba0000020011103dr5p07ecm. I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict; coding as such is in keeping with ICTFY accounts. Journalistic accounts of this event described the Bosnian Serb perpetrators as non-state actors.

Description: A Namibian commando unit in armoured vehicles crossed into Angola and shot dead 16 civilians and wounded 12, Angolan rebel UNITA radio said on Monday. The radio, monitored in the island state of Sao Tome and Principe, gave no reason for the incident which it said happened in the last few days in southern Cunene province. The report could not be independently confirmed and there have been no such reports in the Angolan media.

The United Nations on Friday called for investigations by Burundi's government into a massacre of Hutu civilians by mainly Tutsi troops. "The United Nations special envoy to Burundi deplores the latest violence and the death of innocent civilians, for the most part women and elderly," said a statement from the office of the envoy, Ahmedou Ould Abdullah. Both Abdullah and the United States embassy appealed for the government to establish a commission of inquiry into Wednesday's violence and to publish the results. Witnesses said troops used bullets and machetes on Wednesday night to slaughter whole families, picking easy targets like the old, the sick and the very young. The U.N. statement put the figure of the death toll of innocents at 30 killed on Wednesday when hundreds of soldiers from the mostly Tutsi army moved into the city districts of Kamenge and Gasenyi to flush out Hutu militias. But foreign reporters counted the freshly-butchered corpses of at least 40 women, children and elderly people. Army spokesman Lt-Colonel Longin Minani denied that Tutsi troops were responsible, saying Hutu gunmen were capable of murdering their own tribesmen to tarnish the army's reputation.
Comments: While the U.N. put the death toll at 30, foreign reporters counted 40 bodies of civilian casualties.  The army has denied responsibility, blaming Hutu militias for the massacre.  The U.N. alleges that the Tutsi troops are culpable.

Perp.State.Military: Sarajevo Romanija Corps (a unit of the Bosnian Serb army (VRS))
Description: "A 120 mm mortar shell struck a line of civilians, numbering approximately 50-70, waiting for water distribution in Marka Oreskovica Street, Dobrinja. Seven people were killed and twelve injured." The attack was carried out by Bosnian Serb forces who were engaged in a prolong campaign of shelling civilians in Sarajevo. The Sarajevo shelling campaign was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs, who sought to control parts of Bosnian and who wanted to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions, and non-Serbs, who supported independence for the region. The conflict became militarized about 1992 and included a campaign of ethnic cleansing to organized by Bosnian Serbs.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict. Note that journalistic accounts of the event (Reuters 18 Jun 95 lba0000020011103dr6i06qtr) described the Bosnian Serb perpetrators as non-state actors.

Description: Gunfire and grenade explosions rocked Burundi's capital on Sunday as fighting between Hutu militia groups and the Tutsi-dominated army intensified. Aid workers said displaced Hutus who had taken refuge outside the city reported that between 30 and 40 civilians were killed by mortars fired by the army. "The total could well be higher," an aid worker told Reuters. "But 30 to 40 seems to be a realistic figure." "Our fear is total. There could be an explosion in Burundi," Rwanda's Foreign Minister Anastaza Gasana said in Addis Ababa, speaking of fears that the tribal feud which killed up to a million people in Rwanda last year was about to erupt in neighbouring Burundi.
Mexican officials denied charges on Thursday that police murdered 17 peasants in cold blood, but relatives of the dead insisted it was a deliberate massacre.
Citation:
Reuters News 28 June 1995 lba0000020011103dr6s06ce3
Reuters News 29 June 1995 lba0000020011103dr6t06ep7
Comments: Perps identified as police.  Victims identified as peasants.  Police dispute whether it was a deliberate attack on the peasants or whether the attack was in self-defense.

Description: The killing of seven members of a family in a suburb of Grozny threatened peace negotiations between Russia and Chechen rebels.  Men wearing Russian military uniforms shot the family but Russia's military denied any involvement in the deaths.

Serb forces massacred at least 4,000 and as many as 8,000 ethnic Albanians at Srebrenica in July 1995. At the time, Srebrenica was a UN designated "safe haven" for ethnic Albanian refugees displaced by on-going ethnic violence and civil war. Most of the casualties were Bosnian Muslim men, many of whom were of military age. A Bosnian Serb military official refuted claims that Serb forces had "massacred thousands of people" in Srebrenica. The campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Bosnian Serbs sought to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions; other Bosnians supported independence for the region. Bosnian Serb forces used a campaign of "ethnic cleansing" to force all non-Serbs from proclaimed Serb areas, which included wholesale massacres of non-Serb civilians, as a part of their strategy to gain control over parts of Bosnia.
Secondary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia
Citation: Reuters 29 Oct 95 lba0000020011103drat02fby; Reuters 01 Nov 95 lba0000020011103drb102b7w
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: Bosnian Serb forces killed about 150 Bosnian Muslim men at Cerska Valley  following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Bosnian Serbs sought to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions; other Bosnians supported independence for the region. Bosnian Serb forces used a  campaign of "ethnic cleansing" to force all non-Serbs from proclaimed Serb areas, which included wholesale massacres of non-Serb civilians, as a part of their strategy to gain control over parts of Bosnia.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: Bosnian Serb forces executed approximately 1,000 Bosnian Serb men in the Kravica warehouse following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Bosnian Serbs sought to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions; other Bosnians supported independence for the region. Bosnian Serb forces used a  campaign of "ethnic cleansing" to force all non-Serbs from proclaimed Serb areas, which included wholesale massacres of non-Serb civilians, as a part of their strategy to gain control over parts of Bosnia.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: Bosnian Serb forces executed approximately 1,000 Bosnian Serb men in Orahovac following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Description: Bosnian Serb forces executed around 1,500 to 2,000 Bosnian Serb men in Petkovci Dam following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Bosnian Serbs sought to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions; other Bosnians supported independence for the region. Description: Bosnian Serb forces executed about 500 Bosnian Serb men at the Pilica Cultural Dom following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Bosnian Serbs sought to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions; other Bosnians supported independence for the region. Description: Bosnian Serb forces executed around 1,000 to 1,200 Bosnian Serb men at Branjevo Military Farm following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Bosnian Serbs sought to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions; other Bosnians supported independence for the region. Description: Bosnian Serb forces executed at least 340 Bosnian Serb men in Kozluk following their take-over of the U.N. designated "safe-haven" of Srebrenica. These killings were part of a campaign which killed thousands of Bosnian Muslim men in Srebrenica. This campaign of violence was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs, which became a militarized conflict beginning around 1992. Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: "Bosnian Serb forces fired a barrage of shells into Sarajevo on [23 July 1995] and the Bosnian government said six people were killed and 35 others wounded." These deaths were the latest to result from an on-going campaign of shelling waged by Bosnian Serb forces against Sarajevo since 1992. The incident was also related to an on-going civil/ethnic war in Bosnia.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict. This is in keeping with the journalistic account of this incident.

Victim.Identity.Political: Members of the United Lumumbist Party (PALU)
Description: Doctors in the capital Kinshasa said nine civilians and a gendarme were killed in the clashes, but opposition supporters in Brussels said they believed the death toll was much higher.  "We are moved by and indignant about the deaths at the weekend...We want clarification on the number of dead because the latest figures total 58," said Glenn Ya'Ndongo Mag'Yesha of the Radical National Unity Party (PUNA). He added that many people had since died from wounds inflicted during Saturday's march by the Unified Lumumbist Party (PALU), a group loyal to the memory of slain independence prime minister Patrice Lumumba, and said others had disappeared. On Saturday, security forces clashed with militants from an unrelated and more radical fringe group. The government says security forces fired on militants after a gendarme was killed and when militants threw stones.

District: Benkovac, Gracac, Knin, Obrovac, Sibenik, Sinj & Zadar
Description: At least 150 Krajina Serbs were killed by Croatian forces between August and November 1995 during the "Operation Storm" offensive to recapture the Krajina region of Croatia, which had been held by Krajina Serbs. The campaign of violence was related to a conflict between Croatian and Serb forces, which had engaged in an armed conflict between 1992 and 1995.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Amended Indictment of Ante Gotovina. 19 Feb 2004.

Description: "Croatian army shells smashed into the Serb-held town of Bosanski Petrovac in west Bosnia on [18 August 1995] killing six people and wounding 15." Shells hit a number of civilian targets, including a hospital. Bosnian Serbs alleged that the shelling was an attempt to force the civilian population to flee the area before the Croatian army began an offensive against the town. This incident is related to an on-going conflict between Serbs and Croats in Croatia. The Croatian military began an offensive to re-take the Serb-held Krajina region in August 1995.
Comments: I have coded the perpetrator "Croatian Army" as Transnational because this incident took place in Bosnia, outside of the territory of Croatia.

Description: 66 people were killed and at least 140 injured when the Bosnian Serb army shelled a crowded civilian marketplace in Sarajevo. Later, members of the Bosnian Serb army were charged with crimes against humanity for this incident. The attack occurred in the context of an on-going civil/ethnic war.
Primary.Source: Reuters, International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia
Citation: lba0000020011103dr8s04kab, Indictment of S. Galic & D. Milosevic (http://www.un.org/icty/indictment/english/gal-ii011102e.htm)
Comments: Death and injury counts are from the ICTFY Indictment; news wires reported different death and injury counts.

Description: Soldiers of Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army are persecuting Hutu civilians, killing at least nine and wounding 16 in the last week, Hutu witnesses said on Tuesday. Terrified villagers at Muyira, five km (three miles) from the capital, told Reuters that soldiers killed three Hutus in the past week. The army says it does not target civilians but they are at times caught in the middle of a war with Hutu militants. A Hutu man, who declined to be named, said he saw soldiers from a nearby army position behead an 18-year-old Hutu student and dump the rest of his corpse half-covered in a hole. Other witnesses near the deserted and pillaged former Hutu suburb of Kamenge said six Hutus including two women and two children were shot dead by soldiers at the weekend. No immediate comment from the army was available on the reported killings. They said soldiers fired on traders in a small market on Saturday, killing a woman and wounding two others as they fled. Two children were killed and their mother wounded when soldiers entered a house in the suburb of Gasenyi on Saturday, witnesses said. Another Hutu was shot dead in Gasenyi on Sunday.
Comments: Because the death count was given with the phrase "at least," thus it was recorded as a range, rather than single number reported.

Description: A human rights report detailed the massacre of 600 Serb civilians by Croatian police and military following an operation to retake areas held by Serb separatists in 1995 (as reported by Reuters). The attacks occurred in a number of villages in central and southern Croatian border regions. Croatian forces also reportedly burnt entire villages to the ground and forced all remaining Serbs to leave the area, in effect ethnically cleansing the area. The incident occurred at the tail end of an extended conflict between Croatia and Serb-majority pockets within the country, which was tied to wider ethnic and civil conflicts in the region.
Comments: Report noted that a human rights report had listed 410 confirmed civilian deaths, but placed the actual total deaths at 600.

Description: Rwanda has arrested or jailed nine officers and soldiers in its first action on army killings of 110 Hutu villagers that have hurt efforts to reconcile bitterly divided tribes, its military intelligence chief said on Sunday. The September 12 killings at Kanama village were the most savage by the army since its soldiers killed hundreds of Hutus in Kibeho camp in April. Rwanda says soldiers of its Tutsi-led army raided Kanama after Hutu rebels killed a lieutenant in the area near the troubled northwestern border with Zaire, scene of a worsening Hutu insurgency campaign. The attack raised fears among diplomats that the army is out of control and hungry for retribution against the Hutu population, members of the majority tribe that unleashed a campaign of genocide against minority Tutsis last year.

Sudan government warplanes have launched raids into the country's rebel-held south, killing at least 20 people and causing extensive material damage, a rebel spokesman said on Thursday.  "The regime is having difficulties in Khartoum and is unleashing its frustrations on innocent civilians in the south," said Steven Wondu, spokesman for the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army (SPLA). "For the last week, the Khartoum government has been bombing -- they've been conducting aerial bombardment on civilian centres and markets," Wondu said, adding that bombing raids began on September 16 and were continuing almost daily. At least 20 people had been killed so far and more than 61 injured, he told Reuters. In one raid over Lasu and Ombasi conducted on September 22, 15 people were reported killed and more than 60 injured, Wondo said. There was no immediate independent confirmation of the raids.

Perp.State.Military: members of Arkan's Tigers (the Serbian Volunteer Guard, a paramilitary unit)
Description: "In Trnova near Sanski Most town, approximately 11 non-Serb men were executed by members of Arkans Tigers." This incident was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs; the former wanted to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions while the latter supported an independent Bosnian state. Bosnian Serbs began an armed conflict to take-control of desired areas of Bosnian around 1992. Bosnian Serb forces also began a campaign of "ethnic cleansing" to force all non-Serbs from proclaimed Serb areas, which included wholesale massacres of non-Serb civilians.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Perp.State.Military: members of Arkan's Tigers (the Serbian Volunteer Guard, a paramilitary unit)
Description: "In Sasina, at least 65 non-Serb men were executed by members of Arkan's Tigers under the direct command of Arkan." This incident was related to an on-going conflict between Bosnian Serbs and non-Serbs; the former wanted to unite with Serbs in neighboring Yugoslav regions while the latter supported an independent Bosnian state. Bosnian Serbs began an armed conflict to take-control of desired areas of Bosnian around 1992. Bosnian Serb forces also began a campaign of "ethnic cleansing" to force all non-Serbs from proclaimed Serb areas, which included wholesale massacres of non-Serb civilians.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: First Amended Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic. 22 Nov 2002.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: The Sri Lankan army said on Thursday its air force planes may have killed 70 people in last week's bombings in Jaffna and asked civilians to keep away from Tamil Tiger bases to avoid future casualties.
Comments: The Tamil Tigers originally blamed the Sri Lankan army for the deaths and the NGO Medicins Sans Frontieres independently confirmed the report.  The Sri Lankan army confirmed the report after MSF corroborated it.

Description: At least eight Guatemalan peasants were killed and 15 wounded on Thursday when gunmen attacked their village, United Nations officials said.
Citation:
Reuters News 06 October 1995 lba0000020011103dra6039p5
Reuters News 06 October 1995 lba0000020011103dra6039r6
Comments: Initial report has Perps listed only as unidentified gunmen but update indicated army troops.  Victims were peasant refugees.  Story indicates "high powered weapons" and grenades but coded as firearms as no specific reference to hvy weapons.  Govt. indicates that troops were responding in self defence.  Death totals run from 8 to as many as 30.

Description: A spokesman for Chechen rebel leader Dzhokhar Dudayev said Russian aircraft had bombed two villages in southern Chechnya, Dargo and Belgatoi.  Russian aircraft bombed the mountainous villages, killing 17 and injuring 23.  A Russian Defence Ministry spokesman said he had no information about such attacks, which would violate a shaky ceasefire which had been in place since June.
Secondary.Source: Spokesman for Chechen rebel leader quoted in Reuters

Description: Ethiopia has accused Sudan of beating, torturing and killing Ethiopian refugees and appealed to the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to give them protection. In a letter to UNHCR chief Sadako Ogata read on state-run television on Thursday night, Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin said: "Sudan is committing brutal and sinister acts of beating, torturing and killing Ethiopian refugees". It cited the example of refugee Tesfaye Fasil, saying he was beaten and hanged in prison by Sudanese security men last Sunday, and said Abraha Adem, was also tortured and his body thrown into the Rezoris river in eastern Sudan on October 24. It said the whereabouts were unknown of 53 of 250 Ethiopian refugees rounded up and jailed in Sudanese prisons.

Burundi's government accused Tutsi soldiers on Wednesday of massacring 253 Hutu villagers in a raid on a remote northern province. A statement from the president's office, faxed to Reuters in Rwanda's capital Kigali, said the villagers were killed last Friday by soldiers chasing Hutu rebels near Tangara commune. The hand-written statement said soldiers had acted without the knowledge of Burundi's military authorities after a rebel attack on nearby Gashoho commune, also on Friday. The troops also set houses ablaze and burnt down the commercial centre of Kananira, the statement said. Presidential cabinet chief Mames Bansubiyeko, speaking earlier to Reuters in Rwanda by telephone from Burundi, also put the blame on the military. Army spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Longin Minani had denied reports of killings in Ngozi when contacted by Reuters earlier this week.
Comments: An uneasy co-existence hangs by a thread between Burundi's coalition government, led by the majority Hutu tribe, and the army which is dominated by the minority Tutsis.

Description: Eight civilians were killed in a bomb attack on an Iraqi National Congress (INC), an opposition group that aimed to overthrow Saddam Hussein's regime and establish a democratic government, security office in Salahuddin. Another opposition group, the Supreme Council of Islamic Resistance in Iraq, blamed the attack on the Iraqi regime but did not specify whom in particular had carried it out.
Secondary.Source: Iraqi National Congress, Supreme Council for the Islamic Resistance in Iraq
Comments: In addition to the eight civilians killed, 14 INC members were also killed in the blast. I was not able to determine if these INC members were combatants. As the report specifically separated the civilian and INC member death counts, I have not included the INC members in the death count coded here. These 14 INC members may or may not be combatants according to codebook definitions.

Description: Twenty-eight people were killed and another 70 injured in a bomb attack on an Iraqi National Congress (INC) an opposition group that aimed to overthrow Saddam Hussein's regime and establish a democratic government, security office in Salahuddin. Another opposition group, the Supreme Council of Islamic Resistance in Iraq, blamed the attack on the Iraqi regime but did not specify whom in particular had carried it out.
Secondary.Source: Iraqi National Congress, Supreme Council for the Islamic Resistance in Iraq
Comments: The final death count for this incident was 28, though no information as to the identity of the victims was provided. I have used linked codes to record the different details provided in two reports, which I could not reconcile in a single code.

Description: "The United Nations refugee agency says Bosnian Serb soldiers massacred about 100 Moslem civilians who earlier this month [October 1995] resisted being forcibly expelled from their homes in northern Bosnia." The victims apparently refused to leave Bosanski Novi because they had relatives working as forced labor for the Serbs. This incident was related to an ongoing civil/ethnic war in Bosnia.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict. This is in keeping with the UN and journalistic account of this incident.

Description: The Afghan government said the rebel Islamic Taliban militia had rained rockets on Kabul, killing 35 civilians and wounding 50.  Kabul radio said salvos of rockets had caused casualties in several part of the city.  Mullah Mohammad, a Taliban spokesman contacted by telephone, denied responsibility for the rocketing and accused government forces of deliberately targeting civilian areas to discredit the Taliban.
Comments: The two sides in the war are in dispute over who was responsible for the killings

Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Liberation Tigers of the Tamil Eelam
Description: The Sri Lankan army said on Wednesday that five civilians were killed in crossfire between government troops and Tamil guerrillas in the eastern region.
Comments: The Liberation Tigers of the Tamil Eelam could also be seen as a Non-State ideological group.

Description: The United States, citing "credible reports" of a massacre last month of 430 civilians in Burundi, has called on that government to conduct a thorough investigation of the mounting ethnic violence. The State Department said 430 civilians -- 90 percent of whom were women and children -- were slain by elements of the Burundi military on Nov. 14. Some were strangled to death, according to the report. The Burundi army recently has stepped up its military campaign against suspected Hutu rebels, continuing ethnic violence that has claimed some 100,000 lives over two years of conflict.

Troops killed more than 20 members of the Hutu majority east of Burundi's capital days before a visit by former U.S. president Jimmy Carter, diplomats and aid workers said on Saturday. Diplomats in Bujumbura contacted by Reuters by telephone from neighbouring Rwanda said the Hutus were killed when troops stormed their village in a three-day hunt for Hutu rebels until Friday. Aid workers said troops entered Gasarara village on a hill overlooking Bujumbura on Wednesday to search for Hutu rebels. Western aid workers said they evacuated seven villagers including children with serious injuries from Gasarara and they feared the casualty toll from the operation would be higher. Diplomats and aid workers said they believed the army was trying to clear the last few Hutu strongholds near the capital, dubbed "Tutsiville" after most Hutu civilians fled this year.

A strike called by separatists in protest against the deaths of five Kashmiris largely closed down shops and businesses in Srinagar on Saturday.  The militants had been marching in a procession on Friday when they died during an exchange of fire with paramilitary forces in Budgam district, 14 km (eight miles) from Srinagar.  Indian police and Kashmiri separatists blamed each other for the deaths. Officials said militants taking part in the procession opened fire at paramilitary forces, who returned fire. Organisers of the procession blamed the paramilitary forces. "The army personnel opened fire without any provocation. The Kashmiris were marching peacefully towards a holy shrine after offering Friday prayers", a JKLF leader, Javid Mir, told reporters on Saturday.

United Nations officials cast doubt on Friday on the Rwandan government's explanation of an incident last month in which troops shot dead a group of Hutus. The government has said the Tutsi-dominated army was pursuing armed Hutu rebels in Nyungwe forest on November 30 when its troops ran into hostile fire.  The soldiers overran a rebel settlement after a firefight and discovered 13 bodies, including two women and two children who were caught in crossfire, officials say. "We were pursuing the enemy in an infiltration area," said Emmanuel Ndahiro, an aide to defence minister Paul Kagame, adding: "The nine men killed are assumed rebels." But the U.N. human rights mission in Rwanda disputed the numbers and the circumstances of the government version, saying it had evidence implying the dead were unarmed civilians. "We have statements from survivors who claimed there were no arms there and who made no reference to crossfire. It was confirmed that an RPA (Rwandan Patriotic Army) patrol was involved in the incident," U.N. human rights chief Ian Martin told Reuters.

Afghan government planes bombed areas held by the rebel Taliban Islamic militia south of Kabul.  A Taliban commander in the busy market town of Charasiyab, south of Kabul, said government planes had dropped at least four bombs on civilian areas, killing five people and wounding eight.

Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Hunde Tribe And Rwandan Hutu Refugees
Description: Forty people were killed on Tuesday in the remote Zairean town of Masisi in fighting between government troops and a local tribe protesting at the presence of Rwandan refugees, witnesses fleeing the area said. The witnesses told a Reuters reporter in Goma that chaos broke out on Saturday when armed members of the local Hunde tribe attacked Rwandan Hutu refugees in fights over firewood. One witness who fled to Goma, the region's main town, quoted local officials in Masisi as saying 40 people were killed in Tuesday's fighting. There was no independent confirmation of this figure. "Forty people were killed today (Tuesday)," the witness told a Reuters reporter. "All these were civilians caught in the fighting." Another witness, who also fled Masisi for Goma, described the situation there as "completely chaotic. No one knows who is killing who, Zaireans, Rwandans ...all are affected".

Russian troops used long-range weapons to clear rebels out of Chechnya's second biggest town, Gudermes.  Although independent confirmation for reports was nearly impossible, the town's mayor said the fighting had killed more than 100 civilians.  Russian troops fired on rebels and civilians from helicopters.  Russian troops used artillery and rocket fire on the first day to lift the rebel siege of the Gudermes military headquarters.  A Russian military source told Interfax news agency that troops were unable to use the full force of their heavy artillery against the separatists in the still-populated town.  Russian officials said rebels are taking advantage of the "civilians as protection" and using the reprieve to organize resistance.

Hutu villagers in Burundi have accused soldiers of the Tutsi-led army of massacring up to 50 men, women and children -- shooting them, stabbing them with bayonets and mutilating the bodies, the U.S. ambassador said. The soldiers also fired shells into a schoolroom where frightened Hutus were hiding, the villagers told ambassador Robert Krueger. Krueger told Reuters he had met senior military officers on Tuesday and demanded a full investigation of the incident at Choga village in the hills outside the capital Bujumbura. The alleged massacre came to light when villagers last week took four corpses to the National Unity monument in the capital as a gesture of mockery. "They initially intended to bring all the bodies to one point but were told they might be stopped and more people killed on the way if they did so, and so only these four were brought down," Krueger said.
Comments: No date is given.

Description: Six Moslem Croat civilian detainees were killed by mortar shells. At the time, the victims were digging trenches as slave laborers on the front of Bosnian Serb lines. The victims were among 250 Moslem Croats detained by Bosnian Serb forces, who had rounded up the group between January 5th and 7th. The incident took place against the backdrop of an on-going civil/ethnic war.
Comments: I have coded Bosnian Serb forces as State perpetrators because that status of the Bosnian state and Serb-controlled regions remained disputed at the time of this conflict.

Description: Tanzania accused the Burundian army on Sunday of attacks and killings on Tanzanian territory and warned it would take strong measures if they continued. Tanzanian radio quoted the Foreign Ministry as saying the Burundian army's actions "violated international rules and amounted to acts of aggression". "Tanzania will be compelled to take strong measures to protect citizens and their property if the Burundian government does not stop such acts of aggression," the radio quoted the ministry as saying. It also spoke of killings in Burundi in which Tanzanians were among the victims and warned that Tanzania "would not keep quiet and allow the situation to continue." The violence in Burundi led many people to flee into neighbouring Tanzania earlier this year. Tanzania has closed its border to further refugees because of the serious problems caused by earlier influxes from both Burundi and Rwanda.

Burundi government troops killed about 20 Rwandan Hutus and wounded scores in an attack on a refugee camp in northeast Burundi, Mugano camp.  The raid triggered the flight of nearly 15,000 refugees into Tanzania.  Witnesses said soldiers came with guns and started shooting at the people.  Burundi says it is investigating the attack.  The Tutsi-dominated army had initially linked the attackers to Rwanda's former Hutu army, a charge repudiated by the fleeing Hutu refugees.

Police said five MQM members, including a leading militant named Rehan Ahmed Khan, alias Kana, died in a battle with police in District Central's Khawja Ajmer Nagri area. Two policemen were wounded in the shoot-out and many weapons, including rocket-propelled grenades, were recovered, senior police Superintendent Deen Baloch told reporters. "The men were all wanted by police in several major cases of killings and terrorist activities," he said. MQM leaders disputed the police version, saying security forces arrested the activists from a house before shooting them in cold blood. MQM spokesman Senator Ishtiaq Azhar told a news conference that police beat members of Kana's family and kicked his pregnant wife and beat her with batons.

Thousands of people on Saturday mourned the death of more than 20 people whom Pakistani authorities said were killed by Indian rocket attacks on their side of the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir.
Comments: Indian officials claim that Pakistan actually fired the rocket that landed on the mosque that killed the 20 worshippers.

Description: Survivors of a massacre of Tamils, including women and children, by rampaging government troops in eastern Sri Lanka have identified eight soldiers who carried out the killings, police said on Thursday.  They were remanded pending further inquiries into the February 12 deaths of 24 villagers in the remote village of Kumarapuram in Trincomalee district, a police officer in the area said.
Comments: Tamil politicians and some of the wounded accused government troops of going on a rampage after separatist Tamil Tiger guerrillas killed two soldiers earlier that day.

Description: Afghan government jets bombed the rebel Taliban-held territory south of Kabul, killing eight people and wounding several.  The report came from a Taliban spokesman who said the casualties from the raid were civilians but there was no independent account of the fighting available.  Government-controlled Kabul radio mentioned no such air raid.

The Ugandan army said 88 people were killed in a battle with northern rebels.  The original death toll for the battle was 46, most of whom were rebel fighters and civilians and most of the new additions were part of the army.
Comments: Of the 88 people killed, we know that many of them were civilians but it's impossible to tell how many.

Description: Four years of fighting between Maoist rebels and police had resulted in 249 civilian deaths. The civilians were "either killed by the rebels or were caught in the clash between the guerrillas and the police." Additionally, the rebels had kidnapped about 270 people and had also forced children to join their ranks, a charge the rebels denied. Maoist rebels, who sought to establish a communist state, began a 'people's war' against the government in 1996.
Comments: I have coded perpetrator intent as 'no information/unclear/other' because the report did not address intent. I have coded collateral damage as 'collateral damage' because some of the deaths appear to have been collateral damage in police operations.

Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: victims were at or near Taliban rebel positions
Description: Afghan government jets bombed rebel positions south and west of the capital Kabul, killing up to 50 people.  20 people were also wounded as the jets targeted a building at Charasyab base, where commanders of the Taliban Islamic militia were meeting to discuss plans for their war against the government.  There was no independent confirmation of this report that came from a defence ministry official in Afghanistan.  It was a pre-emptive strike by the government against a Taliban government.
Comments: It's unclear how many of the fifty dead were actually civilians and how many were unarmed Taliban- the report is no more specific than the description provided

Description: A large number of deaths and injuries, mostly among civilians, occurred during Israeli military operations aimed at Hizbollah in Lebanon. The operations began after Hizbollah rocket attacks on northern Israel, despite Lebanese pleas against further Israeli military operations. Hizbollah's pro-Iranian militants had been in conflict with Israel on and off for eighteen years.
Citation: Reuters 13 Apr 96 lba0000020011018ds4d09eon; Reuters 16 Apr 96 lba0000020011018ds4g09936; Reuters 17 Apr 96 lba0000020011018ds4h0966v; Reuters 18 Apr 96 lba0000020011018ds4i0945u; Reuters 22 Apr 96 lba0000020011018ds4m0901r; Reuters 28 Apr 96 lba0000020011018ds4s08rco; Reuters 03 May 96 lba0000020011018ds5308hev
Comments: The intention of the Israeli military was not clear, however as the deaths occurred in the context of military operations I have coded for collateral damage.

Description: Six refugees, two women and four girls, were killed when an Israeli helicopter rocketed the ambulance they were fleeing in. Israel asserted that it thought that the vehicle belonged to Hizbollah. The attack came as the Israeli military was carrying-out military operations aimed at Hizbollah in southern Lebanon. The operations began after Hizbollah rocket attacks on northern Israel, despite Lebanese pleas against further Israeli military operations. Hizbollah's pro-Iranian militants had been in conflict with Israel on and off for eighteen years.
Brazilian police "lost control" and killed at least 23 landless workers, injuring 50 others, in a clash on a remote Amazon highway, officials said on Thursday
Citation:
Reuters News 18 April 1996 lba0000020011018ds4i095ak
Reuters News 19 April 1996 lba0000020011018ds4j091ku
Comments: State police identified as perps.  Victims identified as "landless workers" - coded as both political and socio-economic.  Workers were blocking highway as a protest.  Firearms indicated.  Discrepancy on number of dead 19-25.  Later reports indicate some victims shot execution style.  Regret indicated on part of government - not necessarily on part of police that took part.

Description: Nine Shi'ite Moslem civilians, six of whom were children, were killed in Israeli rocket attacks on Nabatiyeh during on-going Israeli military actions in Lebanon. The operations were in retaliation for Hizbollah rocket attacks on northern Israel. Pro-Iranian Hizbollah guerillas had been in conflict with Israel on and off for eighteen years.
Comments: The intention of the Israeli military was not clear, however as the deaths occurred in the context of military operations I have coded for collateral damage.

Description: A large number of Lebanese refugees were killed and injured when Israeli shells hit a U.N. peacekeeping base where they had sought shelter from on-going Israeli military operations aimed at Hizbollah in Lebanon. Israel stated that it regretted the civilian deaths but refused to halt its operations until Hizbollah ceased its rocket attacks on northern Israel. It also blamed Hizbollah for hiding behind the cover of civilians. Hizbollah's pro-Iranian militants had been in conflict with Israel on and off for eighteen years.
Comments: The intention of the Israeli military was not clear, however as the deaths occurred in the context of military operations I have coded for collateral damage.

Description: Ten people were killed and 25 wounded when a bomb hit a village just outside the rebel region of Chechnya.  The bomb hit the village of Arshty in the region of Ingushetia, just five kilometers from the rebel stronghold of Bamut in Chechnya itself.  Other reports said Bamut was bombed and shelled by Russian forces on the same day and the bomb in Ingushetia was probably a spill over from the fighting in Bamut.

Covering the period between April 19 and July 15, it said the human rights situation in Burundi during the period "was marked by major massacres of civilians, selective murders, forced disappearances and arbitrary arrests".
Comments: The report was rather vague, so there was no number given in regards to death count.

Description: Twelve Indonesian soldiers would be charged with "responding excessively" to recent student demonstrations in south Sulawesi where at least three students were killed, the Jakarta Post newspaper reported on Saturday. April's violent protests in Ujung Pandang, capital of south Sulawesi, started after the government announced plans to raise local bus fares. The authorities say three students were killed, but human rights lawyers say six students died. The Jakarta Post quoted South Sulawesi military commander Major-General Soelatin as saying on Friday the soldiers, three of whom were high-ranking officers, would be charged with employing "excessive response" to the protests.

Russian helicopter gunships attacked the town of Shali in rebel Chechnya, killing and wounding civilians.  The agency that reported the event did not give a casualty figure for the air attack but it said seven people were killed when Russian ground forces opened fire on a civilian convoy trying to flee the town.  A Russian commander said the attacks were a response to rebel fighters firing at Russian helicopters which flew over Shali on a reconnaissance mission.
A report by the U.N. Centre of Human Rights said 118 were killed on April 26 in central Gitega province by the Tutsi dominated army.
Comments: The Reuters report did not specify the weapons used nor the identity of the victims.  One might assume however that they were Hutus.  The report also said that other sources said 233 were dead in the massacre identified in the U.N. report.

Description: Humanitarian sources in Burundi said on Monday more than 375 people, most or all Hutus, were massacred on May 3 in the northern village of Kivyuka.  Humanitarian sources say the Tutsi dominated Burundian army or other extremist Tutsis are to blame for the attack.

The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), now based on the mainland south of the peninsula, said attacks by the military killed at least 20 minority Tamils ahead of the capture of the Vadamarachchi area, the eastern part of the peninsula.
Comments: The rebels claim that at least 20 ethnic Tamils were killed, while the defence ministry says not a single civilian was killed.

Description: Zaire's leading human rights group on Wednesday accused the Zairean army of massacring 30 villagers last month during an operation against rebels in the country's North Kivu Province.
A 12-page report by UN observers said in a series of attacks in May in northern Muramvya province 15 people were killed in one village.
Comments: The report did not name the village where the massacre took place, saying only it was in Muramvya province.

Description: A 12-page report by UN observers said in a series of attacks in May in northern Muramvya province 43 people were killed in a second village.
Comments: The report did not name the village where the massacre took place, saying only it was in Muramvya province.

Description: A 12-page report by UN observers said in a series of attacks in May in northern Muramvya province up to 1200 people were killed in the village of Mushikamo.
Burundi's Hutu opposition said on Thursday the Tutsi-dominated army killed 50 Hutu civilians, not rebels, in an operation south of the capital of Bujumbura.
Comments: The Burundian army claimed to have killed rebels, while the Hutu opposition claims those killed were civilians.

Description: This month, Western aid workers reported another massacre in which 111 Hutu villagers were killed in Mutambu village south of Bujumbura on June 12.
Comments: Aid workers blamed the troops while Defence Minister Firmin Sinzoyiheba denied the killings

Locality: Musama, Kaniga, Munanira and Nyabitsinda hills
Description: The Burundian army strongly denied on Monday charges of involvement in a massacre of 71 Hutu civilians near central Gitega province.  But survivors said an estimated 175 soldiers in six trucks arrived on Kibimba hill north of a town of the same name on Thursday and in five hours killed the 71 with automatic weapons, machineguns and bayonets on Musama, Kaniga, Munanira and Nyabitsinda hills.
Comments: The Chief of the Burundian Army General Staff refuted the allegations saying, "They are false because there were no military operations taking place in that place on those dates, and so these reports cannot possibly be true -- It's as simple as that," he said.

Description: A report by the U.N. Centre of Human Rights said 500 people were killed on June 27 by the army in the troubled northwestern region of Cibitoke.
Comments: The Reuters report did not specify the weapons used nor the identity of the victims.  One might assume however that they were Hutus.

Description: Burundi's Hutu rebel Council for the Defence of Democracy, on Wednesday accused Burundi troops of killing 1000 Hutu civilians at Nyeshenza in cibitoke province on June 27 with support from the Rwandan Patriotic Army.
Secondary.Source: Council for the Defence of Democracy
Comments: Burundi's defence minister denied Hutu rebel charges that Burundian troops, with the help of Rwandan soldiers, had massacred 1000 Hutu civilians in northwest Cibitoke province.  The Rwandan government also denied that their troops had anything to do with the alleged massacres.

Description: Moslem militants and the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) alleged that Algerian forces had killed 300 civilians in a village in the Tlemcen region in retaliation for an attack in which Moslem rebels had killed 50 Algerian special forces. No further details of the incident nor independent confirmations were immediately available. The allegation was related to an  on-going conflict between Islamic fundamentalists and the military-backed Algerian government, which dates back to 1992 when the government canceled elections that Islamists, who hoped to establish an Islamic state, were expected to win.
Secondary.Source: representative of the Islamic Salvation Front

Description: Rwanda's army killed 156 people in search operations for Hutu rebels from July 5 to July 13 in search operations in Gisenyi and Ruhengeri prefectures.  The office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights in Rwanda issued a statement that "many of those killed are reported to have been unarmed civilians."  It also said that some of those killed in separate operations in the troubled northwest were ex-soldiers with the former government army and members of the Interahamwe.
Secondary.Source: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights in Rwanda
Contesting.Source: spokesman for the Rwandese Patriotic Army
Comments: The local RPA commanders said the deaths occurred in violent confrontations, while the statement from the UN says the many were unarmed combatants.

Description: Western aid workers said on Saturday at least seven Hutus were killed three days after the massacre of more than 80 Tutsis by Hutu rebels as protests in the capital by the minority Tutsis fanned ethnic tension.

Scorched.Earth.Tactics: about a third of the homes were destroyed
Description: After a five day blockade, villagers returned to the Chechen village of Gekhi to find wreckage and death.  About a third of the homes in the town were destroyed in a battle between Russian troops and separatist fighters.  The head of the local administration said 14 civilians had been killed and 72 wounded in the fight which broke out after a six-week ceasefire.

At least 20 civilians were killed when Russian warplanes and artillery attacked the village of Makhety in the pro-rebel southern part of Chechnya.  Many residents had been injured in the attack on the village as well.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters of a relocation of a local hospital
Description: At least seven people, including a woman, were killed and 20 wounded when Pakistani rural police opened fire on marchers protesting against the relocation of a district hospital, officials said.  The incident occurred in Awaran town in Balochistan province, some 350 km (210 miles) southeast of Quetta, official sources said on Saturday. The official said police retaliated after some protesters, angry about the shifting of a district hospital venue, opened fire on them during a procession on Friday. Witnesses claimed at least nine people were killed in the shooting, but no official confirmation was available. Local people said police opened fire when people refused to stop a planned protest march in the town.

Other.Tactics: victims' ears were cut off; corpses burned
Description: At least eight people were killed near the Chechen capital in an attack which witnesses blamed on drugged Russian soldiers.  Four burned-out cars and six corpses scorched beyond recognition lay on the road leading west from Grozny and the reporter saw two other corpses covered with blood, whose ears had been cut off.  Interfax news agency said 13 people had died in all.  A Russian military spokesman denied the event but the Russian Defence Ministry just said it had no information on the incident.  A survivor said he was driving when Russian soldiers stopped his car, cut him in the throat and, taking him for dead, dumped him in his car and poured petrol over it.  They were distracted by another car before they were able to shoot at the car to set it alight.  The soldiers' behaviour has been blamed on drugs.
Foreign aid workers also said troops killed 23 people on July 26 at Muyange hill in Giheta commune in the central province of Gitega.

Amnesty International alleged that government forces killed 110 Hutu civilians at Carama, near the capital Bujumbura on July 26, the day after the army deposed Hutu President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.
But Hutus in the area disputed the army's version and said soldiers killed 36 civilians after the rebel attack on Saturday at the coffee plant in Gashuha.
Comments: The Burundian Army says that they killed 30 Hutu rebels after a rebel attack on a coffee research station.  Hutus in the area say they killed 36 civilians.

Description: Reuters News reported 7/27/1996 that violent clashes between police and political demonstrators have killed seven people according to an independent Legal Aid Foundation in a faxed statement. The death toll could not be confirmed. Demonstrators set fire to buildings during the day after the "police seized Indonesia's opposition Democratic Party (DPI) headquarters...occupied...in support of Megawati Sukarnoputri, daughter of Indonesia's last founding president Sukarno". Witnesses described the city as "lawless violence with thousands of people roaming Jakarta's Salemba area" and estimated that 10,000 people were involved in the rioting. "A Reuter correspondent said he saw the political counselor at the U.S. embassy...attacked by a soldier as the diplomat tried to help a woman who had fallen down"; the injury was not serious. Hospital officials said 10 people had been brought in with head injuries; a PDI member said 87 of the Megawati faction were wounded. A later Reuters article reports army claims of only two dead. An article from the AP on 8/07 reports the death toll at three people. More than a month later (9/10), an AP article places the death toll to at least five.
Comments: Sieges/Closures are coded although the intent may not have been malign; police forces seized the PDI headquarters and closed streets to stop the action of demonstrators. The victims are not identified as demonstrators or police forces; they are coded as Noncombatant Status Not Asserted but also Not Contested.

Description: The London-based human rights group Amnesty International said last week that the army had killed 4,050 unarmed civilians in the central district of Giheta between July 27 and August 10.  The army, dominated by the Tutsi minority, staged a coup against the country's Hutu president on July 25.
The privately-owned influential Monitor tri-weekly said a total of 255 of the 327 killed in the war between government forces and Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels were civilians.
Comments: It was unclear whether the civilians were specifically targeted or not and by which group.  There were reports of the rebels specifically targeting civilians, but nothing that could be substantiated.

Description: Amnesty also said 100 people were killed by army troops at Shumba in central Burundi.
Comments: Amnesty did not specify a date when the alleged massacre took place, however it appears that the massacre was a part of the same campaign as the BDI-199607 campaign.

Description: The aid workers told Reuters that more than 200 Hutus were killed by troops on August 7 on several hills at Rutegama commune in Muramvya province, east of the capital Bujumbura.

Scores of civilians, soldiers and rebels have been killed in two days of battles between Russian troops backed by helicopter gunships and separatists trying to seize the shattered Chechen city of Grozny.  Accurate casualty figures have been difficult to come by and impossible to confirm in this conflict but civilians, who make up most of Chechnya's estimated death toll of more than 30,000, were among the victims of the raid.
State-run radio said 13 civilians were killed in crossfire when troops approached six armed infiltrators from Zaire in the town of Kibilira, 47 miles (76 km) west of the capital Kigali.
Comments: Because the civilians were collateral damage, it was unclear who was responsible for their killing.

Victim.Identity.Political: "demonstrators protesting against the Colombian government's drug crop eradication programme"
Description: According to a report from Reuters News on 8/24/1996, "at least five people were killed on Friday when demonstrators protesting against the Colombian government's drug crop eradication programme clashed with security forces for a second day". "One demonstrator was shot dead and eight others seriously injured on Thursday". The clashes have taken place in the southern province of Caqueta, mostly in the capital Florencia, but also in a small town southwest of there, Belen de los Andaquies. The "victims were protesters who had been gunned down by army troops...[One] died of asphyxia after being overcome by teargas".
Secondary.Source: Government officials, local television and radio news sources

Description: Hutu peasants on Thursday accused Burundian troops of killing more than 70 civilians in a village last Sunday during an operation to clear Hutu rebels.
Comments: A spokesman for the Burundian army said it was investigating the incident.

Description: As Afghan government forces fought Islamic Taliban rebels near the city of Kabul, eight civilians were killed and 18 wounded in the exchanges.  Government planes had bombed Taliban positions and both sides used heavy artillery and rockets in the fighting.  Ten homes were also damaged.

Reuters News reported 9/14/1996 that a Nigerian Moslem Shi'ite group had released a statement claiming 14 had died during two days of protests in northern Nigeria. Police denied the casualties and a police spokesman said only teargas was used during the protests. "Residents reported the area was calm on Saturday. But...a spokesman for the Shi'ites Moslem Brotherhood, said "Eleven people were killed in Zaria city during the protest on Friday and many were severely wounded. Three more died today from injuries making a total of 14."
Secondary.Source: Muslim Brotherhood spokesperson, local news sources
