Description: Afghan government jets bombed the rebel Taliban-held eastern city of Jalalabad, killing at least 12 people and wounding 50.

On 9/19/1996 Reuters News reported that "at least seven people died in clashes between Shi'ite Moslems and police in the northern Nigerian city of Kaduna on WednesdaySome newspapers said as many as 15 people were feared to have died in the clashes which erupted during street protests by the Moslems over the detention of their radical leader...The Shi'ites on Wednesday put the number of their dead at three while the police said two of their men were killed."
Secondary.Source: Police and Shi'ite Muslim spokesmen, local news sources

Description: Reuters News on 9/27/1996 reported violence between Palestinians and Israeli security forces killed six Palestinians and two Israeli paramilitary policemen. "On the Temple Mountseveral hundred Palestinians threw stones, injuring five Israeli policemen. Israeli security forces responded with gunfire, killing three Palestinians and wounded more than 50, the hospital officials said." A later Reuters article brings the death toll to seven Palestinians dead. Reports a week later bring the death toll much higher to 73 Palestinians dead in five days of fighting.

Aid workers said more than 100 people were killed by the army at Bururi's Matana commune on October 13.  "On October 13 some undisciplined military killed civilians whom they accused of feeding the assailants (rebels) but there was no proof that they were feeding the rebels," said army spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Isaie Nibizi.
Comments: Aid workers say more than 100 civilians were killed, while the Burundian army admitted to killing around 50.

Description: An unidentified aircraft, presumed to be affiliated with the Taliban, dropped two bombs on the town of Charikar, north of Kabul.  Nine people were killed and six wounded in the attack.  Charikar had been retaken earlier by forces of Ahmad Shah Massood,  military chief of the government of President Burhanuddin Rabbani, which was driven out of Kabul late last month by the Taliban.
About 40 inmates were burned alive early on Tuesday after a fire apparently caused by prison guards broke out in a Venezuelan jail, officials and human rights activists said.
Citation:
Reuters News 22 October 1996 lba0000020011018dsam01k6a
Reuters News 22 October 1996 lba0000020011018dsam01kal
Comments: Perps identified as prison guards.  Victims were unarmed inmates - story gives no indication they were acting as combatants.  Possible that inmates died as collateral damage - unintended side effect of tear gas usage although there is an unconfirmed report that at least one was shot.  Coded as firearms.  Death range listed as "about 40" although official count is 30.

Description: Five people were killed in the Afghan village of Kalakan when a Taliban rocket hit their mud-walled home while they were sleeping.  Relatives said a further six people had been injured.
Zairean women of Rwandan origin who were expelled to Rwanda said on Friday Zairean troops took 41 of their husbands and sons off trucks and massacred them by the side of the road.
Comments: There was no independent confirmation of the event.  No specific day was given just the phrase "last week" thus the day category was left blank.

Description: Thirty-seven people were killed on Friday in fighting south of Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, witnesses and opposition sources said on Monday.
Comments: Witnesses said many of the 37 were killed by mortar rounds fired by the army, however and army spokesman denied this.  It was unclear then whether the rebels or the Burundian army were responsible for the attack.

Description: It also said that in another attack, on December 1 in Mokakuru village in southwest Bougainville, Papua New Guinea troops killed 11 people, some as they slept, and injured another 11.
Comments: The weaponry used by the assailants was not stated in the report.  Nor were details pertaining to how the victims were killed.

Description: Burundian soldiers killed about 700 people in a massacre on December 2-3 in the Kayanza region. The massacre was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsis, a minority group who controlled the army, and Hutus, the majority population in the country. The two sides had been involved in a three-year long guerrilla war.
Comments: The report noted that the Burundian army "routinely denies killing Hutus and blames rebels for the massacres." There was no indication that the army denied this specific incident. This incident is coded as a campaign because it spanned two days. It was also part of a larger wave of violence.

Description: The London-based human rights organisation said on Friday that in the latest case, up to 500 people were massacred in the Pentecostal Church of Nyarurama on December 3.
Comments: We refute the allegations completely, Jean-Luc Ndizeye, spokesman for President Pierre Buyoya, told Reuters by telephone from the Burundian capital Bujumbura.

Description: Papua New Guinea troops killed nine civilians and wounded five others in a mortar attack on a village on the secessionist-racked island of Bougainville.
Comments: The rebel interim government said that the Prime Minister had completely lost control of his military on Bougainville

Description: Burundian soldiers killed 121 people in a massacre on December 13 in rural areas of the capital city, Bujumbura. The massacre was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsis, a minority group who controlled the army, and Hutus, the majority population in the country. The two sides had been involved in a three-year long guerrilla war.
Comments: The report noted that the Burundian army "routinely denies killing Hutus and blames rebels for the massacres." There was no indication that the army denied this specific incident.

Perp.State.Military: agents of the Israeli intelligence agency
Description: Nine people were killed and 44 injured when a bomb exploded in the luggage compartment of a Syrian bus in Damascus. Syria's government blamed the attack on Israeli intelligence agents, who it claimed were trying to de-rail the Middle East peace process. The Israeli government denied the charges and insisted that: "It's [the accusations] a gross lie. Israel strives for nothing but peace and acts solely in peaceful ways." The U.S. government also took a stand on the issue, warning the Syrian government not to make "'wild and irresponsible' statements without evidence." A U.S. spokesperson insisted that: "'There have been over many months a series of unexplained bombings and explosions in Damascus. The United States government has no information about these explosions and we certainly cannot confirm some of the rather wild reports coming out of Damascus this morning about who may have committed these bombing attacks.'" Syrian officials later rejected the U.S. remarks, admonishing the "insensitivity of Washington's remarks." Approximately ten days after the attack a group calling itself the Islamic Movement for Change issued an unconfirmed statement claiming responsibility for the attack, "saying it was in retaliation for Syria's "execution" of one of its militants who took part in an attack on U.S. servicemen in Saudi Arabia last year." The Syrian government dismissed this claim of responsibility, insisting that it was "a fake statement planted by Israel."
Secondary.Source: witness, official Syrian news agency SANA, Israeli officials, US officials
Comments: Reports did not immediately describe the victims as civilians, however the following later statement did: "'Syria was astonished by the statement of the spokesman of the State Department regarding the criminal act which left tens of civilians killed or wounded in Syria,' the spokesman said. "

Description: Burundian soldiers massacred 75 people in the Bururi region. A specific date for the incident was not reported.  The massacre was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsis, a minority group who controlled the army, and Hutus, the majority population in the country. The two sides had been involved in a three-year long guerrilla war.
Comments: The report noted that the Burundian army "routinely denies killing Hutus and blames rebels for the massacres." There was no indication that the army denied this specific incident. I have inferred that this incident occurred in December 1996 based on the context of the report.

Description: Amnesty International reported that hundreds of civilians had been killed by various groups in Rwanda in 1997. The victims were described as primarily unarmed civilians. The perpetrators included: the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA), Hutu militias, and Tutsi civilians. The violence was related to an on-going conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in the country. In 1994 hard-line Hutus perpetrated genocide against Tutsis and moderate Hutus, killing about 800,000.

A U.N. Human rights report described a sharp increase in killings in Rwanda during the month of January 1997. The report specified that "at least 163 of the killings ... were reportedly 'the responsibility of the state, including members of the RPA.'" The killings occurred within the context of ongoing civil strife in Rwanda, were a bloody civil war had turned to genocide in 1994.
Secondary.Source: UN human rights field operation in Rwanda

Description: "Soldiers in Burundi massacred at least 83 civilians [thought to be Hutus] in a single operation," near Rutegama. The soldiers reportedly "circled the hillsides  and killed almost everyone." A later report placed the number of civilian casualties in this incident at 400. Burundi's army is comprised almost entirely of Tutsis, a minority population in the country. The army had often been accused of carrying out massacres against Hutu civilians - who make up Burundi's majority population. This incident was related to an on-going guerilla war conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in the country.
Citation: Reuters 10 Jan 97 lba0000020011002dt1a07xea; Reuters 29 Jan 97 lba0000020011001dt1t02gqq
Comments: It was not entirely clear whether the Burundian army was disputing the occurrence of the massacre or its alleged involvement as the perpetrators of this massacre.

Description: Burundian soldiers shot and killed 126 Hutu refugees after they tried to escape from a refugee camp in the Muyinga province. The refugees were being held at the camp after being expelled from neighboring Tanzania. This incident was related to an on-going conflict between the Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebels, who belonged to the country's majority ethnic group and who sought political empowerment.

Twenty civilians were shot and killed by Rwandan troops. The incident reportedly occurred behind a local communal office during a week-long army crackdown following the killing of 3 aid workers by suspected Hutu militiamen. The description of the shooting of these civilians contradicts the Rwandan government's account of civilian deaths during the crackdown operations, which it asserted were collateral damage. This incident was also related to an on-going conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in the country. In 1994, Hutu militias committed genocide against Tutsis and others leaving about 800,000 dead.

More than 30 civilians were shot and killed by Rwandan troops in Mukingo. The deaths occurred during a week-long army crackdown following the killing of 3 aid workers by suspected Hutu militiamen. The description of the shooting of these civilians contradicts the Rwandan government's account of civilian deaths during the crackdown operations, which it asserted were collateral damage. This incident was also related to an on-going conflict between Hutus and Tutsis in the country. In 1994 Hutu militias committed genocide against Tutsis and others leaving about 800,000 dead.

13 people were killed and 37 more injured when Zairean forces dropped aerial bombs on the rebel held city of Bukavu . Some of the bombs hit near a marketplace in the city. No further details of the incident were immediately reported. The incident was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsi rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, and the Zairean government. The conflict began when the government denied the Tutsis citizenship and tried to expel them to their ancestral homeland in Rwanda.

8 people were killed and scares more injured when Zairean forces dropped aerial bombs on Shabunda. The bombs fell on the same day as another deadly attack in Bukavu. No further details of the incident were immediately reported. The incident  was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsi rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, and the Zairean government. The conflict began when the government denied the Tutsis citizenship and tried to expel them to their ancestral homeland in Rwanda. The rebels had seized a number of border areas of the country, and the government launched an offensive to regain control in October 1996.

51 civilians were reportedly killed by Burundian forces in Burambi in attacks believed to be in reprisal for a Hutu rebel attack that left 13 people dead in Mugara. The army denied the charges. The incident was also related to an on-going conflict between Hutu rebels and the Tutsi-dominated army in the country.
Comments: It was not entirely clear whether the Burundian army was disputing the occurrence of the massacre or its alleged involvement as the perpetrators of this massacre.

Description: More than 100 civilians were reportedly killed by Burundian forces in Mugara in attacks believed to be in reprisal for a Hutu rebel attack that left 13 people dead in the town. The army denied the charges. The incident was also related to an on-going conflict between Hutu rebels and the Tutsi-dominated army in the country.
Comments: It was not entirely clear whether the Burundian army was disputing the occurrence of the massacre or its alleged involvement as the perpetrators of this massacre.

Description: Chinese officials said nine people were killed and 74 injured in the bomb attacks.  Three bombs planted on buses blew up within minutes of each other in Xinjiang's regional capital, Urumqi, on February 25 in an attack apparently coordinated to coincide with funeral rites in Beijing for paramount leader Deng Xiaoping. A fourth bomb failed to explode.
Comments: The victims were random as the buses they were riding were bombed at random.

Description: "A Jordanian soldier shot dead seven Israeli schoolgirls and wounded six while the children were on a field trip to the Israeli-Jordanian border." The attack apparently occurred at a farm called "The Island of Peace" along the border, which Israel leases from Jordan under a 1994 peace agreement.  Reports noted that: "The attack came amid a crisis in Middle East peacemaking between Israel and its Arab neighbours over plans to build a Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem." The solider responsible for the attack seemed to have acted alone, "charg[ing] into a group of girls aged 12 to 14, emptying the clip of his rifle." Both the U.S. and Jordan considered the attack murder, Israelis and Palestinians believed the massacre was connected to the rising political tensions. Jordan's King Hussein later apologized for the incident, stating that "he deeply regretted the killing of innocent Israeli children and vowed on Thursday to work for the rest of his life for Middle East peace."
Citation: Reuters 13 Mar 97 lba0000020011002dt3d08mad, lba0000020011002dt3d08mcj, lba0000020011002dt3d08taj; Reuters 14 Mar 97 lba0000020011002dt3d08man

Description: Ten Moslem students and their teacher died when mortar rounds hit their school on March 16 during fighting between soldiers and guerrillas of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF).
Comments: A special probe panel said the mortar rounds that killed the 11 civilians was probably fired from a Philippine army-controlled area.

Description: Fifty-seven civilian villagers were killed when the Burundian army and Hutu rebels opened fire at the same time in the capital of Bujumbura on 27 March 1997, according to an army statement. This incident is related to an ongoing conflict between the Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebels in the country. The conflict erupted in violence in 1993, when the first democratically elected Hutu president was assassinated.

The death toll from a car bomb explosion in a crowded bus station in the northern city of Jammu rose to 16 on Sunday and a senior official accused a Pakistani intelligence service of carrying out the attack.
Comments: Pakistan's ISI was not available to refute the allegations from the Indian officials.

Description: UNICEF and Save the Children aid agencies stated that they feared that 50 Rwandan Hutu refugee children who had been seized by Alliance rebel soldiers from a hospital in Lwiro had been killed. The kidnapped children, all of whom were sick and suffering from malnutrition, were thrown in the back of a truck by the soldiers before being taken away. One report also noted that 60 adults had been abducted along with the children, though no mention was made of whether the adults were thought to have been killed. The incident was related to an on-going conflict between the Tutsi-dominated Alliance rebels, who sought to overthrow the Zairean government and who controlled the eastern portion of the country, and Hutus in the region. A large number of Hutus had fled into eastern Zaire during a 1994 genocide in Rwanda. At the time of this incident, the Alliance was allegedly operating a liquidation campaign to remove all Rwandan refugees from the region under their control.
Citation: Reuters 28 Apr 97 lba0000020011002dt4s06f6o; Reuters 29 Apr 97 lba0000020011002dt4t06gow
Comments: I have coded the perpetrator Alliance rebel soldiers as a state actor because the journalistic account of the incident portrayed the Alliance as a quasi-state actor. The Alliance, which controlled the region of the country where the incident occurred, was the de-facto "state" actor as no state forces exerted control in the region.

Description: The group Medecins Sans Frontieres accused Laurent Kabila's Alliance rebels of "stepping up massacres of Rwandan refugees" in the Kivu area of Zaire. It also claimed that the rebels were operating on a policy of "total liquidation" of the refugees. It gave no estimates of how many people had been killed. In October 1997, Human Rights Watch accused Kabila's forces of continuing to kill civilians, especially in Kivu. The rebel commander had gained control of the country, now called the Democratic Republic of the Congo, in May 1997. His forces continued to kill civilians after the take-over, often in disputes over land or political power. The HRW report did not specifically identify victims. This alleged campaign was related to an on-going conflict between the Tutsi-dominated Alliance rebel force and Hutus in Zaire. Many Rwandan refugees had fled into Zaire during the 1994 genocide against Tutsis and Hutu moderates.
Secondary.Source: Medecins sans Frontieres, Human Rights Watch
Citation: Reuters 27 Apr 97 lba0000020011002dt4r06egz; Reuters 08 Oct 97 lba0000020011001dta801hi4
Comments: I have coded Laurent Kabila's forces as a state actor because as of May 1997 the Alliance forces were in control of the former Zaire.

Description: Rejecting the Burundian army's assertion that rebels had killed 100 civilians at Kayogoro, the opposition group the National Council for the Defense of Democracy (CNDD) stated that the army had in fact killed 300 civilians at Kayogoro. This incident is related to an ongoing conflict between Hutu rebels and the Tutsi dominated Burundian army. The conflict turned violent in 1993, when troops assassinated the country's democratically elected Hutu president.
Secondary.Source: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD)

Description: A U.N. human rights report documented the killings of more than 2,000 people in the Ruhengeri province of Rwanda. Most of the victims were said to be unarmed civilians. The report identified the perpetrator as the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA). It was noted that the RPA had undertaken operations to halt a Hutu rebellion in the area, but that the mainly-Tutsi RPA had instead killed thousands of civilians in the mainly-Hutu area. The Rwandan government rejected the charge of having killed innocent civilians. It asserted that those who had been killed in its operations were militiamen.
Citation: Reuters 08 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8801i6o; Reuters 10 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8a01fde

Description: An international aid worker in Vavuniya told Reuters at least 10 civilians were killed and more had been wounded from the artillery shelling of Wanni.
Comments: The LTTE say that civilians were targeted but gave no number of deaths.  An aid worker told Reuters by phone that at least 10 civilians were killed.  However, other aid workers said they had not seen large scale civilian movement as a large number of civilians had already moved to safer locations.

Description: one soldier was killed in the fighting and five civilians died when their hamlet on the outskirts of the town of Turbo was caught in crossfire involving Colombia's army, leftist insurgents and a right-wing paramilitary group
Comments: Perps were Colombian military, right wing paramilitaries AND rebels.  Coded as unclear.  Victims were villagers caught in crossfire - collateral damage.  Firearms indicated.

Description: Iraqi newspapers reported that Turkish forces had bombed villages in the northern Iraqi sector of Rawanduz, killing 20 Iraqi Kurd civilians in the process. The report noted that "thousands of Turkish troops, backed by air power, poured into northern Iraq on May 14 in pursuit of separatist Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels who use the region as a base to launch raids into southeast Turkey."
Comments: I have coded this incident as collateral damage as it occurred in the course of a military action, though there was no information available as to whether the civilian deaths were incidental. This event appears to have been reported twice. Varying details, however, have made it impossible for me to determine if one event or two has occurred. Thus, I have code each report separately and have linked the two codes.

Description: Turkish forces bombed the Kurdish-held northern Iraqi areas of Bote, Warte, and Dole-Khanaqa, killing seven civilians in the process according to the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) group. The Turkish forces had "poured into northern Iraq on May 14 in pursuit of separatist Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels who use the region as a base to launch raids into southeast Turkey." The PUK noted, however, that "there were no PKK bases in its territory." The Turkish government had not commented on the event.
Comments: I have coded this incident as collateral damage as it occurred in the course of a military action, though there was no information available as to whether the civilian deaths were incidental. This event appears to have been reported twice. Varying details, however, have made it impossible for me to determine if one event or two has occurred. Thus, I have code each report separately and have linked the two codes.

Description: The ethnic Shan resistance faction on Tuesday accused Burmese troops of massacring 58 civilians in Shan state last month.
Comments: The Shan State Army accused Burmese troops of killing 58 civilians during the first weeks of June.  The Thai government also reported hearing these same allegations from Burmese refugees crossing the border into Thailand.  The Burmese government was not available for comment and thus neither confirmed nor refuted the accusations.

Description: "Fresh clashes in the Central African Republic capital killed at least 10 civilians on Saturday and wounded dozens, including French nationals hurt when a stray mortar shell hit their embassy compound." A total of up to 104 people were believed to have been killed and another 70 wounded in several days of fighting in Bangui. A number of French nationals were injured in the fighting, when two stray mortars hit the French embassy. The deaths occurred as dissident soldiers fought with African peacekeepers. Several army mutinies in 1996 had resulted in disaffected soldiers fighting to overthrow the country's leader.
Citation: Reuters 21 Jun 97 lba0000020011002dt6l03mcb; Reuters 22 Jun 97 lba0000020011002dt6m03il6; Reuters 24 Jun 97 lba0000020011002dt6o03huk
Comments: Report did not address intent, so I have coded the intent variable as no information/unknown. The civilian deaths were described as taking place during a battle, implying that the civilian deaths were collateral damage, so I have coded for collateral damage.

Description: At least 13 people were killed in a spate of attacks in Kinshasa on 04 July 1997. The government asserted that the killings were "the work of 'criminals trying to sabotage the government.'" Laurent Kabila had recently seized power in the now Democratic Republic of the Congo after months of fighting with the Zairean government. A later report indicated that members of the new regime admitted that "President Laurent Kabila's soldiers were involved in [the] recent killings." The same report also asserted that an official statement, which had been aired on the state radio, denied that Kabila's forces were responsible claiming instead that criminals posing as members of the army had perpetrated the killings.
Citation: Reuters 07 Jul 97 lba0000020011002dt7702x39; Reuters 10 Jul 97 lba0000020011002dt7a02ukd

Description: Opposition leaders were digesting Thursday's surprise announcement, but said they would press on with a campaign of mass protests in which at least nine people were killed on July 7 when security forces violently suppressed a rally.

Victim.Identity.Religious: Protesters demonstrating against the desecration of the statue of Bhimrao Ambedkar, a revered leader of the lower social classes
Description: The strike was called to protest at Friday's police shooting on a crowd demonstrating against the desecration of the statue of Bhimrao Ambedkar, a revered leader of the lower social classes, in a Bombay suburb.  Ten people were killed and more than 30 injured in Friday's shooting in Ghatkopar 15 km (nine miles) outside India's commercial capital in the west of the country.

Twenty civilians were reportedly killed by the Burundian army and Hutu rebels in Kabezi on either 12 or 13 July 1997. Local residents "said that the army accused the mainly-Hutu civilian population [of Kabezi] of siding with Hutu fighters." This incident was related to an ongoing ethnic conflict, which broke out in 1993 after troops assassinated the country's democratically elected Hutu president.

Democratic Republic of Congo troops opened fire on a protest march in the eastern town of Uvira, killing a number of people, humanitarian sources said on Saturday. The sources, witnesses and traders who took part in the protest on Monday gave different death tolls, ranging up to 40. The sources, who have close contact with the region and were contacted from the  former Zaire's capital Kinshasa, said demonstrators were protesting after the discovery of five corpses of Uvira residents abducted from their homes.  Traders who took part in the demonstration said 40 people were killed when AFDL troops opened fire as protesters carried the bodies of eight people killed on Sunday.

At least five peasants were killed by Burundian troops in Ruziba on 29 July 1997. The troops had gone to the village because Hutu rebels had been terrorizing the villagers. For reasons unknown, the troops "killed innocent peasants" rather than "engaging the rebels." This incident was related to an on-going conflict between the country's Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebels. The conflict broke-out in 1993 after troops assassinated the country's democratically elected Hutu president.
Military and police authorities in central Vietnam were investigating on Thursday a bloody shooting rampage in which two drunken border soldiers killed seven people and injured four others.
Comments: The tax official was stopped at the border and after an argument with the soldiers was shot and killed along with his family.

Perp.State.Military: security forces including Rwandese Patriotic Army, gendarmerie & communal police
Perp.State.Police: security forces including Rwandese Patriotic Army, gendarmerie & communal police
Description: A U.N. report documented the killings of at least 918 people in 95 incidents in July and August 1997. The attacks were carried out by various state and non-state groups, including the Rwandese Patriotic Army, gendarmerie, communal police, former members of the former Rwandese Armed Forces, Interahamwe militia, and others. The report noted that the number of killings was significantly lower than the previous two-month period.

Seven Lebanese civilians died in several days of violence between Israeli troops and Lebanese militias, which began on 04 August 1997 when "Israel began the latest round of violence by killing five guerrillas of the Islamic movement Hizbollah (Party of God) with a roadside bomb." It was not clear under what circumstances each of the deaths occurred, however most of the victims appear to have been collateral damage to shells and bombs launched by Israel on Hizbollah and other targets in Lebanon. The "Lebanese Foreign Minister Faris Bouez accused Israel ... of intentionally killing Lebanese civilians [in their attacks in order] to wreck a 1996 ceasefire."
Citation: Reuters 07 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8701hgj, lba0000020011002dt8701hhi; Reuters 09 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8a01f9m; Reuters 13 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8d01b7u

Description: "A militia led by a pro-Israeli commander fired shells at the southern port city of Sidon on Monday, killing six civilians and wounding 34, many of them seriously." The leader who lead the attack was in command of the South Lebanon Army (SLA), which operated out of an Israeli occupied area, and another militia in Jezzine, located just outside of the Israeli occupied area. The attacks "followed an increase in attacks on the Jezzine area." There was no indication that the militia's attacks, which appeared to be in retaliation for a bomb attack in Jezzin, had been aimed at legitimate military targets.
Comments: I have coded the perpetrator, an Israeli-supported militia led by an SLA commander, as transnational because the attacks seemed to have originated from an Israeli-held part of Lebanon and because the perpetrator group was specifically supported by a transnational actor, Israel. Reports gave no indication that this attack targeted legitimate military targets, thus I have coded the event as 'not collateral damage.'

Description: Shelling by Nigerian forces trying to enforce an economic blockade on Sierra Leone's capital Freetown killed at least 20 people, including young children, witnesses said on Thursday. State radio put the toll in the barrage, which hit coastal slums in the city late on Wednesday and early on Thursday, at more than 50. Major John Milton, spokesman for the soldiers who toppled Kabbah on May 25, accused the Nigerian troops of targeting civilian areas in the earlier barrage. "The Nigerians shelled the coastal area of Freetown last night and this morning just to kill our citizens," he said. Residents said they believed the salvoes were aimed at a Cypriot registered ship, The Proteus, which arrived offshore on Wednesday with a cargo of rice. "They missed the boat and the shells were flying over and landing in our places," one said. The doctors said they were treating at least 17 people wounded in the incident. Reporters saw at least a further 15 wounded people in areas hit by the shells.
Comments: It is alleged that Nigeria intentionally targeted the civilians, but this has not been proven.

Description: On Friday cross-border shelling killed 8 Pakistani civilians in Leepa and Neelam valley.  2 Indian civilians were also reported killed in a the same exchange of fire in the Indian-controlled area of Kashmir.
Comments: The report did not specify where in the Indian - controlled area of Kashmir the two civilians were killed.

Description: A unit from the paramilitary Border Security Force (BSF), chasing separatist militants on Thursday night, fired mortar bombs towards a forest and some of the rounds fell on homes in Arin, 75 km (45 miles) north of Srinagar, the capital of troubled Jammu and Kashmir state leaving 11 dead.
Comments: Members of the Border Security Force blamed the army for the deaths claiming they do not have use of artillery shells only the army has them.

Description: India traded artillery fire with Pakistan on Tuesday, saying "deliberate and indiscriminate" bombardment from across their ceasefire line high in the Himalayas killed at least 15 civilians and wounded more than 30 on the Indian side.
Comments: No response was immediately available from Pakistan regarding the incident.

Description: India and Pakistan exchanged artillery fire in Kashmir on Wednesday for the second day running, officials said, and 10 civilians were reported killed in the part controlled by Pakistan.
Comments: Indian authorities acknowledge the exchange of fire, but say no casualties resulted from the incident.

Description: Human rights and opposition figures alleged that the Burundian army killed 70 civilians during an operation to hunt-down suspected Hutu rebels at Gitenga hill. The army denied that any killings had occurred, and insisted that "the area was calm." This contested incident was related to an on-going conflict between the Tutsi-dominated Burundian army and Hutu rebels. Violence broke out in 1993 after troops assassinated the democratically elected Hutu president.

"Four human rights groups accused the army of killing and terrorising civilians in Moundou in a bloody October crackdown on FARF," a rebel group. They asserted that 52 civilians were killed in the crackdown.

Dozens of prisoners died during a Hutu rebel attack on a prison in Gisenyi. The prisoners were described as having been killed either in the crossfire of shoot-outs between the rebels and government soldiers or when the rebels set fire to the prison. The Hutu rebels attacked the prison in an effort to secure the release of "hundreds of their colleagues," many of whom were awaiting trial for participating in Rwanda's 1994 genocide.
Comments: I have coded the intent variable as intent apparent but not stated because setting fire to a prison is an action which a reasonable person would recognize as likely to cause deaths. I have coded the collateral damage variable as collateral damage because some of the deaths were the result of cross-fire between rebels and soldiers.

Description: Amnesty International accused forces of the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) of shooting dead 300 people at Gatonde in November 1997, in an attack described as a "large-scale reprisal." The incident was related to an upsurge of Rwandan violence, which began in October 1997.

Amnesty International asserted that Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) soldiers had killed 539 civilians in Jenda in November 1997, in an attack described as a "large-scale reprisal." The incident was related to an upsurge of Rwandan violence, which began in October 1997.

Amnesty International accused forces of the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) of indiscriminately shooting about 150 people at Gashyusha in November 1997, in an attack described as a "large-scale reprisal." The incident was related to an upsurge of Rwandan violence, which began in October 1997.

Amnesty International reported that "thousands of unarmed Rwandan civilians" have been killed since December 1997 in operation conducted by both government and opposition forces. The report added that so many people have "disappeared" in recent months that families are not even bothering to report them as missing; "disappearances" were particularly common after government forces carried out mass arrests.
Comments: Note that at least some of these casualties might also exist in the codebook as single incident codes. Which events were included in this campaign is not clear, hence the campaign identifier could not be used.

Description: Sierra Leone's military junta said on Saturday a Nigerian plane had bombed the town of Zimmi near the Liberian border on Friday, killing 20 people. "The jet dropped one bomb close to a military position in Zimmi but missed the target and hit civilian areas, killing 20 people," a junta spokesman said. The spokesman said reports had been received of another attack on five villages surrounding Zimmi on Saturday. A number of houses had been destroyed, but casualty figures were unknown, he said. There was no independent confirmation of the attacks and no officials were available at the Monrovia headquarters of the Nigerian-led ECOMOG force to comment on the reports.

Turkish security forces killed five people who they identified as Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels along the southern border with Syria. Later Turkey's main human rights group contested that the victims were simply villagers of Arab extraction, not PKK rebels. The Human Rights Association called for an investigation into the killings.

Afghanistan's Taleban Islamic movement said on Thursday its forces were not in the area of a reported massacre of more than 600 civilians last week and the killings could have been the work of opposition forces. The Taleban government's health minister, Mullah Abbas, told reporters that Taleban was not in the area at the time when the opposition alliance says retreating Taleban forces killed the civilians in a northeastern province on January 1 and January 2. The alliance sent a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Tuesday saying the massacre had been committed in four villages and the administrative centre of Qaisar district of Faryab province. "The Taleban left Qaisar 12 days ago," Abbas said, adding that the civilians might have been killed by forces of northern Uzbek warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum to avenge their support for his rival General Abdul Malik. A U.N. investigator who visited the mass graves found that hundreds of captives were thrown down wells and then killed with grenades. A U.N. source in Islamabad said on Wednesday information from some contacts suggested there had been "some killings" in Faryab but it was not clear how many.
Soldiers killed six civilians and wounded at least five others when they opened fire on vehicles at a roadblock on a main highway about 30 miles (50 km) west of Bogota, authorities said on Sunday
Comments: Military identified as perps.  Victims were random individuals stopped at roadblock.  No motive given.  Firearms indicated.  Military commentary indicated that shots may have been fired from the vehicles at the roadblock.

Description: The main human rights group in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Azadho, alleged that President Kabila's troops massacred more than 300 civilians in the eastern market town of Butembo. They carried out the killings while fighting a rebellion by Mai-Mai tribal warriors who had captured a part of the town before government troops went in. According to Azadho, "the soldiers began firing on innocent civilians apparently in order to exert moral pressure on the Mai-Mai to leave."
Comments: Although Reuters does not present the report explicitly as one that could not be independently confirmed, it presents it as an allegation ("The main human rights group in the Democratic Republic of the Congo alleged on Friday that President Laurent Kabila's troops last month massacred more than 300 civilians in a town in the east of the country."), hence I code it as a rumor/allegation EVEN THOUGH the whole report as a whole is presented as a secondary account.

Description: Sudanese army planes bombed a hospital operated by the aid agency Norwegian People's Aid at Yei, a territory controlled by Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA); seven people died and 46 others were wounded.
Comments: The hospital in question treats wounded rebels as well as civilians in the rebel-controlled area; so although some of the casualties might be rebels, they were unarmed combatants at most, so I code the total toll reported.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: hospital "population and staff" (identified as a "civilian target")
Description: Reuters reported on 03/06/1999 that "a high-flying Antonov plane dropped 24 bombs on Wednesday [03/03/1999] on the rebel-held town of Yei in western Equatoria province, forcing the population to flee into protective bunkers"; reportedly, "two bombs fell on the hospital but there were no casualties [in this attack]"; reportedly, "Yei hospital has been bombed on 13 separate occasions in one year killing 23 and injuring 60"

Nigerian police said on Tuesday they had put down overnight protests by Shi'ite Moslems in the northern city of Kaduna but they could not confirm any deaths.  Shi'ites protesting against the arrest of the wife and children of detained preacher Ibrahim El-Zak Zaky said up to 12 of their members had been shot dead in a second night of violence. At least three were killed on Sunday. "It was only with teargas that the protest was stopped," Kaduna State Police Commissioner Yakubu Shuaibu told reporters. "If the Shi'ites are saying people have been killed then where are the bodies? Let them bring them out." "Some people died, about 12 men," said a Shi'ite spokesman in hiding in a working class district of the city. He said they had been unable to retrieve the bodies after police opened fire in the dark.

Local officials in Pakistan-ruled Azad (free) Kashmir said earlier that 21 people had died in an alleged attack by Indian commandos on two houses 600 meters (yards) from the control line. The toll later rose to 22 with the death of one of the three injured.
Comments: There was no report to an Indian government response to the allegations.

Description: Nigerian police have detained 20 opposition activists and are hunting others following anti-government protests in which at least seven people died in the city of Ibadan, opposition leaders said on Sunday. Witnesses in Ibadan said a total of seven people were killed when police opened fire in different locations to disperse rampaging demonstrators. An undetermined number were wounded.

Indonesia's armed forces said on Thursday the country's new government should be given a chance to function, hours after President B.J. Habibie had called on the military to avoid killing demonstrators. He also pledged to look for the truth behind claims that organised groups were responsible for rioting last month, including in the capital, in which around 1,200 people died.

Eritrean forces fighting for control of the northern territories of Ethiopia reportedly caused the death of 20 civilians, wounded 20 others, and caused the displacement of more than 370 people in Badem and Sheraro districts. Eritrean forces admitted that it used force in the region but said it was merely to retake land which Ethiopia had occupied six months ago.

Israeli troops shot dead 8 Palestinians and wounded scores as protests raged across the West Bank and Gaza to mark 50 years of exile and dispossession since Israel's birth. The 8 killed included two boys, aged 8.
Comments: The article stated that "scores were wounded" so I coded the wounded as 25-99.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters marking the 50th anniversary of the creation of Israel
Description: Israeli troops shot dead eight Palestinians and wounded scores on Thursday as protests raged across the West Bank and Gaza to mark 50 years of exile and dispossession since Israel's birth.
Secondary.Source: chief of public security in the Gaza Strip

Description: Afghanistan's Taleban Islamic militia bombed the opposition-held town of Taloqan on Sunday and 31 people were killed, an Afghan news agency said. Afghan Islamic Press (AIP), which is based in the Pakistani border town of Peshawar, quoted Taleban and its foes as confirming the attack had taken place. It was thought to be one of the most serious attacks since U.S.-backed peace talks broke down in Islamabad last month. AIP said the Taleban bombed Taloqan four times from the air, killing 31 people and injuring 43. The movement is known to have ageing Soviet-era jet fighters and some helicopters.

"The ethnic Albanian Kosovo Information Centre (KIC) said on Tuesday that 12 Albanians were killed by police and the Yugoslav army in Southwest Kosovo on Monday and Tuesday [25 and 26 May 1998]." The KIC's allegations were not independently confirmed. The alleged incident was related to an on-going conflict between ethnic Albanians and Serbs in the disputed region.

"U.N. agencies expressed concern on Tuesday over violence in Serbia's Kosovo province, reporting worsening abuses" that had resulted in at least 130 deaths. The deaths were related to a flare-up in an on-going violent conflict between ethnic Albanian separatists and Serb government forces in the disputed Kosovo province.
Comments: Report noted that Serb forces were attacking ethnic Albanian villages and that ethnic Albanian rebels were attacking Serb police forces. The death count I have recorded here likely includes some combatants (Serb police, ethnic Albanian rebels). I have coded the perpetrator as Serb security forces ONLY because all non-combatant deaths appear to have been perpetrated by them.

Description: An Eritrean aircraft bombed a residential area in the northern Ethiopian town of Mekele, killing "nearly 50 people", at least 10 of them children, and wounding more than 100.
Mexican Indians in troubled Chiapas prepared on Saturday to bury eight fellow Zapatista supporters killed in one of the bloodiest clashes yet between rebels and security forces in the fractious state
Comments: Perps identified as Mexican military.  Victims identified as Chiapas rebels that were captured.  Rebel spokesman claim that the captured individuals were later executed - coded as unarmed combatants.  No indication of weapons used.

Description: At least 20 people were killed and more than 50 wounded when Sri Lankan armed forces bombed and shelled civilian areas in the north of the country on Wednesday, the opposition Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) said.
Comments: The Sri Lankan government was not immediately available for comment.

Description: In a 1999 report, Amnesty International alleged that hundreds of people were killed in Togo following elections in June 1998.  Togolese Prime Minister Agbeyome Messan Kodjo appeared before UN Human Rights Commission to deny the allegations, claiming opposition leaders paid Amnesty half a million dollars to write the report, which Amnesty denies.  Amnesty alleged that Togolese security forces had killed several hundred people, specifically opposition activists, and thrown their bodies into the Gulf of Guinea following the elections.  The 1998 election was widely questioned by both opposition parties and foreign monitors.  Investigators from the United Nations and the Organisation for African Unity said they were convinced Togolese security forces  murdered, tortured and raped people after the election.  The report alleges arbitrary and extra-judicial killings, torture and mistreatment as well as rapes and kidnappings of women.
Comments: The bodies were dumped in the Gulf of Guinea, but it was not clear where the event actually took place. Thus, the only location information noted is the country.

Description: A coalition of Indonesian non-governmental organisations (NGOs) said on Monday seven people had been killed in remote Irian Jaya province in clashes with security troops.  The Human Rights Advocate Team For the People of Irian Jaya told Reuters six people were killed on Biak island and one in Sorong between July 4 and 7 during demonstrations. Some Biak residents were reported as saying shortly after the clashes that seven people had been killed, although the reports were not confirmed. Police contacted in Biak on Monday said there were no deaths, only light injuries.
Comments: Police in Biak claim nobody was killed.

Description: Six people were killed by overnight Indian firing and shelling across a control line into the Pakistan-ruled part of the disputed Kashmir region, the official APP news agency said on Friday.
Comments: It was unclear at the time of the report whether the victims were soldiers or civilians.

Description: 11 civilians were killed in Mbuye commune amidst fighting between a big group of Hutu rebels and government forces.
Secondary.Source: state-run radio and Burundi Press Agency
Comments: Whether the civilians were killed intentionally because they were thought to be combatants, or whether it was a case of collateral damage is not clear; because there is no suggestion in the report that it was unintentional collateral damage, I code it as not collateral damage but still code the intent as unclear.

Description: At least 11 people, including a Pakistani soldier, were killed and 20 wounded on Thursday by Indian mortar shelling in the Pakistan-ruled part of the disputed Kashmir region, local officials said.
Comments: There was no comment yet from Indian officials.

Description: Eleven civilians were killed and as many wounded by Indian shelling in various sectors in Pakistan-controlled Azad (free) Kashmir on Wednesday, the official Associated Press of Pakistan news agency said.
Comments: Indian denies that any civilian casualties resulted from the exchange of fire.

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: Iranian officials, members of the Hazara ethnic group, members of the Tajik and Uzbek communities
Description: Survivors of a massacre in the Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif in August described a "killing frenzy" in which soldiers of the ruling Taleban shot "anything that moved," Human Rights Watch said in a report on Saturday. The New York-based group, the first international human rights organisation to interview survivors of the assault, said as many as 2,000 civilians were killed in what it described as one of the worst atrocities of Afghanistan's 20-year civil war. In the takeover of Mazar-i-Sharif, Taleban troops also killed eight Iranian officials at the Iranian consulate and killed an Iranian journalist, creating tension between predominantly Sh'ite Moslem Iran and the Taleban, which is Sunni Moslem and follows a strict conservative sect. Human Rights Watch, which interviewed dozens of survivors who reached safety in neighbouring Pakistan, reported that after the Taleban swept into Mazar-i-Sharif on Aug. 8, its soldiers sought out and killed members of the Hazara ethnic group, who are Shi'ite Moslems. Members of the Tajik and Uzbek communities were also targeted as Taleban soldiers with their trademark black turbans and white flags shot people at random on the streets and bazaars of the northern city, the report said. The report quoted eyewitnesses as saying that women and girls, particularly in certain Hazari areas of the city, were raped and abducted. Thousands of men were held prisoner in an overcrowded jail and many were transported in closed container trucks to other cities. Hundreds died of heat stroke and asphyxiation, according to eyewitnesses.
Comments: The Taleban government, which controls more than 90 percent of Afghanistan but is not recognised by most countries, says the killers were rogue fighters who would be punished. But the HRW report alleged that during the siege, the Taleban governor, Mulla Manon Niazi, delivered speeches inciting violence against Hazaris, accusing them of killing Taleban soldiers, including prisoners, in a 1997 battle for the city. "These speeches clearly indicate that the killings were not the actions of renegade forces, but had the sanction of Taleban authorities," the report stated.

Description: Jets of Afghanistan's Taleban movement bombed the opposition-held central town of Bamiyan on Thursday, killing 13 people and wounding many others, an Afghan opposition group said. A spokesman for the Shi'ite Moslem Hezb-i-Wahdat (Akbari) faction, quoted by the Pakistan-based Afghan Islamic Press (AIP) news service, said most of the victims were children and women. But AIP quoted a Taleban spokesman in the southern Afghan town of Kandahar, Maulvi Wakil Ahmad Mutwakil, as saying he was unaware of any bombing on Bamiyan, one of the few strongholds left with the opposition forces after swift recent Taleban victories in the north of the country. Quoting its own sources, the agency said Taleban jets had been taking off on Thursday from the Kabul airport, without indicating their direction. It also quoted a spokesman for the Hezb-i-Wahdat's Khalili faction, Qair Sher, as saying that the Taleban planes bombed residential areas of Bamiyan from high altitude "causing a lot of deaths and damage to property".

Rebel forces claimed that Angolan and Zimbabwean warplanes supporting Kabila bombed areas around the rebel front line, about 32 miles southwest of Kinshasa, killing "hundreds" of people--mostly civilians.
Comments: Claims could not be independently confirmed.

Description: According to a senior rebel leader in control of the city Goma, an Angolan aircraft struck the Lake Tanganyika port of Kalemie, destroying a number of houses, killing at least 25 people and wounding 40 others.
Comments: The information given by the senior rebel commander could not be independently confirmed, hence the code of rumor/allegation.

Description: Congo rebel forces fighting to overthrow President Kabila claimed that government troops retreating from the eastern towns of Kalemie, Vyura, and Kisangani, killed at least 264 people--mainly ethnic Tutsi civilians but also some unidentified number of rebel troops.
Comments: The rebels' claim could not be independently confirmed. Also note that the noncombatant casualty toll is tainted because of the presence of rebel troops in that number, which was not sufficiently specified to allow me to subtract it from the total death toll.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: all males over seven years of age
Description: Afghanistan's Taleban militia on Monday denied Iranian allegations that its fighters killed civilians when they captured the central Shi'ite town of Bamiyan at the weekend. The movement's senior spokesman, Wakil Ahmed, said such reports in the Iranian media were lies and he invited the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to visit the area on a fact-finding mission.  The spokesman termed reports that Taleban fighters killed all males over seven years of age in Bamiyan a "big lie and conspicuous propaganda."

Victim.Identity.Political: Supporters of former leader Roosevelt Johnson
Description: Roosevelt Johnson, President Charles Taylor's ethnic Krahn rival from the 1989-96 civil war, said on Wednesday that more than 300 people had died in a weekend crackdown on his supporters by government security forces. "There are more than 300 who have been massacred," he told Reuters in a brief interview in the U.S. embassy in Monrovia, where he took refuge on Saturday with his two pre-teen sons and two aides during a gun battle which started the stand-off. Western diplomats, relief workers and residents in the Camp Johnson Road area that bore the brunt of the fighting said that reports of several hundred dead appeared solid. "I have heard credible reports of hundreds killed," one diplomat said. Residents of the Camp Johnson Road area, which became a Krahn stronghold during the civil war, said the same and spoke of truckloads of bodies being carted away. "It was an operation in the night of Friday to Sunday afternoon," one said of the fighting, which began when Taylor's Special Security Unit moved in to clear out Johnson supporters.

seven people were killed in a shootout between government troops and alleged members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  Twelve were injured .  According to local witnesses victims included noncombatants upon whom the soldiers planted weapons.
Comments: Perps identified as Colombian military.  Victims are disputed.  Military referred to them as FARC members while eyewitnesses indicate they were non-combatants.  Firearms indicated.

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: a suspected perpetrator of the 1994 genocide
Description: Two Rwandan army soldiers opened fire in a bar at the Ntongwe commune in the Butare district with the aim of avenging the death of a brother-in-law in the 1994 genocide; they were targeting a specific individual, who ended up among the seven dead as a result of the attack (four others were wounded).
Comments: There is no indication to suggest that even the targeted individual was armed at the time of the incident.

Description: Fourteen villagers were tortured and killed by Serb troops in the Drenica region of Kosovo. The massacre occurred on the same day as another in Gornje Obrinje. Both attacks were related to a crack-down on the KLA in Kosovo, and a wider, on-going ethnic/civil conflict.
Comments: KLA = Kosovo Liberation Army; Report quoted one injured survivor, which I have counted as injured, but did not state a total injured count.

Description: Serb troops surrounded the village of Gornje Obrinje and killed a number of Kosovo Albanian villagers after discovering their hiding place. A Reuters reporter had seen the bodies of 16 victims, including women, children, and elderly people. Local villagers located the badly decomposed body of a 17th victim weeks after the attack. Later, the prime minister of Yugoslavia denied that Serb troops had carried out any attacks on civilians. The attack was related to an on-going ethnic/civil conflict in the disputed region.
Citation: Reuters 04 Oct 98 lba0000020021113dua4018ff; Reuters 13 Oct 98 lba0000020021113duad01t07; Reuters 21 Oct 98 lba0000020021113dual02cn2

Description: According to witnesses, the Burundian army killed 178 civilians during an operation against Hutu rebels at the Mutambu commune in Rural Bujumbura province. This number was contested by the local governor, who reported a civilian death toll of 56,According to a senior regional official, and the Burundian government, who admitted the killing of civilians during the operation but gave the civilian death toll as 30.
Comments: Note that the highest civilian death toll reported by witnesses to local media sources is contested by both the regional governor and the Burundian government. One of the Reuters reports cited in this code gives the account of the witnesses, while the other one reports claims by the local official and the Burundian government.

Description: Tajikistan's defence ministry said on Friday more than 200 people, including bystanders, had been killed in fighting which had raged since rebels captured a town 300 km (190 miles) north of the capital early on Wednesday. "The list compiled by the government of Tajikistan of losses during military activity in Leninabad region is 180 rebels killed, 25 government troops and eight citizens," it said in a statement. A total of 172 government soldiers and citizens had been injured, it said. The ministry did not say how many had been wounded among the forces of rebel commander Makhmud Khudoiberdyev, who led an estimated 1,000 rebels into battle.
Comments: The report presents the death of civilians as collateral damage in the midst of fighting between rebels and government troops, but does not clarify the intentions of the perpetrators.

Description: At least seven people were killed in clashes between troops and protesters in Indonesia on Friday. The military has come in for harsh criticism because troops shot bullets directly into the crowds. Authorities have said the troops were issued only rubber bullets, but these can be lethal at close range.

Students protested in East Timor's capital after allegations that Indonesian troops had killed or tortured scores of civilians in a crackdown on separatist rebels around the village of Alas, about 200 km (125 miles) east of Dili. Details were unclear, but former East Timor governor Mario Carrascalao told Reuters that at least 42 people had been killed during the riots.
Comments: Human Rights groups have unconfirmed reports of the killings, but the Indonesian government denies the events.

Description: According to the pro-rebel Norwegian People's Aid (NPA), the Sudanese government flew an Antonov plane over the rebel-controlled city of Narus, bombing schools and a health center, killing six and wounding 16 others.
Comments: Although Reuters does not explicitly confirm the alleged attack independently of the NPA, it still reports the incident as one that really took place and not as merely a rumor.

Description: Colombian human rights activists said on Monday up to 27 civilians could have been killed when an army plane bombed a village during clashes with Marxist rebels but military chiefs denied the report.
Secondary.Source: Gloria Gomez, Regional Committee for Human Rights
Comments: Colombian military identified as perps.  Victims identified only as civilians.  Deaths occurred as collateral damage in aerial bombing.  Rebels claimed as having used civilians as human shields.  Military sources claim 14 civilian dead.

Description: Fourteen ethnic Albanians were killed in Golubovac in the fall of 1998 by Serb troops, who beat and shot their victims. One man survived the attack by pretending to be dead and later told the story of what had happened. The deaths were related to escalating violence in an ongoing conflict between ethnic Albanian separatists and Serbs in the disputed province.
Colombian civil court ordered its government to pay US$700,000 to victims and relatives of an air force bombing that killed 17 civilians during 1998 clashes with rebels,
Comments: Perps identified as Colombian Air Force.  Victims identified only as 17 civilians.  News report is of settlement of 1998 incident in which the state initially denied both blame and victim identity.  Bombs dropped that targeted rebels; victims were collateral.

Description: At least six people were killed when security forces fired on demonstrators who set fire to a local government building in Indonesia's rebellious Aceh province on Sunday, witnesses and human rights groups said. "Locals who were at the scene said that security forces had opened fire with mostly live ammunition," an official of a leading Indonesian human rights group told Reuters by telephone from Lhokseumawe. He said dozens were wounded and the area was still tense, with helicopters patrolling and troops blocking main roads. Residents said the crowd that attacked the government building had been marching towards Lhokseumawe to protest against the detention of a villager by police. Separatist insurgency has been simmering in the resource-rich, staunchly Moslem province for years. Residents and human rights groups say a nine-year-old army crackdown involved widespread torture, rape and summary executions.

Perp.State.Military: "planes from forces backing President Laurent Kabila", "allied forces from Zimbabwe, Angola, Chad and Namibia shoring up Kabila's beleaguered army" (AGO, NAM, TCD, ZWE)
Description: Reuters reported on 01/11/1999 that according to "aid workers", "planes from forces backing President Laurent Kabila have bombed the rebel-held northeastern Congolese town of Kisangai, killing about 40 people... military and civilians"; reportedly, "a spokesman for the allied forces from Zimbabwe, Angola, Chad and Namibia shoring up Kabila's beleaguered army confirmed the bombing but gave no details"; the report did not indicate how many of those killed were civilians
Comments: It was not clear in the available reports how many of those killed were civilians (reportedly, "40 people [including] military and civilians" were killed in the attack); it was not clear in the available reports whether the perpetrator intended to kill civilians, or whether the civilian deaths were collateral damage, although reportedly "Congolese rebels... condemned [the] bombing raid... saying the attack had no apparent military objective"

Description: 45 ethnic Albanian villagers were killed, many execution-style, by Serb police in an apparent massacre. Serb authorities later denied that the victims had been massacred, which was denied by Western observers in the region. In January 1999, wiretaps revealed that "senior Serb officials in Belgrade" had ordered the massacre because they were angered by the killing of three Serb troops by Albanian guerillas. The incident was related to a recent up-surge in violence and deterioration of a peace agreement of October 1998. The incident was also related to a wider, on-going ethnic/civil conflict between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo province.
Comments: Reports indicated between 40 and 45 people were killed in the incident. The Serbian forensic examiner later claimed that the victims had not been massacred, a claim which Western monitors in the region denied. The wiretap revelation came from a story in the Washington Post, as reported by Reuters.

Description: Reuters reported on 01/29/1999 that, according to local "witnesses", "seventy-six people died when the army attacked a church in Makamba's Muresi commune the same day [01/20/1999] looking for rebels or their supporters"; reportedly, according to a witness, "When we saw government soldiers arrive near Muresi church, we all cried 'save us, we are innocent civilians'... But one soldier replied 'Shoot on them... They collaborate with the rebels"; reportedly, "the army vigorously denied on Friday [01/29/1999] it had killed civilians and blamed ethnic Hutu rebels for the attack"
Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the secondary sources cited in the Reuters report disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided could not be accommodated in a single record

Description: Reuters reported on 01/29/1999 that, according to local "residents [and] witnesses", "government soldiers burned 30 civilians alive in a house on January 20 and killed 36 others after an attack by Hutu rebels"; reportedly, according to an eyewitness, "in Murango locality (Makamba commune) government soldiers came, burned a house with 30 civilians in [it] and shot 36 others in front of the house"; reportedly, "the army vigorously denied on Friday [01/29/1999] it had killed civilians and blamed ethnic Hutu rebels for the attack"
Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the secondary sources cited in the Reuters report disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided could not be accommodated in a single record

Description: A number of ethnic Albanians were killed by Serb forces in the village of Rogovo. The circumstances of the incident were disputed. An international verification mission and an Albanian journalist asserted that the victims of the attack were civilians, while Serb forces asserted that the victims were ethnic Albanian rebels who had been killed during a firefight. This incident was related to an on-going conflict between separatist, ethnic Albanian rebels and Serb forces. An armed conflict had broken out in 1998 when Serb forces began an offensive to crack-down on the rebels.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: "two women, two men and an infant"
Description: Reuters reported on 02/09/1999 that, according to "witnesses", "an Ethiopian plane launched a pre-dawn bombing raid on a small Eritrean village near their disputed border on Tuesday [02/09/1999], killing five civilians and wounding five others"; reportedly, "a Reuters correspondent at the scene said two women, two men and an infant were killed when the Ethiopian plane dropped at least four bombs on Laili Deda, a village of tents housing about 500 Eritreans deported from Ethiopia last year"; reportedly, "the victims were all members of the same family"; a later Reuters report (02/11/1999) indicated that "Ethiopia apologised on Thursday for killing five civilians in a bombing raid in its border war with Eritrea... saying it 'sincerely regrets' the deaths"

Reuters reported on 02/12/1999 that, according to a "senior [Eritrean] government official", "Ethiopian army units had been shelling the area around Zalambessa for the last two or three days [and] there were around 12 civilians killed in the surrounding villages and around 30 homes destroyed"; reportedly, "Ethiopia said it had no word on casualties but that its forces had simply responded to shelling by enemy units"

Indonesian troops opened fire on villagers during weekend clashes between Moslems and Christians in the eastern island of Haruku in the Moluccas, the Indonesian Churches Communion (PGI) said on Tuesday.
Comments: A spokesman for the Indonesian Churches Communion said that 6 people were confirmed killed by troops.  One police officer however said 21 people had been confirmed dead, but not by troops.  He stated that these people had been killed during clashes between villagers.

Description: There have been recurrent reports of unrest between President Saddam Hussein's government and Shi'ites, mostly centered in the south of Iraq, where government forces crushed a Shi'ite-led rebellion at the close of the 1991 Gulf War. The London-based daily al-Hayat reported on Monday that 25 people were killed and 50 were injured in confrontations between protesters and Iraqi security forces.
Indonesian police shot and killed nine people on Monday on the strife-torn spice island of Ambon when they fired without warning on Moslems leaving a mosque after early prayers, witnesses said.
Comments: Witnesses said the Indonesian soldiers responsible were Christians, but this comment may stem from the on going clashes between Moslems and Christians on the island.

Perp.State.Military: "Rwandan elements of the troops of the Rwanda-Uganda alliance"
Perp.Non.State.Ideological: "rebel troops of the Congolese Rally for democracy (RCD)"
Description: Reuters reported on 03/15/1999 that "the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) urged the Security Council on Monday [03/15/1999]  to order an international inquiry into an alleged massacre of about 100 civilians at Kamituga, in South Kivu province, on March 5"; reportedly, Congo ambassador Andrew Kapanga "said the March 5 massacre was perpetrated by 'Rwandan elements of the troops of the Rwanda-Uganda alliance' in that region and were the latest in a long list of massacres for which he said they were responsible"; reportedly, "a Roman Catholic missionary agency, the Rome-based MISNA, said earlier Monday that more than 100 people were killed at Kamituga on March 5 by rebel troops of the Congolese Rally for democracy (RCD) in reprisal for an attack on a convoy on its way from Kamituga to Kitatu"
Secondary.Source: Congolese government officials; MISNA (a Roman Catholic missionary news agency based in Rome)
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Rumor/Allegation since the Reuters report indicated that the government officials were demanding "an international inquiry into an alleged massacre of about 100 civilians"

Description: The British government estimated that at the very least 800 ethnic Albanians had been killed in a Serb crackdown during the end of March 1999. This crackdown coincided with NATO air strikes against Serb targets, which were intended to force the Serb regime to end its campaign against ethnic Albanian separatists and concurrent massacres of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces attacked the village of Kotlina on 24 March 1999, killing at least 17 people. Most of the homes in the village were also burnt in the attack. This incident was part of a campaign of violence in the Kacanik area and was also part of a larger campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: Serbian police and military forces massacred 20 ethnic Albanian school teachers in front of their students in the village of Dobrune on 25 March 1999. The attack came the day after NATO began bombing Serb targets in Kosovo, in an effort to force Serb leader Milosevic to come to an agreement with ethnic Albanians in the area. Separatist, ethnic Albanian rebels had been engaged in an ongoing conflict with Serb forces since 1998.

A villager reported that 24 men from Goden were abducted by Serb forces. He noted that he believed they had been killed. The incident had not been confirmed and no bodies had been seen. Another massacre had been perpetrated in the same village that day, in which Serb forces killed school teachers. The incident was part of an upsurge in violence related to NATO air strikes against Yugoslavia and was related to a wider, on-going ethnic/civil conflict between the Serb-controlled Yugoslav state and ethnic Albanian separatists in majority Albanian Kosovo.
Comments: The deaths alleged in this incident had not been confirmed, thus I have coded perpetrator intent as no information - it is not certain that anyone had in fact been killed.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces massacred 83 people in the village of Bela Crkva on 25 March 1999. The majority of those killed were Kosovo Albanian men and boys, who had been separated from women and children before being stripped, robbed, and shot in a streambed. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: After rounding up all of the members of the village of Velika Krusa, Yugoslav forces shot and killed 40 ethnic Albanian men. Details of the incident were obtained by Human Rights Watch through interviews with survivors. The massacre occurred in a wave of violence against ethnic Albanians, prompted by the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia. It was also related to an ongoing ethnic/civil conflict between Kosovo's ruling Serbs and majority Albanian population.
Comments: Story reported the massacre as allegations by Human Rights Watch.

Description: Human Rights Watch alleged that a massacre may have taken place in the Kosovo village of Mala Krusa. The NGO had interviewed a refugee who stated he had witnessed Yugoslav forces burning 112 bodies (as reported by Reuters). This alleged massacre occurred on the same day, and in close proximity to, another massacre where Yugoslav forces killed 40 ethnic Albanians. The allegations came as Serbs perpetrated a crack-down on ethnic Albanians, in retaliation for NATO air strikes on Yugoslavia. The incident was part of a wider, on-going conflict between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.
Comments: Report was vague as to intent, thus I have coded intent as no information.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces shot and killed 6 Kosovo Albanian men in a home in Dakovica on 26 March 1999. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces rounded-up and executed at least 44 civilians and injured others in an attack on the town of Suva Reka in Kosovo. The bodies of the victims were subsequently buried in a mass grave at a Serbian firing range near Korusa. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces rounded-up and executed about 105 Kosovo Albanian men and boys in the village of Mala Krusa on 26 March 1999. After killing the victims, the forces set fire to the home in which the massacre occurred. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. It is also related to an ongoing conflict between ethnic Albanian separatist rebels and Serb forces; an armed conflict between the two broke out in 1998 after Serb forces began an offensive to clamp down on the rebels. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict and campaign of violence.
Secondary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: Reuters 23 Jun 99 lba0000020010907dv6n05smz; ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces shot and killed about 20 Kosovo Albanians in the village of Padaliste on 26 March 1999. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: Serb forces were believed to have shot and killed 21 people, most of whom were children, in the village of Celine on either 25 or 26 March 1999. The bodies of the victims were discovered by British forces in July 1999. The incident was part of an on-going campaign of violence waged by Serb forces against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces attacked the village of Izbica with heavy weapons on 26 March 1999, causing the villagers to flee into a meadow. The next day the forces rounded-up the villagers, separating the men from women, stealing their belongings, and forcing them to march. The men, totaling at least 116, were shot and killed. The women were forced to walk towards Albania. Serb forces killed two elderly women, who were unable to walk, by setting the tractor they were sitting on afire. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.
