Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces attacked the Qerim district of Dakovica overnight 01-02 April 1999, killing more than 50 Kosovo Albanians and burning a number of their homes. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: An East Timorese resistance spokesman on Sunday accused Indonesian troops of killing 13 civilians in an attack on a minibus in the troubled former Portuguese colony.
Comments: The resistance group clearly distinguished that it was not the paramilitary, pro-Jakarta militiamen who attacked the bus, but rather it was the Indonesian military.

Description: An estimated 1,000 ethnic Albanians were killed by Yugoslav forces in a four-day crack-down on Albanians in Kosovo. In one incident, 45 people - mostly civilians - were killed in the village of Kacanik. The crack-downs were apparently in retaliation for NATO air strikes against Yugoslav targets, and were also related to an on-going conflict between the Serb-dominated Yugoslav state and the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo.
Comments: Report was not specific as to the mode of killing or intent of perpetrators.

Description: The press agency of the Kosovo Liberation Army alleged that "Serb terrorist forces" had killed more than 1,000 ethnic Albanians during a four-day sweep of the Drenica region of Kosovo. This campaign was related to an on-going conflict between ethnic Albanians and Serbs in the country, in which NATO forces had begun involvement.

An estimated 1,000 ethnic Albanians were killed by Yugoslav forces in a four-day crack-down on Albanians in Kosovo. In once incident, 39 people were killed in the village of Malisevo. The crack-downs were apparently in retaliation for NATO air strikes against Yugoslav targets, and were also related to an on-going conflict between the Serb-dominated Yugoslav state and the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo.
Comments: Report was not specific as to the mode of killing or intent of perpetrators.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces and police attacked the village of Slatina on 13 April 1999, killing 13 civilians. Homes in the village were also burnt and looted in the attack. This incident was part of a campaign of violence in the Kacanik area and was also part of a larger campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: The Kosovapress news agency, an army of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army, asserted that 45 civilians had been massacred by Serb forces in the Pec region of Kosovo on 15 April 1999. No information regarding the identities of the civilian victims or where the attack occurred was reported. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Comments: The Reuters report did not cast doubt on the validity of the rebel news agency's account and did not report the event as an allegation, thus I have coded the reporting as a secondary account, not contested.

Locality: Hallaq, Ribar te Vogel, & nearby villages
Description: The Kosovapress news agency, an army of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army, asserted that more than 40 ethnic Albanians were killed by Serb paramilitary and police forces in eight villages in the area of Lipljan. 23 of the victims were killed in the village of Hallaq and another 19 in Ribar te Vogel. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians; it was also related to an on-going ethnic/civil conflict.

Rwandan soldiers killed six disarmed Congolese rebels and 11 Ugandan soldiers standing nearby as the rebels staged a protest against the Rwandan presence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the army said on Tuesday. Leon Kasonga, spokesman for the Congolese Armed Forces, told state television the Rwandan troops had opened fire on the protesters in Camp Ketele in the rebel-held third city of Kisangani but he did not say when. He said the Ugandans had expressed their joy at seeing the 400 disarmed rebels stage their protest march, which he described as an expression of patriotism. "They (the Rwandans) literally shot into the group, killing six Congolese and 11 in the ranks of the Ugandans," he said, adding that the protesting rebels had said they were fed up with the presence of Rwandans in their country.
Comments: Of the 17 people killed, six were disarmed Congolese rebels. The other eleven were Ugandan soldiers standing next to the rebels.

Description: A very large number of ethnic Albanian men were killed in the Kosovo village of Meja on or about 27 April 1999 by Serb forces. Refugees' accounts, which were confirmed by the UN High Commissioner for refugees, reported that Serb forces had rounded up hundreds or thousands of refugees as the passed through the area. The ethnic Albanian men were held in a field. Later huge piles of bodies were reported seen. The UNHCR asserted that if all the reports were correct, the massacre at Meja would be the largest in the Kosovo conflict. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians; it was also related to an on-going ethnic/civil conflict.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces launched an attack in the Dakovica municipality on 27 April 1999 with the intent of forcing all of the local Kosovo Albanians to leave the area. During this incident "many" men were summarily executed, with at least 300 still missing and unaccounted for. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: At least 6 people were reported shot and killed along the border of Montenegro and Serbia by the Yugoslav army. The circumstances of the killings were unclear. The Yugoslav army asserted that "it had been returning fire at Kosovo Liberation Army guerrillas," while refugees stated that "soldiers had opened fire on a column of ethnic Albanians who had fled Kosovo." Montenegro, Serbia's junior partner in the Yugoslav federation, was at political odds with Serbia: it refused to back Slobodan Milosevic, pursued Western-oriented policies, and allowed ethnic Albanian refugees into its territory. The Yugoslav army, however, remained loyal to Milosevic.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces attacked the town of Vucitrn on 02 May 1999. They forced the Kosovo Albanian residents to exit the town and join a large convoy of 20,000 some Kosovo Albanians. The troops burnt a number of homes, shops, and religious sites belonging to the Kosovo Albanians and killed about 104 persons. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: Indonesia's military on Thursday said it would send riot police into the restive province of Aceh where earlier this week security forces massacred unarmed protesters. At least 34 people were killed in Aceh on Monday when security forces fired into a crowd of protesters demonstrating against earlier military atrocities. The military says it fired in self-defence, but witnesses and human rights groups said it came without warning and that protesters were unarmed. "All of us from the military and police regret that there were victims from the army, the police and civilians," Wiranto said. He added that a police sergeant had been shot on Wednesday, and one local newspaper said he had been killed. The resource-rich and staunchly Islamic region on the northern tip of Sumatra has a long tradition of battling Jakarta's rule.

A large number of refugee males of military age were reportedly killed by Serb forces as they attempted to escape to Albania. Reports indicated that Serb forces stopped groups of refugees along the road between Studime and Vushtri and separated men of military age from women, children, and older men before shooting or stabbing the selected men to death. Estimates of the number of victims ranged from at least 50 to possibly hundreds. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians; it was also related to an on-going ethnic/civil conflict.

On 12 May 1999, Reuters reported that "At least 29 people were killed and 16 wounded on Tuesday in a government bombing raid on two towns in the rebel-held east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo... The surprise raid was the latest incident in a regional war in Congo involving at least seven countries that started last August when rebels in the east backed by Rwanda and Uganda took up arms against President Laurent Kabila. Rebel commander Bob Ngoy said a Russian-built Antonov cargo plane dropped bombs in two residential districts of Goma, the rebel headquarters on Congo's eastern border with Rwanda."  An update reported that "The Democratic Republic of the Congo said on Wednesday its forces had bombed targets in the rebel-held east of the country but denied attacking civilians... 'We bombed military targets, including the (rebel) radio. No civilians were hit,' deputy armed forces chief, Commandant Francois Olenga, told Reuters in the capital Kinshasa. 'It was a warning that we are hardening our position. We want to cut the supply lines of the enemy,' Olenga added. Congolese rebels on Wednesday accused the government of targeting civilians in two surprise air raids which they say killed at least 32 people and wounded 43." 

 A third report said casualties had climbed to 51 dead, 47 injured.

NATO sources stated that the 100 deaths reported in the village of Korisa might have been perpetrated by the Yugoslav Army, which it claimed had been "shelling targets in the area." This contradicted the Serb account of the event, which claimed NATO bombs had caused the deaths.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces attacked the village of Stagovo on 21 May 1999, killing at least 12 persons. Most of the homes in the village were also burnt and looted in the attack. This incident was part of a campaign of violence in the Kacanik area and was also part of a larger campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces entered the Dubrava prison on 22 May 1999 and ordered all of the prisoners to line-up in a field. The forces then opened fire on the prisoners. Many died and others were injured. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces attacked the Dubrava prison, assailing drains, sewers, and buildings with grenades and bullets. These actions killed about 50 prisoners and wounded an unspecified number of others. This attack, on 23 May 1999, followed another attack by Serb forces on the previous day. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Perp.State.Military: forces of the Former Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and Serbia
Description: Serb forces surrounded the village of Dubrava on 25 May 1999 and forced all of the inhabitants to leave. The troops later separated the villagers by sex and killed 4 men. Four persons from a single family were also killed as they tried to escape. This incident was part of a campaign of violence in the Kacanik area and was also part of a larger campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians. NATO forces ultimately became involved in the conflict, initiating an aerial bombing campaign in an effort to halt the conflict.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Second Indictment of Slobodan Milosevic et al. 22 Oct 2001.

Description: Police said the 11 were killed in the Carrefour Feuilles shantytown in a shootout with gang members.  Relatives and witnesses say, however, that many of the dead had nothing to do with any gang and the government has promised to investigate the killings.
Citation:
Reuters News 29 May 1999 lba0000020010907dv5t07env
Reuters News 01 June 1999 lba0000020010907dv6107ceu
Comments: Perps identified as Haitian police.  Victims are disputed.  Initial report indicated they were gang members, armed combatants.  Later reports indicate they may have been noncombatant bystanders.  Firearm usage indicated.  According to later report police were chasing 3 alleged criminals which were beaten and killed after being apprehended - the other eight deaths were bystanders.  Coded as both unarmed combatants and unclear.  Intent coded as unclear

Description: An official of the opposition alliance in Afghanistan said 12 members of a family were killed in Taloqan during an air strike by the Taliban.  The attack razed the family's house to the ground and injured two people in an adjacent building.  Taliban jets also carried out air raids over Jabal-us-Seraj but there were no immediate reports about any casualties there.
Indian troops fired mortar bombs across the military control line in Kashmir on Sunday, killing at least 12 people on the Pakistani side of the disputed region, local police said.

Serb troops killed and tortured 180 civilians in the Kosovo region of Drenica during the end of April or beginning of May 1999. Of the victims, 30 were identified as Kosovo Albanians. This incident was part of a campaign of violence organized by Serb forces, led by Slobodan Milosevic, against Kosovo Albanians; it was also related to an on-going ethnic/civil conflict.
Up to 10 schoolchildren were killed by Indian mortar bombs while around 30 Indian troops died in Pakistani retaliatory fire in the disputed Kashmir region on Tuesday, Pakistani officials said.
Comments: India on Tuesday denied Islamabad's claim it had killed schoolchildren in an attack on Pakistan-ruled Kashmir.

Description: On 4 June 1999, Reuters reported that "At least 24 people were killed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo when a Sudanese plane bombed a small town in the north of the country... Rebel chief Jean-Pierre Bemba told Reuters a Sudanese Antonov cargo plane on Wednesday dropped six bombs on Binga, about 1,200 km (746 miles) northeast of the capital Kinshasa.  'This town has been bombed by Sudanese aircraft. They killed 24 civilians and destroyed 14 houses,' Bemba said by satellite phone from northern Congo, adding 19 were wounded in the raid."
Five civilians died in Indonesia's restive province of Aceh when anti-riot police opened fire after mistaking the sound of a burst tyre for gunfire from separatist rebels, witnesses said on Sunday.
Comments: The police were especially jumpy after an attack on a military truck the week before had injured 7 soldiers.

Description: Reuters News reported on 7/12/1999 that "the opposition National Council of Resistance in Iran said many demonstrators had been killed by security forces during protests in Tehran". Exact death tolls were not stated, but reportedly, "A large number of demonstrators were shot and killed and hundreds were wounded" and four people were named specifically. Reportedly, "detainees were hoarded on scores of buses and minibuses of the state security forces and taken to prison." A later report claims at least 30 killed in Tehran and "dozens more dead in other cities."
Secondary.Source: Opposition group: National Council of Resistance
Comments: Initially, the numbers of dead and wounded were not explicit quantities and only four dead were named. However, as the report quotes "a large numbershot and killed," the incident is coded and ranges are given for dead and wounded. An updated report lists at least 30 dead; this is the number coded.

District: Khoi Ratta, Nakial, Neelam valley, Batalik
Description: Heavy Indian shelling across a military control line in Kashmir killed at least 15 civilians on the Pakistani side of the disputed region on Friday and Saturday, Pakistani officials said.

On 4 August 1999, Reuters reported that "At least 518 people were killed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo on Wednesday when Sudanese planes launched an air raid on two fishing villages in the north of the country... Jean-Pierre Bemba, a millionaire businessman who heads the Ugandan-backed Congolese Liberation Movement (MLC), said one Russian-built Sudanese Antonov plane dropped 18 bombs on Makanza and Bogbonga, two small towns on the Congo river about 800 km (500 miles) northeast of the capital Kinshasa... 'Kabila bombed us this morning at 10 o'clock with Sudanese Antonovs. These bombs killed 384 civilians and 134 soldiers,' Bemba told Reuters in the Rwandan capital Kigali by satellite phone from Gbadolite, his base in the north."
At least 20 people have been killed in new unrest in Indonesia's bloodied Aceh province, including 14 civilians blasted to death by grenades, rebels and human rights groups said on Monday.
Comments: apparently the soldiers believed the woodcutters to be members of a rebel group, when in fact they were just woodcutters.

Description: Indonesian soldiers opened fire on a church in the ravaged island of Ambon killing 24 people, the priest who buried most of the dead told Reuters on Thursday.
Comments: 50 Christians had taken shelter in the church when troops opened fire.  It is unclear why the troops targeted this church.  Fighting between Moslem and Christian groups have ravaged the island of Ambon.

Description:
On 14 August 1999, Reuters reported that "Burundian villagers on Saturday accused the Tutsi-dominated army of killing 74 Hutu civilians on Thursday in a crackdown which followed fierce fighting with Hutu rebels near the capital Bujumbura.  The accusations follow similar reports of an army massacre of 147 civilians in a nearby village on Tuesday night, although the army blamed those killings on the rebels."
...
"A senior local government official told Reuters he knew of 17 civilians who had been killed on Thursday but said it was "difficult to know" which side had carried out the massacre. 'There is confusion because the rebels have uniforms like our soldiers, they are Burundian also...so the population can confuse them with our soldiers. That is why they accuse the army,' said Major Balthazar Ntamahungiro, governor of the province of Bujumbura Rurale, which rings the capital. But villagers said they were in no doubt who was responsible for the deaths, which they said occurred at an army roadblock near the small village of Rusaka, in Ruziba district, around 15 km (nine miles) south of Bujumbura."
Comments: Coded based on Villager's witness accounts over army statements

Description: On 19 August 1999, Reuters reported that "...at least 200 people were killed in three days of fighting between Rwandan and Ugandan troops in Kisangani, the Democratic Republic of the Congo's third largest city. Traditionally firm allies, Rwanda and Uganda turned their guns on each other on Saturday in a battle for supremacy in the diamond-rich city. The two sides fought street-to-street with rifles, machine guns and artillery, overrunning residential areas, destroying buildings and forcing civilians to hide in their homes and basements, witnesses said. 'The minimum casualty figure is 200,' said Ugandan-backed rebel leader Ernest Wamba dia Wamba by satellite phone from Kisangani. 'It's mostly soldiers but a good many are civilians. Some families were killed inside their houses.' "
Comments: Decided to code an entry based on report that "many" civilians were among casualties.

Description: Russian warplanes bombed several villages in the breakaway region of Chechnya.  The Russian air force carried out attacks against the villages in the Nozhay-Yurt district, killing 25 and wounding 40 people.  A Russian Defence Ministry spokesman said he had no information about such an attack.  Russian troops are involved in attempts to crush guerrilla resistance in the Chechen region.

Reuters News reported on 9/10/1999 that "at least eight civilians were shot dead by security personnel in Indonesia's troubled eastern island of Ambon". Police reportedly opened fire on protesters trying to burn several government buildings in the island's capital. "More than 60 protesters were reported to have been severely wounded...the death toll was expected to rise."
Comments: It is unclear if the victims were noncombatants, and the incident is coded for this ambiguity.

Description: Guinea on Saturday accused Liberian army soldiers of crossing over their border and killing 28 villagers, but Liberian President Charles Taylor described the allegations as nonsense. Alikaly Fofana, governor of the Nzerekore region in southern Guinea, said the Liberian soldiers attacked three villages in the area around Macenta with guns and machetes on Friday and killed 28 people, including two who were burned alive. "We have no doubt that these were Liberian army soldiers," he told state radio, adding that one of the attackers had been captured by Guinean troops and the rest forced back across the border. "I describe the accusation as complete nonsense," Taylor told reporters on his return from an Organisation of African Unity summit in Libya.  Liberian Information Minister Joe Mulbah also rejected the Guinean charges, telling the BBC's Focus on Africa radio programme that no Liberian soldiers were missing.

A representative of Chechen President Aslan Maskhadov said that 298 Chechens, mainly women and children, had been killed in two weeks of Russian bombardments.  Thousands of villagers had been forced to leave their homes as well.

At least 50 youths were feared killed by Nigerian security forces in the oil-producing Niger Delta, the state-owned Daily Times said on Monday.  Neither local officials, security forces, nor independent witnesses were immediately available for comment.  The newspaper said the youths from the Ijaw Egbesu cult were shot dead in a creek while being taken to prison from the Bayelsa state capital Yenagoa following riots there last week in which four soldiers were reported to have been killed.  Nigerian police have denied the report.
Comments: The combatant status of the youths is not addressed in the report.

Description: The Sri Lankan air force attacked what it states were rebel camps in the northeast.  The Tiger rebels claim that Tamil civilian refugees were targeted and 22 of them were killed in the attack.  The Red Cross confirmed the attack saying its officials said 21 civilians had been killed.

Reuters News reported on 9/25/1999 that civilians had been killed in riots sparked by a new security law and random violence across Indonesia. Reuters reports that "five protesters and a policeman were killed" but describes information about 7 civilian deaths. "Two people were killed...in Jakarta just as the riots were petering out after the law's suspension. Witnesses told newspapers a convoy of 10 troop carriers, escorted by motorcycles, had approached the gates of a hospital and fired shots randomly, killing two and wounding dozens." "On Friday, three protesters were shot dead, apparently by sniper fire, and a policeman was run over and killed. At least 100 people were injured in the violence." "In the remote, restive province of Irian Jaya...two people were shot dead during a riot, allegedly killed by police on Friday".
Nine church workers including two nuns and a priest have been shot dead by Indonesian troops in the eastern part of East Timor, Bishop Basilio do Nascimento told Portuguese television on Monday.
Comments: The victims were 9 church workers including one Indonesian journalist.

Description: Police in violence torn Aceh province have found 15 more bodies dumped in ravines near the site of a recent massacre, bringing the death toll to 71, police sources and residents said on Sunday.
Comments: The military says the victims died in a gunfight between soldiers, police and separatist rebels, but witnesses say they were gunned down after being ordered out of a house.

Description: A Polisario leader on Sunday accused Moroccan security forces of "massacring" people in the disputed Western Sahara, Algerian state-run radio reported. "People are being massacred, repressed and tortured openly and publicly with the United Nations knowledge," Mohamed Khaddar, member of the Polisario Front's leadership, the National Secretariat, was quoted by the radio as saying. It was not immediately possible to confirm the report from Moroccan authorities or independent sources. Polisario said earlier that Moroccan forces had killed or wounded hundreds of people in the territory. In a statement on its website monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation on Saturday, the independence-seeking Polisario called for international pressure on Morocco to force it to "bring to an end the carnage against the civilian population of the occupied Western Saharan territory".  The Algeria-backed Polisario said in the statement that a state of emergency had been in force since Wednesday. Moroccan authorities denied the accusations.
Comments: No independent confirmation was available.

Description: The Chechen president reported that "during the eight months of the current war, civilian deaths are more than 40,000." The current war began on 01 October 1999, "when Moscow poured men and armour into the rebellious province, ostensibly to crush 'bandits' and 'Islamic fundamentalists' based there." An on-going conflict between Russia and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province,  had plagued the area since the break-up of the former Soviet Union. A 1994-96 war ended in Russian defeat and de facto independence for Chechnya.
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding intent in this case. I have coded the perpetrator intent variable as 'no information/unclear/other' as the report did not provide any information regarding intent. I have coded the collateral damage variable as 'collateral damage' as the deaths occurred in the context of a military conflict. In addition to the civilian deaths, 1,500 combatants were reportedly killed during this campaign.

Description: Television pictures obtained by Reuters outside of Nazran showed a charred bus filled with bloody corpses of passengers, apparently killed in an attack.  Reuters got the footage from a photographer in Nazran, Ingushetia who said 11 refugees were killed and 17 wounded but a Chechen official said 41 people had died in the incident.   Prime Minister Putin denied that Russian forces had struck a busload of refugees.  The photographer said the bus was in a convoy of refugees heading from the village of Chevlyonnaya toward the town of Shelkovskaya on Chechnya border with Dagestan.

Although a top Russian general in Moscow denied recent reports of civilian deaths in Chechnya, it appeared the village of Elistanzhi in Chechnya had undergone some kind of attack.  A local prefect said 29 people had been killed and 62 taken to the hospital.  A spokesman for the rebels said 32 died.  Russian officials said all reports of civilian casualties were false and that troops targeted only the rebels.

Two raids by Russian warplanes left 20 dead in the Chechen town of Urus Martan.  The village is full of refugees escaping Grozny.  A Reuters television cameraman filmed six funerals and residents said another five bodies had been taken to Grozny for burial.  On the first day of strikes a Reuters reported counted six dead and around 30 injured.

Russian warplanes bombed the Chechen village of Serzhen-Yurt, killing 27 people and injuring large numbers.  The bombing was a part of the Russian campaign against Islamist rebels in the breakaway region of Chechnya.  A Russian defense ministry spokesman refused to comment on the attack.

A Chechen official said 40 people died when a column of refugees came under fire from Russian aircraft.  40 refugees died and about 100 were wounded when their 20-car convoy came under fire near the village of Shaami-Yurt, west of Grozny.  The refugees were returning to Chechnya after finding the border closed with the adjoining region of Ingushetia.  The Russian military denied its forces had attacked a convoy of refugees and said warplanes had attacked a column of trucks carrying Chechen fighters.

Perp.State.Other: man paid by India's Research and Analysis Wing
Description: Pakistan police said on Monday they had arrested a man who confessed to being an Indian agent and setting off a bomb that killed nine people and wounded 15 in Pakistan-ruled Kashmir.
Comments: The man who confessed to the bombing said that India's Research and Analysis Wing had promised to pay him money for setting off bombs.

Description: The BBC quoted villagers as saying that Russian troops had killed 41 civilians in a rampage through a village near Grozny, Alkhan-Yurt.  Russia strongly denied the report that troops were fighting peaceful populations.  Several residents gave similar accounts of the killings, although the BBC admitted it had seen no physical evidence.  Local witnesses said that soldiers rampaged through the village stealing and killing people, even throwing grenades into cellars knowing that civilians were sheltering there.  A local official said he and his bodyguards had detained the Russian colonel and his deputy whose men had carried out the attacks and handed them over to Russian authorities. Russian prosecutors say there is no evidence soldiers killed civilians and the victims were probably murdered by Moslem rebels hoping to pin the blame on Moscow.  The Russian prosecutor said the villagers were killed when fighting between the army and the rebels was long over and federal troops were no longer in the area.

The Amnesty International published a report in which it accused the Burundian military of massacring at least 43 people--including women and children--in the Kabezi commune in Bujumbura Rural province. Burundian army did not respond to the charges.
A total of 19 ethnic Albanians were "gunned down" in Podujevo, Kosovo by Serb forces in 1999. Two men were later charged with war crimes for the attack.

Seven villagers were killed and an unspecified number were injured by police gunfire at a cultural event in the village of Thaku. The deaths occurred after "a security patrol intervened" at the event, which was "reportedly organized by the radical Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist). The shooting started as police tried to arrest the Maoists, who were waging a violent campaign to topple the constitutional monarchy established then years ago [in Nepal]." This incident was related to the on-going conflict between Maoist rebels and government forces in Nepal; an armed conflict began in 1996 when the Maoists began a people's war against the government.
Comments: There is some ambiguity about intent in this case. Report described the event as follows: "Nine people including two suspected communist guerrillas have died after police opened fire in a crowd in the west of the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal." Firing live ammunition into a crowd, according to codebook definitions, is a situation where 'intent apparent but not stated' should be coded. However, the report also describes the event as having occurred in the context of a police action. To address this, I have coded the perpetrator event variable as 'intent apparent but not stated' and the collateral damage variable as 'collateral damage.' In addition to the 7 villager deaths I have coded in the death count, two people identified as "suspected communist guerrillas" were also killed. I have excluded these combatant deaths from the coded count.

Description: Residents of the village of Bugama accused the Tutsi-led Burundian army of killing 37 Hutu civilians in the village; the army denied the charges.
Comments: I code the deaths as contested since the army denied charges by the residents/witnesses.

Description: A large number of civilians were reported to have been killed by Russian forces in the Chechen village of Katyr-Yurt. The highest reported death toll was 363 villagers and refugees killed. The deaths occurred when "the Russians bombed the village and attacked a convoy of refugees fleeing in cars flying white flags." The entire village was reportedly decimated by the Russian attack. Russian officials denied that its forces had been involved in systematic abuses and that mass graves had been found in Katyr-Yurt. This incident was related to an on-going, militarized conflict between Russian forces and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province. A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.

"Russian helicopter gunships and artillery pounded Chechen villages near Grozny Saturday in a bid to prevent rebels retreating from the fallen capital from reaching mountain strongholds to the south." During this campaign, which followed Russian forces' capture of the Chechen capital Grozny, "many civilians were killed." Russian forces were involved in an on-going, militarized conflict with Chechen rebels, who sought independence from Russia. This event happened during a second war, which began in October 1999, over the province; the first 1994-96 war ended in Russian defeat and de facto independence for Chechnya.
Comments: Report did not specify any estimates of how many civilians might have died or been injured in the offensive. I have coded the offensive as a campaign because it occurred in a number of localities on the same day.

Description: Human Rights Watch asserted that 62 Grozny civilians had been killed by Russian troops in the Aldi district of the Chechen capital. The killings appeared to have occurred when civilians returned to the Chechen capital Grozny after Chechen rebels retreated from the city and fighting between rebels and the Russian military had died down. Russian troops were also reported to have demanded money in exchange for sparing civilians' lives, looted and burned down civilian homes, and raped at least two women. Medicins du Monde also documented the event. Moscow, however, denied that its forces had "carried out systematic abuses." This incident was related to an on-going, militarized conflict between Russian forces and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province. A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.
Secondary.Source: Human Rights Watch, Medicins du Monde
Citation: Reuters 06 Feb 00 lba0000020010821dw260ay2n; Agence France-Presse 23 Feb 00 afpr000020010803dw2n00s3t; Reuters 23 Feb 00 lba0000020010821dw2n06mt9

Description: Sudanese army carried out aerial bombings against a school in the Nuba Mountain region in south Sudan, killing 14 students--most of them first graders--and injuring 17 others. Reuters reports the reaction of the US Secretary of State against the Sudanese bombing of civilian areas, while the Sudanese government responds by saying the school was a "legitimate target" as it was located in territories contested by the government and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLA).
Comments: Because the Sudanese government is reported as saying the school was a "legitimate target", I code the killings as intentional (and asserted) and as approved by the perpetrator.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters opposed to the re-election of an incumbent, whom they accused of "vote-buying and bribery"
Description: The daily Kayahan said police fired at crowds of demonstrators protesting against alleged ballot rigging in southwestern Iran.  After an angry crowd set fire to police cars in the town of Shush, police fired into the crowds.  Five people, including a child, died in the clash with police. The protesters then attacked state buildings and staged demonstrations. The official IRNA earlier reported that 15 people had been injured in clashes in Shush.  It said protesters were angry about the re-election of the incumbent, whom they accused of "vote-buying and bribery".
Comments: It's unclear whether the protesters that were killed were armed or were in any way engaged in violent activity.

Description: On Feb 22, 2000, Reuters reported that, "India said on Tuesday five civilians had been killed by Pakistani artillery fire across the disputed border in the restive northern state of Jammu and Kashmir. 'In yet another shameless display of insensitivity to the lives of innocent people of Jammu and Kashmir, Pakistan army carried out heavy shelling in Tangdar yesterday (Monday),' a defence statement said. 'Approximately 500 shells of artillery and mortar were fired by Pak troops killing five innocent civilians and injuring six. Four civilian houses and seven shops were badly damaged in the firing,' it added."   There was no Pakistani response given in the article.
Comments: India claims the deaths were civilians, and there is no evidence presented to confirm or deny the truth of their claim.  No Pakistani response is presented in the article, though if it had been they may have contested the deaths.

Description: Villagers accused the Burundian army of killing 72 Hutu civilians--mostly schoolchildren between 12 and 14 years old--on Rusunu and Rubana hills of Rutana province; the army denied the charges.
Comments: I code the deaths as contested since the army denied charges by the residents/witnesses.

Description: On Feb 25, 2000, Reuters reported that India was denying Pakistani claims that its commandos crossed the border in Kashmir and massacred 12 Pakistani civilians, including women.  India claims only to have retaliated in kind for previous Pakistani cross-border shelling.  Pakistan claims the deaths of 12 civilians, and calls it a "blatant act of terrorism" by the Indians.
Comments: Coded event as Rumor/Allegation because report centers not on events (of which there were no accounts), but on India's denial of Pakistan's claim that event occurred. India claims only to have retaliated with shelling, in response to Pakistani shelling previously.

Description: Turkish security forces killed 6 Kurdish rebels and lost three soldiers.  They clashed with PKK rebels on Gabar mountain in the Sirnak Province.
Comments: No Comments

Victim.Identity.Political: People protesting against the earlier killing of five people by Indian security forces at Pathribal
Description: At least seven people were killed and six injured in Indian-controlled Kashmir when police opened fire on stone-throwing demonstrators. The demonstrators were demanding the bodies of five Moslem youths who they said were innocent victims of an encounter with security forces following the massacre of 35 Sikhs.  Indian security officials said the five were separatist militants who had been involved in the killing, which came on the eve of U.S. President Bill Clinton's visit to India.  The government imposed an indefinite curfew in the area as a precautionary measure... Seven protesters were killed and dozens wounded when police opened fire to disperse a 2,000-strong crowd at Barkpora village. They had been protesting against the earlier killing of five people by Indian security forces at Pathribal. Security forces had said the five belonged to the Pakistan-based Lashkar-e-Taiba militant group involved in the March massacre of 35 Sikhs in the remote mountain village of Chitisingpora. Later in the year, seven Indian policemen were indicted for firing at the demonstrators.
Comments: It's unclear whether the protesters that were killed were armed or were in any way engaged in violent activity.

Description: During a demonstration in Banjul, police arrested and killed students as they tried to march through the capital.  The students were protesting the alleged torture of a high school student by security force members and the reported rape of a 13-year-old girl by a police officer. Police used live ammunition to restore order, killing at least 12 people and sending many more to the hospital to be treated for injuries. The government blamed student leaders for the rioting and ordered the immediate closure of all schools until further notice. Among the dead was an International Committee of the Red Cross volunteer and journalist with the private Sud FM radio station who was hit by a stray bullet.
Comments: It's unclear whether the protesters that were killed were armed or were in any way engaged in violent activity.

Locality: villages of Duut and Weriang in the town of Malakal
Description: Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) accuses the Sudanese government of using planes to attack civilian targets in the villages of Duut and Weriang in the town of Malakal on the Sobat River; at least 13 people were reportedly killed.
Comments: AFP reports SPLA's accusation--that the Sudanese government bombed and killed civilians--as an uncontested and unquestioned incident, not as a rumor.

Description: The DRC government said in a statement, "the clashes with heavy weapons between Rwandan and Ugandan troops on Friday ... once again left several dozen people dead and hundreds of wounded in the Congolese civilian population." The clashes took place in the city of Kisangani, and a UN source reported the casualty toll as 15 dead and 50 wounded.
Comments: Although the casualties are not explicitly specified as collateral damage, the report says that the civilian casualties occurred in the midst of fighting between Rwandan and Ugandan troops, hence I assume that the intention of the armed forces was not to kill Congolese civilians but each other so I code the civilian casualties as collateral damage. Although the UN source reports an exact number of casualties, the government reports the dead as "several dozen"; to capture this ambiguity, I code the count as range reported.

Description: Turkish border guards killed 9 Afghans and injured 5 trying to enter Turkey from Iran. Police opened fire when a group of Afghanis in the border region ignored an order to stop.
Comments: No Comments

Description: Eritrean troops killed 77 civilians in Zala Anbesa and Irob zones in the central front of the just-ended border war with Ethiopia, local officials said Wednesday, without saying when the killings occurred.
Comments: No independent confirmation of the report was possible.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters opposed to the ruling Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front
Description: Ethiopians voted in general elections that reportedly turned deadly, with security forces allegedly opening fire on protesters. Several hours after the polls closed, an opposition party leader said that government forces killed seven people in Hadiya zone. He said five people died when security forces threw a grenade into a protesting crowd. Two more were killed when police opened fire on another crowd. Authorities could not be reached to confirm the report.

An Afghan civilian, employed as a U.N. aid worker, and six of his children died in an "indiscriminate aerial bombardment" that fell on his home in the town of Taloqan. The bombardment was carried out by the ruling Taleban. The Takhar province, which was under control of "the northern opposition alliance, had frequently been bombed by the national government during an on-going conflict for control of the country."
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding intent in this case. I have coded the perpetrator intent variable as 'intent apparent but not stated' as indiscriminately bombing a city is an act which fits the codebook definition of an action undertaken "which a reasonable person would assume were intended to cause deaths." (Also, as there was no indication that the Taleban had been targeting legitimate military targets.) I have coded the collateral damage variable as 'collateral damage' as the deaths occurred in the context of a military action.

Description: ICRC estimates that at least 619 civilians and 141 soldiers were killed during the week of clashes, the International Committee of the Red Cross statement said, adding that a further 1,700 people were wounded.
Secondary.Source: International Committee of the Red Cross
Comments: ICRC and local Red Cross staff have nearly finished collecting and burying dead bodies, which were scattered across the city and represented a serious health risk, the statement said.

Description: Dominican army officers fired on a truckload of Haitians trying to cross the border illegally, causing the truck to flip over and killing seven people, according to police and news reports
Citation:
Associated Press Newswires 18 June 2000 aprs000020010803dw6i0cql5 
Agence France-Presse 20 June 2000 afpr000020010803dw6k02iui 
Reuters 20 June 2000 lba0000020010820dw6k0389t
Comments: Dominican military identified as perps.  Victims were Haitians killed either from gunfire or when truck flipped as a result of gunfire - noncombatants, NOT collateral.  AFP report indicates one of dead was Dominican and that pursuit of vehicle was due to suspected (but incorrect) drug trafficking.  Reuters report indicates 14 injured.

Description: "Six civilians were killed and others were wounded Friday in the Chechen capital Grozny during a gun battle between rebels and Russian troops." This incident was related to an on-going, militarized conflict between Russian forces and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province. A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding intent in this case. I have coded the perpetrator intent variable as 'no information/unclear/other' as the report did not mention any details regarding intent. I have coded the collateral damage variable as 'collateral damage' as the deaths occurred in the context of a military operation. I have coded the perpetrator identity variable as BOTH 'State Perpetrator: Russian military' and 'Non-state, internal, no state sanction: Chechen rebels' because the report did not specify whose bullets in the gun battle had killed the civilians.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters calling for the results of municipal and local elections
Description: At least five people were killed in Guinea in protests by opposition supporters over delays in the announcement of results from weekend municipal and local elections.  Sources in the town of Mamou in the Fouta Djallon highlands, where the opposition had been confident of victory after Sunday's poll, said three opposition supporters were killed on Tuesday when security forces opened fire there as protesters went on a rampage.  The sources said that the protesters accused the authorities of delaying results to rig them in favor of President Lansana Conte's ruling Party for Unity and Progress  Opposition sources in the town of Fria said that two people had been killed in post-election clashes there. Political sources said that troops had since been sent to Mamou to restore order.

Thousands of refugees fleeing fighting in Guinea have reported random murders, rapes, torture and other widespread rights abuses by Guinean civilians and the military.  Survivors recounted stories of mass detentions, abductions, disappearances of friends and beatings.
Comments: About 150,000 refugees are trapped in Guinea in intensified fighting between Guinean, Liberian and Sierra Leonean forces. Some 55,000 refugees have fled to Sierra Leone since September.

Description: Villagers in the community of Evwreni allege that about 200 policemen in six trucks drove into the community and opened fire, killing 25 people.  Police and witnesses, however, claim that they were attacked by youths and responded with violence, killing some villagers.  Seven policemen died in the fracas.  Local authorities say the Evwreni unrest is rooted in struggle for chieftaincy and is unrelated to a campaign by local communities demanding a greater share of Nigeria's oil wealth.
Comments: This is hotly contested event and it is impossible to ascertain who initiated the incident.

Description: The administration and the military came to our village two weeks ago and said everybody must leave their houses and go to the regroupment camp, one villager told Reuters.  "Those who were killed had refused to go with us. When we returned, we found them dead. Witnesses said the army came and started shooting at them."

Some 200 Falun gong marched to the Central Government Liaison Office in central Hong Kong to protest the killing of a fiftieth Falun gong member.  A spokeswoman for the group also stated that she had a report that Beijing authorities were intending to intensify their persecution of Falun gong members and had even planned to execute more.  The report also stated that 50 million Yuan had been set aside by the government to build more detention centres to put Falun gong members in.
Comments: A human rights group in Hong Kong reported that there had been 24 deaths of the Falungong in July, but did not say when the campaign against the Falungong had begun.

Description: Sudanese government warplanes have bombed two rebel-held towns in the south of the country, killing at least eight civilians and narrowly missing a U.N. relief plane, rebels and aid officials said on Tuesday

A school group got caught in the cross-fire of fighting between Marxist rebels and the army in a war-torn corner of Colombia on Tuesday, leaving four children dead and seven injured, a medical official said.
Citation:
Reuters News 15 August 2000 lba0000020010821dw8f0bdki
Associated Press Newswires 16 August 2000 aprs000020010803dw8g0gthm
Reuters News 16 August 2000 lba0000020010821dw8g0bes0
Agence France-Presse 19 August 2000 afpr000020010803dw8j03bwg
Comments: Initial reports indicated only four killed - later updated to seven.  Perp identified as army.  Govt. claims that the children were caught in cross-fire between themselves and ELN unit - coded as collateral.  Firearms indicated.  Army officer accused ELN of using the children as "human shields."  AP indicates 6 children killed and four wounded.  AP also indicates that eye witnesses indicate no ELN presence, that the military deliberately shot the group - collateral damage claim is therefore speculative.  Later Reuters report indicates five injured and echoes AP reports of eyewitness claims of no rebel presence.  AFP report indicates army admitting that attack may have been in error.

Description: Seven people were killed when Taleban forces dropped bombs in the center of Taloqan, the provincial capital of Takhar. The Takhar province had been the site of several weeks of battles between the northern opposition, which controlled the province, and the ruling Taleban. The two sides had been involved in an on-going conflict for control of Afghanistan.

Turkish warplanes bombed northern Iraq killing 38 civilians and wounding 11.The Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP) said the jets attacked an area inside Iraq close to the borders of Turkey and Iran where Turkish Kurd guerrillas loyal to captured rebel chief Abdullah Ocalan have a number of bases.
Comments: Intent of the warplanes were to kill Iraqi Kurds, however it is unclear whether only Iraqi Kurds were killed because the article simply says "Iraqi civilians."

Description: Although flatly denied by army officials, the villagers said they initially fled an army sweep through the area but were then told to return home by local authorities, who assured them it was safe.  When they approached their homes in Nyambeho, on a hillside northeast of Bujumbura, they came under fire from army troops.
On 27 August 2000, Reuters reported that Pakistani media sources claimed six dead from cross-border shelling in Kashmir.  The report said five of the victims were women.
Comments: Coded as rumor/allegation because report presents a Pakistani media report, but does not substantiate or verify the claim, and even includes (emphasis added):  "Arch-rivals India and Pakistan often accuse each other of cross-border firing in the region. "

Description: Some 40 people, including at least 10 Guinean soldiers, were killed during an attack by armed men in southern Guinea, a source close to the Guinean government said.  The attack took place in the village of Massadou, not far from the border with Liberia, and was carried out by a group in blue uniforms suspected of having come from Liberia.
Comments: Guinea and Liberia have been trading accusations that each is trying to destabilize the other's regime for several months.

Description: Iranian police killed 11 Afghans bandits suspected in participating in drug-trafficking between the Afghan-Iranian border.
Comments: Article was brief and withheld  many specifics.

Description: At least 10 civilians have been killed during a military assault on Muslim kidnappers in the southern Philippine island of Jolo, a survivor fleeing the fighting said Wednesday.
Comments: An eyewitness said that 10 civilians had been killed during the assault, however did not say whether they were killed by the kidnappers or the military.  The official death count by the Philippine government is 4 civilians.

Description:
On 20 September 2000, Agence France-Presse reported that "Seven civilians were killed when Indian troops shelled villages on the Pakistani side of disputed Kashmir on Wednesday, state-run television said. 

Another 11 villagers were injured in the shelling in Neelum valley along the Line of Control, the unofficial border between Pakistani and Indian-controlled parts of Kashmir, it said."
Comments: Coded as rumor/allegation because state run television only source.

Description: Guinean military forces are attacking Sierra Leonean territory with impunity, killing and injuring helpless civilians, according to Amnest International.  Hostilities between Guinea and Sierra Leone began in September 2000 and have intensified recently.  Amnesty said the attacks, intended to target the RUF bases, were staged without care or accuracy.  Witnesses confirmed that "dozens of innocent Sierra Leonean had either died or been wounded in the northeastern district of Kambia by Guinean military shelling.
Eight Palestinians were shot dead by Israeli forces across the West Band and Gaza strip during what Muslim militants called the "Day of Rage"
Comments: I must mention that this article included data about other Israeli-Palestinian killings, but I only coded for the "Day of Rage" killings across the West Bank and Gaza strip.

Description: Ivory Coast has sharply raised the official death toll from the bloodshed that followed last years presidential election, saying 303 people were killed and 1546 injured.  The toll covers the period from the October election to a failed coup attempt in January.  65 people "disappeared" in the violence.  The worst violence took place in the immediate aftermath of the presidential poll won by Gbagbo.  Gbagbo's loyalists took to the streets after army ruler Robert Guei tried to rig the vote.  A number of protestors were shot by security forces.  More bloodshed followed when Gbagbo's supporters clashed with those of former Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara.

Victim.Identity.Political: Participants in a two-day independence rally
Description: At least 25 people died in violence during the three-day run-up to an independence rally in Indonesia's Aceh province. The victims died over a period of three days, Tuesday to Thursday, as security forces purportedly tried to prevent people traveling to the provincial capital, Banda Aceh. According to an unidentified witness, in one incident a 14-year-old boy was killed when soldiers fired at a mosque packed with thousands of residents in the Tualang Cut area of East Aceh on Thursday. Scores of others were wounded in the shooting, the witness said, adding that troops had stepped on Muslim holy books, the Koran, during the operation. The residents were sheltering in the mosque after police barred them from joining the gathering in Banda Aceh. The head of the East Aceh branch of the pro-independence Information Center for Aceh Referendum condemned the mosque shootings. But Aceh police spokesman Senior Superintendent Kusbini Imbar denied security forces had raided the mosque and shot randomly at residents. In a separate incident on Thursday, security forces shot dead two people who tried to resist their attempts to prevent them from going to the rally, according to a local journalist. Two bodies with gunshot wounds were found in a separate area. In Bireun district, four people were killed and dozens others were injured by troops in a similar incident.  In Banda Aceh a body was found near the Baiturrahman mosque. On Tuesday and Wednesday 16 people were killed province-wide, residents and police said. Military brutality and the perceived exploitation of Aceh's oil and gas reserves by Jakarta has fed the separatist sentiment.
Secondary.Source: local witnesses, local police and local journalists
Comments: The government denied the incident in which security forces supposedly fired upon a mosque and killed a youth but the AFP report doesn't mention any other official denials.  Therefore, it appears as if the government only denies one incident in a three day campaign to prevent potential protesters from reaching the provincial capital.

Description: Sudan's main rebel group said a lone government plane this week bombed a town near the Kenyan border where aid agencies are based, killing seven people.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters celebrating the 12th anniversary of Arafat's symbolic 1988 proclamation of Palestinian independence
Description: Israeli troops killed at least seven Palestinians as violence surged in the West Bank and Gaza on the anniversary of Palestinian President Yasser Arafat's declaration of an independent state. Across the West Bank, hundreds of Palestinian protesters clashed with Israeli forces, at one stage drawing anti-tank missile and heavy machine gun fire at a flashpoint junction outside the Palestinian-ruled city of Ramallah. Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian policeman and an 18-year-old boy in the West Bank town of Tulkarm and eight people were wounded, according to the town's governor and hospital officials. The army said it shot at demonstrators' feet in Tulkarm when stone-throwing endangered soldiers' lives. Tulkarm's governor said the Palestinians were killed at a peaceful Independence Day protest on the outskirts of the town. Israeli troops killed another teenager in violence on the edge of the divided town of Hebron and wounded another protester critically.  In the ancient West Bank town of Jericho, hospital officials said soldiers shot dead a 20-year-old Palestinian man during a gun battle. Hours later, 22-year-old Palestinian Ahmed Said Sha'aban was killed by live rounds in the abdomen and back during clashes in the West Bank town of Jenin. A Gaza hospital said it had received the bodies of two Palestinian men shot by Israeli troops in the Karni area. The army denied firing shots in Karni but said it had a firefight with gunmen near the Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom. Palestinian hospital officials said at least 75 Palestinians were wounded in the clashes.
Secondary.Source: Palestinian government officials and hospital officials
Comments: It's unclear if the victims were armed combatants but it is possible that several of them were engaged in violent clashes when killed. It's also possible that many of the victims were collateral damage and died when caught in clashes between violent Palestinians and Israelis.

Description: A rebel group fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) accused government forces Wednesday of bombing two towns in the southeast of the country, killing eight civilians.

Dan Eiffe, a spokesman for the Norwegian People's Aid (NPA) group which operates in the town, said a high-altitude Antonov plane dropped 14 bombs on Yei at 2:45 p.m. (1145 GMT) on Monday, many of them landing in Yei's central market.

Israeli troops shot dead five Palestinians in West Bank, but the army and Palestinian security officers disagreed whether the men had posed a threat to soldiers. An army statement said Israeli force identified an armed gang of terrorists and opened fire. Palestinian officers said the 4 bled to death because army would not let ambulances through the gates to give aid to the shot individuals.
Comments: In regards to the accuracy of the number of deaths, the article said that 5 people were killed, but it also stated that the Israeli army projected 4 deaths which causes some ambiguity as to how many people were actually killed.

Perp.State.Military: Afghan fighters (either Taleban or northern opposition fighters)
Description: "An unknown number of refugees fleeing fighting in Afghanistan were killed and wounded in overnight shooting in southern Tajikistan." The circumstances of the incident were somewhat unclear, but the report noted that fire had come from Afghan fighters. It was also noted that Taleban militiamen and opposition northern alliance fighters were engaged in an armed conflict for control of the country. The fighters may have belonged to either group, but the report noted that "there was no confirmation that the firing had come from Taleban positions" suggesting the Taleban may be responsible for the incident.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters marching on the house of the new president of the Congolese Rally for Democracy, Adolphe Onusumba
Description: Rwandan soldiers killed 20 villagers in rebel-held territory in the Democratic Republic of Congo, according to press reports, but the rebel president immediately denied the allegation. Kinshasa newspapers published a statement by the Solidarite Sankura group which said the violence broke out during a demonstration earlier this month outside the home of the new president of the Congolese Rally for Democracy, Adolphe Onusumba. Soldidarite Sankura said Rwandan soldiers opened fire on protesters who marched on Onusumba's house at Wembo-Nyama in Kasai-Oriental Province to demonstrate their opposition to his recent appointment. Onusumba, new head of the Rwandan-backed rebel faction, said the reports were "completely false." Onusumba insisted that during a tour of the province he had received a warm welcome from the people. The press reports gave no further details of the incident in Wembo-Nyama.
Secondary.Source: published statement by the Solidarite Sankura group

Perp.State.Military: Chechen rebel members of the Russian OMON paramilitary force
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Chechen rebel members of the Russian OMON paramilitary force
Description: A number of civilians were killed and injured when a car bomb was detonated near a mosque in the Chechen village of Alkhan-Yurt. Local officials placed the casualty count at 22 dead and 52 injured, while a Russian official spokesperson stated that only 16 had died and 20 were injured. Police believed that four men, at least one of whom was a member of the Chechen branch of Russia's OMON paramilitary, had perpetrated the attack. This was taken as an indication that, "the rebels are trying to enter the ranks of the Chechen police." The report connected this attack to an on-going conflict between Russia, which sought to retain control of the Chechen province, and Chechen separatist rebel forces.  A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.
Citation: Agence France Presse 09 Dec 00 afpr000020010803dwc90552z; Agence France Presse 10 Dec 00 afpr000020010803dwca056h9

Description: Chinese paramilitary police fired on Muslim demonstrators protesting the hanging of a pig's head at an east China mosque, killing five and injuring more than 40, according to a human rights group. On the day of the shooting over 300 people from Mengcun county, a Hui-populated area in neighboring Hebei province, traveled to Yangxin, but were stopped before the county seat by 100 paramilitary and regular police.  Fighting erupted between Huis and police joined by Han Chinese bystanders. After firing shots into the air that failed to stop the clash, police fired into the crowd of demonstrators. A police official in Mengcun said he had heard of a protest but that he had no details. A government worker and a police official in Yangxin refused to answer questions or said they did not know.
Secondary.Source: Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy

Description: Palestinians accused the Israeli government of stoking violence in the West Band and Gaza Strip by killing Palestinians in attacks that they call assassinations. Israeli troops say that the killings are the result of provocation, however the Palestinians call the victims civilians.
Comments: Quite unclear concerning the victims in these killings. Israel and Palestine have different perceptions about those being killed by the Israeli army. Palestine is calling the killings "terrorism endorsed by the Israeli government."

Description: Sudanese rebels accused the government on Friday of bombing three villages in the south of the country killing six civilians.
Comments: There was no immediate comment from the government.

Description: Fighters of the ruling Taliban movement may have systematically killed up to 560 civilians following their recapture of the central Afghan city of Yakawlang.  Reports from survivors said the Taliban had rounded up and shot men for three days starting on January 7.  Testimony by one survivor that was provided to Reuters said local Taliban officials told him as he left after the killings that orders for the massacre had come from Kandahar, Taliban headquarters.   The Taliban leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, has denied any massacre took place but banned journalists from visiting the region.  A group of 30 village elders who went to negotiate with the Taliban were instead rounded up and all executed, the reports said.  One report said 150 of the 280 confirmed dead had been identified.  But an Afghan who left after the killing had subsided said the Taliban told him 560 people had been executed.

A member of Senegal's separatist movement denied that 30 of his companions had been killed by Guinea-Bissau troops, saying the victims were defenceless refugees.  Guinea-Bissau president Yalla had said on Monday that his troops, which have been clashing with MFDC rebels in recent weeks, had killed 30 separatists.
Secondary.Source: Spokesman for the Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
Comments: No one disputes that this event did happen; it is disputed whether the victims were rebels engaged in combat or defenceless refugees.

Description: Six civilians were killed and many others injured when Democratic Republic of Congo forces bombed a rebel-held town in Rwanda, Rwandan military officials said on Sunday.
Comments: The Rwandan town was apparently a stronghold of Hutu rebels who frequently cross over to DR Congo and attack.

Perp.State.Police: Ethiopian police occupying part of Somalia
Description: Ethiopian troops occupying a Somalian town opened fire on Somali demonstrators, killing 5.

Guinean jets have in the past few days strafed border towns in Sierra Leone, killing at least 17 people and injuring at least 26.  The town of Yeliboya was bombed on Thursday.  Other witnesses fled the border towns of Kambia and Kamakwe after they, too, were bombed.  Also, the Sierra Leone Boat Owners Association claimed that Guinean security forces are holding 10 Sierra Leone boats loaded with foodstuffs.

Victim.Identity.Political: supporters of the Civic United Front
Description: The CUF says it has confirmed that at least 60 of its supporters died on the islands, and as many as 100 people drowned when boats in which they were fleeing were sunk by police firing from helicopters. Police say 23 people, including a policeman, lost their lives.
Liberia said a Guinean helicopter killed more than 10 people in a raid on the northern town of Foya on Monday.  Liberian Defense Minister Daniel Chea described the incident as an unprovoked attack.
Police opened fire on a demonstration by a government opposition group, killing at least 50.  Government reports, too, indicate that at least 40 were killed, including some police officers

Guinean helicopter gunships bombed a town in northern Sierra Leone Wednesday, killing 16 civilians and injuring 12 others, a Sierra Leonean chief said.  Chief Kandeh Lunseni said two Guinean army gunships flew low over Kamakwei town and dropped five bombs.  The casualties were among thousands of people who had come into the streets to cheer the helicopters in the belief that they belonged to the United Nations UNAMSIL force struggling to keep the peace in the West African country.
Comments: Guinean troops have repeatedly crossed into Sierra Leonean territory in recent weeks chasing armed groups that have been attacking Guinean towns and villages, allegedly from camps across the border.  But this one seems unprovoked to me.

Description: Officials in Kinshasa had announced Thursday that the probe into Kabila's assassination had been extended to include the murders of "several" Lebanese nationals abducted by armed men after the killing.
Comments: 18 Lebanese nationals had been arrested by the Congolese army but some of them succeeded in fleeing.  11 could be confirmed as dead.  The Lebanese were arrested in connection with the assassination of DRC President Laurent Kabila.

Disappearances: 16 of the dead were last seen when Russian forces abducted them
Description: Human Rights Watch urged the UN to investigate a mass grave of 51 bodies found in Dachny, Chechnya.  Of the 19 victims identified, 16 were last seen as Russian federal forces took them into custody.  Russian authorities claim that their investigation proved that federal forces were not involved in the killings roughly around the month of February. The Chechen prosecutor insisted that the identified people were civilians.   The Russian authorities claimed that the grave had been dug by Chechen rebels because some of the victims were wearing foreign-made military uniforms and the time of death varies from 2 to 6 months prior to the discovery of the grave.  In addition, only rebels dig such graves according to the Russian prosecutor.  It's hard to say which side was responsible for the killings and to be sure that all 51 were civilians/noncombatants.
Comments: The victims could have been combatants but the Chechen prosecutor insists they were civilians

Description: Violence linked to government troops and separatist rebels and their supporters in the restive Indonesian province of Aceh killed 72 people in the last 18 days of February, a report said Thursday.  Data issued by the Aceh Forum of Human Rights Concerns (FP-HAM) as cited by the Antara news agency, showed that 65 civilians, four government troopers and three rebels were killed in Aceh in the period of February 10-28.
Comments: Unclear if victims were targeted or collateral (most related reports seem to identify them as not collateral).  Unclear if military or GAM is responsible for the killings.

Description: Soldiers fired upon a crowd of mourners lamenting the death of a man in Indian police custody.  Soldiers claim the mourners were violently protesting, throwing rocks, etc.
Comments: There is dispute regarding the victims' combat status, however, and inquiry was launched by the Indian government, supporting claims of unprovoked violence.

Description: Over 30 civilians, six Guinean soldiers and an unknown number of rebels were killed in attacks by gunmen on Thursday and Friday in the southern Guinean town of Nongoa.  The attack was perpetrated by gunmen who Guinea says are helped by Liberian forces and Sierra Leonean rebels.  Other civilians were wounded, while thousands of refugees and local Guineans had fled their homes during the fighting.
Comments: It is unclear from content and context of the article who the intended targets of the attack were.  It is possible that the civilian deaths were a case of collateral damage, but there was not enough evidence to support that conclusion.

Description: Police shot the seven - all between the ages of 15 and 20 - while searching for the killers of a police officer on March 14, 2001. Police said the youths fired first from a house where they found the gun of the slain officer.  But in a report on the killings two years later, Amnesty said the evidence "overwhelmingly points to the young men having been extra-judicially executed."
Comments: Police killed seven youths.  Claim they were returning fire.  Amnesty International disputes claim and indicates youths were executed.  Intent is therefore unclear.

Description: Human rights workers said the bodies of four villagers who had apparently been shot were found on Saturday in southern Aceh, while seven civilians were killed in eastern Aceh.  Rights activist Nasruddin Badai said the victims were executed by Indonesian security forces after being arrested and taken away.
Comments: Military has not commented.

Description: Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid on Friday cancelled a planned trip to Aceh province, where troops are poised to begin anti-rebel operations.  His decision came as police and residents said troops had shot five civilians and two police were killed near the town Wahid had been scheduled to visit.
Comments: Military did not comment.

Description: Indonesian troops searching for separatist fighters killed seven people when they burned a village on the main road between Aceh province and the rest of Sumatra, rebels claimed Sunday.
Comments: Military did not comment.  Was looking for rebels and ransacked and burned village, killing seven.  Victims not identified as civilians per se, nor as combatants.

Description: On Saturday the RCD said that six civilians were killed and 24 were wounded on April 6, and that soldiers had raped women and torched houses in Kasai and Katanga.
Comments: Members of the rebel Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD) refused to allow a plane carrying 120 UN peacekeepers to land demanding a UN condemnation of alleged ceasefire violations by government troops.

Description: According to witnesses and police, at least five civilians were killed when they got caught in the crossfire during a shootout between Chechen rebels and the Russian military.  But the Interfax news agency and state-run RTR television, citing police, described the attack by a rebel assassination squad.  They said gunmen wearing camouflage clothing shot a deputy head of the village administration, a policeman and three other people.  Four people were hospitalized with wounds.
Primary.Source: Both Associated Press Newswires and Interfax News Agency had different versions of the story
Comments: If the Interfax and RTR story is correct, only four civilians died in the fighting because one of the victims was a police officer, but the story's lead says "five civilians were killed"

Description: A student protest in the capital city of Ethiopia turned violent, with police using "clubs and firing live ammunition" into the crowd of demonstrators.  Police claim demonstrators were violent "hoodlums and lumpen", though it is difficult to say which protesters were actively engaged in violence and destruction.
Comments: As usual, there is some ambiguity about the victims' noncombatant status

Description: Iranian forces stage missile strikes on Iraqi areas, killing six Iraqi civilians and wounding more than 36 others.
Comments: The casualty toll coded here is reported by the official INA agency. While the Iraq-based People's Mujahadeen--Iran's main armed opposition group--give a higher death toll, AFP reports INA's numbers as the correct toll, hence I code INA's casualty toll--even though it is the lower of the two--but report it as contested.

Description: "US rights group Human Rights Watch (HRW) has accused the Ugandan army and a Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) militia group of responsibility for the murder of six Red Cross workers in northeast DRC region of Ituri in April 2001.  'The evidence suggests a conspiracy to kill international aid workers was carried out by local Hema community leaders, some of whom were members of the Union of Congolese Patriots (UPC) and Ugandan soldiers,' HRW said....  But Ugandan army spokesman Major Shaban Bantariza denied the charges, saying it was part of HRW's usual accusations against the Ugandan army."
Comments: The victims of this atrocity were identified as ICRC workers, indicating that they were asserted noncombatants.  The weapons used in this killing were coded as primitive because the bodies of the victims were found with "cuts and spear marks."  The Congolese government denied the accusation.

Description: Algeria has been rocked by an unprecedented popular revolt since April in which at least 55 young demonstrators have been killed by security forces and 1800 others have been injured.
