First confined to Kabylie, home to ethnic minority Berbers, the revolt spread to the east of the country, fanned by deep social frustration among youths over unemployment, housing shortages and perceived widespread corruption. The wave of violence was sparked by the death of a Berber teenager in police custody in Kabylie in April.
Secondary.Source: Berber delegate for Tizi Ouzou province
Citation: Reuters; 13 July 2001; lba0000020010713dx7d07l01       Reuters; 24 June 2001; lba0000020010712dx6o00ulo
Comments: The number injured includes not just protesters who were hurt, but also security forces who were injured.

Description: Government forces are raping, torturing and killing civilians in northern Liberia, Amnesty International said in a report that the government dismissed as "malicious and false."  Interviews with victims suggest Liberian forces have detained, tortured and killed more than 200 civilians suspected of supporting rebel forces since late April.  Amnesty said women and girls have been raped at checkpoints as they fled fighting.

Victim.Identity.Political: blast probably targeted exiled Sunni sect leader Maulvi Mohammad Musa
Targeted.Assassinations: exiled Sunni sect leader from Iran
Description: A bomb went off outside a mosque in Herat, killing at least eight people, including an exiled Iranian Islamic scholar.  The Afghan Islamic Press quoted the Heart province governor as saying the blast also injured some 30 people and sparked anti-Iran protests and violence.  He blamed Iran for the blast and said it was aimed at the exiled Sunni sect leader Maulvi Mohammad Musa.
Secondary.Source: Afghan Islamic Press quoted in Reuters

Description: At least nine civilians including a woman and an eight-year-old boy were killed and two others injured as government troops stepped up sweeps against separatists in the Indonesian province of Aceh, residents and rebels said.
Comments: Military denies raping and killing civilians.

Description: Illegal Mozambican migrant workers have accused South African police of killing 14 people by throwing them from a moving train while they were being repatriated.  The 14 had been among a group of 1600 Mozambicans who arrived Friday at the border town of Ressano Garcia, after South African authorities sent them home by train.  According to witnesses cited by Radio Mozambique, those who died had supposedly bribed South African police to let them remain in South Africa.  The witnesses told state radio that the police had received the money, but then threw them from the train to their deaths.  Mozambican authorities also have accused the South African police of arresting Mozambicans on the street or at workplaces, incarcerating them, and then transporting them home by train in inhumane conditions.
Comments: No outside agency has confirmed the report; Mozambican police officials told AFP they did not yet have any information on the report, and they were not expecting South Africa to repatriate any illegal migrant workers on Friday.

Description: Seven civilians were killed and another five injured when a Macedonian army artillery shell penetrated the basement where a family was hiding. The incident was related to a conflict between ethnic Albanian rebels in Macedonian and the government.
Comments: Report did not address intent, so I have coded the intent variable as unclear. It did mention that the village which was shelled was a major military target, suggesting that the civilian deaths were collateral damage.

Description: Dozens of ethnic Albanian civilians may have been killed during a Macedonian army strike against Albanian separatists in and around Vaksince. The alleged civilian deaths were denied by the government. The allegations were not confirmed nor disconfirmed. The alleged incident took place against the backdrop of fighting between the rebel National Liberation Army, an ethnic Albanian group, and the Macedonian army, a Macedonian Slav dominated group.
Comments: Report stated that there were reports of civilians killed in conjunction with the Macedonian military operation. The Macedonian government denied that civilians had been killed, it did however state that a number of guerillas were killed in the operation. It is unclear whether the government was contesting the civilian status of the persons killed or if was simply denying that any civilians were killed. I have coded the noncombatant status as not contested, as there was no clear indication that this aspect was contested.

Description: Reuters reported on 29 May 2001 that "Six Bangladeshis, including a woman, were shot dead by Indian border guards when they crossed the border into disputed Kashmir from Pakistan, police said on Tuesday. The intruders crossed the international border late on Monday near Hira Nagar in the Kathua district, 85 km (53 miles) south of Jammu, the state's winter capital, when they were spotted by a Border Security Force patrol, a police official said. The patrol fired on the intruders, believing them to separatist guerrillas, after they ignored calls to halt, the police official told Reuters. 'It was only in the morning (Tuesday) that we found out they were Bangladeshis,' he said. The border is often used by job-seeking Bangladeshis to enter Pakistan illegally, authorities say. They are frequently transported from Bangladesh and dropped off near the border by gangs in exchange for money."
Comments: The killing of the civilian Bangladeshis is presented as an accident, but not apology or regrets are expressed.

Description: Tension has been running high in Imphal since Monday's violence when 13 people died after police opened fire on rioters in the Manipur state. The rioters were protesting against a government decision to widen a truce with rebels in the neighbouring state of Nagaland. Manipuris say they fear the widening of the truce with tribal rebels in Nagaland is the first step towards carving a new greater province of Nagaland out of their state. The BJP-led coalition government, which is seeking to end a 50-year insurgency by broadening a ceasefire with Naga rebels, says the territorial integrity of Manipur will not be affected.

Two days of violence in Indonesia's Aceh province has left at least 26 people dead, military officials, rebels and human rights workers said Friday. Human rights activist Muharizal Hasan said soldiers fatally shot five civilians during a raid on a suspected rebel hide-out in Keulibeut village in northern Aceh, also on Wednesday. Police arrested four villagers, including three teachers, during the attack.
Comments: Military did not comment.

Description: Russian troops killed around 10 civilians during a search operation in the Chechen village of Alkhan-Kala.  Dozens were also injured.  Witnesses said almost 100 people were arrested.
Leftist rebels blew a hole in the wall of a high-security prison with dynamite and escaped in an operation that left five inmates dead and 12 others injured, authorities said Sunday.
Comments: Perps were prison guards.  Victims were escaping prisoners.  Although aided by FARC forces outside the prison, the prisoners are presumed to be unarmed combatants.  Firearms indicated.

Description: Jamaican Prime Minister P.J. Patterson said he would establish a commission of inquiry to investigate recent violent clashes between gunmen and security forces in which at least 25 people were killed.
Citation:
Agence France-Presse 09 July 2001 afpr000020010709dx79002gxA
Associated Press Newswires 09 July 2001 aprs000020010709dx7900yvr
Reuters News 16 July 2001 lba0000020010716dx7g00qkk
Reuters News 26 July 2001 lba0000020010726dx7q00zz6
Comments: Some reports don't refer to dead as civilians.  Reuters (lba0000020010716dx7g00qkk) is first to do so.  Perps identified as Jamaican police.  Victims alternatively identified as civilians and gunmen.  Coded as "unclear."  Deaths reported as "at least 25."  Govt. investigating police claim that they were fired upon.  No single incidents reported but fighting continued from July 7.  Indications in later story indicate that police killings may have been prompted by desire to "stir unrest ahead of national elections."

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: random, perhaps suspected involvement with Chechen rebels
Kidnappings: arrested 117 people, five found murdered but eight still missing
Description: Russia's only deputy representing breakaway Chechnya said that federal troops had murdered at least five civilians in one village during a wave of "cleansing" operations launched in the republic.  The deputy, who has previously been pro-Moscow, said troops poured into the village and arrested 117 people.  Five people were later found murdered and eight others are still missing, while the rest have been released.  Officials in the region have expressed outrage at the troops' conduct.
Burundi villagers said government troops killed 10 civilians including three women in an offensive against ethnic Hutu rebels this week in hills surrounding the capital Bujumbura.
Comments: The army denied the charge but said armed action in the African country's civil war inevitably put civilians at risk.

Description: Police in the Brazilian city of Sao Paulo said on Saturday they ambushed and shot dead five members of a criminal group blamed for Brazil's biggest prison riot and numerous jail breaks.  Media reports quoted residents as saying police shot first and two of the five killed were innocent bystanders. The police group who stormed the meeting have long had a reputation for being the most violent in the force.
Comments: Perps identified as Sao Paulo police.  Victims include two "innocent bystanders" as well as three members of criminal group, First Commando of the Capital (PCC).  The attack was an ambush and victims are presumed to be unarmed combatants.  Firearms indicated.

Description: Five killed in renewed Jamaica violence.
Citation:
Reuters News 26 July 2001 lba0000020010726dx7q00zz6
Associated Press Newswires 26 July 2001 aprs000020010726dx7q00w9k
Comments: Perps identified as police.  Victims include at least two random deaths.  Indication that firebombings were also part of attack.  AP reports "at least four deaths."

Description: Up to ten ethnic Albanian civilian men were allegedly murdered by Macedonian police on August 12 in the village of Lujboten, near Skopje. Macedonian officials denied any wrong-doing and insisted that any deaths occurred while its forces were returning fire from rebels. Other accounts contested this, asserting that the victims were all wearing plain clothes, some were shot at shot range, and villagers claimed that the men were indeed civilians. A Human Rights Watch report weighted in on the issue, charging that "Slavic forces of Macedonia's government" summarily executed civilians in the village. The group also asserted that that forces had used arson and torture. The killings were described as motivated by "revenge". The incident took place in the context of an on-going conflict between Macedonia and the ethnic Albanian National Liberation Army.
Citation: Reuters 05 Sep lba0000020010905dx9500hs9; Associated Press 05 Sep 01 aprs000020010905dx9500cnl
Comments: The non-combatant status of the victims is disputed - villagers claimed that they were civilians, the government claimed they were "terrorists".

Kidnappings: Allegations that a 17-year-old was kidnapped while tending a herd of cattle and his bullet-riddled body was sent back to his family
Description: The Russian human rights group Memorial alleged on their web site that nine civilians in the southeastern town of Alleroi were shot and killed during a nine-day operation by the Russian army.  The group also alleged that federal troops kidnapped a 17-year-old boy who was tending a herd of cattle.  They said his bullet-riddled body was sent back to his family five days later by Russian soldiers.  The Russian government denied these allegations.
Comments: It's unclear whether the nine civilians killed includes the death of the kidnapped boy or whether his death would bring the death toll to 10

Description: Muslim separatist rebels on Tuesday accused the Philippine army of killing 19 civilians, including children, in an operation to flush out members of the Abu Sayyaf kidnap gang on Basilan island.
Comments: MILF accused military of killing civilians.  Military denies, saying either the people killed were not civilians, or the civilians in question were not killed.

Description: "The Iranian opposition People's Mujahideen Organisation said on Monday three bombs exploded near one of its bases in southern Iraq, killing five civilians and wounding several others." The opposition blamed the Iranian "mullahs' regime" for the attack. "There was no immediate confirmation of the report from Baghdad."
Comments: Reuters reports the incident more as a rumor than a confirmed attack, hence I code it as a rumor/allegation and code the substance of the incident just as it is reported by the alleging party.

Victim.Identity.Religious: "demonstrators protesting the arrest of leaders of a banned Islamic student organization"
Description: Police kill 5 people who were demonstrating the arrest of leaders of a banned Islamic student organization.  Some protesters were involved in violent rioting--there is not information regarding whether those killed were combatants at the time.
Comments: Noncombatant status unclear

Description: On 1 October 2001, Agence France-Presse reported that "At least 13 people were killed and nearly three dozen injured Monday in a powerful suicide bombing outside the state legislature building in Indian-administered Kashmir, police said. A Pakistan-based Islamic militant group claimed responsibility for the attack, saying a suicide bomber drove near the legislature in a car laden with explosives. The blast caused damage to at least 150 buildings around the tightly guarded legislature, including shops and a six-storey hotel. Police said 13 people died, including two policemen, one paramilitary personnel and a woman. Witnesses said, however, that 15 people were killed in the blast. 'Many people bled to death as no one dared to rush to the spot,' said Abdul Rashid, a local shopkeeper said. Reports said gunfire was heard from inside the legislature after the blast and that two militants had managed to enter the building."  Jaish-e-Mohammed (Pakistan) was the group which claimed responsibility.  AFP later updated their report to 17 killed, three dozen injured, and then to 18.  A subsequent report from Reuters indicated that 21 had died.  Eventual reports updated the toll to 40 killed, 60 wounded.
Comments: Used later reports to update toll to 40 killed, 60 wounded.

Description: At least 20 people were killed and many others wounded when Sudan government war planes bombed a large group of civilians fleeing fighting in the town of Raga in Sudan's southwestern Bahr el-Ghazal state, a rebel spokesman here said Sunday.
Secondary.Source: spokesman for the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army
Comments: Kwaje said that SPLA fighters had observed that the kind of bombs used by the government in recent weeks set the grass on fire and the areas where the explosives fell continued burning for several hours.  They suspect the use of napalm.

Description: President Olusegun Obasanjo has apologized for ordering an army raid in which 200 people were killed in apparent retaliation for the deaths of 19 soldiers, a senior state official said Thursday. Obasanjo had previously acknowledged ordering the Oct. 22-24, 2001, attacks. But he had said he acted to restore calm after ethnic Tiv militia fighters ambushed and killed the soldiers, sent to quell months of clashes between Tivs and their Jukun rivals. He had also suggested the soldiers may have acted in self-defense. Witnesses said the soldiers ransacked at least seven villages, shelling houses and gunning down residents indiscriminately.
Comments: The article from which the code was derived focuses on the expression of regret for the incidents occurrence; however, this regret fell outside of the one month time frame stipulated by the codebook for expressions of regret.  Little other information is given, but the perpetrators did shell the homes (scorched earth tactics) and killed villagers indiscriminately.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: random, riding a minibus suspected to contain rebel guerrillas
Description: According to Chechen leadership, six Chechen civilians were killed and several others wounded when Russian troops fired on a minibus near the town of Argun, east of Grozny.  The minibus was passing a control post, on its way to Grozny, when federal troops hunting rebel guerrillas opened fire on the vehicle.

Reports indicate that at least 13 protesters were killed--some of which were engaged in violent behavior.  Eyewitnesses, however, report that over 200 were killed, some by machetes.  The protestors were rallying against an army-imposed curfew, and some of the protesters may have engaged in looting and other destruction.
Comments: Noncombatant status unclear

Description: At least 13 civilians have been killed during military operations in western Burundi, a private radio station reported Friday.
Comments: The government, which said the two soldiers were only injured in the ambush, confirmed the military has been conducting searches of the village and surrounding area since Wednesday, but denied that any civilians had been killed, the radio report said.

Description: Seven villagers shot dead in western Zambia two weeks ago may have been caught in the cross fire during a shootout between Angolan government forces and rebel UNITA troops, according to a senior Angolan official.  The Zambian government accused the Angolan soldiers who crossed into the Zambian border village of Sipuma of abducting 103 Zambians and killing seven others.  The soldiers later released 83 of their captives but the Zambian government said 20 remained missing.  Angola denied holding any Zambians.
Comments: The Zambian and Angolan governments remain in dispute about this incident, Associated Press does not take a side.

Kidnappings: abductions reported after Northern Alliance victory
Description: The United Nations said more than 100 Taliban fighters who attempted to take cover at a school in the northern city of Mazar-e-Sharif were killed by opposition fighters and that hundreds of other people were also killed in the offensive.  It was unclear exactly how many of the victims were civilians and how many were Taliban.  Several incidents of looting, summary executions and abductions had been reported after the fall of the city to the Northern Alliance forces.

A drunken soldier opened fire on a group of Muslim worshippers at a motor park in the northern city of Kaduna, killing six and injuring at least one.  The army authorities said they were already investigating the incident and vowed to bring the culprit to book.  The soldier had asked a preacher to stop his sermon and leave the venue, and opened fire when the preacher continued to preach.
Comments: It is important to note that this was a rampage by an individual soldier, and not the actions of the entire Nigerian military.

Description: The death toll from an armed Muslim revolt in the southern Philippine island of Jolo has risen to 113, including at least 100 rebels, the military's southern command chief said Wednesday. The military suffered six dead while seven civilians were killed in the crossfire, he told reporters.
Comments: Civilians caught either in crossfire or in airstrikes meant to kill Muslim rebels.  No regret expressed in article.  Crossfire mentioned, but it looks like the military is most likely to blame, not the rebels.

Description: Russian forces fought Chechen rebels in an eastern village, Tsotsin-Yurt, for six days in an operation to flush rebels out of the mountainous region.  Ten civilians who were caught in the crossfire between the two sides were killed.

The death of an official in Zimbabwe's opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) brought to 56 the number killed this year in political violence, which human rights groups say has mainly targeted MDC supporters.  The MDC has rejected President Mugabe's re-election, saying the poll was marred by widespread political violence and vote fraud.  Independent Zimbabwean observers, as well as most  western nations and the Commonwealth, have taken a similar stance.

"At least 60 people have been killed in Burundi during more than a week of fighting between the army and rebels near two towns outside Bujumbura, the capital, witnesses said Friday.  The fighting began around noon on Jan. 15 near Kanyosha, about 8 kilometers (5 miles) from Bujumbura, when army helicopters began strafing fields outside the town, said a resident who witnessed the attack but did not want to be identified because he feared for his safety....  At least 24 people were killed in the cross fire between the army and rebels since the fighting began, they said."
Comments: The lead indicates that 60 deaths occurred, and 24 of the victims died in crossfire.  This indicates that the rest of the deaths were combatant deaths, but does not assert that the 24 were noncombatants.

Description: On 28 January 2002, AP reported that "Indian troops fired heavy artillery and mortars across the disputed boundary Monday, killing at least five villagers, including three children...At least 11 others were wounded in the day-long shelling in various parts of the divided Kashmir region, they said. Five villagers were killed and three wounded during shelling in the Hajira sector about 175 kilometers (105 miles) south of Muzaffarabad, police said. They included three children between six and 12 years of age, police added. Eight other civilians were reported wounded by small arms and mortar fire in the Nakial sector about 300 kilometers (180 miles) south of Muzaffarabad, officials said.

"The Sudanese government attacked civilians waiting for food aid at a relief centre in south Sudan, killing 17 and injuring many others, the United Nations and Sudanese rebels said on Thursday.  'Yesterday (Wednesday) at about 1320 hours, a military helicopter gunship attacked the village of Bieh where U.N. World Food Programme (WFP) food was being distributed,' WFP said in a statement.  'The helicopter hovered over the WFP compound and fired five rockets into the surrounding area. At least 17 people waiting to receive WFP food assistance were killed and another two were seriously injured.'"
Comments: The AP report includes the admission of regret on behalf of the perpetrating Sudanese government.

Description: Israeli tanks fired on two cars in the Al-Amari refugee camp near Ramallah, killing six Palestinians--four of them a Hamas militant leader's wife and kids. "The Israeli army apologized for the attack, saying the shell was aimed at a car carrying Palestinian policemen, but missed its target and stressed that it was not an assassination attempt."
Citation:
Agence France Presse: 03.05.2002, afpr000020020305dy35000xd
Hazel Ward
Comments: Although the article does not explicitly say that the victims were all noncombatants, there is no suggestion that they might have been, and what is more, the Israeli army apologizes for the killing of these people, saying that the shell was intended for a car carrying Palestinian policemen. Given these, I assume that the victims were all noncombatants, who were not intentionally targeted, and hence the killings were collateral damage.

Description: "Two weeks of attacks on the ground and from the air by the Burundian army have left more than 400 civilians dead in the hills around the capital, a rebel spokesman said Friday.  The claim could not be independently verified because fighting in the area continues and the army restricts journalists from visiting combat zones.   Lt. Gelase Ndabirade, a spokesman for the Forces for Defense of Democracy, said the army has been attacking rebel strongholds near the capital, Bujumbura, for two weeks using ground troops and helicopters firing missiles and dropping bombs."
Comments: These killings happened as the government was attacking rebel strongholds using troops and helicopters firing missiles and dropping bombs.

Description: Israeli army staged an incursion into Jabalya refugee camp near Gaza City with tanks and troops, backed by helicopter gunships; after four hours of fighting, 17 people were killed--"at least eight of them gunmen"--and 50 were injured.
Citation:
Reuters News: 03.12.2002, lba0000020020312dy3c003jz
By Mohammed Assadi
Comments: I assume that nine of the dead victims who were not specifically identified as gunmen were noncombatants, however, because this is not clearly stated in the report, I code the death count as "range reported" to allow some room for ambiguity.  Because a number of buildings were intentionally demolished by Israeli soldiers during this raid, it was more than likely that some civilians will be part of the casualties. The casualty information is given by hospital sources.

Description: " A rocket-propelled grenade fired by the army hit a house in southeastern Burundi, killing eight people from the same family, including six children, a rebel official and an independent radio station said Wednesday.  Two parents and their children were trying to hide from fighting between the army and Hutu rebels when the grenade struck their house in Mutamba commune, 18 kilometers (11 miles) southeast of Bujumbura, on Monday, African Public Radio said."

Police fired on opposition protesters in the southern Aksy region in March of 2002, leaving five people dead. The violence sparked months of opposition protests in southern Kyrgyzstan, where Akayev's control is weak, and prompted Prime Minister Nikolai Tanayev to warn that the country was teetering on the brink of civil war... Law enforcement officers fired on a crowd protesting the trial of a man.  Officers insist that firing on the crowd was an act of self-defense and dispute the victims' status as non-combatant.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: National Liberation Forces (FNL) - a Hutu rebel group
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: National Liberation Forces (FNL) - a Hutu rebel group
Description: "Sixty people have been killed in two days of fighting between Burundi's army and rebels outside the capital, while 15,000 have fled the combat zone, a private radio station reported Thursday.  Army spokesman Colonel Augustin Nzabampema told AFP there had been fighting in the Nyabiraba district, 20 kilometres (12 miles) from Bujumbura, but neither confirmed nor denied the casualty figures given by Radio publique africaine....  'If people have been killed, they are rebels because this sector has been deserted by its inhabitants for a long time,' Nzabampema said."
Comments: It is unclear how many of the 60 reported deaths were actually noncombatants.  The report only states that some of them were women and children, indicating that these are at least partially noncombatant deaths.  The contestations coded in this case arise from statements from a state official claiming that any deaths occurring in the region were rebel deaths, and that any innocents have left the region long ago.  He is thus not contesting the deaths themselves, but the combatant status of the dead.

Description: "Twenty-seven Burundian civilians were killed in crossfire during clashes between the army and rebels in the hills around the capital Bujumbura on Monday, a privately owned radio station reported.  The radio quoted local people as saying the victims were caught in the fighting while on their way to market in the capital. There was no independent confirmation of the report."
Comments: These dead were killed in crossfire between the rebels and the government.  The rebels are reporting these deaths and are laying blame on the government for attacking the rebel positions when civilians may be easily killed in the process.  The AP reports 28 dead.

Description: Israeli forces carried out a two-week long siege into the Jenin refugee camp in the West Bank (in response to suicide bombings by Palestinians who originated from these areas). According to Israeli forces, about 70 Palestinians were killed--"the vast majority of them militants". According to the Palestinians, however, the civilian death toll was in the "hundreds" (calling it the "Jenin massacre").
Citation:
Reuters News: 04.19.2002, lba0000020020419dy4j00hr5
By Christine Hauser
Comments: Note that Palestinian and Israeli counts of the casualties vary immensely; given the rule followed in this dataset, I code the higher count given by Palestinians, but I also code both the noncombatant status and the death toll as contested. A lot of the casualties occurred when their houses were demolished and a lot of people were buried under rubble; so it is highly conceivable that many civilians were killed.

Description: "Thirty-eight people were killed April 6 after soldiers surrounded a house in the northwestern village of Gihanga, Bubanza Province, thought to be harboring rebels, the Burundi Human Rights League said in a statement.   The occupants opened fire, triggering fierce fighting that killed 29 civilians, seven rebels from the Hutu National Liberation Forces (FNL) and two soldiers, the group said, adding that at least 20 houses were damaged or set ablaze."

Bodies of eight Palestinians belonging to the same family were pulled out of the rubble of their home in Nablus, the West Bank, almost a week after the building was destroyed "when Israeli troops, battling Palestinian gunmen, fired rockets from aircraft and shells from tanks in the crowded area of the old city." Israeli army spokesperson responded by saying that "the area had been the scene of heavy fighting but the army did not target civilian homes."
Comments: Note that although the Israeli army asserts that they did not target civilians homes, and further argue that "buildings in some areas of fighting had been booby-trapped by Palestinian gunmen", they don't explicitly contest or dispute the fact that they might have caused the killing of the civilians in question--they only say that they did not intentionally target civilian homes. I code the intent as unclear but I do not code the incident as contested. Reuters further reports that "Journalists had difficulty obtaining independent accounts of the fighting in Nablus because Israel declared the city a closed military area. Residents were confined to their houses and no journalists were allowed to enter from outside." However, the incident is still presented as a regular secondary account and not merely as a rumor.

Description: Afghan security officers opened fired on a group of poppy farmers who were protesting government policy regarding poppy farming.  Eight were killed and 35 injured.

The Angolan separatist group FLEC-FAC (Cabinda Enclave Liberation Front-Cabinda Armed Forces)  alleged that government troops killed 16 civilians in an attack on a village in Cabinda.  A government spokesman denied the incident, saying soldiers were not deployed near to where the attacks allegedly took place.
Comments: This is an event in dispute and has not been independently confirmed by Reuters or any other international agency.

Description: At least eight people were killed, including two children, when gun battles erupted on Tuesday between government troops and Marxist rebels on the streets of Colombia's third-largest city, authorities said.
Citation:
Reuters news 21 May 2002 lba0000020020521dy5l016ab
Associated Press Newswires 21 May 2002 aprs000020020521dy5l00y46
Agence France-Presse 22 May 2002 afpr000020020522dy5m000rx
Comments: Casualties are collateral damage of military/police raid into Medillin slums which resulted in fighting between them and FARC urban forces.  Both classified as perps hence unknown state role of perps.  Casualties contested AP & AFP reports nine, Reuters report eight.

Description: "Sudanese rebels said on Thursday the government had killed 11 people and seriously injured 45 others in a bombing raid on a village in the south of the war-torn country.  'Eleven people were killed and 45 seriously wounded when the government of Sudan's Antonov dropped 16 bombs on the village of Rier in Mankien county, Western Upper Nile,' the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLA/SPLM) said in a statement issued in the Kenyan capital Nairobi."
Comments: The reported death toll for this bombing attack has been reported anywhere between 11 and 18 dead.  The government later denied these accusations.

Description: "The Sudanese government has again bombed several villages near the country's southern oil fields, killing at least 17 people, Sudanese rebels said Monday.  The government rebuffed the rebel allegations.  A government airplane bombed four villages in Western Upper Nile from May 24-26, the rebel Sudanese People's Liberation Movement said in a statement.   Scores of people were injured, and many of those killed were women and children, the statement said."
Comments: A later reuters report indicated that the government denied these bombings.

Description: On 26 May 2002, Reuters reported that "At least five Indian civilians died when Indian and Pakistani forces traded heavy fire overnight as tension remained high between the two nuclear-armed South Asian neighbours... The victims, who included two girls, died when Pakistani troops pounded the Indian village of Kahnard with heavy machinegun and mortar fire along the international border dividing the state of Jammu and Kashmir from the Sialkot district of Punjab in Pakistan, the [defence] official said. Eight were wounded."

"At least 26 people were killed in heavy fighting in the Somali capital Mogadishu on Tuesday between hundreds of heavily-armed militiamen and forces loyal to the interim government, hospital sources and witnesses said.   Hospital sources and witnesses counted at least 26 dead and 52 wounded, mainly civilians. The dead included five on the government side and 10 militiamen, they said."
Comments: The combatants in this event were described as "heavily-armed," so I coded the weapons used as "heavy weapons."

Description: "At least eight militia members were killed Friday in combat with government forces in the Republic of Congo capital, Brazzaville, military sources said, in an attack that sent panicked locals fleeing to safer parts of the city.  'We have killed eight Ninjas,' a military source told AFP, referring to the militia group who have maintained a stand-off against the government from their base in the neighboring Pool region....  Local witnesses said that five civilians had also been killed in morning gun battles with the militia, who had infiltrated a district some 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the city center."

"Five civilians were killed Saturday during clashes between government troops and rebels at Ruziba south of the capital Bujumbura, official sources and witnesses said.  'Rebels from the National Liberation Forces (FNL) attacked an army position, and five civilians were killed in the attack,' a local official told AFP.   Several people who had fled the area added the army had blindly opened fire in response to the attack, after having lost some soldiers from there own ranks, a version of events disputed by the military."
Comments: The exact perpetrators of these killings are unclear, although the army seems to have been guilty of indiscriminate fire.  Both combatants in this battle were listed as the perpetrators.

Description: Army troops have killed five civilians in retaliation for three separate rebel attacks in which two soldiers and four civilians died, witnesses said Wednesday.
Comments: But army officials said no civilians had been killed by the army in Ruziba.

Description: A regional army spokesman said several civilians were killed in the cross fire, but he did not know the exact number. The government-run newspaper The New Vision reported Tuesday that 16 civilians were killed.
Nine Sudanese civilians were killed and five seriously wounded on Monday when the Khartoum government bombed a strategic town captured last month by rebels, an aid agency official said.

"Nine Sudanese civilians were killed and five seriously wounded on Monday when the Khartoum government bombed a strategic town captured last month by rebels, an aid agency official said.  't 10 a.m. (0700 GMT) the government of Sudan bombed Kapoeta,' Dan Eiffe, liaison officer at Norwegian People's Aid (NPA), told Reuters in Nairobi.  'No SPLA (rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army) military personnel were killed as they were said to be out of the town when the bombing happened. It was carried out by one Antonov plane,' he said."
Comments: Although this event is coded as collateral damage (because it is clear that the government was targeting the town for its military significance in the battles against the SPLA) it is clear that the government did not attempt to avoid civilian deaths.  The government used an Antonov warplane to deliver the bombs.  In a later report, the Sudanese government denied that it carried out this bombing.

Description: A Liberian human rights group has accused forces loyal to former president Charles Taylor of killing hundreds of civilians in a 2002 massacre during the country's 14-year war. The Catholic and Justice Peace Commission, citing testimony from four survivors, said in a statement women, children and elderly people, had been killed in the attack. In a statement published late on Thursday, the commission said the massacre took place in Tubmanburg, some 60 km (38 miles) north of the capital Monrovia on July 18, 2002. "The militias assembled hundreds of civilians and placed them under 'maximum security' surveillance before taking them to the bridge where they were allegedly slaughtered," it said. The statement said the exact number of people killed was not clear. It gave no explanation for the massacre, but said the militias had told the victims their commanders would give them some rice. A former top security official, named by the commission as a commander of the militias allegedly involved in the massacre, denied the accusations.
Comments: The perpetrators were supporters of Charles Taylor, the ruler of Liberia at the time of the incident.  The reason the villagers were killed is not clear so I coded the victims as unclear/other/random.  These allegations seem pretty reliable, although no firm number is given for the death count, the massacre fits with Taylor's history of human rights violations and atrocities.  One militia leader implicated in the attack denied the allegations, but no other voices of dissent are mentioned.  Among the human rights violations in this incident, mass detention is described, as "the militias assembled hundreds of civilians and placed them under maximum security surveillance" before they were killed.

Description: An Israeli missile strike hit a crowded area in Gaza City, killing a military commander of Hamas but also 14 other bystanders, including nine children.
Citation:
Reuters News: 07.31.2002, lba0000020020801dy8100ed5
By Dan Williams; 07.23.2002, lba0000020020723dy7n014lp; Agence France Presse: 07.23.2002, afpr000020020723dy7n004ha
Comments: Even though the missile attack targeted a Hamas commander, who also ended up killed in the attack, Israeli sources neither deny the killing of civilians nor do they suggest that it was an accident or collateral damage, hence I code it as "intent apparent" and not as collateral damage. Furthermore, Sharon is cited as praising the attack in question, calling it "one of the most successful operations".

Description: Up to 300 people have been killed and up to 100,000 displaced during an attack by government forces and allied militia on an oil-rich county in south Sudan, a senior rebel official told AFP on Tuesday.
Comments: Another Sudanese source put the toll at more than 1,000. Neither toll could be independently confirmed.

Description: Two army offensives just outside Burundi's capital has left 24 civilians dead, among them old women and small children, survivors said Thursday, as negotiators from both sides prepare for peace talks next week.
A government official in Kabezi, Emmanuel Baragiye, said the 18 victims "were all civilians who had just left mass and were caught in the crossfire of the fighting between the army and the rebels."
Comments: Army spokesman Augustin Nzabampema denied the claims that government troops had killed civilians.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: Random villagers caught between government and rebel fighting
Description: Russian troops launched a special operation against Chechen rebels in the villages of Shalazhi and Gekhi-Chu that has killed 32 rebels but resulted in 11 civilian casualties as well. The fighting broke out after rebels reportedly attacked an Interior Ministry checkpoint and multiple other targets after that.  Most of the fighting in the campaign has taken place in forested areas surrounding the villages and death resulted from crossfire or the dropping of bombs by helicopters.
Fighting between Hutu rebels and the Tutsi-dominated army in hills surrounding Bujumbura left 30 civilians dead and forced 1,500 others to flee their homes, an independent radio reported Tuesday.
Comments: Capt. Manirakiza, an army spokesman, said no civilians were killed in the fighting.

Description: Vieira de Mello referred in his letter primarily to the mass killing of 173 mainly civilians which took place on September 9 in the central town of Itaba in the province of Gitega.
Comments: Last month, the army described the Itaba massacre as a result of "errors of judgment" and said an enquiry had been set up.

Description: The plane returned and bombed several villages south of Mirmir Monday, killing at least 12 civilians, including five women and seven children, Kwaje said.

Representatives of Iteka in Kanyosha, 20 kilometers (12 miles) south of Bujumbura, had counted the bodies of 10 adults and six children. He said some had been shot and others had been burned in their homes.
Secondary.Source: Iteka human rights organization in Burundi

Description: What began as a military uprising to oust President Gbagbo soon became an ethnic conflict with reports of foreigners and Muslims being targeted in the capitol city of Abidjan by gangs armed with machetes.  The insurgency began the morning of 19 Sept. when rebels launched coordinated attacks on military installations, government sites, and Cabinet minister's houses throughout CIV.  A total of 270 were killed and 300 injured, but no breakdown on the casualties was available.
Comments: No breakdown of the casualty count was available so many, if not most of the deaths could be armed combatants or collateral damage.  However, because the article mentioned the targeting of foreigners and Muslims, I felt that it could be considered code worthy.

Description: Seventeen people died when a displaced people's camp at Amadi in Mundri county of Western Equatoria was bombed on Saturday.
A family of nine perished when a bomb fell on their home as they slept in Atar in Western Upper Nile's Abyei county. A total of 14 bombs were dropped in the area, the SPLA said.
Israeli tanks and armored vehicles backed by helicopters staged an incursion into the Gaza Strip, killing 9 people--three of them militants--and injuring 20 others.
Comments: The casualty numbers and their break-up is given by Palestinian hospital sources and families; note that the injured number is not broken up into combatant and noncombatants injuries. Numbers are not contested by the Israelis.

Description: An Israeli raid into Khan Younis in the Gaza Strip left 14 Palestinian civilians dead and 80 others wounded--most died when a helicopters missile hit a crowd of people who had come out of their houses and gathered outside a mosque thinking the raid was over.
Citation: Reuters News: 10.07.2002, lba0000020021007dya700tsr; Agence France Presse: 10.07.2002, afpr000020021007dya700ayi
Comments: Casualty information is given by hospital officials, who said that all the dead were civilians but the wounded toll of 80 included combatants; because I have no information for how this number breaks up, I code the total toll given. While the Israeli army said that "the helicopter launched the missile at a source of fire directed at tanks withdrawing at the end of the operation," they did not explicitly deny the civilian killings either, hence I code deaths and their civilian status as uncontested. Also note that one of the reports updates the death toll from 12 to 14.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: people who died in military and police custody "during a controversial anti-crime drive"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 01/10/2003 that "Bangladesh's main opposition Friday [01/10/2003] blasted a government decision giving immunity to the armed forces for their actions during a controversial anti-crime drive in which nearly 40 people reportedly died in custody"; reportedly, "the government has confirmed only 12 deaths and says all the victims died in hospital of heart attacks after being handed over to police"; reportedly, however, "human rights groups have reported that 44 people died in custody or in the hospital... [and] relatives claimed detainees were tortured"; reportedly, "troops... detained 10,000 suspects" during the "12-week-old operation"
Secondary.Source: Amnesty International, Relatives of the victims
Comments: Mass Detentions coded as Yes since reportedly "more than 10,000 people were detained" during the anti-crime drive; Other Tactics coded as Yes (Torture) since reportedly "relatives claimed detainees were tortured"

Description: Six Palestinian civilians were also killed by the Israeli army during an incursion into Rafah.
Comments: This report is actually about worldwide reactions to Israeli killing of civilians, particularly what happened in the event coded here. Although it is mentioned that the civilians were killed during a firefight between the army and militants, no information is given to suggest that it was collateral damage.

Description: Residents accused government troops of burning down homes and shooting civilians in attacks that targeted Muslims and migrants from Burkina Faso.  The military has staunchly denied involvement and claims that the attackers were rebels dressed as troops with the aim of tarnishing the fine reputation of the Ivory Coast military.  The head of the Islamic Council received reports that 56 Muslims had been shot dead and buried, while 19 other bodies were still lying in the streets.
Comments: The perpetrators in this incident remains in contestation.

Mass.Detentions: Rebels took hostages attending the theatre
Description: Chechen militants seized a theater in Moscow, took more than 800 hostages and claimed that they would blow up the building if the war in Chechnya was not terminated.  To prevent the militants from detonating more than 100 pounds of explosives rigged to the theater, Russian forces stormed the theater and used an opiate-based gas to knock out the attackers.  Authorities insist that all the 41 militants were killed and none were allowed to escape.  Of the 128 noncombatant deaths, five of the victims were killed by gunshots but the rest died because of the gas.  Sixty-seven of the freed hostages still remained in hospitals at the time of the report and five were in grave condition.
Chad on Friday accused neighbouring Central African Republic of killing more than 150 Chadian nationals as security forces there hunted down rebels after six days of fighting in the capital Bangui.
Comments: Central African Republic denies the event occurs and says that any Chadians who may have been killed were fighting with the rebels.

Description: Government troops killed at least 100 civilians in a town in the southern Democratic Republic of Congo, witnesses and a human rights group said on Thursday.
Comments: It was unclear whether the victims were caught in crossfire between the soldiers and Mai Mai traditional warriors, or if they were killed because they were supporters of the Mai Mai.

Description: Ivory Coast rebels accused government troops of bombarding the western village of Pelezi with helicopters the night of 27 Nov., killing about 12 people, and wounding an equal number.  The Ivorian army confirmed that helicopters had indeed attacked the rebel territory, and French troops in the area were unable to confirm the allegations.
Comments: Information about the event is sparse. It is unclear whether civilians were the intended target of this attack, but the quotes from the army sources point towards the conclusion that the rebels holding the town were the target of said attack.

Description: Ivory Coast's army admitted on Wednesday that scores of people in a mass grave in the west of the country were killed by government troops, but said they were rebels who died in fighting rather than civilians. The rebel Patriotic Movement of Ivory Coast (MPCI) has said the grave in Monoko-Zohi, 70 km (45 miles) northwest of the loyalist-held cocoa town of Daloa, contained the bodies of 120 civilians - mostly foreign immigrants - killed by Ivorian troops after a raid in the rebel-held area. Foreign media have quoted residents of the village as backing the rebels' version. Government officials initially said loyalist troops had not been to Monoko-Zohi, near an area where a helicopter bombarded rebel positions on November 27 after President Laurent Gbagbo's forces accused them of breaking a ceasefire.
Comments: The facts are in dispute, but the rebel's version is lent credibility by the eyewitness accounts of the villagers.

Description: A spokesman for the Red Cross said that at least 150 people have died in the western town of Man, which was seized by rebels on 28 Nov. before being reclaimed by loyalist forces.  Two of the victims were reportedly executed by rebels for being suspected thieves.  According to one eyewitness, the loyalists just fired on civilians if they tried to run.
Comments: From the facts presented in the article, it seems that both the rebels and government loyalists can be held culpable for the more than 150 deaths.  Although firearms were the only weapons mentioned, it is possible and highly likely that other forms of violence were employed.

Description: During an Israeli incursion into the el Bureij refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, 10 unarmed people--including two UN employees--ended up dead.
Comments: While not each of the casualties are identified separately as civilians, this articles is about EU's reaction to Israel for killing civilians; the Danish president of the EU is quoted as saying that it "strongly condemns military or other violent actions directed indiscriminately against a civilian neighbourhood" and that "a massive intervention of that type in a densely populated urban area can only lead to the loss of innocent lives, as was the case today." Hence, I assume that all of the ten reported dead were noncombatants.

Description: France will demand an explanation from the authorities in Ivory Coast as to why a government military helicopter attacked a rebel-held village, killing 12 civilians and wounding several others, the foreign ministry said Thursday. Twelve civilians died when Ivorian troops loyal to President Laurent Gbagbo, fighting a rebellion that is into its fourth month, bombarded Menakro, a fishing village about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of the inland capital of Yamoussoukro on Tuesday. At least one Russian-made MI-24 helicopter was used in the attack.  Ivory Coast army spokesman, Lieutenant-Colonel Jules Yao Yao, said the dead were insurgents and not civilians.
Comments: The motive for this attack is unclear, the government has not provided an explanation for the incident, although they did claim that they were responding to an earlier attack.  It is unclear whether the civilians were the direct target of the action and an army spokesman disputes the fact that the victims were civilians.  The number of injured is also unclear, the text mentions that several were injured.

Description: Amnesty International demanded an inquiry into the alleged extra-judicial killings committed by security forces in Burkina Faso.  The Burkinabe Movement for the Rights of Man and the People (MBDHP) alleged that 106 people had been killed in a crackdown on bandits.  The country's security minister denied the charges and questioned the toll provided by the rights group, without providing an official figure.  The security minister did say that a sharp rise in banditry called for "rigorous methods" to combat the problem.
Comments: The beginning date for this crackdown on bandits was not given, but it is presumably recent in relation to the publication date of the article.

Description: The Associated Press reported on 11/04/2004 that, according to local police sources, "from January to October this year [2004], 600 civilians have been killed" in insurgency-racked Jammu-Kashmir; reportedly, "last year [2003] during the same period, 1,125 civilians... were killed, according to [IND] government statistics"

"More than 65 people have died and nearly 180 been wounded on the Pakistani side of the LoC in Indian shelling" through 22 August 2003.  Later attacks brought the total to 80 dead by September 1, with another 3 dead and 1 injured by September 9. A September report put the injury count at 206.  Shellings across the Line of Control are common in the on-going Indian/Pakistan dispute over control in Kashmir.
"Some 104 people, including 70 rebels, 31 civilians and three soldiers were killed in northern Uganda in January during army operations against Lord's Resistance Army rebels, the army said Wednesday.
Comments: It should be important to note that these civilian deaths may be double counted in earlier codes from Uganda for this January.  Additionally, it is not clear whether or not these civilians died at the hands of the LRA or government fighters.  There are no details regarding the circumstances of these killings; this seems to be a monthly report on the progress of the anti-rebel activities in the north of the country.

Description: "Eight civilians were killed on Monday by Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army in a reprisal strike in a Hutu- dominated neighborhood of the capital, Bujumbura, witnesses said.  Local authorities denied the witnesses' version of events.  Witnesses said the incident took place after a group of unidentified people stole a gun from a paramilitary policeman, who managed to run away.  Army soldiers arrived, surrounded the district of Taba, and then gunshots were heard, several dozen witnesses told AFP.  'The soldiers killed a person from the documentation service (Burundian secret service), as well as three construction workers building a house and a man and his three children,' said one witness.  The killings were confirmed by a source in the local administration, who asked not to be named.  Jean de Dieu Niyongabo, a local government official, said rebels dressed in civilian clothes had opened fire on soldiers on a patrol, 'who then returned fire.'"
Comments: The government disputes the reported eyewitness version of the facts, saying that the "civilians" who were killed were actually in the vicinity of plainclothes rebels, whose fire the rebels were returning, thus claiming collateral damage.  The civilian version of the facts is what I reported because they seem more likely and were corroborated by an anonymous source in the local government.

Description: On Monday, "fighting between the rebel National Liberation Forces, or FNL, and government soldiers killed eight people and injured two others, said Jean de Dieu Niyongabo, a local government official.  The fighting began in the Taba neighborhood of Bujumbura after rebels captured a government soldier, Niyongabo said.  The soldier escaped and alerted other soldiers in the area, he said.  A witness, who declined to be identified, said all those killed were civilians."
Comments: There are two perpetrators in this case, because the civilians were killed in the crossfire from a battle between government forces and the FNL.  An eyewitness account identified all the dead as civilians.  The word "crossfire" does not appear in the article, and although it is presumed that the weapons used were firearms, there is no concrete indication of that.

Description: Ivory Coast helicopter gunships on Thursday strafed a rebel-held town in the west of the country and killed 15 civilians, insurgents said in the west African state. Felix Doh, head of the Ivorian Popular Movement of the Far West (MPIGO) rebel group based in the west of the country, told AFP that two government helicopter gunships fired on the town of Grabo. Ivorian army spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Jules Yao Yao confirmed that government troops "were engaged in operations in the Grabo region," but did not confirm the firing. However, both French and Ivorian military sources said government forces had launched a military operation against rebels who were headed from Grabo to Tabou, a major port near the western border with Liberia, in which helicopters were used.
Comments: International news sources could not confirm this attack, and the Ivory Coast's military has denied killing the civilians.  However, the army did admit to being engaged in operations in the area against rebels, and that is why I coded this event as collateral damage.  Every indication points to the conclusion that the villagers were not intentionally targeted.

Description: "A human rights group Friday accused Burundi's army of killing dozens of civilians, raping women and burning and looting hundreds of houses last month as the government and rebels were negotiating to end the central African nation's 9 1/2-year civil war.  New York-based Human Rights Watch said the attacks took place in Mwegereza in the eastern province of Ruyigi on Jan. 19 after government soldiers had cleared rebel fighters from the area.  'Possibly more than 80 civilians' were killed by army soldiers including a pastor and 16 women and children, the group said in its report....  Some of the dead were shot, while others were clubbed or stabbed with bayonets, the report, based on eyewitnesses accounts, said....  Army spokesman Col. Augustin Nzabampema acknowledged that there had been fighting in the area, but he said the army had not deliberately killed civilians....  The rights group also accused rebels of the largest faction of the Forces for the Defense of Democracy, or FDD, of killing and raping civilians, as well as enlisting children into its fighting force.... Burundian soldiers also raped women from the area, burned and pillaged homes, and refused to allow people who fled to return to gather harvests and work their fields, the paper said."
Comments: The weapons used in this atrocity are both firearms and primitive weapons.  The event is contested because the government troops deny any intentional killings of civilians.  There is a range reported because between the two accounts there could be anywhere from 32 to more than 80 deaths.  80 is the number recorded because that estimate appeared in both accounts.  While the accusations are mainly directed at the Burundian military, the report adds that the rival FDD may also have killed civilians, raped women, and enlisted children into their forces (this last charge prompted the citation under "other tactics" category -- there is no indication that the army was involved in such activity).  The charge that the Burundian army refused to allow workers return to the fields constitutes the denial of food aid to the population.  The burning of domiciles constitutes the employment of "scorched earth tactics."

Description: "Burundian rebels killed four soldiers and the army killed 13 civilians in separate incidents, officials said Thursday.  13 civilians - nine women and four men - were killed between Friday and Saturday when the army shelled their village outside of Giheta, a central town 03 kilometers east of Bujumbura, said a local official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.  Col Augustin Nzabampema, the army spokesman, said soldiers believed they were shelling a position held by the rebel Forces for the Defense of Democracy, or FDD - the country's other main Hutu rebel group.  He could not say how many people died during the shelling."
Comments: The weapons used in this killing are "heavy weapons" because the news article described the incident as a "shelling."  Also, the admission that the killing was a mistake allowed me to code the perpetrator intent as "killing intentional, civilians not intentionally targeted."  Also, the admission by the army of this mistake has been interpreted as a regret on behalf of the perpetrators.

Description: "Sudanese government troops have captured a town in southern Sudan from rebels fighting a 20-year civil war, killing 20 civilians and violating a cease-fire agreement, a rebel spokesman said Saturday.  It was not immediately possible to reach government officials for comment.  George Garang, a spokesman with the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, said more than 1000 government troops and allied militia - supported by tanks and helicopter gunships - attacked Akobo in Eastern Upper Nile on Friday.  He said it was not known how many soldiers from each side were killed in the fighting, but said 20 civilians were killed and thousands of others forced to flee their homes.
Comments: If these killings actually occurred, it is possible that they were unintended civilian casualties that occurred as the government pursued rebel fighters (collateral damage) but there is no indication whether or not that is the case.  It should be noted that the government could not be reached for comment.  The report chronicles the use of firearms and mortars in the siege of the town, and while it does not directly state that the civilians died by these means, they are assumed to be the weapons used in the deaths.

Description: 16 killed, dozens injured in anti-tax protests, dead include at least 4 police officers
Citation:
Agence France-Presse 13 February 2003 afpr000020030213dz2d003pj
Agence France-Presse 13 February 2003 afpr000020030213dz2d00264
Agence France-Presse 13 February 2003 afpr000020030212dz2d00eyy
Comments: Victims are a mix of police and protesters.  Protesters are noted as having thrown rocks but at buildings not military thus questionable status as non-combatants.  Perps identified as state military   .Military did fire warning shots and teargas but unclear if these caused casualties.  Injured figure updated in later afp report (afpr000020030213dz2d00264).  Later report indicates military sharpshooters were responsible (afpr000020030212dz2d00eyy).  Death estimates updated (afpr000020030214dz2e00c7t).

Description: "At least 400 civilians have been killed and another 500 are missing after Congolese rebels allied with the government seized a key town in northeastern Congo and launched a two-day campaign of murder, rape, looting and destruction, a rival rebel leader said Saturday.  Thomas Lubanga, head of the Union of Congolese Patriots, or UPC, said the victims were killed on Feb. 24-25 after his troops were pushed from the strategic town of Bogoro during an attack by the rebel Congolese Rally for Democracy-Liberation Movement, or RCD-ML, and allied Lendu tribal militiamen.  Both groups receive aid from the government of President Joseph Kabila.  There was no way to independently verify the claim; the U.N. mission to Congo, or MONUC, which is aware of the reported killings, said the area is too dangerous to permit its unarmed military observers to investigate....  Some 47 girls, including some as young as 12 years, were raped by RCD-ML fighters and their Lendu allies before the assailants set fire to houses in the trading center, Lubanga said by telephone from his headquarters in Bunia, capital of restive Ituri province."
Comments: The number of dead reported in this article was 400 with another 500 missing.  This is a range of death because the lead cited "at least" 400 deaths.  The injured number reported in this code is the only number given in the article other than the dead or missing toll.  These 47 injured refer to the number of female victims who were reported "raped."  There were also citations of looting and destruction, and burning of homes indicated in the "other tactics" category.  The perpetrator in this case is identified as both a state and non-state actor because the group is described both as a rebel and government allied group.  Since these accusations could not be independently verified, the event is coded as a Rumor/Allegation.  The AFP report cites 300 deaths, and Reuters cites "hundreds" dead.

Description: Iraqi missiles meant to target allied warplanes flying overhead hit a civilian area in Hamam al-Alil, near Mosul, killing "at least seven people".
Comments: Because the report states that the missile was believed to have targeted allied warplanes, I code the killings as unintentional and as collateral damage.

Description: Sudan's foreign minister said Wednesday that fewer than 5,000 people have died in the country's war-torn Darfur region, far short of a UN estimate of 30,000 to 50,000 dead. "Those who are saying 30,000 or 50,000, we are telling them, 'Tell us the names'," Mustafa Osman Ismail told a press conference. "Show us the graves where these people have been buried." The estimate fell far short of one made earlier in Tokyo by UN High Commissioner for Refugees Ruud Lubbers. He said 30,000 to 50,000 people had been killed since fighting began in February 2003 between anti-government rebels, militias, government forces, and what is known as Sudan's proxy Arab militia, the Janjaweed.
Secondary.Source: UN High Commissioner for Refugees Ruud Lubbers
Contesting.Source: Sudan's foreign minister Mustafa Osman Ismail

Description: Government helicopter gunships attacked a rebel-held Ivory Coast town, killing 20 civilians and injuring many others, a rebel leader said Sunday. Sgt. Felix Doh, leader of a rebel faction in western Ivory Coast, said his forces were attacked in Bin-Houye, a border town 320 miles northwest of the commercial capital, Abidjan. Ivory Coast government officials confirmed fighting took place in the town, but said rebels attacked loyalist forces first. The claim of civilian casualties could not immediately be verified.
Comments: The civilian deaths could not be verified and the details of the incident are in dispute.  Rebels claim that helicopters attacked and killed 20 civilians, while government forces claim that they were simply responding to an attack, which would make the unverified victims collateral damage.

Description: Israeli tanks and armoured personnel carriers entered the El Bureij refugee camp in the Gaza Strip; eight Palestinians were killed and 35 were wounded--"It was not known if they were armed."
Comments: Because the report explicitly says that "it was not known if they [casualties] were armed" but their noncombatant status is not explicitly contested either, I code it as not contested but code the death toll as "Range Reported" to capture the ambiguity that at least some of the casualties might have been combatants. Note that one of the articles update the death toll from seven to eight.

Description: Israeli forces staged an incursion into the Jabalya refugee camp in the Gaza Strip with tanks and helicopter gunships, killing 15 Palestinians and wounding "dozens" others; most of the people were killed when tanks fired "flechette shells" which are "anti-personnel weapons which spray hundreds of tiny darts in all directions" and some others were killed when their houses were hit by helicopter rockets.
Comments: I code the death count and victims' noncombatant status as contested because of the following statement: "An Israeli army spokesman said only one flechette was fired when a soldier spotted a Palestinian about to launch a rocket, but witnesses charged the shell was deliberately aimed at a group of civilians that included children." As a result, intent is also coded as unclear.

Description: Oil giant Shell evacuated four oil facilities Monday, joining ChevronTexaco in a massive pullout from the Niger Delta, where ethnic violence has killed scores and razed entire villages. Ijaw activists, meanwhile, accused Nigeria's military of attacking and firing indiscriminately on residents in three villages, killing 10 people. Military officials denied the allegations. At least 90 people were reported killed since March 12, when ethnic fighting between Ijaw and Itsekiris drew in the army.
Comments: See linked events.  This code consolidates the other linked incidents into a campaign format, but the specific details are hazy.

Description: Israeli troops backed by helicopter gunships, with armored vehicles and bulldozers, staged a raid in the Nusseirat refugee camp in southern Gaza Strip; 7 people, two of them children, ended up dead and 12 wounded.
Comments: Palestinian security forces and hospital sources are cited for information about the casualties. Although they are not explicitly identified as noncombatants, a number of them are specifically identified as getting killed when their houses were demolished; since there was no specific target mentioned in the article, I assume that the attack was applied arbitrarily against the people in the area and since it should have been known to the perpetrators that demolishing buildings with people inside will cause casualties, I assume that the killings were intentional and that the casualties were noncombatants (there is no indication to the contrary). Note that one of the articles updates the death toll from five to seven.

Description: "Brig. Gen. Kale Kaihura, a senior Ugandan officer in the region, said all the warring groups in Ituri signed the cease-fire except the rebel Union of Congolese Patriots, or UPC, which said 45 civilians were killed Tuesday during fighting between its forces and Ugandan troops.  The UPC refused to sign because it accused Ugandan troops of continuing to attack its positions, said UPC leader Thomas Lubanga.  Lubanga said the civilians were killed during fighting between the UPC and Ugandan troops in Fataki, 65 kilometers northwest of Bunia, Ituri's main town where the cease-fire was signed."
Comments: It is unclear what type of weapons were used in these killings.  The killings were made known when the UPC declined to sign a ceasefire agreement with the government troops.  Upon refusing this request, the UPC claimed that 45 civilians were killed in the battle.  There are two perpetrators in this event, both combatants in this battle are listed because it is unclear from the lead as to who was killed by whom.  Additionally, this code is an allegation because the government has made no statement on the matter and it has not been independently verified.

Description: Weary and frightened villagers straggling in from the bush in western Ivory Coast tell of dozens of killings and wanton abuses after a surge of fighting that has soured hopes of peace. The involvement of warring Liberian tribes, inured to atrocities by years of bloodshed at home, has made an armed rebellion in this corner of the West African country even more savage and tangled. It is hard to get a precise toll for recent deaths from the accounts of those limping into the French-protected town of Duekoue - two women shot by the road here, five people killed there, another nine at a cocoa farmer's camp in the bush. "They killed 20 people last Wednesday. They just came and killed them. Women, old people, they killed them," planter Cesar Zrho, from a village north of Duekoue, said on Sunday.
Comments: This is a broadly worded report with few specifics. The alleged perpetrators include Liberian tribes, CIV rebels and CIV military.  Whether or not the victims are simply caught in the cross-fire of a civil war is not for certain, but the eye-witness accounts imply that civilians were often the targets.

Description: "The Rwandan army and a Kigali-backed rebel group have been carrying out 'systematic massacres' in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo since the beginning of the month, witnesses have said.  'Forces of the (rebel) Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD), backed by the Rwandan army raided the village of Burhale on April 13, and torched the houses some with their inhabitants still inside,' civil society group Reseau France Congo reported....  The witnesses, who survived the attack, said the rebels 'pillaged the health centre, the school and the parish church.'  Other witnesses said 'massacres of civilians had been carried out by Rwandan troops and the RCD in several towns in the Walungu area', in Sud-Kivu province."
Comments: There are two perpetrators listed in this case because the Rwandan army and its allied rebel group, the RCD, are accused of carrying out these systematic massacres.  The event here is contested because in the second report, the Rwandan government whole-heartedly denies that the killings ever took place.  There was no number of dead reported.  The weapons used were primitive and firearms because there were reports of shooting and the burning of occupied dwellings.  The scorched earth tactics coded here are the burning of homes.  The account of the killings alleges that the killings have been going on "since the beginning of the month" so the dates for this campaign are April 1 to the dateline of the lead.  The news article that prompted this code includes anecdotal accounts of some of the killings, but not a comprehensive list, so some of the details (like location) have been omitted from this code because it would not be representative of the whole event.  This said, the attacks seem to have been localized in Sud-Kivu province, so that is included in the code.

Description: "Representatives of the Hema ethnic group said late on Friday Lendu fighters had killed several hundred civilians in a village near Bunia, the capital of Ituri District, which lies 80 km from the border with Uganda.  The Commander of the Ugandan army in Congo, Brigadier Kale Kaihura confirmed his men had received reports of the massacre."  "Thomas Lubanga, head of the rebel Union of Congolese Patriots, or UPC, said 942 people were killed Thursday and Friday during raids by soldiers from neighboring Uganda and allied Lendu tribal fighters seeking to kill him, four weeks after they drove him and his group from Bunia, capital of restive Ituri province.  He said most of the victims were killed Thursday during a dawn raid on Largu, some 40 kilometers north of Bunia, where Lubanga was in hiding with dozens of his fighters.  Others were killed at the nearby Roman Catholic mission at Drodro and in the town of Bulkwa.  'The Ugandans started shelling the town (Largu) with mortars and rocket-propelled grenades at 6 in the morning, before soldiers and Lendu militia moved in one hour later,' Lubanga said by satellite telephone from an undisclosed location in northeastern Congo.  'They went from house to house, shooting people, hacking others to death and setting homes on fire ... This went on for hours."
Secondary.Source: tribal representatives, foreign military spokesman, rebel leader
Comments: The exact death count and weapons used in this killing are unavailable, though I interpreted the phrase "several hundred" deaths to indicate 100-999 deaths.  The date is also likely inaccurate.  This date corresponds to the date of the Hema allegation, and is the best indicator of the time of the massacre, though it is possible a multi-day event that happened just prior to this allegation.  A later AP report cites 942 deaths during the two days coded.  In this later report, the perpetrators are identified as Ugandan forces and their allied Lendu fighters; this lead also indicates that primitive weapons, firearms, and heavy weapons were used in the raids.  Also the burning of homes registers here as the use of scorched earth tactics.  An even later AP report cites the UN total of 966 dead.  Later UN totals cite 150-350 dead, but the original eyewitness accounts remain the totals coded here.  Later reports indicate that cannibalism was involved in this massacre (this was coded in the "other tactics" category).

Description: Government and rebel forces battled in Ivory Coast's western borderlands on Monday, days after the insurgents' first participation in a unity government meant to end the west African nation's civil war. Some 60 civilians died in recent days when government helicopter gunships attacked the insurgent-held town of Bin-Houye, near Ivory Coast's border with war-riven Liberia, rebel leader Felix Doh said by satellite telephone. Government spokesman N'Goran Aka said no civilians had died in the fighting, which Aka said continued Monday after rebels advanced Saturday against loyalist positions. "They attacked us, and we reacted with the arms at our disposition," said Aka, who said an unspecified number of government troops had suffered light injuries. Rebels "are all dressed in civilian clothes ... So when their soldiers are killed, they claim we killed civilians. It's not true. (Any dead) were combatants." Neither account could be independently verified.
Comments: Hefty allegations from both sides; it is impossible to discern who gives a truthful account.  That is why this event is coded as a rumor/allegation.

Description: Ivory Coast rebels accused the army of killing 15 civilians in a helicopter raid on a rebel base on Tuesday, a day after international peace monitors urged the grounding of the gunships. An army spokesman said he knew nothing of any strike on Danane, but he accused the rebels of attacking loyalist positions nearby and said the forces would use all means at their disposal to defend themselves. "We are still counting the casualties but there are 15 dead. They are civilians," said Bamba. He did not say if rebel fighters were also killed. If proved true, the attack would certainly deal another blow to a French-brokered peace agreement for the world's top cocoa producer - which brought rebel ministers into a power-sharing government last week after repeated false starts. There was no independent confirmation from the isolated region, where the conflict has been exacerbated by links to Liberia's civil war. Liberians, hardened by years of killing, rape and pillage, fight on both sides.
Comments: The rebels have alleged that this attack took place, but the CIV army has vehemently denied any knowledge of fighting in the area.  It is unclear whether Liberian mercenaries were involved, or if the alleged attack was provoked and civilian casualties could be considered collateral damage.

Description: Ivory Coast rebels said on Tuesday that government combat helicopters were continuing to attack western rebel-controlled areas, killing nine people, despite a promise by President Laurent Gbagbo to ground the aircraft following a peace accord. The Ivory Coast Patriotic Movement (MPCI), the country's largest rebel movement, said in a statement government helicopter gunships had killed six people on Tuesday and three on Monday in the towns of Zouan-Hounien, Danane and Mahapleu, all close to Ivory Coast's border with Liberia. The spokesman for Ivory Coast's Chief of Staff, Lieutenant Colonel N'Goran Aka, rejected the rebel accusations and told AFP the combat helicopters had not taken off on either Monday or Tuesday.
