But a French military official told AFP on Monday he had seen government helicopters flying to the west, and an informed source, who declined to be identified, said on Tuesday army gunships were seen in the west.
Comments: This event has been denied by the alleged perpetrators; therefore, the incident was coded as a rumour/allegation.

Description: West African peacekeepers headed to rebel-held territory in western Ivory Coast on Friday to investigate reports of fighting and claims that government helicopters bombarded a market, killing and wounding civilians. Rebel claims that Mi-24 helicopters have repeatedly bombed their positions this week have cast a shadow over the creation of a power-sharing government, including rebel ministers, meant to end a seven-month civil war in the former French colony. A spokesman for the regional peacekeeping force said a team was in the western town of Vavoua, where rebels say 10 civilians and one insurgent were killed in a helicopter raid on Wednesday. Aid workers said they knew of at least one death there.
Comments: This event is an allegation that has not been confirmed by an independent agency.  One death was confirmed by an aid worker, but rebels claim that 10 civilians fell victim to the government attack.

Description: Nigerian security forces accompanying ruling party politicians killed six opposition supporters in a polling day attack Saturday in a Niger Delta village, South African election monitors said. Derrick Marco of the Institute of Democracy in South Africa (IDASA) said that his monitors had confirmed that six people had been killed and five injured in the attack in Oporoma village, Bayelsa State. Another IDASA official told AFP that security personnel accompanying the Bayelsa State justice minister, a member of President Olusegun Obasanjo's ruling party, had opened fire on opposition youth supporters.
Comments: See linked events for more information about election violence in Nigeria.

Description: Opposition leaders in Adikpo, a sleepy market town in central Benue state, said 18 of their supporters were gunned down by soldiers as Nigerians went to the polls to cast ballots in presidential and state elections. "It was a deliberate execution because the government is brutal, primitive and blood thirsty," said Paul Unongo, the Benue state governorship candidate of the main opposition All Nigeria Peoples (ANPP) for Benue. The army acknowledged on Thursday that soldiers killed four people Saturday in Adikpo. But a spokesman said they acted in self defence, denying opposition charges of an unprovoked massacre.  Police told Reuters eight people were killed. "If they had not started throwing stones the soldiers would not have fired," Onwuamaegbu said. "We've had too many of our soldiers killed because we adopted a less aggressive posture."
Comments: The soldiers and police allegedly responsible for killing up to 18 people have denied that the attack was unprovoked and claim that only 4 people died in the incident. Had the victims been engaged in stone throwing and blocking the ballot boxes, then that could be considered combatant behavior and the event would not be codeable.

Description: Soldiers loyal to former Liberian President Charles Taylor massacred 369 civilians last year in three southeastern villages, accusing them of supporting rebels in the area, the country's human rights commission said Saturday. The killings in April 2003 were allegedly ordered by the former commander in the region, William Sumo, the report said. Sumo's whereabouts are not known, but he is believed to be in Liberia. Defense Minister Daniel Chea, who held the same post under Taylor, described the report as "hard to believe." Quoting witnesses and survivors, the commission said the massacres took place after villagers and local chiefs expressed opposition to a 27-vehicle convoy that was carrying weapons and Liberian government soldiers to neighboring Ivory Coast to support a rebel faction in that country's civil war. Dempster said that after the convoy entered Ivory Coast, Sumo returned to the three villages and "accused them of supporting rebels that were attacking the (former) government of Liberia. This lead to mass arrests ... followed by executions." "Fifty-three people were executed in Yubor, 100 were executed in River Gbeh, and the rest, 216, were executed in Tuobo Gbaweleken," the report said.
Secondary.Source: Independent National Commission on Human Rights
Comments: AP presents this report from Liberia's human right's commission as established fact, the only voice of dissent is a defense minister who also worked under Taylor, who describes the report as "hard to believe," yet never actually contests the occurrence of the event.  The victims were explicitly described as civilians, targeted by soldiers for opposing the movement of a convoy through their region.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 08/18/2004 that, according to "a report by the [Indonesian] military [on] a major anti-guerrilla operation [launched] in May 2003", "147 civilians lost their lives and 155 others were wounded" during the operation; reportedly, the military report did not "[apportion] blame for the civilian casualties"

The Associated Press reported on 08/28/2004 that "human rights groups accuse the [Indonesian] military of operating death squads in the province [Aceh], and claim many of the victims killed are civilians"; reportedly, "Jakarta launched a fresh offensive in May 2003 and imposed martial law... troops have since killed more than 2,000 alleged rebels, most of them unarmed, army figures show"

Israeli forces backed by helicopter gunships staged an incursion into the Shijaia neighborhood outside of Gaza City, killing twelve Palestinians while looking for a Hamas militant and demolishing his family home. According to residents of the neighborhood and witnesses, six of the dead were civilians, including children, and six others were militants.
Comments: Although the identity of six of the victims as civilians is reported by witnesses and area residents, Israeli sources does not deny this (at least it is not mentioned in this article), hence I code six as noncombatant-status-asserted civilians. Although the report says that the Israeli forces at the time were after a Hamas militant, there is not enough information to say that the civilians were killed by accident in this pursuit and that they were collateral damage.

Description: The Ogele Club, an Ijaw cultural and political organisation, said in a statement: "Nigerian army and navy oil warriors deployed to defend Chevron, Shell and other oil companies... opened fire on civilians, killing 12 and injuring 18 others in Warri and the Ogbogbene community." But an eyewitness told Reuters Ijaw militants attacked a naval base in the oil city of Warri on Friday, contradicting Ijaw activist accounts that they were simply holding peaceful protests. The eyewitness, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the violence began on Friday morning when Ijaw militants arrived in 10 speedboats and attacked soldiers and marines at a port in Warri. Army spokesman Emeka Omeamegwa denied soldiers had clashed with Ijaws at all. A navy spokesman said he could not yet comment on the matter.
Comments: These allegations have not been verified, the army denies any involvement and eyewitnesses claim that the Ijaw were engaged in violent behavior leading up to the incident.  See linked event for related information.

Description: "Fighting between Burundi's army and Hutu rebels has uprooted 12,000 people in recent days, swelling a near half a million-strong population of homeless and needy in the tiny African country, officials said on Thursday.  The Tutsi-dominated army has said it has killed about 100 Hutu rebels since it began an offensive in northwest Bubanza province on May 5 against the Hutu Forces for the Defence of Democracy (FDD), the main rebel group in a decade-old civil war.  The FDD, fighting to end the political dominance of minority Tutsis in the country of 6.5 million, denies it lost fighters in the clashes and said any dead were civilians killed by the army."
Comments: This code is considered a "Rumor/Allegation" because the alleged perpetrators deny that civilians were killed in this campaign, claiming that they killed about 100 Hutu rebels during the offensive.  The Hutu Forces for the Defence of Democracy (FDD) denies these claims saying that the Tutsis have not killed and FDD fighters, but only civilians.  The report backs neither side of the story, so I coded the accusation and denial here.

Description: Six people were killed and nine others were wounded Wednesday when the Indian army shelled border villages in Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, officials said.
Comments: A Pakistani administration official alleged the jeep had been targeted by the Indian troops who had been observing it.

Description: "The army killed 23 Hutu rebels during fighting in central Burundi, a spokesman said Monday, but the insurgents claimed the dead were civilians.  The Hutus, were killed in Sunday fighting along the border between the provinces of Gitega and Mwaro, army spokesman Serge Nizigama said.  Gelase Ndabirabe, a spokesman for the rebel Forces for the Defense of Democracy, or FDD, said the victims were civilian men and boys rounded up by the army.  It was impossible to verify either claim."
Comments: This event includes an accusation on the part of the FDD that the army did not in fact kill rebels in this attack, but rounded up civilian Hutu males and massacred them.  The news article does not verify either side of the story, and the codes here indicate the rebel accusation, noting the contestation on behalf of the Burundian army.

Description: "At least 100 people have been massacred in northeast Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) at the lower tip of Lake Albert, Ugandan army sources said.  The attack, which reportedly happened on Saturday, could not be immediately verified by independent sources.  'The Lendus attacked the Hemas in Kyomya, about 30 kilometres from the Ugandan border, when they realised that withdrawing Ugandan forces - stuck there due to heavy rains - had finally withdrawn,' Brigadier Kale Kaihura told AFP."
Comments: The deaths recorded in this AFP lead were given in a range ("at least 100," but this number was later upped to "nearly 350.").  There was no indication as to what weapons were used in the killings.  The intent here is asserted because the Lendus attacked the Hemas in Kyomya once the Ugandan forces had vacated the area.  A day later, Reuters reported that the Lendus killed "352 civilians" at Tchomia, which is in the same area as Kyomya, indicating that this is a second report on the same event.  The AP cited "at least 100" dead.  While the incident ahs been blamed on Lendu fighters, there have been reports that Congolese government troops were involved in these massacres as well.

Description: "At least 146 people were killed and 88 others injured in northern Uganda last month, as fighting continued to rage there between Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels and government forces, an army spokesman said on Tuesday.  'Fifty-seven LRA rebels were killed, along with 81 civilians and eight of our soldiers during battles in the region,' Lieutenant Paddy Ankunda told AFP by telephone from the northern town of Gulu.  Ankunda said 77 civilians and 11 government soldiers were also injured.  He said some of the slain civilians were either hacked to death or killed during rebel raids or ambushes, or caught in crossfire."
Comments: These killings were reported in a single news article that counted all deaths during the month of June.  The civilian deaths documented here indicate the number of civilians killed either in LRA raids or in the crossfire of fights between the LRA and Ugandan soldiers.  Both are coded as perpetrators, and the two intent categories coded indicate these two options as well (LRA raids = intent asserted, crossfire killings = killing deliberate but noncombatants not intentionally targeted).

Description: A military spokesman in Pakistani Kashmir accused Indian forces of opening fire on a jeep carrying civilians in the Neelam Valley, 90 km (56 miles) northeast of Muzaffarabad, capital of Pakistani Kashmir killing 9 and injuring 6 others.
Comments: Indian officials said the exchange of fire had not been heavy enough to cause such casualties saying the exchange of fire had been routine.

Description: A heavy exchange of artillery and mortar fire between Indian and Pakistani soldiers on Thursday killed at least five civilians and wounded another four on the Indian side of Kashmir, the army said.
Comments: The victims appeared to be random as the artillery rounds hit a house and a truck with no apparent deliberate motive.

Description: In the narrow muddy lanes of the camp, dotted with straw huts, residents are still traumatised by the recent upsurge in fighting between Liberian rebels who besieged the capital city of Monrovia and government forces. 11 people have been killed and another 24 injured.
Comments: This is not a case of collateral damage; government troops on their way to Monrovia began shooting refugees in a camp and raping women and girls as young as five.

Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: a senior Hamas militant and his family
Description: An Israeli missile strike targeting Hamas leaders in the Gaza Strip killed seven people, including a senior Hamas militant, his wife, and his toddler daughter, as well as bystanders, and wounded more than 40 others. "An Israeli security source said the missile strike followed a Defence Ministry order for the army "to use everything they have" against the Islamic militant group Hamas."
Comments: Even though the actual target was a senior Hamas militant, there is no indication that he was armed and able to defend himself at the time, so I code him as "unarmed combatant". Although the report does not explicitly identify four people other than the Hamas person and his family, there is also no indication that they were combatants. Furthermore, the report explicitly mentions that "more than 40 bystanders" were injured in the incident, so I assume that the four remaining dead were also bystanders. I still code the death count as "range reported" to leave room for this ambiguity. Because the Israeli security forces are cited as saying "the missile strike followed a Defence Ministry order for the army "to use everything they have" against the Islamic militant group Hamas", I code the killings as "intent asserted".

Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: MASSOB (Movement for the Actualisation of the Sovereign State of Biafra
Description: A militant group seeking a separate state for the ethnic Ibo people of southeastern Nigeria claimed Tuesday that police shot dead 17 of its members.
Comments: This allegation has not yet been verified, and the police vehemently deny that they targeted this group.  They claim that it was a raid on armed robbers and that only one was killed.

Victim.Identity.Political: Protesters in a nation-wide, general strike
Description: Union organizer claims police have killed 10 protesters.  Police admit to killing four in one instance, and did not contest victims' noncombatant status, however, the official number of deaths is given as 8.

Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Lendu tribal fighters; Hema tribal fighters
Description: "More than 80 people, mostly civilians, were killed in fighting among rival tribal militias, rebels and government soldiers in troubled neighboring northeastern Congo, a spokesman for one of the militias said Thursday.  The fighting in Chomia on Tuesday began when Lendu tribal fighters along with Congolese soldiers and rebels tried to seize the town from a Hema tribal militia, said Kitembo Bitamara, a spokesman for the Hema group....  [A spokesman] said 54 civilians were killed by the attackers.  The Hema lost only three fighters but managed to kill 28 of the assailants, he said."
Comments: These 54 civilian deaths are assumed to be the result of the violence among the three perpetrators.  It is assumed that the deaths were purely a case of collateral damage, but the number of civilian deaths as compared to combatant deaths may suggest otherwise.  Nonetheless, they are coded as collateral damage because there is no evidence that the perpetrators aimed to kill the civilians as such.

Description: "n army helicopter gunship mistakenly fired on a group of people gathered to bury a person when it was pursuing rebels in northeastern Uganda, killing about nine civilians, the army spokesman said Friday.  The incident occurred Tuesday as the army pursued rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army, or LRA, across a river bordering Karachi and Lira districts, about 370 kilometers (230 miles) northeast of Kampala, said Maj. Shaban Bantariza.  'They (the civilians) were fired at accidentally. The pilot mistook them for a group of rebels who had been hiding in the area,' Bantariza said.
Comments: This was a case of mistaken identity, the military perpetrator thought that they were attacking a group of rebels instead of a group of civilians.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Burundian rebels (Forces for the Defence of Democracy - FDD)
Description: "Foreign rebels fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo have killed 11 Congolese aid workers taken hostage from a project backed by a British Christian agency, the United Nations said on Thursday.  The UN report said they were killed on July 24 by Hutu rebels from Burundi's Forces for the Defence of Democracy (FDD) and former Rwandan soldiers, also Hutus, who fled Rwanda after that country's 1994 genocide."
Comments: The victims were held hostage before they were killed, and there is no indication as to how the UN found out about their deaths.  These actions constitute the employment of kidnapping and disappearances by the perpetrators.

Description: Indian security forces shot dead five unarmed Bangladeshi civilians who were attempting to illegally cross the Pakistani/Indian border at Kanachak in Kashmir. The victims were shot around the time that Indian soldiers engaged in a gun battle with Islamic militants also trying to illegally cross the border, though at a different location - fighting which officials described as routine.

Region: State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir
Description: Six Pakistani civilians were killed when artillery shells hit the town of Hajira. The Indian shells originated from cross-border fire between Pakistan and Indian troops in the disputed Kashmir region. This type of cross-border fighting was reportedly common in the region. An additional fifteen Pakistanis were injured in the attack.
Comments: The report did not specify that the artillery shell which killed the Pakistani civilians was Indian in origin. I have inferred from the reports assertion that the two countries traded fire across their border that the shell in question, which hit on the Pakistani side of the border, was Indian in origin.

Description: "Sudanese rebels accused pro-government militias Monday of killing some 300 civilians in Kuttum, the second largest town in North Darfur state.  'We call on international organisations to investigate what happened in Kuttum,' Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) Secretary General Mani Arkoi Minawi told AFP here by telephone.  Minawi charged that some 350 pro-government militiamen entered Kuttum on August 5 after the SLM pulled out of the town....  'They burnt and destroyed houses and shops,' added the rebel chief, who said he was speaking from an area near Kuttum."
Comments: The scorched earth tactics involved with this incident include the burning of homes and businesses in the town of Kuttum.  The weapons used in this lead were at least primitive weapons (fire), but there were likely firearms and possibly heavy weapons used as well, even though there is no mention of these in the article.

Region: State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir
Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: "five people including two women and two children"
Description: Five people were killed and six injured in Pakistani Kashmir when Indian forces fired mortars over a military line dividing the disputed region. The deaths were the most recent in a string of victims killed by Indian shellings in the on-going dispute for the Kashmir region.

"Sudanese rebels accused government forces Tuesday of having killed 46 civilians and destroyed 500 villages in North Darfur state, in the west of the country.  'Antonov planes bombarded on Sunday and Monday the city of Kornoy, at the extreme west of North Darfur, killing 46 people, including children, women and elderly,' said Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) Secretary General Mani Arkoi Minawi.
Comments: Heavy weapons were coded because Antonov planes bombarded the targets during this raid.  Scorched earth tactics were coded here because as a result of these bombings, over 500 villages were destroyed.

Region: State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir
Locality: Til Mera, Palani, Hatli Inderla Nar, Sihala Morha
Description: Six people - five women and one infant - were killed and six injured in Pakistani Kashmir when Indian forces fired mortars over the military Line of Control (LoC), which divides the disputed region. Pakistani authorities stated that the attack was unprovoked. The deaths were the most recent in a string of victims killed by Indian shellings in the on-going dispute for the Kashmir region.

"The rebel movement in western Sudan charged Sunday that pro-government militias had killed 81 civilians in the past two days as well having 'systematically violated' an eight-day truce.  In a telephone call to AFP in Cairo, Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) secretary general Mani Arkoi Minawi accused the Sudanese government of having 'systematically and daily violated the truce' since it took effect September 6.  Seventy-five civilians were killed Friday when militiamen allied to the government launched an attack against residents of Khashaba, in the north of Kuttum province, Minawi said.  Sixteen shepherds were killed Saturday when pro-government militiamen launched another attack in the area of Abu Leiha, he added."
Comments: This campaign is actually the combination of two related incidents that were reported simultaneously.

Description: The toll from Bolivia's civil unrest reached five dead and more than 50 wounded Sunday, after troops fired on anti-government protesters near the capital and the government accused opposition leaders of trying to mount a coup (AFP-AFPR000020031013dzac00004).
Citation:
Agence France-Presse 12 October 2003 AFPR000020031013dzac00004
Reuters News 13 October 2003 LBA0000020031013dzad00166
Agence France-Presse 14 October 2003 AFPR000020031014dzae001n3
Agence France-Presse 15 October 2003 AFPR000020031015dzaf001hd
Associated Press Newswires 15 October 2003 APRS000020031015dzaf0007t
Comments: AFP report on the 12th (AFPR000020031013dzac00004) was the first to indicate the death toll was greater than five.  Death toll both updated and disputed by later AFP reports and the NGO, The Assembly of Human Rights.  Noncombatant status indicated by death of five year old on October 11th otherwise generally indicated as "protesters."  Firearms were indicated as the primary weapons although "large caliber weapons, including heavy machine guns" were also indicated.  Some indications that specific individuals are being targeted.  Catholic church & other humanitarian organizations specifically refer to incidents as a "massacre."  Original protests started in La Paz area but later incidents extended state-wide.

Region: State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir
Description: Pakistan on Monday condemned as "unprovoked and senseless" Indian shelling which killed 12 people, including seven women and a three-year-old child living on the de facto border in disputed Kashmir.
Comments: The firing appeared indiscriminate across the India/Pakistan border, thus the victims appeared to be random.

Description: Soldiers killed 30 protesters in El Alto on Sunday and three others on Saturday.
Comments: Linked incident to uprising in Bolivia that started in September.  Single incident report of 30 casualties in El Alto.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Hutu rebels from the extremist forces for National Liberation (FNL)
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Hutu rebels from the extremist forces for National Liberation (FNL)
Description: "Six civilians and one policeman were killed in Burundi's northern suburb of Kinama, undermining a peace deal between the government and Hutu rebels, officials said on Tuesday.  Officials blamed the attack on Hutu rebels from the extremist Forces for National Liberation (FNL). They said the rebels ambushed two policemen riding a bicycle on Monday to grab their guns, killing one officer and injuring the other. Government soldiers patrolling the suburb pursued the rebels, prompting a heavy exchange of fire. Six bodies of civilians were discovered on Tuesday.
Comments: The civilian deaths coded here occurred when shots were exchanged between government forces and the rebel attackers.  It seems that the rebels intended to attack civilians, but there is no way to tell from the articles when the victims were killed.

Description: Citizens protested against closures and roadblocks.  Military troops were sent in to quell the protests, resulting in dozens of deaths.
Comments: Noncombatant status unclear

Description: Indian military artillery shells hit several houses and a police station late Monday in the Kamri and Mini Merg regions of Pakistan's Himalayan northern area, leaving seven people dead, said army spokesman Maj. Gen. Shaukat Sultan. One policeman was injured.
Comments: The firing appeared indiscriminate across the India/Pakistan border, thus the victims appeared to be random.

Description: Israeli warplanes and helicopter gunships struck Gaza Strip five times in one day, killing 10 Palestinians (two of them Hamas members) and wounding more than 100 people. Even some members of Sharon's government regretted the incidents, arguing "the failure to differentiate between civilians and terrorists turns all the Palestinians into potential suicide bombers."
Citation:
Reuters News: 10.21.2003, LBA0000020031021dzal002pz
By Matt Spetalnick
Comments: The death toll and the civilian/combatant break-up is reported by medics. Because even some of Sharon's own coalition partners were regretful about the killing of civilians in these incidents, I code "perpetrator regrets."

Region: State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir
Description: Pakistani and Indian troops traded mortar and artillery fire, killing five civilians and wounding at least eight others on Pakistan's side of divided Kashmir, officials said Wednesday.
Comments: The firing appeared indiscriminate across the India/Pakistan border, thus the victims appeared to be random.

Description: "Sudanese state forces and pro-government militia fighters killed more than 60 people on Saturday in two attacks in the west of the country, a rebel leader said on Sunday.  The Sudanese government and the western-based rebel group, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A), agreed a ceasefire in September, and extended it last week, to end fighting that began in February in the arid and poor western Darfur region.  'The government carried out two attacks against civilian areas yesterday (Saturday) in the Darfur region which killed dozens of people and made many thousands homeless,' Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur, an SLM/A leader, told Reuters."
Comments: The Sudanese forces and the pro-government militia coordinated this attack on villages in the Darfur region.

Description: Police fired rubber bullets at rock-throwing protesters Tuesday during a general strike that paralyzed the nation. Protest organizers said at least six people were killed and 60 injured.
Citation:
Associated Press Newswires 11 November 2003 APRS000020031111dzbb003xb
Agence France-Presse 11 November 2003 AFPR000020031111dzbb002bk
Comments: Killings took place in the cities of Santo Domingo and Santiago and the towns of Bonao, Higuey, and La Vega according to Ramon Perez Figueroa with the Council of Unified Transportation Workers Union.  Victims given as "rock-throwing protestors."  Intent unclear since although military fired upon the protestors it is noted that they used rubber bullets.  Police said they could not confirm any deaths or injuries.  AFP (AFPR000020031111dzbb002bk) reports only three dead.

Description: "The last rebel holdouts in Burundi clashed with government troops in a slum on the northern outskirts of Bujumbura, and 11 people, including a soldier, were killed, an official said Thursday.  The fighting began Wednesday when rebels from the National Liberation Forces, or FNL, moved into the Kinama neighborhood, 5 kilometers (3.1 miles) from downtown Bujumbura, and attacked a group of soldiers, killing one, said Jean Pierre Ntigarika, chief the city's northern district.  Seven civilians were caught in the crossfire and killed in the fighting that ensued, he said. The rebel also killed three members of a government militia known as the Peace Guardians."
Comments: The seven civilian deaths reported here are a result of collateral damage in a firefight between rebels and government troops.  Both of these combatants were coded as the perpetrators of this event, even though it is unclear as to which side actually killed the victims (it may have been both).

Description: "At least 10 civilians were killed Friday during a bombing raid by Sudanese government forces on villages and rebel positions in the country's troubled western Darfur region, a rebel official said.  The official from the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) accused the government of committing with the bombing attacks a 'flagrant violation of the ceasefire' that has been in place since September 3."
Comments: The heavy weapons used in this event were bombs used in a air raid over a handful of villages in the Darfur region.  The reuters report upped the death count to about 30 (but this report extended the campaign to include a ground raid).

Description: "Rebels from the west of Sudan said on Friday government air raids had killed 14 people in the poor arid region, in what they said the latest breach of a ceasefire agreement signed by both sides.  The rebel Sudan Liberation Army/Movement (SLA/M) emerged as a fighting force in the western Darfur region in February, accusing the Khartoum government of marginalising the area."
Comments: This campaign is a combination of two incidents, one bombing raid killed 6 people in north Darfur, and 8 people were killed in a raid in west Darfur.  In a later Reuters report the death toll was upped to 40 and 60 injured (AFP updated their report 47 dead and 37 injured).

Description: "At least 24 people, most of them women and children, were killed in a battle between government troops and rebel fighters in Burundi, a human rights group said Wednesday.  The battle between the Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebels from a faction of the National Liberation Front also left one government soldier dead on Monday, Pierre-Clavier Mbonimpa, chairman of the Organization for the Defense of Human and Prisoners' Rights, said."
Comments: The noncombatant death count in this code is questionable.  There were 24 deaths reported, and "most of them [were] women and children."  There was one confirmed combatant death included in this count so I listed 23 as the death count

Description: "A western Sudanese rebel group said on Thursday the Khartoum government had killed 25 civilians after launching an air raid in the poor Darfur region of Africa's largest country.  The Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), one of two main rebel groups that started a revolt in Darfur in February and accuse Khartoum of marginalising the area, said a plane bombed civilians for 15 minutes on Wednesday morning."

"Ethiopia's prime minister on Thursday dismissed a report that said the army had helped kill more than 1,000 people in ethnic murders in the west of the country, calling it a 'fiction' that had duped outsiders.  The Swiss-based World Organisation Against Torture (OMCT) said an estimated 1,137 people had been killed from December 13, 2003 to March 31 in the Gambella region with Ethiopian state forces backing highlanders attacking the Anuak ethnic group....  The OMCT said Ethiopian security forces had backed highlander militias in a campaign of systematic killings and mass rapes of the 100,000-strong Anuak community, driving thousands of refugees into neighbouring Sudan."
Comments: The killing campaign alleged in this code is categorically denied by the Ethiopian government.  The weapons were not specified, but the dates and death numbers were.  Mass rape was included in the accusations made against the perpetrators of this event.

Description: "A Sudanese politician said on Monday that Arab militias had killed 19 people and burned seven villages at the weekend in the western Darfur region.  Jafar Ismail also urged the government to stop an escalating conflict in Darfur, where two main rebel groups launched a revolt in February saying the Khartoum government marginalised the impoverished area.  Rebels accuse government forces of air raids and other attacks and say Khartoum has armed Arab militias to attack African tribes in the region, where tensions over scarce resources are rife."
Comments: the scorched earth tactics coded here are the burning of seven villages in Darfur.

Description: Six Palestinians--one of them a gunman according to Palestinian officials, while three of them gunmen according to Israeli troops--were killed and "at least 17 Palestinians" were wounded by Israeli soldiers during gun battles that occurred after they entered the Rafah refugee camp with armored vehicles.
Comments: I code the death count as contested because while the Palestinians report five of the six dead as civilians, Israeli military sources assert that they "believed they killed three gunmen."

Description: Police in Brazil killed thousands of people last year in the name of fighting crime and routinely tortured suspects in police stations, Amnesty International said on Wednesday.
Citation:
Reuters News 14 May 2004 LBA0000020040514e05e0000y
Reuters News 26 May 2004 LBA0000020040526e05q0033o
Reuters News 28 August 2003 lba0000020030828dz8s00vsu
Comments: Insufficient details given to list specific incidents so coded as campaign. Perps identified as police and reference made to "death squads."  Victims were identified only as "thousands of people."  Weapons used were not indicated.  Torture specifically listed as utilized tactic.  Police intent is unclear.  Report indicates that killings were "in the name of fighting crime" but do not indicate if they were incidental/deliberate or mixed.  Later note indicates police death squads used for "social cleaning" which would imply intent - but its unclear to what extent this applies to all the killings.  Reuters report (LBA0000020040514e05e0000y) indicates "many of these cases are executions."  First indicated in August 2003 Reuters story (lba0000020030828dz8s00vsu) - "Police killings in Rio soar."

Perp.State.Police: "corrupt police belonging to a death squad"
Perp.Non.State.Criminal: "a gang that murdered for hire twenty-five of the suspects were Parana state police, the rest were civilians linked to the gang"
Description: The Associated Press reported on 06/16/2005 that "federal agents launched a major operation in a southern state Thursday to arrest corrupt police belonging to a death squad that killed 30 people last year [2004] alone about 400 federal police were deployed around the southern city of Curitiba... to arrest 31 people accused of being involved in the gang that murdered for fire, stole cars and sold drugs"; reportedly, "twenty-five of the suspects were Parana state police, the rest were civilians linked to the gang"
Comments: It is unclear how best to code the Perp State Role in this case--reportedly, most of the perpetrators were "corrupt police belonging to a death squad", although reportedly a number of "civilians" were also involved in the "gang"

Description: The Associated Press reported on 03/04/2004 that "Red Cross officials are teaching Indian troops fighting separatists in the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir how to avoid human rights abuses following accusations that at least 17 people have died in their custody this year"; there were no further details about the deaths provided in the AP report
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Rumor/Allegation since the wording in the AP report seemed to express some doubt regarding the credibility of the secondary source's account (reportedly, "Red Cross officials are teaching Indian troops how to avoid human rights abuses following accusations that at least 17 people have died in their custody this year")

Description: The Associated Press reported on 11/04/2004 that, according to local police sources, "from January to October this year [2004], 600 civilians have been killed" in insurgency-racked Jammu-Kashmir; reportedly, "last year [2003] during the same period, 1,125 civilians... were killed, according to [IND] government statistics"

"Rebels in western Sudan on Saturday accused government forces of massacring civilians in a village in the remote Darfur region and called for urgent help for thousands of people uprooted by fighting.  The Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) said 200 civilians including children and elderly people were killed on Friday in an attack on Sorra village."
Comments: This is an unsubstantiated accusation of atrocity.  The Reuters report does not verify the accusation.  There is no identification of weapons used in this alleged atrocity.  The victims identified in the accusation are said to be civilians, so their noncombatant status is asserted and was not reportedly contested.  The seizures coded here include the fact that the government forces allegedly emptied towns of their inhabitants, who fled the violence.

Description: "Sudanese government planes have bombed the town of Tine in the western Darfur region, a diplomat in Chad said Tuesday.  'The bombardment comes after an ultimatum made a few days ago by the Sudanese authorities, demanding that the town of Tine be evacuated, failing which they would raze the town,' the diplomat said....  The rebel Movement for Justice and Equality (MJE), which controls Tine, confirmed in a statement that the Khartoum government had launched a bombing raid on the town and other areas in Darfur on Monday, killing 45 people, 'most of them children, women and the elderly....'  Personnel at the Sudanese embassy in Chad refused to confirm or deny the alleged bombing raids.  'If there were bombings, they would only target rebel sites and positions,' the embassy said, adding that 'no civilians live in Tine, only rebels.'"
Comments: The bombings here reported are not confirmed by the Sudanese government, and furthermore, Khartoum refuses to admit the killing of any civilians.  The Sudanese embassy said that "if there were bombings, they would only target rebel sites and positions no civilians live in Tine, only rebels."  Since the article does not indicate that only rebels live in Tine, the noncombatant status of the victims is coded as "contested" even though the article contains no explicit assertion that the residents were noncombatants. The vicitm identity in this case is tough to code.  On one hand, they could have been random residents of the town, but on the other hand, they probably were politically targeted because of the circumstances surrounding the bombing.  Prior to the alleged bombings, the government warned the residents of the region to evacuate.  This indicates that the government prepared to bomb for a specific reason, namely to kill rebels.  Presumably there would be a political gain in doing so, and even if civilians did die in the meantime, there would have been political gain (e.g. the government is "tough on rebels.")  Therefore, the vicitms are coded as both "random/unclear/other" and "political."  Also, for these reasons, I have chosen to code any noncombatant deaths as "collateral damage."  The intent is coded as "intent apparent but not asserted" over "killing deliberate, but victims not intentionally targeted" because it is obvious that the possibility of "collateral" deaths existed in this instance.  Later Reuters and AFP reports confirm that the bombing did occur.

Description: Eleven people, including nine rebels, were killed in the province on Wednesday, said military spokesman Sapari, while three guerrillas were captured. GAM commander for the East Aceh region Daud said most of the 11 killed on Wednesday were civilians and not rebels.
Comments: The military implicitly denies the killed as civilians by reporting that 9 of the 11 killed were rebels (with no report on the ID of the other 2), while the GAM claims "most" "were civilians and not rebels".

Description: "Sudanese government forces on Thursday bombed the Chadian side of the border town of Tine, killing several civilians as the regained control of the Sudanese half of the city in the strife-torn Darfur region.  The bombing was the first incident on the Chadian side of the border since the Sudanese military started air attacks on positions of rebels who have been fighting the government in Khartoum since February 2003.  A source close to the Chadian army told AFP that 10 civilians were killed and 16 injured in the bombing at 10:00 am (0900 GMT).  However the regional coordinator for the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in Tine, Yvan Sturm, said that two civilians were killed and 15 injured in the attack.
Comments: This is the same event as the previous code (BNL 0317 01), but a few details differ.  For instance, this AFP report cites two different death and injured counts; one identical to the previous code, and another that cites 10 dead and 16 wounded.  The AFP report also asserts the noncombatant status of the victims by naming them civilians.  Because the AFP report agrees with both death counts, it is cited in both codes.

Description: "Sudanese forces and pro-government militia have burned several villages and killed more than 175 civilians in west Sudan in recent attacks during an ongoing government offensive, a rebel official said on Sunday.  Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur, chairman of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army (SLA),... said more than 100 civilians were also killed on Saturday when five villages were torched in the Jebel Moon area, northeast of Geneina.
Secondary.Source: SLA chairman Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur
Comments: This event was reported in the same lead as the linked event.  They happened on the same day, but were reported separately and with separate death counts.  The death estimate is approximate therefore it is coded as a range.  The "Scorched Earth" tactic employed in these killings is the reported burning of the victim's homes.  In the same vein, the weapon used is "primitive" because the only means reported is fire.

Description: "Sudanese forces and pro-government militia have burned several villages and killed more than 175 civilians in west Sudan in recent attacks during an ongoing government offensive, a rebel official said on Sunday.  Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur, chairman of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army (SLA),... told Reuters four villages were burned and more than 75 civilians killed in government-led attacks on Saturday in the area of west Jebel Marra, about 200 km (125 miles) east of Geneina."
Secondary.Source: SLA chairman Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur
Comments: This event was reported in the same lead as the linked event.  They happened on the same day, but were reported separately and with separate death counts.  The death estimate is approximate therefore it is coded as a range.  The "Scorched Earth" tactic employed in these killings is the reported burning of the victim's homes.  In the same vein, the weapon used is "primitive" because the only means reported is fire.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 02/08/2004 that, according to an Indian "army spokesman", "five civilians died in a three-day raid by the Indian army on a suspected rebel hideout in Kashmir"; reportedly, the spokesman said "the civilians were porters hired by the army who died in the crossfire"; reportedly, however, "residents of the closest town, Bandipore, alleged that the five dead were among some 25 civilians taken as human shields by the army"
Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the two secondary sources cited in the AFP report disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided by the two secondary sources could not be accommodated in a single record (the AFP report did not indicate which account of the event it considered more credible)

Description: The AFP report told that "Indian army personnel found guilty of using five civilians as human shields during a gunfight with Muslim rebels in Kashmir have been punished, a senior minister said Tuesday. The five civilians were killed in the February 8 firefight near the northern town of Bandipora, sparking massive anti-government protests and threats by moderate separatists to pull out of talks with the Indian government."

"Amnesty International said Wednesday it had received reports of 'horrifying attacks' against civilians in western Sudan by government forces fighting a yearlong rebellion.  The London-based human rights group said it had information that government-backed militias attacked five villages in southern Darfur on Feb. 11, killing between 68 and 80 civilians.  Between Feb. 10 and Feb. 12, government aircraft also bombed 11 towns and villages in west Darfur, while pro-government militia killed people fleeing their homes, including an Islamic preacher, Amnesty said in a statement.  Government soldiers also allegedly abducted 30 girls in an attack in west Darfur last week, Amnesty said.
Comments: The perpetrators in this case are "government warplanes" and "government-backed militias" that carried out air and ground raids on these "civilians" in western Sudan over three days.  The weapons included bombs dropped from warplanes and firearms on the ground.  The range of deaths reported by both AFP and Amnesty was 68-80.  The alleged kidnapping of 30 girls by government forces "last week" is included in this code because it seems to be related to this campaign although no date was given.

Perp.State.Other: "former interior minister under ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide"
Description: Associated Press wrote "Haiti's former interior minister under ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was charged Monday in connection with killing political opponents last year, officials said.  Privert, who had been held for a year without charges, was taken to St. Marc, the town on Haiti's west coast where he allegedly helped orchestrate killings of Aristide opponents during last year's uprising that led to Aristide's ouster in February 2004 and his exile to South Africa. The number of people killed in St. Marc on Feb. 11, 2004, and the circumstances, have been disputed. On April 7, a U.N expert on human rights said that he had a list of 25 people killed, while others say up to 60 died. The details of how Privert was charged weren't disclosed."
Comments: Not really clear how the incident occurred (if it is only an accusation), and who were the perpetrators.

Description: Egyptian security forces attacked the southern town of Nakhalia on the Nile, where a big family convicted of criminal activities, including vendetta killings, took as hostage 80-250 civilians living in the area. The attack came days after the security forces have been holding the town under siege, which reportedly resulted in food shortages. In addition to the arrest of a number of family members, the attack also killed 20 and injured 30 of civilian who were being held hostage, according to what a family/clan member told Reuters.
Citation: Reuters News: 02.28.2004, LBA0000020040228e02s008ho; Associated Press Newswires: 02.28.2004, APRS000020040228e02s004mr
Comments: The two sources cited here do not contradict each other. Reuters, however, quotes a named family/clan member regarding the number of casualties that resulted from the attack, while Associated Press simply reports that "some of the estimated 80 hostages are feared dead". Because the Reuters report explicitly mentions that the casualties could not be independently confirmed either by them or by Egyptian officials, I code the event as a rumor/allegation. On the other hand, there is no indication that the particulars of the event, including the casualties, are specifically contested; they are simply not confirmed.

Description: The Associated Press reported on 02/28/2004 that, according to local officials, "Pakistani forces opened fire on a minibus Saturday [02/28/2004] when it failed to stop at a roadblock in a tribal region where anti-terrorism operations have been ongoing, killing at least 11 people"; reportedly, "the bus was filled mostly with Afghan refugees on their way to the border"; according to a local resident, "a taxi driving near the minibus was also hit, and the driver killed"; reportedly, "he [the local resident] said as many as 12 people were killed, and seven more injured in the incident" (a later AP report indicated that 13 people had been killed); Reuters reported that "at least 10 people were killed when Pakistani troops opened fire on a van they mistakenly believed was carrying Islamic militants"; a separate AP report indicated that a Pakistani "army spokesman" claimed that "the killings... occurred only after paramilitary forces were fired on" by "someone in the bus"--reportedly, residents disputed the army's claim, saying they were "outraged by the shootings" and that "innocent people were killed in this operation... it was a civilian vehicle and the army is at fault"; reportedly, Pakistani President Musharraf, in a "message to the bereaved families... expressed his 'profound grief and sorrow over the incident'"
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse, Associated Press, Reuters
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Secondary, Not Contested since the AFP, AP, and Reuters reports cited local officials and local residents and since the AFP, AP, and Reuters reports seemed to present the occurrence of the event, as described by the local officials and residents, as a fact (here and throughout, when I have encountered reports in which only one secondary account of a given event is offered, I have interpreted the lack of an expression of doubt regarding the credibility of the secondary source's account as tantamount to representing the occurrence of the event, as described by the secondary source, as a fact); Intent coded as Noncombatants Not Intentionally Targeted and Collateral Damage coded as Collateral Damage since the wording in the reports suggested that the incident was a case of mistaken identity (reportedly, "Pakistani troops opened fire on a van they mistakenly believed was carrying Islamic militants"); Regrets coded as Perpetrator Regrets since, reportedly, Pakistani President Musharraf sent a message to the bereaved families to express his "profound grief and sorrow over the incident"

Perp.Non.State.Religious: "suspected Sunni Muslim radicals", "outlawed Sunni group Lashkar-e-Jhangvi"
Victim.Identity.Religious: "people [taking part in] a parade by Shiite Muslims observing their holiest day"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 03/02/2004 that, according to local witnesses and hospital sources, "at least six people were killed when unidentified gunmen opened fire on a parade by Shiite Muslims observing their holiest day in southwest Pakistan Tuesday [03/02/2004]"; reportedly, "shots were fired into a procession by thousands of Shiites marking the holy day of Ashura in the busy Meezan Chowk area of central Quetta, the capital of southwest Baluchistan province"; reportedly, "a nurse at Civil Hospital in the city of Quetta" told AFP that "we have received six bodies and 20 to 25 injured, all of them with gunshot wounds"; a later Reuters report indicated that, according to local hospital sources, "at least 37 people were killed and more than 150 were wounded when suspected Sunni Muslim radicals attacked a procession of the rival Shi'ite community in southwestern Pakistan on Tuesday [03/02/2004]"; a later AFP report raised the death toll to 48; another, later AFP report indicated that "most of the killings were caused by police fire" when police began firing indiscriminately after "terrorists... opened fire and threw grenades on the procession"
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse, Associated Press, Reuters
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Secondary, Not Contested since the AFP and Reuters reports cited local witnesses, local government officials, and local hospital sources and since the AFP and Reuters reports seemed to present the occurrence of the event, as described by the local witnesses, local government officials, and local hospital sources, as a fact (here and throughout, when I have encountered reports in which only one secondary account of a given event is offered, I have interpreted the lack of an expression of doubt regarding the credibility of the secondary source's account as tantamount to representing the occurrence of the event, as described by the secondary source, as a fact)

Description: In Haiti, five people were killed while "peacefully" marching "through the capital to the palace gates" to call for a new government and army. Opponents of Aristide gathered outside the palace gates were shot by what witnesses claim were "chimeres," "the toughs Mr. Aristide has used to enforce his authority."

Government troops armed with automatic weapons opened fire on a village in the oil-rich Niger Delta this week, killing 51 people, a local activist group said Saturday. The military denied the claim. The alleged attack occurred at dawn Tuesday.
Comments: The military has denied this claim, but the local activist group and eyewitness accounts have been detail-rich.

Description: "Sudan's army bombed a town in the western Darfur region, killing six civilians and injuring 25, eyewitnesses said on Saturday, weeks after the government said major military operations were over in the area.  A resident of Sherya town, about 70 kilometres east of the Southern Darfur state capital Nyala, said that Antonov planes began bombarding the town on Friday evening and Arab militias known as 'Janjaweed' attacked at the same time."
Comments: This seems to be a coordinated attack by the Sudanese army and the "Janjaweed" or an Arab militia group.  At the same time, Sudanese planes bombed the Darfur town, and the militia stormed the town, looting and firing guns in the air.  The Janjaweed stole cattle and burned houses (scorched earth tactics).  Both of the perpetrators are listed, even though the air raid is considered the only weapon that actually killed any victims.

Description: Seven Colombian policemen and four civilians they had arrested were killed on Saturday when an army patrol confused them with Marxist rebels in one of the country's worst incidents of friendly fire, the police said.  Investigators are looking into all possibilities, including whether the platoon, the police unit, or both, were involved in criminal activities, a police official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. They also have no doubt that evidence at the scene of the shooting was tampered with before their arrival, the official said.
Citation:
Reuters News 20 March 2004 LBA0000020040320e03k00at0
Associated Press Newswires 09 April 2004 APRS000020040409e0490046g
Comments: Victims identified as Colombian policemen and four civilians under their custody.  Friendly fire incident implies perp regret.  Later report indicates location but also calls into question whether killings were deliberate.  State issued formal investigation indicating that the killings were in error though.

Description: Reuters reported on 03/20/2004 that, according to "a senior security official", "up to 13 civilians died in western Pakistan on Saturday [03/20/2004] when their vehicles were fired upon"; reportedly, "there were differing accounts and death tolls, with two officials saying a Pakistani army helicopter had been responsible for the attack in South Waziristan where troops have been battling al Qaeda and allied militants for days"; according to "a local security official", "12 people including women and children had been killed by an army helicopter hunting militants on Saturday afternoon... 'After the army received casualties the gunship helicopters were directed to hit the cars,' said the official"; however, "an army spokesman denied that civilians had been killed but said some people had been killed in an army attack early on Saturday when trying to escape through the army cordon... 'A number of people were killed there but they were those who were trying to escape... No innocent people have been killed'"
Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the secondary sources cited in the Reuters and AFP reports disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided could not be accommodated in a single record

Victim.Identity.Political: Hamas leader, Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, and his associates
Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: Hamas leader, Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, and his associates
Description: Hamas spiritual leader Sheikh Amed Yassin and seven other Palestinians with him were killed when an Israeli helicopter fired missiles on them as they were leaving a mosque in the Sabra neighborhood of Gaza City.
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse, Associated Press Newswires
Citation:
Agence France Presse: 03.22.2004, AFPR000020040322e03m0011c
by Sakher Abu El Oun; Associated Press Newswires: 03.22.2004, APRS000020040322e03m004sd
By IBRAHIM BARZAK
Comments: Witnesses and security forces are quoted. I code the perpetrator as approving the incident and the casualties given the following quote in the article: "While condemnation of the assassination poured in from around the world, Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon congratulated his armed forces on their deadly dawn strike outside a Gaza City mosque." I also take this as a sign of explicit intent to cause whatever casualties happened. Given the identity of the victim--Yassin--this is clearly a targeted assassination.

Description: At least 10 Malians, including a Muslim cleric, have been killed in violence in Ivory Coast's main city Abidjan since the Ivorian army quashed an anti-government demonstration there last week, an official said Thursday.
Comments: Many different numbers were reported in this event.  All agree that Malians were targeted and killed after the demonstrations as well as during.  Officials in Mali claim at least 10, the press say 7, but Malians in Ivory Coast say that the toll could exceed

Description: An Agence France Press report told "Ivory Coast's peace process was in shambles Thursday as opposition parties and former rebels quit the unity regime in protest at the killing of up to 30 people by security forces who quashed a demonstration against President Laurent Gbagbo."
Comments: Articles later noted a significant difference between the government's and the opposition's count of the deaths.  Agence France Presse (AFPR000020040327e03r000xz) wrote that "The streets of Abidjan returned to life Saturday after two days of bloody clashes between demonstrators and police that the opposition says killed about 160 people and the police insists killed 25, including two of their own. "There are about 160 dead," said Alphone Djedje Mady, secretary general of the Ivory Coast Democratic Party. "The dead were counted at the morgue."" Then, in a later report the official death toll was raised to 37 (AFPR000020040328e03s000pz).  Yet, accordingly, the oppositions' assessment was raised to 300 AFPR000020040328e03s000un). One other report told that 'between 350 and 500 people were killed' (AFPR000020040328e03s000y0).

Description: Dozens of Malians have been summarily executed in a security forces crackdown in neighboring Ivory Coast, a political group here charged late Monday. "They are killing Malians and other foreigners by the dozens" in the wake of the quashing of a banned anti-government protest in Abidjan last week, an official of African Solidarity for Democracy and Independence (SADI), told AFP in the Malian capital Bamako. He said many Malians were killed Friday at a mosque in Abobo, a working-class district of Abidjan, Ivory Coast's main city, adding that many more had gone missing. SADI, in a statement released in Bamako, condemned "killings and persecutions of Malians" and charged that police stations in Abidjan had become "centers for summary executions."
Comments: This is merely an allegation by the SADI political group in Mali and has not yet been confirmed or denied.  No specifics are given.

Description: "[An army spokesman] said that on Sunday evening, a mortar fired by the army to repulse a Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebel attack on a camp for displaced people 80 kilometers (50 miles) from thee northern town of Gulu, went astray, killing five of the camp's residents.  'Our forces were trying to shell rebel positions near Atiak Camp in order to keep them away, but one of the mortar shells landed inside the camp, killing five civilians,' [the spokesman] added.  'Of course, it was a mistake on our part and we sincerely apologise for the mishap...."
Comments: This code is linked to a code that was reported in the same lead, but the perpetrators and other particulars of the code are different.  This was a case of collateral damage because the army was intending to shell LRA positions and accidentally hit a civilian area.  The army spokesman apologized for the mistake and promised an investigation into the matter indicating perpetrator regret.  Heavy weapons were used in this killing.

Description: According to a resident, British troops opened fire on people around indiscriminately after anti-tank rockets hit their headquarters in the city of Amara, where clashes between the British and supporters of al Sadr have been ongoing; 12 Iraqi residents ended up dead and 27 were wounded.
Comments: The director of Amara's health department is quoted as saying "we have counted up until now 12 dead and 27 wounded among the population." Because there is no indication that militiamen were among the victims (Sadr supporters were clashing with the British troops), I code all as noncombatant victims. Because a resident is quoted as saying that British soldiers reacted to the anti-tank rocket attack by "opening fire on people nearby", I assume that the killings were intentional--they were knowingly aiming at whoever was around at the time.

Description: Fourteen Brazilians were killed overnight, most of them by police, in drug-related violence in Rio de Janeiro.  Police shot dead nine people in three separate standoffs with suspected drug criminals in Rio's slums, and found two more bodies in other slums, they said.
Comments: Presumably victims were involved in drug-trafficking, article indicates they were killed in standoffs with the police.  Included in dataset because of "Human rights groups treat these kinds of police operations with suspicion and believe that often alleged criminals are shot execution-style by police."

Description: 12 Iraqi noncombatants were killed in the midst of fighting between Italian coalition troops and "firebrand cleric Moqtada Sadr's militia" in Nasiriyah.
Comments: AFP reports a total death toll of 15 Iraqis but specify that 3 of them were Shiite rebels; I assume the rest to be noncombatant victims. Reuters reports "15 Iraqi civilians and Iraqi soldiers" as killed. To capture the ambiguity, I code the count as "range reported". Because the report does not specify whether it was Italian or Shiite militia fire that killed these people, I code both as perpetrators.

Description: Six Iranian pilgrims and three Iraqis traveling in their vehicle between Babel and Kerbala came under fire when they approached  Polish checkpoint; all five ended up dead.
Comments: Although the intent is not explicitly given, because the victims were shot at when they approached the Polish checkpoint, I assume that the Polish forces found them threatening for some reason--maybe they didn't stop--and ended up firing at them directly and intentionally. There is no information to suggest that this was an accident or that the victims were unintentionally killed as collateral damage. There is some confusion between the two reports on the number of Iranians killed (5 vs. 6), and the three Iraqis is not mentioned at all in one of the reports, hence I code deaths as contested and code the combined toll as the number dead. However, note that both reports are Reuters reports so it might simply be that the more recent report is an updated and more correct one, but because the incident is not the main news in the more recent article and the other report deals exclusively with the incident, I chose not to disregard the latter.

Description: Military accidentally kills 5 civilians.  The civilian deaths happened Saturday night in the remote southeast, when a patrol searching for rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, gunned down a peasant family carrying a sick baby to hospital. Three youths, aged 14 to 17, and the six-month-old were among the dead.
Comments: Victims apparently random.  Obviously non-combatants as children were included.  Colombian military mistook them for FARC rebels in the darkness.  Story reports President Uribe's public apology for the killings.

Description: At least eight minority Christians were killed in clashes with Vietnamese authorities during protests in the country's Central Highlands earlier this month, Amnesty International said Thursday. The London-based group said the eight included a blind woman.
Comments: Vietnam denies Amnesty's account, saying only 2 were killed.  Amnesty believes the victim count will exceed 8, and that they were protesting, not rioting, when killed by authorities.

Description: Colombian soldiers have accidentally killed five civilians, including two children, the army said on Sunday, admitting another mistaken killing just three weeks after troops killed 11 policemen and civilians in an incident still under investigation.
Citation:
Reuters News 12 April 2004 LBA0000020040412e04c0001a 
Associated Press Newswires 12 April 2004 APRS000020040412e04c00aw4
Comments: Victims were identified as "peasants", including children, that were mistakenly killed by a military patrol.  Associated Press article (APRS000020040412e04c00aw4 ) indicates President Uribe pushing for investigation.

Description: Militias backing the Khartoum government have violated a ceasefire in Sudan's western Darfur region, killing 32 civilians, a rebel group charged Thursday.  Colonel Abdallah Abdel Karim, military spokesman of the Justice and Equality Movement (MJE), said Janjaweed militiamen and government troops had torched villages northwest of the Darfur state capital Geneina near the border with Chad on Wednesday.  Karim ... added that the 32 people allegedly killed in the raids were 'mostly women, elderly and children.'  The claim could not be independently confirmed."
Comments: While primitive weapons (fire) are the only form of weapons reported in this article, that does not preclude the use of other weapons, specifically firearms, in this case.  This event is also coded as a case in which "scorched earth tactics" were used because the perpetrators reportedly "torched" a number of villages northwest of the Darfur state capital Geneina.  This event is a subset of a larger campaign that spans the first months of 2004 and into 2003.  All the reports in this campaign are coded with their own campaign identifier code and also linked as BNL 0317 02.

Description: "At least 11 people, including soldiers and Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels, have been killed in a rebel raid of a displaced people's camp in northern Uganda, the army said Friday.  'Seven civilians, two of our soldiers and two LRA rebels were killed when the rebels attacked Odek Displaced People's Camp, situated some 50 kilometres southeast of Gulu town,' army spokesman Lieutenant Paddy Ankunda told AFP by telephone....  Other sources in Gulu said the rebels attacked and overran the military detachment guarding the camp and that the civilians died in crossfire during the ensuing battle on Thursday evening."
Comments: The civilian deaths in this code allegedly took place as the LRA attacked the camp, overran the military guards, and a battle ensued.  The military hinted that the civilians were all killed by the LRA, but that is not reported as a fact.  The civilians were said to have been killed "in crossfire" indicating that firearms were used in the killing.

Description: "Angolan security forces are reported to be raping, killing and expelling illegal Congolese diamond miners and their families, the United Nations said on Thursday.  Tens of thousands of Congolese, including children, have been forced out this month, some after many years in the southern Africa country and, in order to prevent smuggling, many have been subjected to 'unhygienic internal body searches' that have caused trauma and death, a U.N. statement said.  Miners and their families are then forced to cross the Tungila river into Congo, where some have drowned, it added."
Comments: The exact number of dead victims in this event is not reported, as are the exact beginning and end dates.  The report only cites that Congolese miners have been killed, raped, and expelled from Angola "this month."  The other tactics coded here are unsanitary body searches and the forced expulsion from Angola.  Primitive weapons are the only "weapons" coded (referring to deaths as a product of unsanitary body searches) but firearms were likely involved in some killings as well (though these were not mentioned).

Description: Seven boys died in a fire in a youth detention center in Brazil because guards did not open the boys' cell doors as they screamed for help, human rights groups said on Friday.
Secondary.Source: Amnesty International & National Movement of Human Rights (local)
Citation:
Reuters News 14 May 2004 LBA0000020040514e05e003iy
Associated Press Newswires 14 May 2004 APRS000020040515e05e00007
Comments: Victims (7 incarcerated boys) lit a fire in their cell.  Story indicates that police guards did not respond to pleas thus resulting in their deaths (weapon listed as unclear - neglect?).  Described by National Movement of Human Rights as "massacre."

Description: "Sudanese government forces killed six civilians and wounded 10 others in aerial bombardments in the latest ceasefire violation in west Sudan, a rebel spokesman said on Tuesday.  The government was not immediately available for comment, but Sudanese military sources said last week they were still pursuing rebels in an area near the latest reported attack despite a truce signed in April between the two sides.  'he government carried out aerial bombardment using Antonov planes and helicopters on the Korma area in Northern Darfur state targeting our soldiers resulting in the death of six civilians and the injury of 10,' Mohammed Mursal, spokesman for the Sudanese Liberation Army (SLA), told Reuters."
Comments: The weapons used in this killing were Antonov planes and helicopters that dropped bombs over the region.  The Sudanese forces were likely targeting rebels in the area, and ended up killing civilians in the process.  While these civilian casualties were probably expected, it is assumed here that the killings were a case of collateral damage.

Description: As part of an Israeli incursion into Rafah, which started as a response to a rocket attack from the camp to an armored Israeli vehicle (and it killed five soldiers inside), 28 Palestinians were killed and 235 have been wounded; "at least five" of the dead were combatants. A number of rockets were fired, targeting "gunmen" according to the army. "Dozens" of houses and other buildings were also destroyed with the goal of "removing possible Palestinian vantage points or cover for potential attackers."
Citation:
Associated Press Newswires: 05.14.2004, APRS000020040514e05e00af1
By TAMER ZIARA
Comments: Because how many of the victims were combatants and how many were noncombatants is not clear, I code the death count as "range reported" after coding the count as 23 (28 total death toll minus 5 explicitly identified by residents as militants). Because missiles from helicopters were fired at the Rafah camp and buildings were being destroyed intentionally, I assume that the killings were intentional.

Description: A fire raged through a Honduran prison killing 103 inmates and injuring 25 others, amid allegations jail guards had refused to let young gang members out of their cells, authorities said.
Citation:
Reuters News 17 May 2004 LBA0000020040517e05h001kn
Agence France-Presse 17 May 2004 AFPR000020040517e05h00h21
Reuters News 17 May 2004 LBA0000020040517e05h001or
Agence France-Presse 17 May 2004 AFPR000020040517e05h00jtx
Agence France-Presse 17 May 2004 AFPR000020040517e05h00l55 
Associated Press Newswires 17 May 2004 APRS000020040517e05h00aq8
Associated Press Newswires 17 May 2004 APRS000020040517e05h00asy
Agence France-Presse 18 May 2004 AFPR000020040518e05i004jx
Agence France-Presse 18 May 2004 AFPR000020040518e05i00i7m
Comments: Initial death count 102, updated to 103 in later stories.  Multiple sources indicate intent on part of guards to let prisoners die although initial start of fire was accidental.

Description: According to a hospital official, "nine Iraqis, some militiamen and some civilians, were killed and 14 others injured in clashes" between Shiite militiamen and Italian coalition troops in Nasiriyah.
Comments: Whether it was the Italians or the Shiite fighters that caused the deaths of the victims in question is not known, therefore, I code both as perpetrators. Also, how many of the victims were noncombatants is not clear, hence I code the total toll given but code it as "range reported" to capture the ambiguity.

Description: Death toll from an Israeli operation in Gaza, "designed to smash tunnels used by Palestinian militants to smuggle weapons from Egypt", reached 41 in two days: 10 of these victims were killed when Israeli soldiers used helicopters and tanks to disperse a demonstration in Rafah, and because demonstrator deaths are not coded in this dataset, only 31 noncombatant deaths are coded here. Incidences took place in southern Gaza--Jenaina neighborhood of Rafah, the Brazil quarter of the neighboring refugee camp, Tal al-Sultan, etc.
Comments: 10 of the 41 victims reported in the article were killed as Israeli troops dispersed a demonstration, so those 10 are excluded from the count (given the coding rules of this dataset). The 31 remaining victims are not explicitly identified as either noncombatants or combatants, however, because the report also mentions that "the UN Security Council passed a resolution overnight criticising Israel for killing Palestinian civilians and demolishing their houses," I assume that at least a portion of the victims were noncombatants. To capture the ambiguity, I code the death toll as "range reported". Because the incursion included destroying houses and other buildings, in the name of destroying tunnels, I code the killings as intentional.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 09/14/2004 that "Amnesty International Tuesday [09/14/2004] accused the armed forces in Laos of brutally torturing and killing five ethnic Hmong children in what the human rights group describes as a 'war crime'"; reportedly, "Amnesty said it had gathered evidence 'including video and witness testimony of an attack by Lao soldiers against a group of five children, four of them girls, in the Xaisomboune military zone on 19 May 2004'"; reportedly, "the London-based group called for United Nations agencies and aid groups to be given immediate access to Hmong rebels inside Laos following the attack, which it said also included the rape of four of the victims"; reportedly, "according to Amnesty, the unarmed children, aged between 13 and 16, were mutilated before being killed... four of the five were girls and were also raped... the assault was carried out by a group of approximately 30-40 soldiers"; reportedly, "a foreign ministry spokesman in the Lao capital Vientiane, Yong Chanthalangsy, dismissed the Amnesty report as 'false allegations aiming at creating disorder'"
Contesting.Source: "a foreign ministry spokesman in the Lao capital Vientiane, Yong Chanthalangsy"

Description: "Forty-five Sudanese were killed in a recent attack on a village by pro-government militiamen in Darfur, the main rebel group in the troubled western region said Sunday.  The Arab militia unknown as the Janjaweed, which has been accused of atrocities, attacked Abquarajel village Thursday, a senior Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) member, Mohamed Mersal, told AFP by telephone here.  Another 10 people were wounded in the attack on the village located 15 kilometres (almost 10 miles) south of Nyala, the capital of Southern Darfur state, he said."
Comments: There was no indication from the lead about the weapons used in these killings, but the Janjaweed are known to use firearms in their killings in Darfur.  Reuters reported 56 casualties and AFP cited only 45, but I chose to code the Reuters number.  The later Reuters report also claimed that the perpetrators were using firearms in the raid.  In the AP report the governor of South Darfur Province claimed that a band of rebels were responsible for the killings, implicitly denying the accusation that the government had a role in the deaths.

Description: Associated Press report told "Demonstrators set fire to the Labor Ministry on Thursday after Lebanese soldiers shot and killed five people and wounded 12 others during protests against the government's economic policies, security and hospital officials said."
Primary.Source: Associated Press, Reuters, Agence France Press

Description: "Villagers in west Sudan said Sudanese aircraft bombed their village on Friday and killed at least 11 people, but a local airport official denied there had been any attack.  The witnesses told Reuters by mobile and satellite telephone from the area that an Antonov plane and helicopters bombed the village of Tabit, about 40 km (25 miles) southwest of al-Fashir, the capital of Northern Darfur state. A rebel official also reported an aerial attack....  'There has been no aerial bombardment. These people are lying. We are going to hear a lot of these kinds of lies in the future,' the official said by telephone."
Comments: An Antonov plane and helicopters are the alleged means that were used to deliver bombs on the town.  The Sudanese military flatly denies that the event occurred, calling the witnesses "liars."  There were a range of deaths reported ("killed at least 11 people").  A rebel group cited 20 dead and 17 wounded in a separate report.

Description: Twenty-four people have been killed in a two-day assault by government forces on a village in Sudan's war-ravaged western Darfur region, the rebel Justice and Equality Movement (MJE) said on Tuesday. Khartoum's forces launched an air strike on the village of Adjidji, south of Geneina in West Darfur, in breach of a ceasefire agreement, MJE spokesman Colonel Abdallah Abdel Kerim told AFP by satellite telephone.
