"The Janjaweed (pro-government Arab militias) and the army then attacked the village and killed 24 people," all civilians," he said. The attack reportedly took place on Monday and Tuesday. Fighting between government forces and two rebel groups in Darfur has left some 10,000 people dead since February 2003 and sparked what the United Nations has described as the world's worst humanitarian crisis.
Secondary.Source: The rebel Justice and Equality Movement
Comments: Because heavy weapons were used in the initial strike, this was coded as such.  The article made mention of the follow-up attack by the army and militia the next day, but fails to mention what weapons were used in the second phase.

Description: "The main rebel group in Sudan on Monday claimed that 204 civilians have been killed in the south of the country over the last few days in renewed fighting with government forces and Khartoum-backed militias.  ' can confirm that there has been fighting around Akobo (on the border with Ethiopia). Our sources on the ground indicate that 204 civilians were killed,' Sudan People's Liberation Army's (SPLA) spokesman George Garang told AFP by phone.  There was no independent confirmation of the death toll...."
Comments: There are no reported dates for this event, because the only time identification given in the article was that there was reported fighting "over a few days."  the day fields have been left blank, but it is reasonable to assume that the fighting both began and ended in the month of may.  The weapons used in this fighting were not identified.

Perp.State.Military: "the 4,000-strong Rapid Action Battalion (RAB), comprising soldiers and police officials"
Perp.State.Police: "the 4,000-strong Rapid Action Battalion (RAB), comprising soldiers and police officials"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 04/17/2005 that "Bangladesh Sunday [04/17/2005] defended a controversial crime-fighting unit after the European Parliament accused it of extra-judicial killings, saying criminals are killed in crossfire in other parts of the world as well"; reportedly, "a leading Bangladeshi human rights group, Ain-O-Salishi Kendro (Law and Justice Centre), too, has accused the RAB of carrying out extra-judicial killings and demanded an inquiry into each death... media reports and another local rights group, Odhikar, have put the number of people killed by the RAB since June at around 100"
Secondary.Source: Local human rights groups, local media, the European Parliament

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Dissident soldiers led by General Laurent Nkundaare
Description: At least 27 people -- among them eight civilians -- have been killed in three days of fighting in the troubled northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo town of Bukavu, UN officials said on Friday. The Congolese Red Cross said that five bodies had been picked up in the town on Thursday, according to the UN mission there, known as MONUC. Between 2,000 and 4,000 dissident soldiers led by General Laurent Nkundaare took control of Bukavu on Wednesday after a series of clashes with the regular DR Congo army.

Soldiers in gun-mounted speedboats clashed with ethnic militants in the rivers of Nigeria's oil delta on Friday, and militants and villagers claimed dozens of fighters and civilians were killed. A navy spokesman denied any casualties. Hundreds of soldiers and police have been deploying to villages of Ogbakiri, Buguma and Tombia near the eastern oil city of Port Harcourt since last week. Going outside his house, community leader Lloyd Eyime said he saw soldiers in speedboats firing upon his riverside community. "They have been burning houses and shooting at people, both young and elderly," Eyime said. When Eyime returned, he said, he found about 30 bodies lying about the otherwise abandoned village. Kenneth Etu, a village elder from Ogbakiri, said he saw 15 dead bodies. Dokubo Asari, one of the two feuding ethnic Ijaw commanders involved, said his men were fighting back. A senior navy official in Port Harcourt denied anyone had been killed or injured. Most villagers deserted their communities during fighting before security force members began arriving, he said. "Over 70 persons, including children, women and the aged were killed in the military attack on Ogbakiri," Kingsley Kuku of the Ijaw Youth Council said. Anyankwee Nsirimovu of the Institute of Human Rights and Humanitarian Law put the death toll at over 100 but said the exact figure might never be known.
Secondary.Source: Villagers and Residents of the oil delta
Comments: The military has denied knowledge of the event and claims that zero people died and zero people were injured; yet, they readily admit that soldiers have been deployed to the area in the past week.  Witnesses have cited at least 45 deaths, but have said that "dozens" may have perished in the attack.  The Institute of Human Rights and Humanitarian Law put the toll at over 100 but say the exact figure may never be known.

Locality: Sunny Zion, Idegbagbene, Odiogbogbene, Opia, Ogboinbiri
Description: Security forces raided five villages in Nigeria's oil-rich southern delta, leaving 15 people dead and homes ransacked and burned, residents and militant leaders said Thursday. Troops in speedboats with mounted machine guns raided the villages of Sunny Zion, Idegbagbene, Odiogbogbene, Opia and Ogbinbiri between Sunday and Wednesday, said Maj. Said Hamed, spokesman for the region's 3,000-strong military-police task force. But he was unable to confirm whether anyone was killed in what he described as a "cordon-and-search" operation to "fish out" gunmen accused of taking oil workers hostage for ransom and large-scale theft of crude oil. But Bello Oboko, president of the Federated Niger Delta Ijaw Communities militant group, said 15 people -- including women and children -- were shot dead or drowned while fleeing the troops. Residents "fled when they saw the soldiers setting their houses on fire," Oboko said. "Three men who tried to run away were shot dead," he said, speaking to The Associated Press by telephone from Warri.
Contesting.Source: Spokesman for the Nigerian military-police task force

Description: Reuters reported on 08/04/2004 that, according to local police and hospital sources, "heavy fighting between guerrillas and Iraqi security forces on Wednesday [08/04/2004] in the northern city of Mosul killed at least 12 civilians and wounded 26 people"; reportedly, "the clashes erupted on Wednesday morning and sporadic gunfire continued into the afternoon"; a related AFP report indicated that "at least 14 Iraqis were killed Wednesday as violence engulfed the northern city of Mosul, bogged down in bitter clashes between police and insurgents"; a related AFP report indicated that "Mosul's hospitals said 14 bodies, including those of two women, were brought in along with 52 injured, mostly civilians"
Comments: Sieges/Closures coded as Yes since, reportedly, "streets of this city [Mosul] of about 1.75 million were deserted after authorities imposed a curfew starting at 3:00 pm until an unspecified time on Thursday morning"

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: "Shiite Muslim militiamen" "radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al-Sadr['s] Mehdi Army"
Perp.Non.State.Religious: "Shiite Muslim militiamen" "radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al-Sadr['s] Mehdi Army"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 08/06/2004 that, according to "Sadr representative Sheikh Saad al-Basri", "in the main southern city of Basra five people were killed and three wounded in fresh clashes [between British troops and Shiite militiamen]"

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: "Shiite Muslim militiamen" "radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al-Sadr['s] Mehdi Army"
Perp.Non.State.Religious: "Shiite Muslim militiamen" "radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al-Sadr['s] Mehdi Army"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 08/06/2004 that, according to local police sources, "in Nasiriyah, seven civilians were killed and 13 wounded in overnight clashes between the Mehdi Army [militiamen of radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al-Sadr] and Italian troops"; reportedly, "four people died, including a woman who was about to give birth, when an ambulance was blasted in the crossfire"
Comments: Intent coded as Noncombatants Not Intentionally Targeted and Collateral Damage coded as Collateral Damage since, reportedly, at least four of the seven victims were killed by "crossfire"

Description: Eight Iraqis were killed and 33 wounded in fierce clashes in Hilla between Shiite Muslim militiamen and Polish-backed Iraqi police forces.  Hilla and Babylon hospitals said the dead and injured included civilians, police and militiamen but provided no specific numbers for each category.  Militia loyal to radical cleric Moqtada Sadr attacked police stations and government buildings with mortars and gunfire on Friday following a demonstration that turned violent.

Russian artillery strikes killed many rebels outside Chechnya's capital of Grozny after fighting broke out between rebel and police forces just days before elections.  Different sources give various death counts. Shabalkin put the number of death among Russian servicemen and Chechen police at 12 and said at least 18 militants were killed.  The newspaper Kommersant reported that 300 fighters participated in the attacks on police stations, police patrols and polling stations and more than 50 people, mostly civilians, were killed. Vremya Novostei newspaper cited regional health officials as saying as many as 30 police and 48 civilians were killed while about 20 fighters' bodies were recovered.  An official in Chechnya's Moscow-backed government told AP that more than 30 people were killed.
Comments: It's very unclear how many civilians died, how they died and who caused the deaths

Description: Eight Palestinians were killed in Jabalya between four days as Israeli tanks entered the refugee camp in what the army calls an operation against militants.  Five of those killed have been civilians and medics say over 100 Palestinians have been wounded during the raid. The army's move in northern Gaza is aimed at stopping militants from firing makeshift Qassam rockets into southern Israel.
Comments: The report offers no specifics on the deaths but does say that five of the dead were civilians

Description: The Associated Press reported on 09/08/2004 that "Pakistani troops opened fire at a bazaar in this tense tribal town [Wana] on Wednesday [09/08/2004], killing six tribesmen and wounding 11, moments after a land mine exploded near a nearby army convoy"; reportedly, "injured witnesses accused soldiers of spraying fire at innocent civilians in the wake of the blast in Wana, the main town in South Waziristan, a tribal region near the Afghan border where al-Qaida-linked militants are active"; according to a local resident, "moments after the blast, some soldiers started firing at the people who were present in the bazaar... we don't know who attacked the army, but they killed our innocent brothers without any reason"; reportedly, a Pakistani army spokesman said "six people 'died in a cross-fire' in Wednesday's clash, but said he didn't know yet if they were 'civilians or miscreants'"; a related AFP report indicated that "eight people were killed and 11 injured" in the incident; reportedly, "six people, all local tribesmen were killed on the spot and two more died in the hospital"; according to the AFP report, "[PAK] military officials said the civilians died in firing by 'miscreants'"
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse, Associated Press, Reuters
Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the secondary sources cited in the AP report disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided could not be accommodated in a single record

Description: Reuters reported on 09/09/2004 that, according to a local witness, "Pakistani jet fighters and helicopter gunships launched air strikes on the South Waziristan tribal area bordering Afghanistan [sic], killing dozens of people on Thursday [09/09/2004]"; reportedly, "around 40 members of Afghanistan's deposed Taliban militia and other Islamic militants came under attack when they gathered in the village of Laggimanzai"; reportedly, "many civilians were also killed in a subsequent air strike when they gathered to survey the damage in the village"; a related Reuters report indicated that a Pakistani military spokesman said, "I am giving you an explicit statement that there were no civilian casualties, including women and children"

The Associated Press reported on 09/13/2004 that "Pakistan's army said it has killed 150 militants in a series of counterterrorism operations this year in South Waziristan, where fighting continued Monday [09/13/2004] with artillery barrages against suspected al-Qaida-linked fighters"; reportedly, "a local tribesman reported eight people had died in the most recent fighting, and intelligence sources confirmed at least one death, but an army spokesman said reports of civilian casualties in recent clashes were unfounded"; according to the local resident, "shells fired by [PAK] security forces hit three homes in Makin... [killing] eight people... including two women and two children aged 6 and 4"; reportedly, "[PAK] intelligence officials... confirmed that one man was killed when his home was hit in crossfire between militants and security forces in Makin... He [a PAK intelligence official] said there were other reports of civilian casualties, but these could not be confirmed because the area was off-limits"
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Rumor/Allegation since the AP report indicated only that the local resident "claimed" that eight civilians were killed

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: "al-Qaida-linked terrorist[s] Chechen, Uzbek and Arab militants"
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: "al-Qaida-linked terrorist[s] Chechen, Uzbek and Arab militants"
Perp.Non.State.Religious: "al-Qaida-linked terrorist[s] Chechen, Uzbek and Arab militants"
Description: The Associated Press reported on 09/17/2004 that, according to a local "resident of Makin, Gul Badar Mehsud a large number of civilians were killed in the [PAK security forces'] five-day operation against the militants in the village"; reportedly, however, "Sultan [a PAK military spokesman] denied the allegation"
Ten Palestinians, including a young schoolgirl, were killed in separate army raids in the West Bank Wednesday, September 15 by Israeli forces.  One of the victims was a young school girl.

The Israeli army began a major offensive in northern Gaza aimed at rooting out gunmen who launch rockets into Israel.  Ninety-seven Palestinians have been killed in 15 days of fighting.  At least 55 of them were militants and most of the rest were believed to be civilians, Palestinian medics say.  Israel says the vast majority of Palestinian dead were gunmen.

Associated Press told "Supporters of ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide wielded machetes and threatened to cut off the heads of Haitian police and the interim prime minister during demonstrations on Monday No violence was reported in Monday's demonstrations in the capital Port-au-Prince. But at least 14 people were killed in clashes Thursday and Friday, including three police officers who were shot to death and then beheaded."
Comments: a later report said a total of 18 were killed (including three police officers), but it was not clear if the number was referring to Thursday and Friday, or these two days plus Monday.

Description: Thirty-two Palestinians and three Israelis were killed in fierce battles in the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday during a massive and open-ended Israeli army operation. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon approved recommendations by top defence officials for a broadening of the operation, army radio reported toward the end of one of the deadliest days in Gaza since the Palestinian uprising began in 2000. In the operation codenamed "Days of Penitence", the army will carry out an "aggressive and ongoing activity" in Jabaliya refugee camp and the nearby town of Beit Hanun in a bid to halt Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel, it said. "We are intending to make the Palestinians pay a heavy price so they will understand that continuing to fire Qassam rockets does not pay," a defence official said, quoted by the radio. Hospital officials said a total of 32 Palestinians were killed, including four "terrorists" whose bodies an Israeli military source said were being held by the army, and at least 140 people wounded in the day's violence.
Comments: The number of those killed takes into account that four of the 32 Palestinians were deemed terrorists (combatants) and three Israelis were killed in addition to the Palestinian casualties.  In short: 32-4+3=31.

Description: According to the National Coalition for Haitian Rights based in New York, at least 170 people have been killed by Haitian officials in the last month.  In an effort to stop the violence by both people for and against Aristide, officials have gone into pro-Aristide slums such as Bel-Air and Cite Soleil to hunt criminal gang members.
Comments: The Associated Press reported 79 people had been killed.  It is unclear if all the victims were killed by officials and whether or not the "criminals" had weapons of their own.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 04/23/2005 that, according to Bangladeshi officials, "two Bangladeshi farmers were shot dead Saturday [04/23/2005] by Indian border forces in the latest in a spate of frontier clashes"; reportedly, "the farmers were shot dead by the Border Security Force men after they strayed into no-man's land at Hairharpur on the Jhenidah-Chhabish Paragana border"; reportedly, "the shootings followed Bangladesh's accusations of 'unprovoked firing' by Indian border [troops] Friday [04/22/2005] that wounded two villagers"; reportedly, "in the past, the Border Security Force used to catch farmers who strayed into their territory and hand them to [Bangladeshi border forces]... [although] since last October Indian forces have [s]hot dead at least 24 Bangladeshi citizens"

Perp.State.Military: "senior army officers" in southern Thailand, "security forces"
Description: Agence France Presse told "Eighty-seven protesters were killed after security forces broke up the protest in the southern province of Narathiwat, including 78 people who died in custody, most of them suffocating after 1,300 of them were bound and piled into the backs of army trucks"... Reuters reported "Six Muslim protesters were killed in southern Thailand on Monday in clashes with security forces in the region's worst violence in months "Six protesters were killed in the clashes," Southern Army Commander Pisan Wattanwonngkeree told state Channel 9 television. "We are detaining more than 1,000 of them," he said adding that dozens were wounded..." The following day Reuters added that "At least 78 people died in a crush in southern Thailand on Monday after police and troops fired shots to disperse a crowd of Muslim demonstrators outside a police station, a justice ministry official said on Tuesday. The 78 deaths were in addition to six people already confirmed killed in Monday's violence in the restive region."
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse, Associated Press, Reuters
Comments: 78 died in custody, and also "Seven other civilians were shot dead during the suppression of the protest." 87 is the highest number reported "Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said on Wednesday security forces had made mistakes in their handling of a Muslim riot and voiced regret at the loss of nearly 80 lives in military custody."

Description: When the Israeli army fired at least four air-to-ground missiles at a national security service position in the Khan Yunis area.  Eight Palestinians were killed, two of which were secret service officers, and 25 were wounded.

Rebel accusations that new government air raids killed 26 civilians in Sudan's troubled Darfur region cast a pall over peace talks in Nigeria, where African Union mediators struggled Wednesday to broker an end to fighting that has killed tens of thousands of people. A Sudan army official denied the rebel report. Lt. Gen. Mohammed Ismail, deputy chief of staff of the Sudanese army, said there had been no new violence in Darfur, which the United Nations has said is site of the world's worst humanitarian crisis. A spokesman for the rebel Sudan Liberation Army, Mahgoup Hussain, said the bombings occurred Tuesday and Wednesday in Allaiat, a town in eastern Darfur. Hussain, who said a pregnant woman was among the 26 victims, spoke at the end of a third day of peace talks that so far have failed to yield any agreement. The conflict has displaced 1.5 million people since it started in February 2003.

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: "members of a Pakistani tribal delegation which included elders of the dominant Mahsud tribe"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 10/27/2004 that, according to "a [PAK] military spokesman", "fourteen tribal leaders trying to help Pakistani forces organise the surrender of Al-Qaeda-linked militants in a remote region near the Afghan border have been killed"; reportedly, "another six people were injured in the incident, Major General Shaukat Sultan told AFP, laying the blame for the deaths on a militant rocket attack"; according to the PAK military spokesman, "'the casualties were caused by miscreants"; reportedly, however, "another tribal elder who said he was present during the tragedy, Azizullah Mahsud, claimed the military was responsible, and local press reports raised the prospect of a 'friendly fire' mistake"; reportedly, "the incident occurred Tuesday [10/26/2004] in the tribal tow of Sheikh Ziarat near Spinkai Raghzai in the troubled South Waziristan region where Pakistani troops are engaged in a hunt for Al-Qaeda-militants and their local sympathisers"
Secondary.Source: Local press reports, "[a] tribal elder who said he was present during the tragedy"
Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the secondary sources cited in the AFP report disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided could not be accommodated in a single record

Description: Reuters told "About a dozen people killed by police have been exhumed in the Nigerian city of Kaduna to help check claims by residents that the bodies were those of protesters in a strike last week, officials said on Tuesday [October 19, 2004]." A Reuters report on November 5th says "Nigerian human rights activists accused police of extrajudicial killings on Friday after police said they killed 12 suspected robbers trying to break out of jail. The burial of the 12 in a mass grave in northern Kaduna last month prompted a formal inquiry by the state government after local residents in the mainly Muslim district of Tudun Wada claimed police had killed the group during a protest march. "The 12 bodies were those of suspects arrested for different armed robbery incidents around Kaduna," Kaduna state police commissioner Mohammed Yesufu told the inquiry on Thursday, in comments obtained by Reuters on Friday. "They were being distributed into cells when they tried to escape detention and were shot dead by the police," Yesufu said, adding that firearms and other weapons had been recovered."
Comments: Not a lot details about the incident, but the report also told "The police had outraged residents in the northern city after they shot dead a young boy during last week's general strike that was called by labour unions in the oil-producing country."

Description: The Eritrean government denied on Sunday reports that many people had been killed early Sunday at a prison where people who have avoided military service are detained. "I can't say there were no incidents, but to say that some 20 people had died is totally exaggerated," Eritrean Information Minister Ali Abdu told AFP by telephone in Asmara on Sunday. Earlier on Sunday, a high-ranking diplomat, who asked not to be named, told AFP: "I spoke to a direct witness, who told me 25 people were killed by guards during a prison riot" at Adi Abieto jail near Asmara. An Eritrean opposition website asmarino.com had earlier reported that "guards had started the shooting, killing over 20 detainees." "It is natural to have some kind of incident because some of the detainees were gangsters. I don't have the details of the operation," Ali Abdu said. The roundup on Thursday was aimed at catching "gangsters" in order "to preserve security" in Eritrea, "we found gangsters" who were imprisoned, he added, stressing that it is a "national security affair and it is not other people or diplomats' business."

Ivorian authorities said a total of 57 civilians were killed and more than 2,200 injured between November 6 and 10, including an unconfirmed number by French troops -- but there is no specific toll for the Hotel Ivoire protest. The death toll was provisional, not definitive, the defence ministry source added. In every case, the French soldiers were acting in legitimate self-defence or to defend themselves and others, the source said.
Agence France Presse reports "The seven were shot dead Tuesday when a strike by farm workers demanding more pay descended into violent clashes. "

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: Young men and elders from the village of Ojobo
Description: Grieving residents of the river port of Ojobo in the jungles of the Niger Delta have accused Nigerian soldiers of shooting dead seven unarmed demonstrators during a community protest on an oil rig operated for the Anglo-Dutch energy giant Shell. On November 20, a group of young men and village elders took a flotilla of speedboats across the Bomadi Creek from Ojobo to "Rig 75", a mobile platform operated for Shell by the US firm Parker Drilling, to protest at what they see as the oil companies' failure to honour a promise to invest in the community.  As the protesters boarded the rig troops arrived from a nearby oil facility, Shell's Benisede flow station, where they are based. Gunfire soon broke out. What happened next is unclear and bitterly disputed; while the army insists that no-one was killed and Shell says that an initial inquiry found no evidence of fatalities, clearly distraught relatives showed reporters seven fresh graves which they said were filled with the victims of the shooting. Army spokesman Colonel Yusuf Mohammed said: "They are all telling lies. The elders were having a meeting with the oil company when the youths disrupted them. The soldiers came to disperse them and only some few of them were injured. The army did not kill anybody, it's all lies." However, both the army and Shell confirmed that 12 young men were shot and wounded in the incident and flown by company helicopters to the oil city of Warri for treatment. The military said they were injured during a scuffle in which a demonstrator attempted to grab a soldier's weapon. In Ojobo's run-down general hospital, 28-year-old Stanley Pakemi was recovering from what doctors confirmed to be the wounds from a whipping. He told reporters that he had been arrested after the shooting and taken away to Benisede, where he was imprisoned for two days inside the Shell facility. "The soldiers beat me four times daily. They used electric wires and horsewhips," he said. Shell said they had no information on his allegation.

Rwandan troops have killed at least 19 Congolese civilians during an attack on a Congolese town, a Congolese military commander said on Tuesday.  "Nineteen people have been killed in the attack on Bukumbirwa. These were civilians who died," Col. Etienne Bindu, the acting military commander of Congo's North Kivu region, told Reuters. He said the attack happened on Sunday. There was no independent confirmation of the attack.
Secondary.Source: Col. Etienne Bindu, the acting military commander of Congo's North Kivu region
Comments: Because the deaths were reported as "at least 19 civilians," I indicated range reported.

Description: A rebel group Friday accused the Sudanese military and allied militias of carrying out a massacre of dozens of civilians in the strife-torn Darfur region of western Sudan this week. A Sudan Liberation Army (SLA) spokesman told AFP that government forces had killed up to 100 civilians around Adoua, 45 kilometers (30 miles) north of Nyala, the capital of South Darfur state, between November 29 and December 2. The fighting broke out when government forces, backed by armored carriers and an Antonov aircraft attacked SLA-controlled Adoua, forcing out the 30 SLA fighters defending the town, according to Ali. "Nearly 600 Arab Janjaweed militias were also involved in the assault," the spokesman added. "Some of our fighters died in the battle and others withdrew from the town." He said that civilians caught up in the fighting were unable to flee and many of them were killed by the Janjaweed, the government proxy militias blamed for many atrocities in the region. There was no independent confirmation of the charges and no immediate comment from the Khartoum government. Local authorities refused to allow an AU helicopter to land in the town to investigate, as the military had yet to wipe out the evidence, according to the SLA spokesman.

A rebel group in Sudan's troubled Darfur region accused pro-government Arab Janjaweed militias and the police Wednesday of attacking a village in South Darfur and killing 17 civilians.  "They then mutilated the bodies and buried them in a mass grave," the Sudan Liberation Movement charged in a statement received by AFP in Cairo and which claimed the attack took place Monday at Tawal Balal. It added that the attackers also raped four women, including a 17-year-old girl.

On 15 December 2004 AFP reported that "Indian soldiers shot dead five men on the Kashmir border with Pakistan."  The event occurred at "Babarnallah in Hira Nagar district, 100 kilometers (60 miles) from...Jammu."
An army spokesman said, "Indian troops spotted five young men trying to cross the border and asked them to surrender... When they refused to surrender they were gunned down. The identity of the intruders is being established." Border security force sources said the men may have been Bangladeshi migrants trying to reach Pakistan.
Comments: Although army claims victims "refused to surrender" it appears they were civilians.

Victim.Identity.Political: civilians accused of supporting Mayi Mayi militiamen
Description: Renegade army soldiers in eastern Congo recently massacred at least 30 civilians, including women and children, to avenge the death of three of their troops, the U.N. mission in Congo said.  Troops slaughtered the civilians on Dec. 17 in the village of Buramba because they suspected them of supporting Mayi Mayi militiamen in the area, the U.N. mission said in a statement on Friday. "The mission says the exact number of civilians killed could be higher, given that the rebel government troops could have burned a certain amount of bodies and could have killed civilians in the hills overlooking Buramba," said a spokeswoman for U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan at the United Nations headquarters in New York. The massacre was apparently carried out in revenge for the earlier killings by Mayi Mayi militia of three soldiers who had tried to steal rice in Buramba.

Maoist rebels ambushed two separate army patrols in western Nepal near Madhuradanda village and Chisapani.  At least five civilians, including a 13-year-old boy, were killed in the crossfire along with many rebels and soldiers.
Comments: The report does not explain whether the civilians were killed in the Madhuradanda attack or the Chisapani attack, or both.

Description: Colombia's attorney general on Wednesday charged seven soldiers in the 2004 killing of five members of a peasant family -- including three teenagers and a six-month-old baby. The soldiers were arrested in 2005 and have confessed to gunning down the family, but insist they mistook them for leftist rebels during a nighttime patrol in a guerrilla stronghold near Cajamarca, 150 kilometers (90 miles) southeast of the capital. The soldiers said they ordered the civilians to surrender and opened fire when they started to run away. Colombians have followed closely the case that called attention to the brutal methods used by the military in its pursuit of armed insurgents who've been trying to overthrow the government for four decades.
Comments: The date of this incident is unclear. It occurred sometime in 2004, but no specific day is given.

Perp.State.Other: United Self Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC)
Description: Fighters from the right-wing paramilitary group United Self Defense Forces of Colombia, or AUC, went to the rural farmhouse of Orlando Diaz, who was wanted for killing a man.  The fighters killed Diaz and his sons on Sunday, Jan. 2.
Comments: It is not clear how many people were killed.  The report says Diaz and his "sons" were killed.

Description: Palestinian leaders believed Israeli tank shells killed seven Palestinian children in a strawberry patch.  The Israeli military said the shells were aimed at nine masked militants involved in firing mortar rounds earlier and soldiers confirmed that members of the cell were hit.  However, the director of the local hospital in the town of Beit Lahiya said the dead were between the ages of 11 and 17.  No militant Palestinian groups claimed the victims as members but the Israeli military insisted it was informed by Palestinian liaison officers that six of the sever were 17 or older, and that four or five of them were members of the Islamic militant group Hamas.  Nevertheless, an area army commander gave a guarded apology saying "If we hit innocent Palestinians, I'm sorry for that.  You have to remember that the (militant) groups fire from the cover of these heavily populated civilian areas."  Six people were also wounded.
Secondary.Source: Israeli military officials and Palestinian politicians

Victim.Identity.Political: Members of All Amhara Unity Party
Description: At least five members of all the All Amhara Unity Party, a member of the Coalition of Unity and Democracy were killed in recent attacks by members of Ethiopia's ruling party in the last month, opposition officials reported to the Associated Press on February 8.  Twenty-two opposition members were also seriously wounded in attacks in the past month in the northern Amhara state according to opposition leaders.
Comments: This code overlaps between January and February 2005.

Description: Reuters on Jan 14 reports "A strike brought the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo to a standstill on Friday as public transport shut down and businesses remained closed in protest at the possible postponement of elections.   Local human rights organisations say at least four people were killed on Monday when police used tear gas, batons and AK-47 rifles to stop thousands of demonstrators reaching the centre to demand elections take place by June 30 as planned.  ... Tshisekedi [opposition leader] gave a higher toll for the violence, saying seven people had been killed and 31 seriously injured."

Six Palestinians were killed by Israeli fire in the Gaza Strip Saturday, January 15.  Four died in an Israeli incursion into the Zeitun neighborhood of Gaza City, as reported by Palestinian medics.  Two more died in Rafah refugee camp in the southern Gaza Strip.  The Israeli operations came after six Israelis were killed in a Palestinian militant attack, prompting the government to order the attacks in Gaza.

Sudan said on Sunday it was probing a U.N. report that its air force bombed a town in Darfur and promised to punish the troops if it were true. A United Nations spokesman said on Friday that the Sudanese air force bombed the town of Shangil Tobaya, near el-Fasher, capital of North Darfur, last week killing or wounding 100 people and forcing thousands to flee. "We have formed an investigation committee to find out what happened and if there was a bombing," Sudanese Interior Minister Abdel Rahim Mohamed Hussein told Reuters on a visit to Dubai. "Armies all over the world have committed mistakes and it is possible that an isolated bombing took place. If this is so, we will punish the offenders."

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: "members of the Beja community of eastern Sudan"
Description: Agence France Presse reported "At least 14 people have been killed in clashes between demonstrators from a local tribe and security forces in Port Sudan, on the Red Sea, the local governor said Saturday.  Provincial governor Major General Hatim al-Wasilah al-Sammani told AFP that 14 people were killed and 16 others wounded in the clashes. "

Victim.Identity.Political: Followers of a suspected terrorist leader
Description: Kuwaiti police stormed suspected terrorist hideouts on Monday, January 31.  They were after Amer Khlaif al-Enezi, a wanted militant leader, authorities said.   The police killed the leader and four of his followers.  Three others were injured.
Comments: It is not clear if the victims were armed or not.  It is also not clear if some of the victims and those wounded were collateral damage.

Description: Reuters told "Nigerian security forces shot dead about six protesters at an oil export terminal operated by U.S. energy giant ChevronTexaco (CVX.N) on Friday, a community leader said.  "It was a peaceful protest, but instead of talking to us they sent the military to shoot us. About six of our people have been shot dead and about 10 critically wounded," Austin Ajurenmisan told Reuters by telephone from Escravos. ... A Reuters eyewitness in the nearby city of Warri said 13 people with gunshot wounds, including one with a bullet in the eye, were in hospital there. "

Villagers accused Nigerian troops of killing at least 30 people and burning homes during a raid in an area of the southern Niger Delta where two villages have been battling for control of oil-rich lands.  A Nigerian military spokesman said no raid took place.  The date of the supposed raid was Saturday, February 19.
Comments: The Nigerian military is charged with killing innocent people.  The motive behind these killings is unclear.

Description: The United Nations on Wednesday said that 13 people had died after being tortured by forest guards in the war-torn African nation of Ivory Coast. It said the guards were carrying out government orders to arrest villagers last month who had been "illegally occupying" Marahoue National Park. Twelve died in prison and a thirteenth in hospital several days later, it said.
Comments: The villagers may have been engaged in illegally activity if they were occupying the forest, however their deaths clearly went beyond the orders of the government and their torture warrants the coding of this event.

Description: An estimated 50 people were killed in Tuesday's battle in nearby Loga town between armed men from the Lendu ethnic group and U.N. troops hunting militiamen suspected of murdering Congolese civilians.
Comments: It is unclear whether the 50 people killed were armed combatants or not.

Description: Brazilian authorities are charging 12 police officers with the murder of 29 civilians.  The police officers were off-duty and went into the slums to apparently get rid of "undesirables."  It is not clear as to whether their superiors knew anything about the incident.  The shootings occurred on March 31 in Rio de Janeiro.
Comments: The original death count was 31, but on April 11 the Brazilian authorities dropped the count to 29.  They said that two people were killed in an unrelated shooting.

Description: Togo security forces and allied militia fighters have killed at least 150 people since April elections, Amnesty International said in a report released Tuesday.  The London-based rights group said witnesses told investigators of bodies being buried or dumped in morgues anonymously and that the number of people killed is likely to be "much, much higher."  Justice Minister Jean Abi Tchessa was skeptical of the report, telling The Associated Press: "We are waiting to see where and when all those people were killed in Togo." At least 22 people were earlier confirmed killed in violence since April 24 elections won by Faure Gnassingbe, son of the late 38-year dictator Gnassingbe Eyadema. Togo's opposition cried balloting fraud and citizens took to streets in many neighborhoods in the capital, Lome, and elsewhere in the country. Security forces moved into the streets and the ensuing violence caused 40,000 refugees to flee. Amnesty said the human rights violations caused by security forces and military-trained militia included extrajudicial killings, kidnappings, arbitrary arrests and torture. Togo slipped into crisis in February when Eyadema, one of Africa's longest-reigning strongmen, died and the military installed his son in the presidency. Gnassingbe bent to intense international pressure and arranged the elections.

Reuters told "Security forces fired teargas at youths in Togo's capital in a wave of protests in which at least 10 people have been killed since the son of Togo's late ruler won a disputed presidential vote. As police and protesters clashed in dirt backstreets of the seaside capital Lome, the losing opposition candidate declared himself president, and called on his supporters to remain mobilised, warning they might have to sacrifice their lives."
Comments: There is a campaign (TGO-200504) identified for this line of incidents in Togo after the elections. Yet, because the codebook asks to code any separate incident with specific information to be coded, I included this as an incident, which is the first report of deaths in the protests. A later report on June 10th, 2005 (LBA0000020050610e16a0015r) speculates that the death toll for the campaign was up to 800.

Description: Associated Press report told "Amnesty International Friday decried what it called a pattern of political killings by the Haitian police, whose spokeswoman denied accusations that officers this week shot and killed as many as nine peaceful demonstrators without provocation. Police spokeswoman Gessy Coicou said Friday that demonstrators and Haitian journalists were mistaken when they reported that Haitian police fired Wednesday on a demonstration in support of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, slaying five people instantly and leaving four others with fatal wounds. "There was no demonstration," she said. Instead, she said the deaths occurred when gunfire erupted as police tried to capture bandits attacking people in neighborhoods around the U.N. peacekeeping headquarters. Four witnesses independently told The Associated Press this week that police pulled up behind demonstrators and fired as the march approached the U.N. building"... Reuters reported "At least five people were killed by gunfire during a political demonstration on Wednesday in Haiti, which is preparing for elections in the autumn to replace its interim government. Police officers, many wearing black masks over their faces, fired at demonstrators during the march in the capital, Port-au-Prince. Renan Etienne, central director for Haiti's administrative police, said "bandits" had attacked a police patrol and that "the police returned fire." "We know that two bandits were killed, but we can't call them demonstrators," Etienne said. Five bodies lay on the street, some with gunshot wounds in the back, and at least three people were injured. No police were hurt, Etienne said... Several protesters and witnesses disputed the police account and said police fired at them without provocation"

Human.Shields: Yes, 14 civilians were used by militants as shields
Description: An Uzbek government official acknowledged the deaths of 45 civilians in the May 13 crackdown on protesters in Andijan. The government had earlier only acknowledged the death of 14 civilians used by militants as human shields.  When announcing the higher death toll the government official gave no explanation for the higher death toll.  The Foreign Ministry later said the terrorists took 65 people as hostages, 14 of whom were brutally killed.
Secondary.Source: Uzbek Deputy Prosecutor-General and Uzbek Foreign Ministry
Comments: Government offered no explanation for the deaths of the other 31 civilians and they made no statement of regret.  Description of the protesters as either terrorists or militants is highly disputed by international critics

Description: Four women and three men were found shot to death on Thursday, May 26 in Recife.  Brazilian authorities suspect police officers might be the perpetrator.  The killings occurred after the victims engaged in a heated altercation with an off-duty police officer.  The men and women were allegedly dragged from their homes, tortured, tied up, and then shot to death in execution style killings.  The perpetrators were five men wearing bags over their heads.
Comments: Police cannot confirm that police killed these victims.  It is still under investigation.

Description: Reuters reported that, according to morgue workers and witnesses, "as many as 25 people were killed in police raids on Friday [06/03/2005] and Saturday [06/04/2005] in the slums of Haiti's capital after the government said it would get tougher on gangs"; reportedly, "clerks at the morgue in the General Hospital said they had taken in 17 bodies on Saturday and three bodies on Friday after the raids in Bel-Air and other Port-au-Prince slums, centers of support for ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide... a Reuters journalist also saw five other bodies in two different areas of Bel-Air... residents said the dead were shot by police and accused police of setting slum homes on fire... police officials had no immediate comment on the death toll and it was not clear whether all the victims were killed in the raids, or if some were shot as gang members returned fire"; reportedly, "human rights groups have accused the Haitian police of summary executions and abuses against supporters of Aristide--allegations denied by the government"

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: "demonstrators protesting alleged fraud in last month's disputed elections"
Description: Agence France Presse reported "At least eight people were killed in Addis Ababa on Wednesday as Ethiopian police battled demonstrators protesting alleged fraud in last month's disputed elections, hospital sources told AFP."
Comments: Information Minister said the government regretted the deaths but defended police actions )AFP report, AFPR000020050608e168003ah).

Description: Associated Press reported that "Police opened fire on a group of angry villagers protesting water shortages Monday in a western Indian desert state, killing five people, a news report said. Dozens of villagers blocked a highway near Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan state, demanding water from a nearby dam to irrigate their farm lands, the Press Trust of India news agency said. The villagers attacked police with stones when they tried to clear the highway, said Nawdeep Singh, inspector-general of police. Batons were used first in an effort to disperse the crowd, but officers later opened fire, PTI quoted Singh as saying. Five villagers were killed and another 10 people, including a police officer, were injured, Singh said."

Reuters reported on 06/30/2005 that "in the poor suburb of Diadema, five Brazilians were killed in a shootout with police on June 22"; reportedly, "police said they were returning fire but families of the victims told local media they were unarmed and riddled with so many bullets they were unrecognizable"

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: civilians living in the Eastern Front
Description: Rebels in eastern Sudan claim the Khartoum government launched an intensive aerial bombing campaign on civilian targets in the eastern Red Sea state.  They accused the government of doing so in retaliation for losing a ground battle against the insurgents in the Eastern Front.  They said the bombing in the east began in the Barka Valley 23 June and continued the next day, resulting in a large but unknown number of civilian casualties who filled hospitals in Port Sudan and Tokar.  The Sudanese Information Minister dismissed the claims as "unfounded" and insisted the government is committed to protecting property and citizen lives.
Secondary.Source: Eastern insurgents and Sudanese government officials

Description:
Agence France Presse told "Several people were reported killed Thursday as police fired on hundreds of opposition supporters in the Democratic Republic of Congo protesting delays in moving the country towards democracy. 
"There was at least one dead; there are probably more," General Benjamin Alongabony, the national deputy police chief, told AFP, while the main opposition Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) put the toll at least six in the capital Kinshasa and others elsewhere." A Reuters report told "Congo's opposition said 24 people were killed on Thursday in a series of protests across the vast central African nation where thousands marched to demand the government quit because of delayed elections. "

People in the Haitian village Cite Soleil claim that at least nine civilians were killed when U.N. troops raided their shantytown in one of the multinational force's largest offensives against armed gangs loyal to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.  Journalists were not allowed inside Cite Soleil when the troops stormed the slum and it was impossible to verify claims by residents that peacekeepers were responsible for civilian deaths.  A UN spokesman denied that peacekeepers opened fire on civilians and could not confirm whether any bystanders were killed as the troops came under heavy fire and were forced to retreat.  The spokesman also said that gang members killed several suspected informants after the raid.  People in Cite Soleil insist that gunfights between troops and gangsters in the slum's narrow and crowded streets killed bystanders.  Five men, two children and two women were killed in the July 6 fighting according to neighbors and relatives of the victims.  Doctors Without Borders said the hospital received 27 gunshot victims on the day of the raid, all said they were from Cite Soleil.
Secondary.Source: Local villages and Doctors Without Borders hospital officials

Description: Iraqi security forces detained, tortured and killed 10 Sunni Muslims, an influential Sunni group said Monday. Government officials had no comment, but a doctor at a Baghdad hospital confirmed receiving the bodies.  The Association of Muslim Scholars said members of an Interior Ministry commando brigade detained the men Sunday as they were visiting relatives at Nour Hospital in Baghdad's predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Shula. "The men were taken to a detention center where they were tortured, then locked in a container where they suffocated," the association said in a statement.
Secondary.Source: doctor and The Association of Muslim Scholars

Description: A gun battle between Pakistani soldiers and militants killed 18 people, including women and children, in a northwestern tribal region near the Afghan border, the military said Sunday. A military source, speaking on condition of anonymity for security reasons, said the dead included 15 women and children and two men. The source spoke to The Associated Press from the northwestern city of Peshawar.
Comments: The militants were not identified further.  And the government stated that the shootout only resulted in a few civilian deaths.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: "demonstrators against a government decision to hike fuel prices"
Description: Agence France Press told "At least 39 people have been killed in two days of clashes in Yemen, one of the poorest countries on the planet, when protests over a sharp rise in fuel prices turned violent, witnesses said. Among the dead were four members of the Yemeni security forces. At least 50 protestors were also wounded in the capital and at least six towns in the south and north of the country, with government forces backed by army tanks and armored vehicles deployed along main roads."

Sudanese troops and helicopters killed seven civilians and wounded about 10 in attacks on villages in the western Darfur region, the rebel commander of the area told Reuters on Monday.  A Sudanese official who did not want to give his name said the attacks were aimed at rebel bases not civilians and the only casualties were rebel fighters.  The attacks took place at two separate sites along the road between Nyala and al-Fasher on Sunday, rebel commanders said.  "They (Sudanese forces) killed three civilians in Abu Hamra and four in Sheng al-Tobei," said Adam Yacoub, the rebel Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) commander of the area. "About 10 people were wounded in total," he added.  The Sudanese official, who cast doubt on the details given by the rebels, said the attack came as a response to an assault on an unarmed government convoy on Saturday in the same area.  "The armed forces attacked two rebel camps after the attack on our unarmed convoy ... All those who died in the attacks were rebels," the official said.
Secondary.Source: Adam Yacoub, rebel SLM commander of the area

Description: New York Times reported that "Unrest has rocked Iran's northwestern region of Kurdistan in recent weeks leading to the deaths of more than a dozen civilians and several members of the country's security forces. () Human Rights Watch reported that 17 people had been killed in three weeks of violence in several towns. A Kurdish group, the Democratic Party of Iranian Kurdistan, posted on Web sites the names of people it said were the victims. It said more than 200 people had been injured. Four members of Iranian security forces were killed near Oroumieh, a northwestern city, the ISNA news agency reported"... Associated Press reported that "Iran should investigate the killing of at least 17 people in anti-government protests in the western province of Kurdistan, Human Rights Watch said Thursday. () Human Rights Watch said it obtained a list of 17 protesters killed by the security forces, including three people shot dead in Oshnavieh on July 26, two people shot dead in Baneh on July 30, one person shot dead in Sardasht on August 2, and 11 people shot dead in Saqqez on August 3."

Five people, one of them a child, have been killed by men in military uniform near the village in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) from which they had fled last month, a United Nations sponsored radio station said Monday.  They were killed Friday in the village of Birwa, about 12 kilometres (seven miles) from their home village of Nyakakoma in Nord-Kivu province which they left two weeks ago, radio Okapi said. Witnesses said the attackers were Mai Mai tribal militias who raid the villages, which are then looted by the government forces called in to free them.

Associated Press reported that "Iran should investigate the killing of at least 17 people in anti-government protests in the western province of Kurdistan, Human Rights Watch said Thursday. () Human Rights Watch said it obtained a list of 17 protesters killed by the security forces, including three people shot dead in Oshnavieh on July 26, two people shot dead in Baneh on July 30, one person shot dead in Sardasht on August 2, and 11 people shot dead in Saqqez on August 3."
Comments: Specific information provided about this incident, which is a part of a larger campaign.

Victim.Identity.Political: suspected gang members loyal to ousted president
Description: Police in Port-au-Prince stormed slum in the capital city, apparently to root out armed supporters of Aristide.  Conflicting reports about whether violence was carried out by police or civilians, though indiscriminant violence was reported.
Comments: Police claim intent was to restore order in the capital, witnesses claim the violence was indiscriminant.

Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: "[suspected] gang members aligned with ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide"
Description: The Associated Press reported on 09/01/2005 that, according to "a top U.N. official in Haiti" and local witnesses, "police were involved in an Aug. 20 killing spree at a soccer stadium in an impoverished neighborhood southwest of the capital"; reportedly, "U.N. Special Envoy Juan Gabriel Valdes said police from outside the Martissant neighborhood participated in the killings... earlier this week newly appointed Haitian police chief Mario Andresol said several officers were being questioned for their possible involvement in the killings"; reportedly, "at least nine people were killed in the attack, either by machete or by firearms, Valdez said... He said the killings, which come as Haiti lurches toward restoring order ahead of fall elections, were planned... Witnesses claimed police were seeking gang members aligned with ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide when they stormed the soccer game... Other police and civilians surrounded the stadium, shooting or hacking people with machetes as they tried to flee"; reportedly, "Andresol said an investigation established that police were the only people at the scene with guns, 'so we know police did the shooting'"; reportedly, "The U.N. will work with the interim government and the chief of Haitian police to 'put an end to all acts of lynching and all criminal acts perpetrated by police, by people dressed like police, or by common criminals who take justice in their own hands against their opponents,' Valdes said Thursday during a press conference; reportedly, "Andresol said he had received 'reports of police summarily executing suspects,' and would not tolerate them... Andresol said that certain officers within the Haitian police had gone rogue... He also said police sometimes used outside elements to operate within slums too dangerous for regular officers... He said these men, working either for police or on their own account, were often armed with heavy weapons they received from the former rebels who ousted Aristide in February 2004"

The Associated Press reported on 10/09/2005 that "last month [09/2005], British forces used armored vehicles to storm a Basra jail and free two of their soldiers who had been arrested by Basra police... during the raid, British forces learned that Shiite Muslim militiamen and police had moved the men to a nearby house... the British then stormed that house and rescued them"; reportedly, "at least five Iraqi civilians were reportedly killed in the fighting, and Gov. al-Waili responded by suspending all cooperation with British forces... he also demanded the return of the two freed British soldiers, something Britain's government has refused to do"

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: militants from the Islamist Hamas movement
Perp.Non.State.Religious: militants from the Islamist Hamas movement
Description: AFP reported: "Several Palestinians were killed Sunday evening during clashes between police and militants from the Islamist Hamas movement in Gaza City, a security source said. Police Major Ali Makawi and several civilians were killed in clashes that took place mainly in the Shati refugee camp, the source said, without being able to give an exact casualty figure."
Comments: It is somewhat unclear whether the "civilians" were involved in the clash or if they were killed in the crossfire.

Description: Rebels and Sudanese forces have clashed in North Darfur with artillery fire killing 5 civilians, the Sudanese government said Monday. The African Union, which is monitoring a shaky cease-fire deal between rebels and the government in the crisis-wracked Darfur region, said rebels attacked an army outpost early Sunday, which was followed by "heavy bombardment" apparently from Sudanese soldiers. The fighting took place southeast of the town of Kutum before Sudanese soldiers chased the rebel fighters from the Sudan Liberation Army into the nearby villages of Kenin and Nadi, the AU said in a statement. But the Sudanese government accused "a group of armed movements in Darfur (of launching) waves of indiscriminate shelling" on Kutum, which resulted in "human and material damage" on Sunday and Saturday. "The outcome was the death and injury of a group of children, women and elderly citizens," said a statement issued by a Sudanese government delegation at Darfur peace talks in the Nigerian capital, Abuja. Another five civilians were injured.

Israel carried out a rocket attack  near the Jabaliya refugee camp in the crowded Gaza district.  The attack was aimed at two Islamic jihad members but also killed five passersby and wounded another 14.  The attack came as Palestinians were leaving the mosque after evening prayers.  The Israeli actions camp in response to a suicide bombing  in Israel the day before and the Israeli chief of staff declared a "war to the bitter end" against Islamic Jihad.

Victim.Identity.Political: "opposition supporters," members of Civic United Front
Description: A Reuters report told "The president of Zanzibar won re-election on Tuesday after a violence-plagued poll, but the opposition alleged fraud and promised protests in a growing political crisis on Tanzania's volatile tourist islands. Security forces clashed with opposition supporters throughout the day and aid workers said one person was shot dead during disturbances on the island of Pemba. Police and journalists there could not confirm a report by the opposition Civic United Front (CUF) that as many as five of its members were killed on Pemba, a CUF bastion. (...) Police could not confirm the deaths reported by CUF but said three officers were badly hurt in Pemba when a tear gas canister backfired during a confrontation with opposition supporters."

Associated Press reported "Riot police clashed with dozens of opposition supporters in Ethiopia's capital Tuesday, leaving eight people dead and 43 wounded in renewed protests against disputed elections, according to the Information Ministry."
Primary.Source: Reuters, Agence France Press, Associated Press
Comments: An Associated Press article (APRS000020051106e1b6001wk) said "Ethiopia's prime minister said Sunday he regretted the deaths of at least 46 people killed in a week of clashes between demonstrators and police. "

Description: Agence France Press reported "At least 27 people were killed and around 150 injured, many with bullet wounds, in the Ethiopian capital on Wednesday in a second day of clashes between armed police and demonstrators, hospital sources said. Doctors in five main hospitals in Addis Ababa told AFP that the dead succumbed to wounds inflicted by bullets as police fired on demonstrators early in the day in several areas in the capital. "
Comments: An Associated Press article (APRS000020051106e1b6001wk) said "Ethiopia's prime minister said Sunday he regretted the deaths of at least 46 people killed in a week of clashes between demonstrators and police. "

Description: Ethiopia said on Friday that unrest in its restive regions was under control after allegations by rebel groups this week of a massacre in the east and an uprising in the south-west.  The Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF), a group of ethnic Somalis fighting for the independence of their large eastern region, said government troops shot dead at least 30 prisoners and civilians in Qabri-daharre town on Tuesday.  Responding to the ONLF report, Ethiopia's Ministry of Information said prisoners in Qabri-daharre had killed two wardens during an escape bid. Most were re-captured.  The ministry did not confirm or deny the ONLF report that 30 prisoners and civilians had died when troops opened fire. But it did, however, dismiss as "totally false" the ONLF accusation there was "indiscriminate" shooting at civilians in the town.

Government troops raided a gathering of suspected communist rebels on a farm in the central Philippines on Monday, killing 10 people and wounding five others, the military said.  Human rights activists and left-wing Rep. Satur Ocampo, however, denied the victims were rebels and accused the army of "massacring" farmers and political activists who were holding a vigil in a rice granary on central Leyte island.  On the other hand, Maj. Lope Dagoy, commander of the army's 19th Infantry Battalion, said a 45-minute firefight broke out after soldiers raided the rebel gathering on the farm. He said 10 guerrillas were killed, five wounded and 13 captured, while the military suffered no casualties.
Contesting.Source: Human rights activists and left-wing Rep. Satur Ocampo

Description: Gunmen wearing Iraqi army uniforms burst into the home of a Sunni Arab sheik Wednesday, killing him, three of his sons and a son-in-law in an attack police said may have been aimed at discouraging members of the minority from participating in next month's election.

Police killed at least four people, most of them minors, during a weekend clash in a shantytown outside Rio, adding to a wave of violence plaguing Brazil's best-known city, police and local media reported Monday. The state security secretariat's press office said investigators were looking into allegations that the police may have killed innocent people during the operation Saturday night in the Estado shantytown in the city of Niteroi, just across the bay from Rio de Janeiro. The O Globo newspaper said five people were killed, two of them age 11. The O Dia newspaper said four people were killed, with only one of them 11. Police told O Globo that the deaths occurred after suspected drug gang members opened fire on a police patrol. Human rights groups such as Amnesty International say Brazilian police routinely kill innocent civilians in slums and then justify the killings as self defense. In 2003, more than 2,000 police killings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro were not investigated but instead attributed to "resistance followed by death," Amnesty said in report issued last week. Amnesty said judges sometimes sign warrants that allow police to search entire neighborhoods, encouraging the view that all poor people are criminals.

Victim.Identity.Political: villagers protesting "inadequate government compensation for taking their land to build a power plant"
Description: An Agence France Presse report from 01/13/2006 stated that Chinese Human Rights Defenders (CRD) called the shooting of up to 30 protesters on 12/06/2005 a deliberate attack. "The December 6 shooting occurred during a confrontation between troops and villagers from Dongzhou in Guangdong province protesting" over government compensation for taken land. "Villagers say up to 30 people may have been killed when troops opened fire on the crowd, although official media have put the figure at only three. CRD...refuted claims by the local government in Shanwei city that troops started shooting in response to chaos during the protest. ...CRD...said the villagers posed no serious threat to the 1,500 troops as the majority of the 2,000 to 3,000 villagers at the scene were unarmed."
Comments: This event might have been coded from previous information; however as official counts are only at 3 dead and the attack is just now labeled as deliberate: it is likely that the event was not coded.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 12/07/2005 that "Two more Egyptians were killed in violent incidents in the Nile Delta Wednesday [12/07/2005], medical sources said, bringing to six the number of people who died during the final day of the parliamentary elections... Mohammed Ahmed Mohammed, 25, and Mustafa Abdel Salam Mohammed, 61, died of bullet wounds to the head in violence that erupted in the Sharqiya governorate, in the villages of Qattawiya and Beni Shebl respectively, an official at Zagazig university hospital told AFP... another man was in critical condition, having sustained brain damage after being shot in the eye, the source said, adding that a total of 40 wounded people had been brought to the hospital... Mohammed Karam al-Taher also died of bullet wounds during the clashes that broke out shortly after the end of polling in the village of Qattawiya when ballot boxes were being transferred to tallying centres, medical sources had said earlier"; reportedly, "the village is considered a stronghold of the opposition Muslim Brotherhood and lies in a constituency where the officially banned Islamist movement already had an elected MP in the outgoing parliament"; a related AP report indicated that "Violence swept the final round Egyptian parliamentary elections Wednesday [12/07/2005], as police used tear gas and rubber bullets to keep Muslim Brotherhood voters from reaching polling stations... seven men and a 14-year-old boy were shot and killed"; reportedly, "supporters of the banned Brotherhood fought back, hurling stones and molotov cocktails and cornering security forces in some towns"; a later AP report indicated that an additional "man died Sunday [12/18/2005] of gunshot wounds to the head sustained during the final stage of Egypt's elections earlier this month"; reportedly, "Ihab Saleh Ezz el-Din, 27, died in hospital after being shot Dec. 7 in Damietta"
Comments: It is unclear whether this event qualifies as an atrocity, according to codebook definitions, since an AP report indicated that at least some "supporters of the banned Brotherhood fought back, hurling stones and molotov cocktails and cornering security forces in some towns"

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: villagers with whom the soldier had an earlier argument
Description: A Nepalese soldier ended an argument with a group of villagers by spraying them with bullets, killing at least 11 people and injuring 19. The killings occurred in Nagarkot and drew a slew of protestors to the hospital where the injured were being treated. The Nepalese army identified the soldier who opened fire and said he was killed in the incident. It did not elaborate.  The army's human rights cell insists it was an "act of madness of just one soldier" but villagers were not appeased.  Other details of the attack were not provided.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Rally for Democracy and Liberty (a rebel group made up largely of deserters from Chad's army, purportedly backed by Sudan)
Description: At least 100 people were killed in an attack by a rebel group on a town in Chad near its border with Sudan, Chadian officials said, the latest violence to erupt on the long, porous border between the two troubled nations.  A rebel group made up largely of deserters from Chad's army attacked the town of Adre early Sunday morning, Hourmadji Moussa Doumgor, Chad's minister of information, told Reuters.  He blamed the Sudanese government, saying it backed the rebel group, known as the Rally for Democracy and Liberty. The group is demanding that President Idriss Deby of Chad step down.  The attack comes as Chad struggles with a tide of financial, security and political woes. Mr. Deby seized power in 1990, ending a bloody civil war that had tortured the country on and off since its independence in 1960. While Mr. Deby is credited with bringing stability and, under pressure, multiparty democracy to Chad, divisions within the country's powerful military and the ruling Zaghawa tribe have undermined his authority.
Contesting.Source: Sudanese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Jamal Ibrahim
Comments: Chad has accused the RDL of being a militia used by the Sudanese government.  Sudan denies the claim.

Victim.Identity.Political: people "protesting the killing of a teenaged boy by troops in the north"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 12/26/2005 that the "Ugandan army killed at least four civilians in the last two days, three of them on Sunday after a group of villagers protested alleged military brutality in northern Uganda." According to an army spokesman, the army mistook civilians for rebels on 12/25 ; and on 12/26 when "villagers gathered and attacked a military detachment...in self defence, the soldiers opened fire killing three of them and injuring 15". Catholic church reports contested this information, claiming seven people were killed and sixteen injured. A Reuters News report on 12/27 supported claims that soldiers in Uganda shot seven protestors and wounded 16 others outside of the army barracks at the Lalogi Camp. Military officials are investigating the incident as it was "unclear why shots were fired at people." According to the Chief of Defence Forces, the crowd was armed: "they came with pangas (machetes), stones and sticks, demanding to carry out mob justice". However, the army is "investigating how that first soldier shot at civilians and who incited the population against the army." A report from the Associated Press contests the fact that the protesters were armed. A report from Reuters on 12/29 states that two soldiers had been arrested for the incident.
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse; Reuters News; The Associated Press
Citation: Agence France Presse: 12/26/20005 AFPR000020051226e1cq008py;  Reuters News: 12/27 LBA0000020051227e1cr000oq, LBA0000020051229e1ct000wy; The Associated Press: 12/27 APRS000020051227e1cr001tt
Comments: The victims are coded as Noncombatant Status Asserted but also Contested; reports from army and government officials claim that the victims were armed and perhaps attacking the army barracks. Reports from humanitarian and religious organization claim that the protesters were unarmed civilians.

Victim.Identity.Political: Sudanese refugees staging protest outside UN offices
Description: Articles from the Agence France Presse and Reuters News reported ten Sudanese refugees killed by Egyptian riot forces in Cairo, including at least one child. Reportedly, several thousand riot forces "armed with sticks and shields stormed" a small square where the Sudanese had been protesting for three months. According to the interior minister, a resulting stampede left 30 protesters injured, "most of them the elderly and young." An AFP reporter witnessed several people being dragged away from the struggle as refugees tried to resist evacuation. The refugees were forced onto buses and government officials stated that the refugees had been taken to "temporary camps" and would be allowed to return to their homes. Later reports from AFP brought new information. The Egyptian interior ministry "claimed that the protesters, some of them drunk, began throwing bottles at police and attacked them with sticks, injuring three officers and 30 policemen." Statements from the UN refugee agency said the organization was shocked and saddened by the tragedy. The head of the agency said "There is no justification for such violence and loss of life." Allegations from "witnesses said another three children and a woman had died after being taken to detention centers, although there was no confirmation." Sudan's government has invited the refugees to return home. The Associated Press coverage of the event on 12/30 claimed that security officials had reported at least 20 dead, including three children. According to the report, "An official Interior Ministry statement said 12 protesters died and 74 police were wounded...one of the protest leaders at the camp told The Associated Press that 26 Sudanese were killed, including 17 men, two women and seven children." The AP reportedly saw "police brutally attacking the Sudanese with truncheons...The AP saw no stampede. The protesters could not flee because the camp was completely encircled by police with water canons at each corner. An updated Reuters News article brought the death total to 23 according to a mortuary official report and the Health Ministry said 50 Sudanese were injured. A next-day report from AFP (12/31) stated the death toll at 25, including several children. "UN chief Kofi Annan had described the deaths as a 'terrible tragedy that cannot be justified'". Human Rights Watch and other humanitarian organizations condemned the attack.
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse; Reuters News; The Associated Press
Secondary.Source: Witnesses, protest leaders, Sudanese human rights monitoring group at the South Center, security officials

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 01/03/2006 that "Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger rebels on Tuesday [01/03/2006] accused troops of shooting dead five Tamil students in the restive northeastern port town of Trincomalee... the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) said the victims together with family members were relaxing at a seafront park on Monday [01/02/2006] when they were initially attacked with a grenade... within minutes, troops rushed to the scene and opened fire, a rebel statement said... 'As five of the students were being shot and killed, four other students tried to escape by running,' it said... 'As they ran, the Sri Lankan military's special forces fired at them and the escaping students incurred injuries on their arms and legs'"; reportedly, "the defence ministry said a grenade the students were carrying had exploded prematurely and caused the deaths of the five... 'Those young men, suspected to have arrived there in order to carry out an attack on the troops or the police, were on the beach at the time their grenade went off bringing death to five of them,' the ministry said in a statement... it said troops and police rushed to the scene and recovered one more grenade, an abandoned motorbike and four bicycles, believed to have been used by the victims"; reportedly, "the incident sparked tension in Trincomalee, 260 kilometres (160 miles) northeast of the capital... large crowds gathered outside the main hospital while forensic tests were being carried out on the victims, local police officials said... there has been a spate of deadly bomb attacks against security forces in the embattled northeast since last month in violence linked to the island's decades-old ethnic conflict"; a later AFP report indicated that although the Sri Lankan defense ministry claimed "the five were killed by an explosive device they carried on themselves... autopsy reports confirmed that they had been shot, three of them in the head, doctors at the main hospital in Trincomalee"
Secondary.Source: "the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE)"; "doctors at the main hospital in Trincomalee"

Victim.Identity.Political: Konbh tribe members protesting the construction of a steel plant"
Description: The Associated Press reported on 01/02/2006 that a clash between police and protesters left eight people dead, including one police officer. "Police opened fire Monday on demonstrators who had hurled stones and arrows at them, killing five villagers on the spot...Two injured persons later died in a hospital, Press Trust of India news agency said...About 500 ethnic tribespeople had gathered to voice opposition to a government decision to allow a private company to build a steel plant. Residents say the plant will deprive them of their land...state authorities deployed nearly 400 police officers on Monday to prevent anyone from blocking the project". A later AP report claims at least 12 tribespeople dead.
Secondary.Source: Press Trust of India, police officials
Comments: Although the report states that police fired after stones and arrows were thrown, it is still unclear whether the victims themselves were combatants or not. Victim identity is coded as Noncombatant Status Contested.
