Description: Agence France Presse reported on 01/11/2006 that "Pakistani forces shot dead 12 suspected tribal militants in the country's unstable southwest Wednesday [01/11/2006] after a roadside bomb blast killed three soldiers, a government official said... the incidents near the Pirkoh gas field, about 400 kilometres (250 miles) southeast of Quetta, were the bloodiest for months to rock the increasingly volatile province of Baluchistan... the three paramilitary Frontier Corps soldiers died and three were wounded when their vehicle carrying food for the gas field was hit a remote controlled bomb, district coordination officer Abdul Samad Lasi told AFP... shortly afterwards dozens of armed insurgents attacked the gas field, which is near Dera Bugti, the stronghold of diehard anti-government tribal chieftain Nawab Akbar Bugti... 'The soldiers retaliated and killed 12 miscreants,' Lasi said, using the official Pakistani jargon for extremists... 'The miscreants wanted to occupy the gas field,' he added... the violence came as Pakistan celebrated of the Muslim festival of sacrifice, Eid Al-Adha"; reportedly, "However the Jamhoori Watan Party, a regional political group in Baluchistan with links to tribal leader Bugti, rejected the government's account of the incident... Party secretary general Agha Shahid Bugti denied that any tribesmen were killed in the clash, saying that 12 civilians who were arrested after the blast in Pirkoh were 'later killed in the custody of the paramilitary forces'... he said that 16 civilians also died in shelling and rocket attacks by paramilitary forces late Tuesday [01/10/2006] in Dera Bugti town and Loti area, while another was killed when he stepped on a landmine"; reportedly, "the death tolls given by both sides were impossible to verify independently"
Secondary.Source: "the Jamhoori Watah Party, a regional political group in Baluchistan with links to tribal leader Bugti"

District: Pirkoh gas field 400 kilometers southeast of Quetta
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 01/11/2006 that "Pakistani forces shot dead 12 suspected tribal militants in the country's unstable southwest Wednesday [01/11/2006] after a roadside bomb blast killed three soldiers, a government official said... the incidents near the Pirkoh gas field, about 400 kilometres (250 miles) southeast of Quetta, were the bloodiest for months to rock the increasingly volatile province of Baluchistan... the three paramilitary Frontier Corps soldiers died and three were wounded when their vehicle carrying food for the gas field was hit a remote controlled bomb, district coordination officer Abdul Samad Lasi told AFP... shortly afterwards dozens of armed insurgents attacked the gas field, which is near Dera Bugti, the stronghold of diehard anti-government tribal chieftain Nawab Akbar Bugti... 'The soldiers retaliated and killed 12 miscreants,' Lasi said, using the official Pakistani jargon for extremists... 'The miscreants wanted to occupy the gas field,' he added... the violence came as Pakistan celebrated of the Muslim festival of sacrifice, Eid Al-Adha"; reportedly, "However the Jamhoori Watan Party, a regional political group in Baluchistan with links to tribal leader Bugti, rejected the government's account of the incident... Party secretary general Agha Shahid Bugti denied that any tribesmen were killed in the clash, saying that 12 civilians who were arrested after the blast in Pirkoh were 'later killed in the custody of the paramilitary forces'... he said that 16 civilians also died in shelling and rocket attacks by paramilitary forces late Tuesday [01/10/2006] in Dera Bugti town and Loti area, while another was killed when he stepped on a landmine"; reportedly, "the death tolls given by both sides were impossible to verify independently"
Secondary.Source: "the Jamhoori Watah Party, a regional political group in Baluchistan with links to tribal leader Bugti"

Description: The Associated Press reported on 01/22/2006 that "Tribal militia and Pakistani security forces exchanged rocket and mortar fire in southwestern Pakistan, an official said Sunday [01/22/2006], leaving nine civilians dead and four soldiers wounded... about 500 rockets were fired in late Saturday's [01/21/2006] clash in Dera Bugti, a restive tribal town southeast of the provincial capital of Quetta in Baluchistan, local government administrator Abdul Samad Lasi said... rebels attacked an army base, a telephone exchange and government offices, Lasi added... the tribesmen are blamed for carrying out the attacks to press for more compensation for resources extracted in the sparsely populated region... they also oppose government plans to build new military garrisons... the government said it increased the number of troops in the area to protect gas fields... the rocket attack on the base housing the Frontier Corps -- responsible for security in the area -- damaged several buildings... the rebel assault also extended to several government buildings and a telephone exchange, knocking out Dera Bugti's communications link, Lasi said... it is not immediately clear how many rebels were involved in the attack... 'The Frontier Corps retaliated. The terrorists must have suffered casualties, but I do not have any details,' Lasi said by satellite phone... but a spokesman for a local tribal leader said nine civilians, including women and children were killed, while 14 others were injured... 'The Frontier Corps carried out rocket and mortar shelling into the town without any provocation, destroying two dozen homes and a Hindu temple,' spokesman Agha Shahid Bugti said... meanwhile, a human rights group said that security forces in Baluchistan have allegedly been responsible for "some" summary executions, deaths among civilians and "indiscriminate bombings" on civilian populations... 'There were alarming accounts of summary executions, some allegedly carried out by the paramilitary forces,' the independently run Human Rights Commission of Pakistan said in a report... 'HRCP received credible evidence that showed such killings had indeed taken place,' said the report that was issued in the capital Islamabad by its chairperson, Asma Jehangir... 'HRCP expressed grave concern over the fact that militants had placed land mines along roads, and appealed to all sides in the conflict to give up violence in favor of a negotiated resolution to the complex issues of the province,' said the report, compiled by group members who visited Baluchistan, including Jehangir... a Baluchistan government spokesman dismissed the report as 'one-sided' and denied allegations troops were involved in executions or firing on civilians"
Secondary.Source: "local [PAK] government administrator Abdul Samad Lasi", "a spokesman for a local tribal leader"

Perp.State.Other: "men claiming to be Interior Ministry commandos"
Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: "an Iraqi working as an interpreter for British troops"
Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: "[a] former military intelligence official", "an Iraqi working as an interpreter for British troops"
Description: The Associated Press reported on 02/06/2006 that "In Baghdad's southern Abu Dashir neighborhood, police found the bodies of two more brothers seized from their home late Sunday by men claiming to be Interior Ministry commandos, said Lt. Maitham Abdul-Razzaq... the two brothers, both Sunni Arabs, were shot repeatedly and found with their hands and legs bound... Sunni Arabs accuse Shiite-backed security forces and militias of targeting their community in a campaign of sectarian killings... sectarian tensions are high ahead of the feast of Ashoura this week, which marks the seventh century death in battle of the revered Shiite saint Imam Hussein, grandson of Islam's Prophet Muhammad"; reportedly, "Gunmen also killed an Iraqi working as an interpreter for British troops based in Basra, police said... drive-by gunmen killed a retired teacher, aged 60, and wounded his son in southern Baghdad; while a grocer, car dealer, former military intelligence official and an innocent bystander in three separate attacks in the capital's western suburbs"

Agence France Presse reported on 02/08/2006 that four more people were killed "during a fifth day of protests against cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed" as police opened fire to control the crowd.  "A provincial official said police had opened fire to control the crowd of about 400 demonstrators" who were reportedly throwing stones. An army brigade commander "said the protesters had set ablaze four tankers supplying fuel to a base for the US-led coalition. They had also blocked a key highway passing the city." "The new deaths bring to 11 the number of Afghans killed in riots against the publication of newspaper cartoons of the prophet. Four died on Tuesday and three were killed on Monday."
Comments: The report does describe acts of violence (burning cars, throwing stones) by the protesters so the victim identity is Noncombatant Status Not Asserted and Contested.

Victim.Identity.Political: "villagers protesting against alleged atrocities by soldiers"
Description: Reuters News reported on 02/10/2006 that eight villagers (and one paramilitary soldier) were killed in clashes with security forces in the northeastern Indian state of Assam according to police officials. "Police opened fire after hundreds of villagers stormed a police station and a military camp in two towns...They had been protesting the killing of a villager suspected to be a sympathiser of a separatist group." A senior police official defended the attack claiming the forces had to open fire to control the mob. "Later the protesters set on fire a small railway station, many houses of railway workers and a post office in Makum." In an Associated Press article, the incident is said to have taken place in the town of Lajum (also in Assam). A later report from the Associated Press on 02/13 brings the death toll to 10: "On Friday, thousands of people marched to a police station in the town of Lajum in Tinsukia district to protest the death of a civilian in army custody two days earlier. Police fired on the advancing crowd, killing 10. A mob then lynched a paramilitary trooper and took several weapons.
Comments: There is confusion about the location of the incident, so all towns mentioned are listed in the coding. The report offers information from police officials that the protesters may have been involved in violence against the security forces. The victims are coded Noncombatant Status Asserted but Contested. The last report from the Associated Press confirms the fact that the crowd participated in violent action after the protest, but it is still unclear whether the original protest was peaceful or an attack.

Description: The Associated Press reported on 02/16/2006 that "The Shiite-dominated Interior Ministry announced an investigation Thursday into claims of death squads in its ranks as police found a dozen more bodies, bringing the number of apparent victims of sectarian reprisal killings here to at least 30 this week... the probe was announced after U.S. military officials indicated there was evidence to support the allegation of death squads... the 12 men found on Thursday had been bound and shot in the head execution-style... in the death squad case, Iraqi security officials said the Interior Ministry probe would focus on a single incident involving 22 Iraqi policemen who U.S. authorities said were detained last month before they were able to kill a Sunni Arab man north of Baghdad... 'They were dressed as Iraqi highway patrolmen but only four of those individuals were planning to conduct a kidnapping and subsequent murder of a Sunni individual,' Maj. Gen. Rick Lynch told reporters Thursday... Maj. Gen. Joseph Peterson, who commands the civilian police training teams in Iraq, gave a slightly different version to the Chicago Tribune for a story Thursday about the death squad... Peterson said the 22 men were wearing police commando uniforms but turned out to be employed by the Interior Ministry as highway patrol officers... He said four were believed to be ringleaders while the 18 others were likely following orders... Maj. Gen. Hussein Kamal, who announced the investigation, said the four policemen identified by Peterson as ringleaders had been transferred to the U.S.-run Abu Ghraib prison in western Baghdad and the rest were held in Iraqi jails... however, Sunni Arabs have been complaining for months about kidnappings and murder by Shiite-led commandos operated by the Interior Ministry... Kamal, Iraq's deputy interior minister in charge of domestic intelligence, hinted that the scope of the probe could go beyond the 22 policemen arrested last month... 'After Iraqi authorities were informed by the Americans about the so-called commando forces engaging in assassinations, the interior minister immediately formed an investigation committee to uncover what has actually happened,' Kamal said... Shiite control of Iraqi security forces is a burning issue for politicians trying to form a new government that the U.S. hopes will end the violence... Sunni Arabs and U.S. authorities oppose sectarian Shiite leaders with links to militia groups heading the ministry, but Shiites vow to maintain control of the portfolio... Sunni Arabs, particularly in Baghdad, have complained for months that members of their community have been kidnapped by police uniform-wearing forces, executed and dumped throughout Baghdad... 'Interior Ministry special forces detained my brother and four cousins two weeks ago from (Sunni Arab) al-Aqsa Mosque in northern Baghdad's Shula neighborhood,' 24-year-old security guard Ayad Ali Mahdi said... 'After two days, their bodies were found in pickup truck on a highway. It was horrific. Their bodies were tortured and mutilated by drills and an oxyacetylene welder,' Mahdi said... the relative of another victim described how two dozen men wearing security forces uniforms broke into his northern Baghdad home last month, pushed his pleading wife aside and dragging out his two brothers, the only men at home at the time... 'We contacted many police stations searching for them but couldn't find any trace. After nine or 10 days, we heard 36 dead bodies were found near (the southern Iraqi city of) Kut, and I found my brothers among them,' said Sunni Arab taxi driver Youssef Abdul-Karim, 35... 'They were blindfolded, handcuffed and severely tortured. One of my brothers had drill wounds in his head, while the other was shot in the head and chest'... Iraq's human rights minister, Nermine Othman, said Interior Ministry officials have been behind numerous execution-like murders, either by taking part in the roundups and killings or providing police uniforms, information on potential victims and weapons to culprits"
Secondary.Source: "Maj. Gen. Hussein Kamal, Iraq's deputy interior minister"; "an American military official in Baghdad"; "Human Rights Minister Nermine Othman"

Iraq's human rights minister, Nermine Othman, said Interior Ministry officials have been behind numerous execution-like murders, either by taking part in the roundups and killings or providing police uniforms, information on potential victims and weapons to culprits"
Secondary.Source: "Maj. Gen. Hussein Kamal, Iraq's deputy interior minister"; "an American military official in Baghdad"; "Human Rights Minister Nermine Othman"
Comments: Start Day is an approximation (reportedly, the bodies were found on 02/16/2006)

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: "suspected militants from Egypt and Saudi Arabia"
Victim.Identity.Unarmed.Combatants: "suspected militants from Egypt and Saudi Arabia"
Description: Reuters reported on 02/22/2006 that "Gunmen in police uniforms seized 11 Sunni men suspected of being insurgents from a prison in the mainly Shi'ite city of Basra on Wednesday, police said... among those killed in the apparent reprisal attack for the bombing of a major Shi'ite shrine earlier in the day were two Egyptians, police sources said... the other nine were Iraqis"; a related AFP report indicated that "gunmen stormed a prison in the city and lynched 10 suspected militants from Egypt and Saudi Arabia... a group of 20 gunmen also managed to force their way into the city's Mina prison and seize 11 suspected foreign fighters from Egypt and Saudi Arabia, all but one of whom they killed, police said"; a later Reuters report indicated that "Gunmen in police uniforms seized a dozen Sunni men suspected of being insurgents from a prison in the mainly Shi'ite city of Basra on Wednesday and later killed 11 of them, police and British forces said... among those killed in the apparent reprisal attack for the bombing of a major Shi'ite shrine earlier in the day were two Egyptians, police sources said... the others were Iraqis... the attackers arrived in a convoy of cars at the Maakel prison and 11 of the prisoners were later found with gunshot wounds elsewhere... a 12th was in a critical condition in hospital with gunshot wounds, said a spokesman for British forces occupying southern Iraq, who added that the gunmen had said they were from the Interior Ministry and presented documents for the prisoners... six bodies were found in Republic Street, police said... three were discovered in the Sekak district of Basra... two more were found in Leader Street... all of the bodies were now in the morgue in Basra, a police source said... Sunni political leaders accuse U.S.-led occupying forces and security forces loyal to the Shi'ite-led government of detaining large numbers of minority Sunnis on flimsy evidence of links to the rebels"
Israeli soldiers shot dead five Palestinians in the West Bank city of Nablus on February 23. It was the deadliest day of violence since last month's election of the radical Islamist movement Hamas.

A rebel group on Saturday accused Sudanese government troops and their militia allies of killing 27 people and stealing livestock in attacks on villages in the Darfur region of western Sudan.  The attacks, which took place on Friday according to the rebel group, came as diplomatic efforts intensified at the African Union (AU) and the United Nations to speed up peace talks and solve a row over a proposed U.N. presence in Darfur.  "These villages have been completely destroyed. They killed 27 people, 17 are injured and six are missing including children," he said, adding that he had obtained this information by telephone from JEM members in the area.  "They took 150 heads of cattle and 300 sheep," Tugod said.  government army spokesman in Khartoum said the army and popular defence forces, the official militia, had not moved into the area.
Secondary.Source: Ahmed Tugod, chief negotiator for the Justice and Equality Movement

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: noncombatant locals including women and children
Description: The Associated Press reported on 3/11/2006 that Pakistani soldiers targeted a suspected militant hideout, killing about 30 militants according to army reports. However, residents and a "hard-line cleric" claims that the dead were noncombatant locals including women and children. An army general said the attack was launched after repeated clashes between militants and security forces. He is quoted, "We did that with full accuracy on authentic intelligence, and according to our information about 30 miscreants, who included foreigners, were killed." The army would not reveal the identity or nationality of those killed.  Two residents told an Associated Press reporter that they saw women and children among the dead. The cleric, also an opposition lawmaker condemned military actions during a session of the National Assembly. Another opposition leader was critical, but offered cooperation with the government through talks. The targeted compound was said to belong to a pro-Taliban cleric; it is unclear if he was at the location at the time of the attack.
Comments: The identity of the victims is contested in the report over whether or not the victims were militants or noncombatant locals. I marked the identity of the victims as unclear and marked their noncombatant status as contested.

Description: Associated Press Newswires reported on 3/31/2006 that: " Afghan authorities have detained a border police commander accused in the killings of 16 Pakistanis, a provincial governor said Friday. Abdul Razzak, a police commander for the Spin Boldak border district, has been taken into custody and temporarily replaced in his job pending an investigation, Asadullah Khalid, governor of the southern province of Kandahar, told The Associated Press. Afghan authorities have launched a probe into the killings, reported March 21, amid conflicting claims that the victims were Taliban fighters entering Afghanistan from Pakistan or Pakistani tribesmen traveling to a religious festival in northern Afghanistan. Razzak had claimed the victims were Taliban fighters killed by his soldiers during a two-hour battle near Spinboldak, and included a midlevel Taliban commander who for months had allegedly led cross-border raids from secret bases on the Pakistani side of the frontier. However, Saqib Aziz, a Pakistani government official in the neighboring town of Chaman, alleged the victims were Pakistanis from the Noorzai tribe and killed because of a blood feud with Razzak's clan." A related Reuters report mentioned that: "...Raziq said at the time the 16 men were Taliban trying to infiltrate into Afghanistan from Pakistan. He said they were killed in fighting after his forces surrounding them in mountains east of Spin Boldak, near the Pakistani border. But many residents of Spin Boldak, and the Pakistani town of Chaman over the border, dismissed Raziq's account and said the men were innocent civilians. Pakistan also denied they were Taliban, saying the men were visiting Afghanistan for a traditional new year holiday.
Secondary.Source: "governor of Kandahar"; "Pakistani government official" "residents of Spin Boldak"
Contesting.Source: "border commander, Abdul Razzak" "Pakistani government official, Saqib Aziz"
Comments: 16 Taliban Fighters/traveling tribesmen reportedly killed on 03/21/2006, dispute about victims' identity emerges on 03/31/2006

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 3/31/2006 that the recent death of a toddler brought the death toll in southeastern Turkey to seven this week. "The bullet was apparently shot by a policeman firing into the air to disperse" about 200 Kurdish protesters in Batman. Protests in southeast Turkey began 3/27 in Diyarbakir (about 45 miles west of Batman); "Six people, including two children, died in clashes between Kurdish protesters and Turkish security in Diyarbakir... The crisis began...when thousands of people confronted security forces after the funerals of four of 14 PKK rebels killed by the army...Hundreds of Kurdish youths went on the rampage...attacking police with stones and petrol bombs and vandalizing shops and public buildings."
Secondary.Source: Hospital, government officials, local news agency
Comments: The report describes events in more than one location, but calls attention to the death toll across southeast Turkey. The protesters are identified as participating in violence, but the dead include children. The victims are thus coded as Noncombatant Status Asserted but Contested.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: "a 3-year-old boy"; "a 6-year-old and two young men"; "a 20-year-old man"; "elderly women"; "a 78-year-old man"; "people"
Description: The Associated Press reported on 04/01/2006 that "A 3-year-old boy was shot and killed during renewed clashes pitting angry Kurds against Turkish police and paramilitary officers in the southeast, officials said, increasing to seven the death toll in the worst street violence in a decade in the overwhelmingly Kurdish area... the death followed reports that a 6-year-old and two young men wounded during earlier clashes died overnight in hospitals"; a later AP report indicated that "A 20-year-old man was killed and at least seven others were injured Sunday [04/02/2006] as protesters in Turkey's Kurdish-populated southeast refused to stay off the streets for the sixth consecutive day of anti-state rioting... policemen who said they hadn't slept for days stood nervously on guard in Kiziltepe, a southeastern town home to much of the violence, and nearly every street corner here hosted a policeman with an assault rifle at the ready... outside the main hospital, an officer, his face covered with a black balaclava, brandished a grenade launcher and an M-16 rifle, apparently to dissuade family members of any of the injured from causing more trouble... hospital officials said the 20-year-old man was killed and three others injured in clashes with police Sunday, but would not say how... local Kurdish officials said they were hit by gunfire... the death Sunday brings to nine the number of people killed in a week of rioting set off by funerals for 14 pro-autonomy Kurdish guerrillas killed by Turkish troops"; a later AP report indicated that "A group of men stopped an Istanbul bus full of passengers Sunday night and tossed gasoline bombs at it, leading to three deaths when the driver reversed his flaming vehicle onto a sidewalk and ran over a group of people nearby, police officials said... at least two of those killed were elderly women, and another woman was injured and in serious condition, the police said... police said they suspected Kurdish militants were behind the attack... private NTV television said men gathered around after the attack and shouted slogans for the PKK, an outlawed Kurdish separatist group that is considered a terrorist organization by the United States and the European Union... the three deaths come on the sixth day of riots between Kurdish demonstrators and security forces that have spread from the southeast to Istanbul, which is the country's largest city and has a large Kurdish population... tension has been high in Turkey recently, and if the Istanbul bus attack is proven to have been carried out by pro-Kurdish demonstrators, it would bring to 12 the total number of people killed in related violent incidents in the past week"; a later AFP report indicated that "the death toll from a week of violent clashes between Kurdish protestors and Turkish police rose to 15 Monday [04/03/2006] when two more people died from their injuries, an official said... one of the dead at the hospital in Diyarbakir, the biggest city of the country's mainly Kurdish southeast, was a 78-year-old man who doctors said was struck during the clashes, the official added... the second was an 18-year-old man"
Comments: It was unclear from the available reports how many (if any) of the reported victims were engaged in violent activity at the time they were killed; however, reportedly, a number of the dead were very young children--including a 3-year-old and 6-year-old boy--who are presumably too young to have been actively participating in "anti-state rioting"; also, a number of "elderly women" were reportedly killed in a "molotov cocktail attack" on a bus, and a 78-year-old man was also reportedly killed

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 04/02/2006 that "rebels killed three Shiites from a family heading to Balad Ruz in search of their son who had been kidnapped the day before, police said... in the southern port city of Basra, lawyer Matr Kaabi was gunned down by armed men in the centre of the city... he was the second lawyer to have been shot dead within a week in Basra, after Maymouna Hamdani who died Thursday when gunmen pumped nine bullets in her... in the Sunni district of Khadra, a policeman was shot dead by unknown gunmen, while in the central Mustansiriyah area the religious tourism head at the transport ministry, Walid Sobhi Ahmed, was kidnapped from his car... in Hawija, 220 kilometers (137 miles) north of Baghdad, a civilian died when gunmen clashed with the Iraqi army, police said... the brothers of Sunni politician Saleh al-Mutlak and Khalaf al-Alyan were also kidnapped in separate incidents over the past week, reported an aide to Mutlak on Sunday"

District: 12 miles from the town of Vang Vien
Description: Laos Monday denied allegations that its army killed 26 Hmong civilians north of Vientiane last month, saying statements from two foreign organisations were propaganda.  Amnesty International and the US-based Fact Finding Commission (FFC), a group that advocates the cause of Hmong rebels in Laos, said the attack took place on April 6, 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the town of Vang Vien. The attack killed 26, mainly unarmed women and children, they said over the weekend, adding that four others were injured.
Secondary.Source: Amnesty International and US-based Fact Finding Commission
Comments: The government of Laos says no such attack occurred.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Justice and Equality Movement and Beja Congress
Description: Clashes between the Sudanese army and opposition forces in the country's east saw eight people killed, the army said in a statement Wednesday. The incident saw forces loyal to the Justice and Equality Movement, from Darfur, western Sudan, team up with the Beja Congress, from the east, to attack army positions in eastern Sudan, according to an army statement run by SUNA, the official news agency. Brigadier Osman Mohamed Al Aghbash said six civilians and two people from the attacking groups died, said the statement in his name. The opposition forces "attacked army positions in Wagar and Tinay, simultaneously," destroyed a truck, burnt down a police station and knocked down telecommunications equipment, the statement said.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: Random: six people, including a child
Description: Reuters reported on 04/13/2006 that "six people including a child, were shot dead by police in northern Bangladesh during protests over high food prices and shortages of power and fuel." Authorities reinforced security in Kanshat to stop the protests, which have flared since January.  Officials reported the numbers of six dead and over 100 injured. "Nearly 20 policemen were also injured. Police detained dozens of protesters, raided many homes and beat women and children, local officials and journalists in Kanshat said. 'Indiscriminate firing by police on people is absolute barbarism. Instead of solving their problems, the government is trying to suppress the people by force,' Sheikh Hasina, chief of main opposition Awami League, said in a statement."

A Chadian rebel leader Thursday alleged French fighter planes on Thursday bombed several rebel-held towns in eastern Chad, causing an unknown number of civilian casualties.  France -- which has 1,200 troops present in the country -- immediately denied the charge, the defence ministry said that "warning shots" had been fired towards rebels columns advancing on the capital on Wednesday.  "We have just learned that since this morning, in eastern Chad, French army aircraft have been carrying out a military intervention," the representative in France for the United Front for Change (FUC), former Chadian foreign minister Laona Gong, told AFP. "We deplore the numerous civilian victims of the French bombings in the towns of Adre and Moudeina", he said, without giving a precise number of casualties. France's defence ministry said a French Mirage jet had fired warning shots near a rebel column advancing on the capital N'Djamena from the east on Wednesday morning, as a "political signal". The long-distance shots were fired around 250 kilometres (150 miles) east of N'Djamena, and caused no casualties, defence ministry spokesman Jean-Francois Bureau said.
Secondary.Source: Representative for the United Front for Change, former Chadian foreign minister Laona Gong
Contesting.Source: French defense ministry spokesman Jean-Francois Bureau

Description: The Agence France Presse reported on 04/30/2006 that: four children were among 16 civilians killed in government air strikes in northeastern Sri Lanka according to statements from UNICEF and the UN. UNICEF representatives were checking on reports that an additional 24 children were wounded. A UN statement is cited as saying that up to 21,000 people had fled their homes in the Trincomalee district after the air strikes (which ended on 04/24/2006) and earlier violence. Tamil Tiger rebels reported only 15 civilians being killed, "a figure that the top local government official essentially agreed with." While the military has not issued an official apology or regrets for the dead, the Sri Lanka government has set aside $1 million in aid for the thousands who fled. The military says it acted in self-defence when it launched air and naval strikes after an assassination attempt on the army chief in Colombo. Another story from the Agence France Presse reports that Scandinavian truce monitors claim that the government may be responsible for "extrajudicial killings" and that "government air strikes on Tamil Tiger targets in northeastern Trincomalee district were a clear violation of the 2002 ceasefire accord." A government military official said, "We are unconvinced about the 'facts' on which the statement has been made by the SLMM [Sri Lanka Monitoring Mission]."

Associated Press Newswires reported on April 26, 2006 from Nepal that: "soldiers opened fire Wednesday on a crowd of thousands of villagers angry about the death of a local woman at an army base in southwestern Nepal, killing six and wounding at least 11, officials said....Versions why the shooting occurred differed dramatically. Both the military and rights activists agree that thousands of angry civilians marched on the camp in the village of Belbari, angry about the woman's death there the night before. But while Bhupendra Poudel, the defense ministry spokesman, said the crowd tore down the camp's barbed wire, sought to snatch solders' guns and tried to storm the small base, Kunjan Aryal of the rights group INSEC-Nepal said the villagers were protesting peacefully. "They were not trying to storm in," he said. "They were simply protesting." Poudel also said the woman -- a suspected Maoist -- had been shot when she tried to slip into the base. Aryal, though, said the villagers believed the woman had been raped and killed by the soldiers. Poudel said 11 villagers had been injured, while Aryal put the total at 29.Aryal also believed the crowd had been emboldened by the country's political turmoil, when weeks of protests of hundreds of thousands of people forced King Gyanendra to return power to elected officials a few days ago. "Because of the recent political changes they appear to be bold enough to march up to the army camp and seek justice," said Aryal, adding an INSEC staff member was at the base at the time of the shooting." A related Reuters report noted that "The demonstration was not linked to weeks of pro-democracy protests" and placed the number of protesters at the camp at approximately 100. However, Agence France quoted a rights activist as saying "some 2,000 people had gathered at the base after rumours spread that the woman had been raped and killed by a soldier."
Primary.Source: Associated Press, Reuters News,  Agence France Presse
Secondary.Source: "Bhupendra Poudel, the defense ministry spokesman" "Kunjan Aryal of the rights group INSEC-Nepal"
Citation: Associated Press 04/26/2006 (APRS000020060426e24q000fh); Reuters 04/26/2006 (LBA0000020060426e24q001ho); Agence France Presse (AFPR000020060426e24q002yj)
Comments: The Reuters and Agence France reports did not include the quote by Kunan Ayal (asserting that villagers were protesting peacefully), the only quoted the defense ministry's statement (stating that the villagers were storming the base and the soldiers acted in "self-defence") while the Associated Press report noted this discrepancy.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 05/03/2006 that the death toll from sectarian riots in India rose to six.  The riots left four dead on Monday; two were killed by police firing on the crowd and two others were stabbed. The death toll rose after one man died of injuries early Tuesday and another man was burnt alive in his car which was stopped by the mob.  "The clashes erupted after authorities demolished a small Muslim shrine Monday, saying it was constructed on government land."
Comments: Because noncombatants died from the actions of both police and rioters, I marked the perpetrator identity as Multiple (State and Non-State).

Victim.Identity.Political: "suspected members of the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam"
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 05/05/2006 that "Government soldiers shot dead seven civilians in Sri Lanka's northern Jaffna peninsula after a grenade attack wounded three soldiers in the same area, a pro-rebel website reported Friday. The victims were on their way to attend a birthday party Thursday when troops opened fire with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades, the Tamilnet website said." Government sources said the dead were not civilians and were suspected members of the LTTE.
Comments: It is unclear whether the victims were rebel members or civilians; this is marked under victim identity and intent.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 05/07/2006 that "the British military spokesman in Iraq, Major Sebastian Muntz said 'five of our troops perished in the helicopter crash' on Saturday [05/06/2006]... in London British Defense Secretary Des Browne said that up to five troops died in the crash... 'There were no more than five people on board the helicopter,' he told BBC television... the crash sparked bloody clashes Saturday with at least five Iraqis killed and dozens wounded when British troops sent to recover their dead from the crashed Lynx helicopter clashed with an angry mob... two Iraqi children were among the dead in the clash... following the rising tension on Saturday, Iraqi police had imposed a curfew from Saturday 8:00 pm (1600 GMT) to 6:00 am (0200 GMT) Sunday... it was lifted on Sunday... Muntz said the situation at the site of the crash was under control and troops had nearly completed recovering the wreckage of the helicopter that crashed in the largely residential district of Al-Rabbat"

Agence France Presse reported on 05/14/2006 that "Security sources said last Wednesday [05/10/2006] that 10 suspected Islamic militants had been killed by the army in the Jijel area in an attack on a hideout in scrubland near Chefka, after troops surrounded the location for nearly a month... the alleged Islamic radicals were identified by the security source as belonging to the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC)... several newspapers and local sources said three women and three children were among the 10... the GSPC, considered close to Al-Qaeda, has rejected a presidential reconciliation charter which offers to pardon armed Islamists who have not committed blood crimes and are still underground"

Perp.Non.State.Criminal: First Command of the Capitol gang members
Description: A crime wave broke out in Sao Paulo prisons, orchestrated by the Frist Command of the Capitol gang, who ordered a killing spree behind bars. Total death toll, with prison guards and police was put at 187. Since many victims were found with gunshots to the head, human rights groups fear that police used excessive violence and that innocent people were executed in retaliation for killings of officers by gang members. The violence broke out after the transfer of gang leaders to a remote high security prison
Citation: 27 May 2006 Reuters News LBA0000020060527e25r0000v     26 May 2006 Associated Press Writer APRS000020060526e25q00294

Description: At least six people killed in clashes between ruling and opposition parties during the week of local and legislative elections. Both parties claimed victory during the elections and shootings were identified as method of death.

Perp.Non.State.Criminal: First Command of the Capitol gang members
Other.Tactics: Yes (buses set ablaze, banks shot up)
Description: Twenty-two suspected gangsters killed overnight. Human rights groups suggested police engaged in extermination of gangsters in retaliation for the bloody gangster offensive in Sao Paulo. A large percentage of the bodies were not identified. In another report, death range noted as "police shot dead at least 18 assailants early Wednesday."
Citation: 17 May 2006 Reuters News LBA0000020060517e25h001nr 17 May 2006 Agence France Presse AFPR000020060517e25h003ev
Comments: It is unclear whether police killed gangsters in retaliation for other police deaths, or just in the process of halting the gangster attacks on Sao Paulo do the movement of gang members to high security prison.

Perp.Non.State.Criminal: First Command of the Capitol gang members
Description: Ten more people were killed overnight as authorities cracked down on gang violence in Sao Paulo and added to the clashes between authorities and gang members that began on May 12. Eight buses torched overnight and shots were heard in neighborhoods.
Secondary.Source: media reports, governor of Sao Paulo Claudio Lembo

Perp.Non.State.Criminal: First Command of the Capitol gang members
Description: Fifteen people died in clashes between powerful prison gangs and authorities bringing the total dead in Sao Paulo's gang related violence to 170 since May 12.

In Friday's worst violence, a gun battle between suspected insurgents and Iraqi police killed five civilians and wounded eight in Jihad, a neighborhood of western Baghdad, said police Lt. Maitham Abdul-Razzaq.

Soldiers fired on unarmed police in East Timor's capital Thursday, killing nine and wounding 27, as international troops landed to try to end the fighting that threatens to push the country closer to civil war.  Among the wounded were two United Nations police advisers, part of U.N. staff trying to end an hour-long attack by soldiers on the national police headquarters in Dili, U.N. spokesman Stephane Dujarric said in New York. The U.N. police and military advisers had negotiated a cease-fire with the Timorese soldiers, under which the police officers were to surrender their weapons and leave the building, Dujarric said. "As the unarmed police were being escorted out, army soldiers opened fire on them killing nine and wounding 27 others, including two U.N. police advisers," he said.

Reuters reported on 06/04/2006 that "A Sunni religious group in the Shi'ite-dominated Iraqi city of Basra said on Sunday [06/04/2006] that police had gunned down 12 unarmed worshippers in a Sunni mosque but police said they were returning fire against gunmen... a police source said they received a tip that 'terrorists' had taken refuge inside al-Arab mosque and were fired on when they surrounded it on Saturday night [06/03/2006]... they said nine gunmen were killed and six arrested... Sunnis often accuse Shi'ite militias of infiltrating Iraqi police units and of carrying out killings against members of Iraq's once-dominant minority... 'We accuse the security forces (police) in Basra for what happened,' said the Sunni Endowment in a statement read to Reuters by one of its officials... 'Only worshipers were killed in the mosque,' it said... 'They killed unarmed people inside the mosque'... but a police source rejected this account, saying police were fired at when they came to the mosque in the centre of the southern city... 'We got information that terrorists were inside the mosque and when we got there they fired at us and we responded,' the source said... security in Iraq's second city has deteriorated sharply over the last year as feuding Shi'ite factions tussle for powers"
Secondary.Source: "a Sunni religious group the Sunni Endowment"

Perp.State.Military: Afghan policemen preparing to join Taliban guerrillas
Description: Five Afghan police shot dead seven fellow officers as they slept. The seven policemen were asleep when the other five jumped, killed them, took their arms and then joined the Taliban. Afghan officials were still searching for the perpetrators at the time of the report.

An Israeli air strike on Tuesday killed eight Palestinian civilian in Gaza City with a missile intended to target a disabled van carrying militants. Israel expressed regret for the deaths of the civilians.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: Members of the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra (MASSOB)
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Members of the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra (MASSOB)
Description: Authorities in Nigeria's southeast Anambra State have banned a separatist group after clashes between its members and the police were reported to have left several people dead, officials said on Sunday.  At least seven people, according to press reports, were killed in clashes on Friday between the police and suspected members of the Actualisation of the Sovereign State of Biafra (MASSOB) in the Upper Iweka district of Onitsha, a major city in Anambra. But Anambra police spokesman Fidelis Agbo denied to AFP by telephone that anybody was killed in the unrest.

Victim.Identity.Religious: Civilians sheltering in Roman Catholic church
Description: The Associated Press reported on 6/18/2006 that soldiers fired on Tamil villagers taking shelter in a Roman Catholic church on 6/17, killing five. Sri Lanka's government has denied responsibility, blaming the attack on the LTTE (Tamil Tigers). Witnesses and "an international aid worker said Sri Lankan forces were responsible". According to witnesses "Sri Lankan forces stormed the church...indiscriminately shooting inside, and then fired wildly through the village." Around forty fishing boats were burned in attacks blamed on navy sailors. The government called the reporting of the incident an attempt to discredit the security forces. A witness said the Tamil Tigers may have provoked the attack by attacking a navy base hours earlier.
Comments: The incident is recorded as Contested as the Sri Lankan government denies the charge. All other reported evidence points to the State as perpetrator, and the incident is thus coded.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 6/30/2006 that "at least six people were killedrebel Tamil Tigers said". Reportedly, three civilians were killed in a Claymore attack on 6/28 and another three men were shot later that night. The Tamil Tigers blamed the Sri Lankan military. There was no reported response from the Sri Lankan government.

Thirteen people, including one soldier, were killed Friday in political violence as campaigning began for Congo's first competitive elections in decades, a human rights worker said.  Demonstrators in the western city of Matadi attacked and killed the soldier before troops retaliated firing on the crowd, killing 12 civilians in the crowd, said Christian Malidini, of Congo's Association of Human Rights Defenders. Malidini, who spoke by telephone from the city 400 kilometers (250 miles) southeast of the capital, Kinshasa, had no further details. Officials in the city couldn't immediately be reached for comment.
Secondary.Source: Congo's Association of Human Rights Defenders

Description: Nine Palestinians were killed and 24 others wounded Thursday during Israeli bombardment of the northern Gaza Strip town of Beit Lahiya, local medical sources said. Two militants from the armed wing of governing Palestinian movement Hamas members were previously reported to be the only casualties. Israeli forces launched two air raids on the Atatra neighborhood in western Beit Lahiya, which was hit simultaneously by tank shelling, a Palestinian security source said.
Comments: It is unclear if the two Hamas members who were killed were part of the nine victims or in addition to them.

Description: Israeli forces killed a seventh Palestinian in the northern Gaza town of Beit Lahiya on Friday. One Palestinian was killed and three were wounded Friday when an Israeli helicopter gunship fired two missiles on a house in northern Gaza, local medical and security sources said. The targeted house was located in Beit Lahiya, where six other Palestinians were killed by Israeli forces exchanges of fire, air strikes and tank fire earlier Friday.
Comments: It is unclear how many of the casualties were civilians.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 07/12/2006 that: "Nine Palestinians were killed, including seven children, and 37 wounded when Israeli aircraft bombarded a house belonging to a Hamas leader near Gaza City, medical sources said. The nine Palestinians died when an F-16 jet demolished a house at Sheikh Redwan, north of Gaza City, belonging to a leader of the governing Hamas movement, Nabil Abu Salenyeh, security and medical sources said. Three more missing bodies were found in the rubble after an initial toll of six, all believed to be from the same family. Another three casualties were in a serious condition in hospital, medical sources said. " An Agence France update indicated that: "Israel said it had wounded the leader of Hamas's military wing, Mohammed Deif, in the overnight attack but a spokesman from his Ezzedine al-Qassam Brigades denied the claim. Army radio reported that Deif, considered public enemy number one by Israel, was wounded as he took part in a meeting with at least three other senior Hamas military commanders. Islamic University lecturer Nabil Abu Salmeeyah, his wife and five children died in the attack, medical sources said, after the bodies of three girls were found underneath the rubble of the demolished three-storey house. Two other non-immediate family members, also children, were killed in the strike on the house of Abu Salmeeyah, a member of Hamas's political wing, in Sheikh Redwan, north of Gaza City. Another 37 people were wounded, three of them critically after witnesses said two bombs were dropped on the house, also severely damaging neighbouring homes in the densely populated neighbourhood...An Israeli military spokeswoman said the strike was carried out following information received by the domestic intelligence service Shin Beth and after Defence Minister Amir Peretz personally gave the go-ahead."
Citation: Agence France Presse 07/12/2006 (AFPR000020060712e27c003jv); Agence France Presse 07/12/2006 (AFPR000020060712e27c003kk)

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 07/12/2006 that: "Five Palestinians were killed in another Israeli air strike in the central Gaza Strip on Wednesday, medics said."

Agence France Presse reported on 07/13/2006 that: "The bodies of 12 members of the same family were retrieved from under the rubble of a house destroyed in an Israeli air strike on the village of Zibqine, southeast of the main coastal city of Tyre, police said. "

Agence France Presse reported on 07/13/2006 that: "Twenty-seven Lebanese civilians, including 10 children, were killed and 20 others wounded in Israeli air strikes on southern Lebanon early Thursday, Lebanese police said. A Shiite Muslim sheikh, his wife and eight children were killed when an Israeli missile struck their home in the village of Dweir, near the main central town of Nabatiyeh, they said. At dawn, relief workers were attempting to recover the remains of the children scattered in the family olive grove, an AFP correspondent said. "
Comments: I didn't include the "20 wounded" because it appeared that the count is a sum from all the airstrikes carried out in Lebanon.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 07/13/2006 that: "Twenty-seven Lebanese civilians, including 10 children, were killed and 20 others wounded in Israeli air strikes on southern Lebanon early Thursday, Lebanese police said...Another family of seven, including a 10-month-old baby, was killed in the village of Baflay, near the coastal city of Tyre, police said. "

Agence France Presse reported on 07/13/2006 that: "Twenty-seven Lebanese civilians, including 10 children, were killed and 20 others wounded in Israeli air strikes on southern Lebanon early Thursday, Lebanese police saidAir strikes also killed two civilians in Baraashit, five in Shour and three in Srifa -- three villages near Tyre -- police said. A total of 20 other civilians were wounded, hospitals said."

Associated Press reported on 07/15/2006 that: "At least 12 Lebanese villagers, including women and children, were killed Saturday in what appeared to be an Israeli air strike on a convoy of vehicles fleeing a village near the border with Israel in southern Lebanon, a witness said. The convoy was leaving the border village of Marwaheen, when it was attacked. An Associated Press photographer said he counted 12 bodies in two cars that were destroyed by the attack shortly after midday (0900GMT). Several hours earlier, Israeli forces across the border told villagers by loudspeaker to leave the area by 6 p.m. (1500GMT) or else the village would be destroyed. They did not give a reason for the ultimatum. The convoy of several vehicles was hit near the border fence about 1 kilometer (0.62 miles) from the village. 
The residents said they had first gone to a U.N. peacekeepers position manned by Ghanian forces to take refuge but they were turned down. There was no immediate confirmation from U.N. peacekeepers, who have a force in southern Lebanon.

Agence France Presse reported on 07/15/2006 that: "Eleven children and seven adults were killed Saturday in southern Lebanon, their bodies consumed by flames when an Israeli warplane opened fire on their two vehicles, UN peacekeepers and hospital sources said. Their charred bodies were extracted from the wreckage of the minibus and car they were traveling in and taken to hospital. 
A doctor, Ali Zeineddine, said they were burned alive. "It is very difficult to identify the bodies or to distinguish between girls or boys, as the 18 victims perished from the fire triggered by incendiary shells. They grilled," Ali Zeineddine, the doctor who examined the bodies, told AFP. Photographs taken at the scene of the carnage show bodies of young children and adults torched to a cinder, some of the corpses unrecognizable with limbs burnt entirely off. They had been among residents fleeing villages close to the Israeli border and were killed when missiles struck a car and a minibus near Shamaa, hospital sources said. The children were aged between 7 and 12. "We managed to extract four bodies which were completely burnt and evacuated to Tyre, but the others remained in the burning car for more than three hours because the Israeli shelling on the border road prevented us from carrying out our mission," said civil defense worker Abbas Moghrabiyeh... "A logistics team has retrieved 13 bodies," an officer with the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) told AFP. A rescue worker who transported the first bodies to Tyre said five more were left in the minibus. Ten other people were transported to hospital for treatment for burns and fractures, medics said. Four of them were hit in the minibus and the six others -- a couple and their four children -- in a small car. " Another Agence France Presse report indicated that: "The Israeli army said Saturday it regretted the deaths of 18 Lebanese civilians killed in an Israeli helicopter attack, but said Hezbollah militias were to blame for putting their lives in danger. The military said in a statement that Israeli forces had targeted an area near the southern Lebanese port city of Tyre, "used as launching grounds for missiles fired by Hezbollah terror organisation at Israel." "The IDF (Israeli Defence Force) regrets civilian casualties while targeting the missile launching area," it said. "Responsibility for endangering the civilian population rests on the organisation which operates and launches missiles at Israel from populated civilian areas," the army said."
Secondary.Source: UN peacekeepers and hospital sources, the military
Citation: Agence France Presse 07/15/2006 (AFPR000020060715e27f0066b); Agence France Presse 07/15/2006 (AFPR000020060715e27f005wz)

Description: An article from the New York Times on 7/21/2006 reported an attack that killed 23 civilians following Israeli warnings to evacuate the village of Marwaheen on 7/15/2006. The civilians were in a truck heading for Tyre when an Israeli helicopter fired a missile at the truck. The only survivor was a 4-year-old girl who suffered severe burns.

Six Palestinians were killed in the northern town of Beit Hanun by Israeli armor in retaliation for the capture of an Israeli soldier. Israel said it wanted to wage a "continuous operation designed to destroy and uproot the rocket launching infrastructure in the Beit Hanun area."
Eight members of a Canadian family of Lebanese descent were killed Sunday in an Israeli air strike. The family was vacationing in Aitaroun.

Nineteen civilians were killed Sunday. Israelis attacked a building containing a military office. The Israeli military claimed it did not realize civilians were seeking shelter inside the building. Israel said it regretted causing civilian casualties.

In Rmeileh, a minibus carrying two families that were attempting to escape air raids in the area was hit by an Israeli missile. Twelve civilians were killed in the attack, including two women and three children.

In Aitaroun, six civilians were killed Tuesday night when Israeli jets bombed houses in an attempt to cripple Hizbollah. The dead belonged to two couples from the same family living in one house in the border town.

Agence France Presse reported on 7/20/2006 that civilian Palestinians were killed in an Israeli raid to destroy arms and munitions. The Israeli air strike was launched on the Gaza Strip's Maghazi refugee camp. According to medics, three Palestinian civilians were killed 7/20, and two other civilians died of injuries sustained 7/19. A later article from the AFP states that over 100 Palestinians were wounded in the attack on the camp.
Comments: The Collateral Damage category is marked unclear as the mission of the Israeli military operation was to destroy arms and munitions, but the target was a refugee camp that would have clearly held civilians.

Description: Israel raids on Lebanon aimed at weakening Hizbollah resulted in the death of 25 Lebanese civilians on 19 July in the village of Srifa, 20 miles from Tyre. 10 houses were also destroyed in the raid.
Comments: This report of civilian deaths was part of an article outlining all major events during the past 24 hours in Lebanon and did not explain the nature of the raids.

Description: During raids on Lebanon by the Israeli army designed to weaken Hizbollah, five civilians were killed in an air raid "against a number of trucks" near Maarabun on a road to the Syrian border.
Comments: This report of civilian deaths was part of an article outlining all major events during the past 24 hours in Lebanon and did not explain the nature of the raids.

Description: Fifty-five civilians were killed in Lebanon on Wednesday as Israeli jets and gunboats bombed the country in retaliation for Hizbollah's kidnapping of Israeli soldiers. Israel vowed its "intensive war" would go on as long as necessary against militants.

Agence France Presse reported on 7/23/2006 that "the deaths of 11 more people in Israeli attacks Sunday raised the total number of people killed in Lebanon since the start of the conflict to 361". "Almost all those killed Sunday were in the south...Seven civilians died near the main southern town of Tyre, including a 23-year-old female freelance photographer. The others were three people killed when an Israeli missile blew up their minibus that was part of a Red Cross convoy, two people killed when another missile destroyed their house, and a civilian was killed in the bombardment of another house...The number of wounded in Lebanon Sunday stood at around 50."
Comments: While the lead sentence reports 11 civilians killed, 13 deaths are reported in the article. The larger number is coded.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 7/24/2006 that "five Palestinians, including a child, were killed Monday by Israeli tank fire in two separate incidents in the northern Gaza Strip...A 60-year-old Palestinian woman and her 11-year-old grandson were killed in the neighborhood of Sudania, west of Beit Lahiya. ...Earlier, three Palestinians were killed and three wounded when an Israeli tank fired on a building in Beit Lahiya". A later article from AFP reports the death of a five-year-old girl in Beit Lahiya.
Comments: While the report states that the deaths were two separate incidents; they are covered together and took place in the same locality and are thus coded together.

Description: Reuters News reported on 7/25/2006 that Israeli attacks killed 12 civilians in the Gaza Strip. "Medics said two girls, one an infant, and their mother died when a tank shell struck a house near Jabalya, a Hamas stronghold. A three-year-old-girl was killed earlier in the day." The rest of the deaths are not described. "Nearly 80 people were wounded, including a cameraman for Palestinian television. Six were in critical condition."
Comments: The article reports the deaths to have occurred on Wednesday (7/26/2005) but as the report was released at the end of 7/25, the date is assumed to be an error.

Description: Reuters News reported on 7/25/2006 that "An Israeli air strike on a village in southern Lebanon overnight killed a family of seven...The raid on the village of Nabatieh killed a man, his wife and five children". A later article from AFP reported that seven killed in Nabatieh brought the total of Lebanese civilians killed in the Israeli dispute to 335 dead and 800 wounded since July 12.

Despite a high death toll in Gaza, with 23 people killed on Wednesday alone, the world's attention has been focused on Lebanon, where Israeli forces have been fighting Hezbollah guerrillas since July 12.  The 23 Palestinians killed Wednesday included 16 militants; two unidentified men; a mother and her 5-year-old and 8-month-old daughters; a 3-year-old girl; and a man who was believed to be mentally handicapped.

Agence France Presse reported on 7/26/2006 that seven Palestinians, including a child, were killed in a raid on Gaza City according to reports from hospital officials. A Palestinian died earlier bringing the death toll to eight, and several were wounded in the three Israeli air raids. A Reuters article states that the Palestinians "had gathered to observe the forces. The army said it had carried out an air strike against several militants who had fired an anti-tank missile at the soldiers." Later reports from AFP bring the death toll to 15 but claim that at least six were militants. "An Israeli military spokesman told AFP that the air force had carried out 15 air strikes east of Gaza City on Wednesday, targeting 'armed gunmen'".
Comments: The coded number is the number of supposed civilians killed.

Description: A Palestinian teenager and a militant were killed Friday as the Israeli army ended a bloody two-day incursion in the Gaza Strip, which a visiting EU official said was in a state of "total crisis."  The deaths came as Israeli troops withdrew from eastern Gaza after a two-day operation that the military said was aimed at rooting out "terror infrastructure" and that left 29 dead. At least 13 of the dead were militants, including five from the Hamas armed wing and two from the Popular Resistance Committees.

Six civilians were also killed in an Israeli air raid on four houses in the border village of Ain Arab in southeast Lebanon, police said. UN peacekeepers were heading to the village which has been cut off from the rest of the country by Israeli bombardment of the main road.

The seven members of the Kharakeh family were crushed to death along with another man under the rubble of their two-storey house which was destroyed in the Israeli raid close to the town of Nabatiyeh in central Lebanon.

The U.N.'s top human rights official on Monday welcomed Israel's pledge to investigate the killing of at least 56 people, mostly women and children, in an Israeli air strike in the southern Lebanese town of Qana.  Israel expressed regret for the civilian deaths in Sunday's air strike in Qana, but blamed Hezbollah, saying its fighters used the area to launch rockets into northern Israel.

Five members of the same family -- including two children -- were killed Sunday in an Israeli air raid on Lebanon which destroyed their house in the border village of Yaroun, police said.  "The bombardments intensified on the village and a house two stories high collapsed completely, burying the five members of the Khanafer family who lived there," said police.
A report from the Agence France Presse on 7/21/2006 tells of seven Brazilians killed in the violence in Lebanon. No specifics are available about the attack. Three children were among the dead.

Agence France Presse reported on 08/02/2006 that "Five Palestinians including a child were killed in an overnight Israeli air raid and artillery strikes targeting Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip, hospital sources said early Thursday. Twenty six others were injured in the attacks, they said."

Agence France Presse reported on 08/02/2006 that "Seven civilians were killed on Wednesday evening in an intense Israeli bombardment of the Tyre region in south Lebanon from the air, sea and ground, police said. An 80-year-old couple died when their house in Tair Harfa collapsed after being hit and five people were crushed to death under the rubble of a three-storey house in the village of Yarun, police said."

Reuters reported on 08/02/2006 that "At least 10 civilians were killed and two wounded in an Israeli air strike on a village near the eastern city of Baalbek on Wednesday, security sources said. They said warplanes bombarded the village of Jammaliyeh during clashes nearby between Israeli airborne commandos and Hizbollah guerrillas, destroying several houses. They said five, members of the same family, were found dead in one house. Five more were found dead in other collapsed houses." An Associated Press update provided further details regarding the identity of some of the victims: "An Israeli attack involving heavy air strikes and a helicopter-borne commando raid killed at least seven people in the eastern Lebanese city of Baalbek, witnesses said Wednesday... A missile hit the house of the village's mayor, Hussein Jamaleddin, instantly killing his son, Ali, the mayor's brother, Awad, and five other relatives, witnesses said. The mayor and his relatives were political opponents of Hezbollah, residents in Baalbek said. The dead apparently were the victims of random Israeli air raids, they said." A related Agence France report stated that:" Eleven civilians, including a Syrian national, were killed and five Lebanese were captured during an overnight raid by Israeli commandos on the eastern Lebanese town of Baalbek, police said Wednesday. "A civilian who had been reported as missing was found wounded. So, a total of five people were kidnapped by the Israeli commando," a police officer told AFP. "Eleven civilians, including a Syrian, were killed during Israeli raids and clashes with the Israeli airborne commando in Baalbek, while about 20 others were wounded," he said."
Primary.Source: Reuters, Associated Press, Agence France Presse

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 08/04/2006 that  "At least 23 people were killed Friday when an Israeli air strike hit workers who were filling a refrigerated container with boxes of fruit and vegetables close to the Lebanon-Syria border, the civil defence service said, giving a new toll." A Reuters update indicated that "Israeli war planes killed at least 33 fruit-pickers, mostly Syrian Kurds, when they attacked a farm just inside Lebanon's border with Syria on Friday, witnesses and officials said. Syria's official news agency called the strike a "new Israeli massacre". It said 17 of the dead were Syrian workers, including five women, killed while they were picking peaches and loading them onto trucks. "I was picking peaches when three bombs hit. Others were having lunch and they were torn to pieces," said Mohammad Rashed, one of 20 people injured in the attack and taken to a Syrian hospital across the border. "Most of those who were admitted suffered very bad wounds. We are talking about amputations and very severe burns," Arfan Bali, head of surgery at the National Hospital in the Syrian border town of Qusayr, told Reuters. The workers were on a farm near the Lebanese village of Qaa in the northern tip of its eastern Bekaa Valley when the Israeli jets struck. A Lebanese security official said the aircraft fired at least three rockets at a structure as a truck was being loaded with peaches and plums. An Israeli army spokesman said that air strikes in the Bekaa targeted two buildings that military intelligence information had showed were used by Hizbollah to store weapons. But footage shown on Lebanese and Arab televisions showed bodies of what appeared to be farm workers lined up near the ruins of a small structure in fruit groves. Strewn nearby were baskets used to hold fruits."

Reuters reported on 08/04/2006 that "An Israeli air strike on a house in the frontline Taibeh village in south Lebanon on Friday killed seven civilians and wounded 10, a security source said. The source said the raid destroyed the house, where civilians were sheltering during fierce battles in the outskirts of the village between Israeli forces and Hizbollah guerrillas. "

In a searing indictment of the Sri Lankan government, Swedish-led cease-fire monitors on Wednesday accused government security forces of killing 17 aid workers early this month in Mutur in one of the worst attacks against humanitarian workers worldwide in recent years.  The statement, issued by the Sri Lanka Monitoring Mission, cited three reasons for its conclusion. First, it noted, security forces had been in Mutur at the time of the killings. Second, the government had barred the monitors from the scene immediately after the bodies had been discovered. Third, confidential conversations with ''highly reliable sources'' had pointed to the culpability of the security forces. The 17 employees of the French branch of the international aid agency Action Against Hunger were found dead on Aug. 6 in the agency's office in Mutur. Fifteen of the employees had been shot in the head. Two had been shot in the back, as though they had been trying to escape their attackers, agency officials said at the time.

Locality: Ansar, village east of port of Sidon
Description:
Agence France Presse reported on 08/06/2006 that "Six civilians were killed and five wounded early Sunday in an Israeli air raid on a village in south Lebanon, police said. An air-to-ground missile destroyed a house in Ansar, a village east of the port of Sidon, killing six of its occupants and wounding five others, the police in the main town of south Lebanon said. Half an hour later Israeli warplanes returned to bombard Ansar as rescue teams tried to sift through the rubble searching for more victims. Shortly after the raids on Ansar, the fighter-bombers carried out a series of raids on villages southeast of Sidon, the police said. 
On Saturday Israeli planes had dropped leaflets over south Lebanon warning that they would bombard positions of the Shiite Hezbollah group, especially in Sidon, a town situated 40 kilometres (25 miles) south of Beirut." An Associated Press update provided more details about the victims: "...In the day's deadliest incident, a warplane hit a house during four waves of missile strikes in the southern village of Ansar, killing a man named Ibrahim Asie and four of his relatives, Lebanese security officials said. It was not immediately clear whether Asie had links to Hezbollah. "

Agence France Presse reported on 08/07/2006 that "At least five civilians were killed Monday when Israeli jets launched two successive raids on three buildings in the southern Lebanese port city of Tyre, causing them to collapse, rescue workers on the scene told AFP. The apartment buildings were situated next to the target of an Israeli naval commando operation last week that was aimed at killing top Hezbollah militants." A related Associated Press report indicated that "Israeli air strikes on an apartment complex in the southern port city of Tyre killed at least 5 people Monday afternoon, rescue workers said. 
Rescuers said they came under fire and were forced to flee before retrieving the bodies. An ambulance was hit by an Israeli missile as it sped away from the scene, ambulance driver Shadi Jradi said. It was the same apartment complex where Israeli commandos launched a raid early Saturday, where ambulance workers had said six people were killed. Israel said it killed several Hezbollah commanders who had been planning rocket attacks. On Monday, explosions and gunfire were heard in the area and ambulances raced to the spot, where four buildings in the complex had been bombed and flattened. The destroyed buildings included the one raided by Israeli commandos two days earlier. Several other surrounding structures were damaged. Emergency services got a report that 5 people were dead, and rushed to the scene. But before rescuers could retrieve the dead, they came under gunfire and were forced to flee, Jradi said. An Israeli missile hit the back of the ambulance, but it was able to drive away from the area."

Reuters reported on 08/07/2006 that " Lebanese Prime Minister Fouad Siniora said on Monday that one person had been killed in an Israeli air strike on the southern border village of Houla, rather than 40 as earlier feared. A resident said about 50 people had been found alive under the rubble. "The massacre in Houla, it turned out that there was one person killed," Siniora told reporters. "They thought that the whole building smashed on the heads of about 40 people ... thank God they have been saved." " A Reuters update revised the death toll and gave additional details about the air strikes: "Israeli air strikes destroyed several houses in the south Lebanese border village of Houla on Monday, killing five people and wounding around 20, the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon said...Lebanese security sources said aircraft first destroyed a house where 17 people were hiding in the Hamameer district of the village. Up to six other strikes a short time later hit four nearby houses where about 40 people were staying. Residents initially said they had feared the people in the buildings were dead, adding that most were shepherds and their families who had refused to flee the fighting and leave their livestock behind. Security sources said rescue workers were unable to reach the scene immediately because Israeli aircraft were still bombing the area. Hizbollah guerrillas had attacked Israeli forces near the village earlier in the day, wounding five soldiers. "

Associated Press reported on 08/07/2006 that "An Israeli strike on the southern Beirut suburbs shortly after nightfall Monday killed at least 10 people, according to a count of bodies at a hospital. Security officials said there were at least 20 total casualties, but did not specify how many were dead versus wounded. An Associated Press photographer counted 10 bodies at a nearby hospital after the strike. Local television stations showed rescuers trying to pull survivors out of the rubble of a building toppled by an Israeli strike in the Chiah suburb, a predominantly Shiite region where support for Hezbollah is strong. Three explosions rocked Beirut within two hours of the departure of Arab foreign ministers who had gathered in the Lebanese capital in a show of support for the embattled government. Lebanese security officials said Israeli naval artillery fired on the southern suburbs from ships off the Mediterranean coast, where they also were enforcing a sea blockade. Other security officials said it was an air strike. Earlier Monday, Israeli warplanes repeatedly pounded the district, a Hezbollah stronghold that is largely in ruins." A related Reuters report indicated that "An Israeli strike hit a crowded area in Beirut's southern suburb on Monday, destroying a residential building and killing at least 15 people and wounding 30, rescue workers said. They said Israeli rockets hit the Shiyyah neighbourhood that has been spared in Israeli bombardment so far. Hizbollah's stronghold of Haret Hreik nearby had been leveled by air strikes over the past four weeks. Rescue workers were still clearing the rubble of the destroyed building to look for more people believed buried alive, witnesses said. Buildings in the street were also badly damaged, they said." While an Agence France update mentioned "At least 20 people were killed late Monday in an Israeli strike on a suburb of southern Beirut, the official ANI news agency reported. "The number of martyrs in the massacre perpetrated by the Israeli enemy rose to 20," ANI reported. Previous reports had put the toll from the strike at eight dead." An Agence France Presse report on 08/08/2006 stated that "The death toll from an Israeli strike that hit residential buildings in the Shiah district in south Beirut rose to 31 Tuesday after more bodies were extracted from the rubble, hospital sources said."
Primary.Source: Associated Press, Reuters, Agence France Presse
Secondary.Source: security officials, rescue workers, official ANI news agency

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 08/07/2006 that "Ten people were killed and 23 wounded in the village of Brital south of Baalbek city when several houses collapsed after air raids, civil defence sources said. "

Agence France Presse reported on 08/07/2006 that "Eleven people were killed and 30 wounded in a series of Israeli air strikes in the east of Lebanon around the city of Baalbek, security and civil defence sources told AFP. "

Reuters reported on 08/07/2006 that: "An Israeli air strike killed six civilians and wounded two, all members of the same family, in southern Lebanon on Monday, rescue workers said.  The workers said earlier they had been unable to try to rescue the family in the village of Ghazzaniyeh because of Israeli planes circling in the area and the fear of further air strikes. But they later cleared the rubble and found six dead, but pulled out two members of the family alive." An Agence France update revised the death toll: "At least 14 civilians were killed Monday when Israeli air strikes hit buildings in Ghaziye, east of Sidon in southern Lebanon, police said. "Fourteen civilians, including women and children, were killed during their strikes and their bodies were extracted from under the rubble of three buildings and a villa," police said. Lebanese civil defence officials said they had made contact with survivors trapped beneath the rubble. An earlier toll had said that eight people had been killed."

A roadside bomb exploded near an ambulance in a Tamil rebel-held part of northern Sri Lanka, killing five people, including a doctor and two nurses, a senior rebel official said Wednesday.  Seevarathnam Puleedevan, the rebel official based in the insurgents' stronghold in the north, blamed the army's special forces for the blast late Tuesday in the rebel-held part of Vavuniya district. But Maj. Upali Rajapakse, a military spokesman, denied the charge, saying government forces do not enter rebel-held areas.   The other victims of Tuesday's blast were the doctor's wife and the driver. Dr. Kathirkamathamby Jeyamalina was returning with his crew and his wife to Nedunkerni hospital after admitting a patient at another hospital at around 11:30 p.m. when the blast occurred, a rebel Web site reported earlier.
