Agence France Presse reported on 08/08/2006 that "At least six people were killed Tuesday in Israeli raids on the village of Ghaziyeh, close to the south Lebanese city of Sidon, police said. "The raids struck at 1430 (1130 GMT) the village of Ghaziyeh, which killed three civilians and destroyed two buildings," police said. " A related Reuters report indicated that "Israeli air strikes killed 14 people and wounded 23 in the southern Lebanese village of Ghaziyeh on Tuesday, rescue workers said. The air strikes hit the village as mourners were burying 15 relatives killed in a bombing the previous day, but were not in the immediate vicinity of the funeral, a Reuters witness said. The mourners chanted anti-American slogans after the air strike on the Shi'ite Muslim village, he said. "What was targeted was a building that belonged to a senior Hizbollah member," an Israeli army spokeswoman said. "It was on the other side of the town, not anywhere near the (funeral) procession." She said all residents of the area had been told in advance to leave."

Agence France Press reported on 08/08/2006 that "Five civilians were killed late Tuesday in an Israeli raid in eastern Lebanon, near the border with Syria, police said. Four other civilians were wounded when air strikes hit a convoy of trucks carrying fruits on a road in the Ersal area, they said. "

Agence France Presse reported on 08/09/2006 that "Seven people, including a political member of Hezbollah and his family were killed in an Israeli air strike Wednesday which destroyed their home in the Bekaa valley of eastern Lebanon, police said. Police said Hassan Sader, his wife and his five children died under the rubble when the four-storey building where they lived collapsed after a bombing raid by Israeli fighter jets. " A Reuters update indicated that "An Israeli air raid on the Lebanese town of Mashghara on Wednesday killed at least five people, medical sources said. The raid on the town in the Bekaa valley in eastern Lebanon struck a building where a local Hizbollah official lived, the sources said. "

Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger rebels said on Thursday more than 50 civilians were killed and 200 wounded in their territory in the island's east during a major army offensive to capture a disputed water supply.  Army artillery and air force fighter jets pounded rebel positions in the east as ambulances ferried dozens of wounded troops to hospital and the military moved tanks, munitions and fresh soldiers to the battlefront through green paddy fields. "There are over 50 dead (civilians) because of artillery and mortar shells fired by the Sri Lankan military as well as fire from Kfir fighters," S. Puleedevan, head of the Tigers' peace secretariat, told Reuters by telephone from the northern rebel stronghold of Kilinochchi. Fifteen of the dead were taken to a hospital in the rebel-held town of Vakarai, to the south of the site of the fiercest fighting since a 2002 truce, he said. Another 35 bodies were still to be moved.  The military had no confirmation of civilian deaths, but accused the Tigers of moving heavy guns to populated areas, and said any deaths were the rebels' fault.

Agence France Presse reported on 08/11/2006 that "Israeli warplanes struck a convoy Friday carrying Lebanese security forces and civilians that had been escorted out of Marjayun in south Lebanon by UN forces who were no longer with them, killing at least five and wounding 16, police said. They had earlier said four people, among them army and police, were killed "and 16 wounded -- some seriously -- by nine bombs fired by Israeli drones at on a convoy of vehicles which was en route from Jib Jannin to Kefraya in the south of the Bekaa valley". Three Lebanese army vehicles were hit and set ablaze, they added. Several civilian vehicles were also struck." An Associated Press report indicated that "- An Israeli drone fired at a convoy of refugees fleeing southern Lebanon on Friday night, killing at least seven people and wounding 22, an Associated Press photographer said. The Israeli military said it was investigating the incident. Lutfallah Daher, the photographer, was with the convoy when it was hit near the Bekaa Valley town of Chtaura, about 30 miles north of the Litani River. Israel has said it would attack any vehicle on roads south of the Litani, assuming it was carrying Hezbollah weapons or fighters. The photographer said that when the convoy left the Israeli-occupied town of Marjayoun in southern Lebanon, it was made up of more than 600 civilian vehicles in addition to vehicles carrying 350 Lebanese soldiers and police. A few vehicles had left the convoy before it was hit, the photographer said....Two armored U.N. peacekeeping vehicles were to have accompanied the convoy, Daher said, but were not present when Israeli forces in Marjayoun gave the convoy permission to head north. Israel's military said no convoys had been coordinated with the army." A related Reuters report stated that "Israeli aircraft fired rockets at a convoy of hundreds of cars carrying people fleeing southern Lebanon on Friday, killing at least seven and wounding 36, witnesses and medical sources said. The Israeli army confirmed it carried out an air strike on the convoy, saying it had acted on the mistaken suspicion Hizbollah guerrillas were smuggling weapons in the vehicles and that it regretted any harm to non-combatants. The army said a military inquiry concluded the convoy had been denied a request for permission to move but that it had set out anyway. "The attack was carried out based on a suspicion. It was found to be incorrect," an army spokeswoman said." An Agence France update provided additional details on the Israeli military statements regarding the incident: "The Israeli army said Saturday that a convoy of Lebanese security forces and civilians bombed by its drones in south Lebanon had not received a travel authorisation and was suspect. The Israeli military "identified suspicious movement along a route forbidden for travel which had been used by Hezbollah to transport rockets and other weaponry," a statement said. "Acting on the suspicion that these were Hezbollah terrorists transporting weaponry an aerial attack was carried out," it added... "It is important to note that a request for the passage of the convoy was submitted to the IDF (Israeli Defence Forces) coordination apparatuses prior to its departure and was not authorised," the army statement said. "
Primary.Source: Agence France Press, Associated Press, Reuters
Secondary.Source: witnesses, medical sources, army spokeswoman, AP photographer
Citation: Agence France Press 08/11/2006 (AFPR000020060811e28b004k0), Associated Press 08/11/2006 (APRS000020060811e28b000e5), Reuters 08/11/2006 (LBA0000020060811e28b0010q), Agence France Presse 08/11/2006 (AFPR000020060812e28c004v7)

Description: Reuters reported on 08/11/2006 that "Israeli air strikes killed seven people and wounded one in northern Lebanon on Friday, medical sources said. They said Israeli planes struck the area of Balenat al-Hissa, near Lebanon's northern border with Syria."

Agence France Presse reported on 08/11/2006  that "Fifteen civilians were killed Friday, including 11 in an attack on a key bridge, in strikes by Israeli warplanes across Lebanon, police sources said. Israeli fighter bombers shot missiles at the bridge in the Akkar plain, near the border with Syria, and returned for a second strike when residents had gone onto the bridge to inspect the damage. Fifteen people were wounded and rushed to three hospitals in Akkar after the early morning strike."
Agence France Press reported on 08/12/2006 that "Five civilians were killed Saturday when Israeli aircraft bombarded a village east of the port city of Tyre in south Lebanon, police said. "

At least 15 people were killed and many more wounded when shells hit a church where residents had sought shelter near Sri Lanka's Jaffna peninsula, the pro-rebel Tamilnet.com website said Monday.  The church on the islet of Kayts near Jaffna was hit on Sunday, the Tamilnet said, charging that the shells were fired by the Sri Lankan military from its Palaly base. "At least 15 persons were killed and 20 severely wounded when rockets and artillery shells fired from Palaly military base hit St. Philip Mary Church in Allaipiddy, Sunday morning," the Tamilnet said.

Agence France Presse reported on 08/13/2006 that "At least five civilians were killed and nine wounded overnight as Israeli forces staged a series of attacks across Lebanon, police and hospital officials said Sunday. A mother, her three young children and their Sri Lankan maid were killed overnight when Israeli bombs flattened their home in the southern village of Burj el-Shemali, police said. Neighbors tried in vain to dig them out and rescue services had still not arrived at the site two hours later as the nearby port city of Tyre was coming under continued raids."

The death toll from an Israeli air strike on Sunday on Beirut's southern suburbs climbed to 14 and rescue workers were looking for more bodies, a medical source said on Monday. Israeli warplanes hit areas including the Rweis and Sfeir districts on Sunday at least 18 times in one of their most intense raids on the southern suburbs. Hizbollah said it had no presence in the hit areas. The group's main offices were based in another part of the southern suburbs and destroyed earlier in the war.
Comments: It was unclear if any Hezbollah militants were killed in the attack.

Description: Two more Israeli air strikes hit the Bekaa Valley village of Brital late Sunday, killing at least eight people and wounding nearly two dozen, a civil defense official said. Among the eight dead was a child, whose body was found Monday. Civil defense workers were trying to haul out some of the rubble of a flattened house, in order to reach the body. The raids destroyed three houses in Brital, about 15 kilometers (9 miles) from Baalbek, civil defense official Ali Shukur said. More people were believed to be under the rubble, he said. Residents said one of the homes housed a Hezbollah office.
Comments: It was unclear if any Hezbollah militants were killed in the attack.

Description: Tamil organisations say 61 children were killed and 150 wounded in Monday's air force bombing on what they described as an orphanage in rebel-held northern Mullaitivu district.  UNICEF and international observers in the area have rejected Sri Lankan claims that the building hit was a Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) rebel training facility and that those killed were child soldiers.

Victim.Identity.Political: Demonstrators against a proposed coal mine
Description: On Saturday, security forces opened fire on a group of demonstrators who tried to take over a local office of Asia Energy, a British coal company, at Phulbari in northern Dinajpur district, 272 kilometers (170 miles) north of the capital, Dhaka.  At least six people were killed, and about 50 others were wounded among several thousand protesters, who had gathered at the scene under the banner of the leftist National Committee to Protect Oil, Gas, Power, Port and Mineral Resources.

Sri Lanka's Tamil Tigers said at least 20 civilians were killed and 26 wounded in air force raids on Monday in the island's east, as the army launched a new push into Tiger territory. The military said it had raided identified rebel targets south of the strategic port of Trincomalee 145 miles (230 km) northeast of the capital, Colombo. It said 8 soldiers were killed and 28 wounded during fighting to take rebel-held villages.

Fighting between Shiite militiamen and Iraqi government troops in the central town of Diwaniyah left at least 81 people dead, according to an AFP tally of official accounts. "We killed 50 gunmen in the clashes and this incident resulted in the deaths of 23 of our soldiers and injuries to 30 of them," Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki said in a statement issued as head of the Iraqi armed forces. Diwaniyah's health director Hamid Jaathi said the town's two hospitals had also received eight civilian dead and treated 61 wounded bystanders after Monday's 12-hour gun battle between security forces and the Mahdi Army militia.

Five Palestinians were killed and three wounded by tank fire in the Shejaiya neighborhood of Gaza City, where Israeli troops have been conducting operations since Saturday night, hospital officials said. The operation is part of a two-month Israeli offensive in the increasingly lawless territory that has targeted militants but often killed civilians. According to witnesses, all five were civilians.

Five villagers were killed and numerous others wounded when soldiers attacked their homes in the northeast of the Democratic Republic of Congo, UN-sponsored radio said Tuesday. The attack took place on September 5 at Monoli II, a small village in Isangi district, around 250 kilometres (155 miles) west of Kisangani, capital of Orientale province. Radio Okapi did not say where the soldiers came from but broadcast witness accounts that they had looted the village before setting fire to its houses. The central African country went through a bloody civil and regional war between 1998 and 2003 and is still plagued by violence -- in the eastern provinces far from the capital Kinshasa in particular.
Comments: The perpetrators were identified as soldiers, but it was unclear whether they were members of Congo's army or if they came from another state. I therefore coded the state role as unclear.

Description: Reuters reported 11/2/2006 that Tamil Tigers claimed five civilians were killed by Sri Lankan air assault and accused the air force of dropping four shells near a hospital in Kilinochchi. Nordic truce monitors confirmed that the bombing was close to the hospital; reportedly it "was the closest that air force bombs have fallen to the rebel nerve centre since a 2002 ceasefire." A Tamil Tiger spokesman reported that a mother, father, two children and their grandmother were all killed when a bomb destroyed their house. He claimed that fragments caused damage at the hospital (500 metres away); causing wounded patients to flee. "The military said it had targeted two Tiger military targets it viewed as threats to national security."  A later report from AP states that "a spokesman for European truce monitors confirmed the air strike and civilian deaths. [...] He said that five civilians were killed and three others wounded in the bombing".
Comments: The civilian deaths are contested by the military but confirmed by international truce monitors. The deaths are coded as not collateral damage; the military would contest this.

Description: The Ugandan army said Monday it had killed 12 people in weekend bombing raids against tribal warriors accused of shooting at a military helicopter over the country's restive northeast Karamoja region. But sources in the area said the death toll was much higher and spoke of residents reporting as many as 500 people killed with many more injuries from the bombing near the Kenyan-Ugandan border town of Kotido. Army spokesman Major Felix Kulaije dismissed reports of mass casualties as "nonsense" but confirmed that military aircraft had conducted bombing around Kotido, 600 kilometers (372 miles) northeast of Kampala.

Reuters News reported on 11/8/2006 that Tamil Tigers claimed 45 civilians were killed and 125 injured when the Sri Lankan army artillery fire hit a camp for the internally displaced. The military claims noncombatants were not targeted, but that they fired at Tiger positions in retaliation for attacks. Later estimates were at least 65 dead, and 300 injured. The Nordi Sri Lanka Monitoring Mission confirmed that an IDP center had been hit; Amnesty International condemned the attack. The Sri Lankan government expressed regret on 11/9/2006 and accused the Tigers of using human shields.
Secondary.Source: Tamil Tigers; Red Cross and medical officials

Description:
Associated Press reported on 11/08/2006 that "Israeli tank shells landed in a residential neighborhood north of Beit Hanoun early Wednesday, killing at least 18 people in their sleep, including eight children, according to witnesses and hospital officials. 
Khaled Radi, a health ministry official, said of the 18 dead, 13 were from the same family. He said at least 40 more were wounded, all civilians. Four hospitals across Gaza were treating the wounded, whom Palestinian hospital officials said were all civilians. Palestinian security officials said that five tank shells landed in the area within 15 minutes. Most the casualties were caused to a row of homes belonging to members of the extended Alathamna family. The Israeli army said its preliminary investigation indicated it had fired from a far distance toward the area that was struck. The army said it was targeting areas where rockets had been fired in recent days at the Israeli cities of Sderot and Ashkelon. However, the army would not yet confirm or deny whether it had struck the civilians, saying further investigation was necessary. Rahwi Hamad, 75, said he was awoken by the sound of explosions at about 5:15 a.m. and emerged from his home to find body parts and pools of blood in the streets. 
"I saw people coming out of the house, bleeding and screaming. I carried a girl covered with blood," he said. "Inside the houses, we evacuated dismembered bodies. We saw legs, hands, parts of heads stuck to the wall. Everything was disgusting. this is the worst, bloody scene I have ever scene." " A related report by Agence France Presse reported that "Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert Wednesday expressed regret over shelling that killed 18 Palestinians in Gaza, including women and children, and offered humanitarian assistance to the wounded. Olmert and Defense Minister Amir Peretz in a statement jointly "expressed their regret over the deaths of Palestinian civilians in Beit Hanoun." They "offered the Palestinian Authority urgent humanitarian assistance and immediate medical care for the wounded," the statement said. Peretz informed the premier "that he has ordered an urgent investigation into the matter and a halt to artillery fire in the Gaza Strip until the completion of the inquiry into the circumstances, the background and the considerations that led to the tragic results." On 11/09/2006 Reuters indicated that "Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said on Thursday a technical failure by Israeli artillery was responsible for the deaths of 18 Palestinian civilians in a north Gaza town hit by shelling on Wednesday. "It was a technical failure of the Israeli artillery. I checked it and I verified it," Olmert said in broadcast remarks. "This is not the policy."
Primary.Source: Associated Press, Agence France Presse, Reuters
Secondary.Source: Khaled Radi, health ministry official; Palestinian security officials, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert
Citation: Associated Press 11/08/2006 (APRS000020061108e2b8002ri); Agence France Press 11/08/2006 (AFPR000020061108e2b8002er); Reuters 11/09/2006 (LBA0000020061109e2b9003ci)

Description: Rebels from the NRF, the coalition that has rejected the peace deal, said in a statement that janjaweed backed by the army killed dozens of people over the past few days -- including 15 in two separate raids on Sunday. The Sudanese military categorically denied it conducted or backed any raids.

Rebels from the NRF, the coalition that has rejected the peace deal, said in a statement that janjaweed backed by the army killed dozens of people over the past few days -- including eight on Monday in the South Darfur village of Angabo. The Sudanese military categorically denied it conducted or backed any raids.

A Sudanese rebel group has accused government troops and allied militias of attacking its positions in northern Darfur, killing more than 50 people. An army spokesman denied the claim.  Abdel Wahed al-Nur, head of one faction of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army (SLA), said the army, backed by janjaweed militia, attacked the Deir Mazza area on Wednesday.  "About three armed men of the movement were also killed in the attack. The innocent citizens included women and children," Nur said late on Wednesday, adding that the government used fighter planes.  A Sudanese army spokesman who declined to be named said on Thursday no operations had been conducted in that area in the past few days and the report was "100 percent incorrect".

The NRF said that about 500 janjaweed backed by regular Sudanese soldiers attacked the North Darfur town of Madu. The assailants "gathered some children in a grass hut and burnt them alive inside it. Parents who interfered were shot dead," the statement said. A U.N. official in the region said Sunday's violence occurred when the janjaweed came to Madu to recruit fighters and were poorly received by the ethnic African villagers. The official spoke on condition of anonymity because of the difficulties facing international workers in Darfur. The official said observers were investigating reports that four children and two adults were killed during the Madu raid but could not confirm that children were intentionally burned alive. The Sudanese military categorically denied it conducted or backed any raids.

A shell apparently fired by Congolese troops fighting forces loyal to a dissident general near the Ugandan border landed among a group of some 12,000 refugees in Uganda, killing at least seven, the Ugandan military said Wednesday. Another seven people were injured in the incident late Tuesday as Democratic Republic of Congo soldiers battled renegade commander Laurent Nkunda's fighters in the eastern DRC, an official said. "Unfortunately, a stray bomb dropped amidst the refugees on the Ugandan side of the border and killed seven Congolese refugees," an army spokesman told AFP. "Seven other people were injured."

A U.N. official confirmed Tuesday that a new Sudanese government air force bombing had killed eight members of a family in a North Darfur village. Jar al-Naby, a field commander for the rebel group that controls the zone, said government aircraft bombed the village of Hashaba on Monday, destroying one house. Two men, five children and their mother were killed, he said on the telephone.

Agence France Presse reported on 12/24/2006 that five Bangladeshis were killed in the crossfire between Indian and Bangladeshi border troops. The civilians were stopped attempting to cross the border with their cattle. The Indian police also seized 17 cows.

AFP reported 1/21/2007 that a Tamil Tiger website claimed 56 civilians had been killed by the Sri Lankan forces in the first two weeks of January. "Thirteen civilians in Batticaloa, five civilians in Trincomalee, 17 civilians in Mannar, eight civilians in Vavuniya and 13 civilians in Jaffna were killed". There was no comment in the report from the Sri Lankan government. The Tamil Tiger source also recorded the "disappearances" of 27 other civilians.

A report from Agence France Presse records a claim by Tamilnet.com that 15 civilians, including 4 children, were killed and an additional 30 injured in raids carried out by the Sri Lankan air force. The air force claimed the attacks targeted a Sea Tiger base, confirming attacks had been carried out north of Mannar. Tamil sources said the raid against the coastal town of "Padahuthurai, near Mannar, left only five out of 25 homes standing." A later AFP report brought the death toll to 20 and recorded military statements denying that civilians were targeted deliberately and that compensation for civilian deaths would be paid.

AFP reported 1/8/2007 that 11 civilians were killed in "clashes over the proposed purchase of farmland to build special economic zones in India's Marxist-ruled West Bengal state". Only 4 were initially reported dead, but 7 succumbed to injuries in the hospital; "several people were also injured". A group of armed officials shot at villagers "keeping watch to block government officials from giving notice of the takeover of land". Reportedly, tensions in the area were high already from an early incident where "angry villagers fought pitched battles with police and attacked government offices" following rumors about the land takeover.

Eight nomadic herdsmen from Warsow, Somalia were apparently killed in "crossfire" during a January 8 air strike. Ethiopian forces have been accused of the air strike, but the Ethiopian prime minister and the US defense department deny this claim. Witnesses say the men were civilians.
Secondary.Source: clan elder, witnesses, and AP reporters

Description: Reuters News reported 1/25/2007 that Bangladesh was investigating the deaths of "at least 19 people [that] had been killed in [police] custody in the last 10 days." A human rights group, Odhikar, raised the complaint to a local newspaper; "police say around 3,000 people--including activists and lower officials of major political parties--have been arrested in the last week alone." Police admitted that "a number of 'criminals' linked to political parties have died in custody, but blame the deaths on natural causes such as heart failure or say they were shot during escape attempts." A second report from the AFP on 1/26 recorded claims by Human Rights Watch that Bangladesh security forces are involved in extrajudicial killings since a state of emergency was declared 1/11. "Bangladesh's leading human rights group, the Law and Mediation Center, has said at least five people have been killed in army custody and 22,000 arrested since then."

"Darfur rebels" from the Justice and Equality movement accused on Sunday the Sudanese government of bombing rebel-controlled areas of north Sudan. A spokesperson said 17 civilians had been killed in the two days of bombings. The Sudanese government "regularly denies" allegations of bombing as this violates a UN ceasefire agreement.

Security forces clashed with protesters on Monday both in the capital as well as throughout the country. The demonstrators were calling for President Lansana Conte to give up power to a transitional government. The Health Ministry reported the fatality count, and the article noted that "the vast majority are believed to have been civilians either protesting or caught in crossfire."
Comments: Some protesters were reported to have been throwing rocks, which prompted security forces to fire on the crowd, but the number of rock-throwing protesters killed thusly was not differentiated from the number of peaceful protesters and bystanders.

Description: AFP reported on 2/16/2007 that Tamil Tigers accused Sri Lankan security forces "of killing 39 civilians and blamed them for the disappearance of 39 others in the last two weeks." The attacks and kidnappings had reportedly occurred during military attacks on the island's northeast. The Tigers "said the highest number of killings was in the northern town of Jaffna, where 18 civilians died." The defence ministry claimed that the war plane attacks destroyed "mortar positions, a day after bombers 'completely destroyed' the LTTE's maritime bases in Chenmalai along the northern coast".
Comments: Reported deaths took place over a time span of two weeks; the event is coded as a campaign.

Description: Agence France Presse reported a statement by Tamil Tigers on 3/4/2007 that accused Sri Lankan forces of killing 5 civilians in the north-east. Few other details were available, and the military denied involvement in the deaths.
On March 8, AU peacekeeping forces in armored vehicles in Mogadishu were hit by a rocket-propelled grenade. A gun battle ensued. Ten civilians were killed in the attack.
Secondary.Source: Dahir Muhammad, vice chairman of Medina Hospital
Citation: 09 March 2007  The New York Times; NYTF000020070309e3390002o
Comments: Given that the gunbattle that ensued was between the AU forces and unidentified gunmen, I coded this event as multiple perpetrators (state and non-state) since it is likely that casualties resulted from both the unidentified gunmen and the AU's gunfire.

Description: Heavy fighting between DRC troops and guards of opposition leader Bemba has lead to the deaths of 10 civilians brought to various morgues around the city.

Gunmen, some of them apparently police officers, participated in the revenge killings of scores of Sunnis in the aftermath of a huge double suicide bombing in a Shiite area on March 27. The gunmen went house to house in a Sunni neighborhood, dragged people into the street and shot them in the head, witnesses and local leaders said. The killing went on for several hours before the Iraqi Army intervened. The police are mostly Shiites, although the city is mixed. An Iraqi Army spokesman said the final toll from the retaliatory violence was 70 people killed, 40 kidnapped and 30 wounded. ''They were all Sunnis,'' said Maj. Gen. Khorsheed Doski, the spokesman for the Third Brigade of the Iraqi Army.

Agence France Presse reported 3/30/2007 that "at least eight civilians were killed and several others wounded" in the Batticaloa district of eastern Sri Lanka as government troops and Tamil Tigers "exchanged artillery and mortar fire". Four men and four women were killed by shells, reportedly as a result of Tamil Tiger fire. An AFP article on 3/31/2007 reports claims by the rebel group accusing the Sri Lankan military of the attack.
Comments: The government and Tamil Tigers both accuse each other of the civilian deaths. The perpetrator is therefore coded as Multiple Perpetrators (State and Non-State) and both groups are identified.

Description: AFP reported 4/8/2007 that "six unarmed people were killed by troops in Indian Kashmir  as they attempted to cross a ceasefire border into the Pakistan zone of the state." Although the group had stopped with a warning, the troops fired on them. A military official said that the troops suspected that they were Islamic militants, but identifications had not been made.

Fighting broke out along the Afghan border between Afghan and Pakistani troops on May 14. The incident began when Pakistani forces allegedly crossed into Afghan territory. Six afghan police and seven schoolchildren were killed. Pakistan has denied responsibility for any of these deaths.

Associated Press reported on 05/16/2007 that "Fighting erupted between police and members of a Shiite militia in the southern city of Nasiriyah on Wednesday, killing nine Iraqis and wounding 75, police said. 
The clashes between the Mahdi Army followers and police began about 2 a.m. in the city center. Both sides remained on the streets by sunrise, and Nasiriyah's shops remained closed, said a police spokesman in Dhi Qar, the province where Nasiriyah is located. He said the nine people -- six civilians, two Mahdi Army commandos and one policeman -- were killed and 75 Iraqis were wounded. The police officer spoke on condition of anonymity out of concern for his own safety. It was not clear what started the fighting in Nasiriyah, 320 kilometers (200 miles) southeast of Baghdad, but supporters of radical Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr's Mahdi Army often clash with members of the rival Shiite Fadhila in mostly Shiite southern Iraq."

According to a report from Reuters News, at least five people were killed and 9 wounded, caught in the crossfire between Pakistani security forces and Islamist militants in the northwestern town of Tank. A report from AP brought the wounded toll to 12.

Victim.Identity.Political: Family members of Hamas Parliament member and a neighbor
Description: The Israeli Air Force struck the home of a Hamas Parliament member in Gaza on May 20, killing eight people, Palestinian hospital officials said. The Parliament member, Khalil al-Hayya, was not in the house at the time. An Israeli Army spokeswoman, Capt. Noa Meir, said that according to the army's initial findings, the army ''identified and hit a five-member terrorist cell based on prior intelligence -- they were the target of the attack.'' According to another report, the Israeli military said the missile hit a group of armed militants outside a house. Officials at Shifa Hospital in Gaza City said that the dead included seven members of Mr. Hayya's family, including three of his brothers, and a neighbor. Mr. Hayya, 44, who arrived at the hospital surrounded by supporters shortly after the attack, said his brothers were ''part of the Palestinian people'' and had nothing to do with politics.
Citation: New York Times; 21 May 2007;  NYTF000020070521e35l0001n                   Associated Press; 20 May 2007;  APRS000020070520e35k001p7

Description: Ethiopian troops shot and killed five bystanders on May 30 after a land mine exploded as their convoy passed through the center of a western Somali town, police said. A remote-controlled land mine detonated in the town of Belet Weyne as the last vehicle in the convoy, a water tanker, passed. "Then the Ethiopians opened fire on civilians," police Col. Yusuf Aden told The Associated Press by telephone from Belet Weyne, 180 miles north of the capital, Mogadishu. "Five people, all of them passers-by, were killed and three others were wounded." The explosion rocked the town center, and huge plumes of smoke rose into the sky, said Ali Iid, a witness. The Ethiopian soldiers fired in all directions, then controlled movement at the site for 10 minutes before driving off, Iid told the AP by telephone.

A family was traveling to a funeral on June 1 when they were ordered to stop at the checkpoint near the village of La Joya, in Mexico's Sinaloa state, according to local media. When they failed to stop, Mexican soldiers reportedly opened fire on the van. Two women and three children were killed.

Two Colombian soldiers assigned to fighting rebels in the southern part of the country were arrested for killing six unarmed civilians, including a child, during a killing spree early on June 10, the army said.  The soldiers appeared to be drunk when they entered a party being held in a school in the town of San Vicente del Caguan and opened fire, killing three, witnesses told reporters.  Three more victims, including a nine-year-old boy, were found shot dead near the building, the army said in a statement. The two soldiers were responsible for all six deaths and were arrested later on Sunday

Associated Press reported on 06/14/2007 that "Palestinian security officials said an Israeli tank shell killed six people -- including five children -- in the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah on Thursday, but the Israeli military denied there was any army fire in the area. Hamas security officials initially reported that four children were killed, but hospital officials said five children from the Abu Matrok family, all under 16, had died. Fatah security officials said the children were in a car with an adult driver, who was also killed. All the officials spoke on condition of anonymity, in keeping with policy when reporting attacks."

A land-mine explosion in Mogadishu triggered a gun battle on June 19. Abdishakur Abdi Rahman, who was driving a bus that was passing as the blast went off, said Ethiopian troops opened fire on his vehicle after the blast. "The explosion occurred as the Ethiopians were passing us, then they opened fire on us," he said. "Two passengers were killed and my conductor was wounded." Haji Mohamud Igaal told the AP that his three teenage relatives and three others also were killed.

Ethiopian warplanes bombarded several towns in the disputed Ogaden region on June 21, killing 40 civilians including women and children, a rebel official said Monday. The Ethiopian government denied civilians had been targeted or warplanes used, saying rebels had been captured in an operation it said was continuing.

Residents of a besieged Rio de Janeiro slum on Thursday accused Brazilian police of indiscriminately killing innocent youths during an assault against drug traffickers holed up in its maze of streets. Security forces and gangsters battled for five hours with guns, grenades and armoured cars in the Alemao favela on June 27 in the biggest and bloodiest offensive against traffickers in the crime-swept city. Authorities said the dead were all traffickers. Residents told human rights workers several of the victims were innocent bystanders and the police had also looted shops and houses. Authorities insist their actions were justified.
Comments: Brazilian police claimed that all those killed were drug traffickers.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: "a number of civilians caught in the crossfire"
Description: A stand-off at the Red Mosque in Islamabad between armed students and Pakistani security forces left 22 civilians dead. "A number of civilians caught in the crossfire of the initial street fighting were also among the dead." The mosque standoff involved women and children from associated schools "who officials say are being held hostage by the mosque's senior cleric"; these effective human shields restrained government action until the final day of the week-long siege. Although "no bodies of women or children had been found" after the event, several bodies were burned beyond recognition and "dozens of children and young men and women who attended a religious school attached to the mosque remained unaccounted for Wednesday".
Comments: No specific number of civilians was reported; however a total death count of 106 included 73 militants and 11 Pakistani forces. The remainder are assumed to be civilian dead.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 07/19/2007 that "An Egyptian policeman on Thursday shot dead eight relatives, including three of his brothers, during an argument over an inheritance, a security source said. The 28-year-old state security officer used his service pistol to kill the brothers, two of his sisters-in-law as well as three nephews aged 15, 16 and 24, before being arrested, the source said. A niece and a nephew, aged 18 and 28 respectively, were also wounded in the shooting in a village outside Minya, a Nile city around 200 kilometres (135 miles) south of Cairo. Locals said the man had a reputation for abusing his influence as a state security officer."
Six people were killed and ten injured on a minibus when they were attacked by Ethiopian soldiers who had just come under grenade attacks by insurgents.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center.

Description: At least 15 were killed Thursday in the Degan village of North Waziristan Agency after government troops shelled the area in response to a roadside explosion in the area that had injured soldiers. While an army spokesman insisted that those killed were militants, residents of Degan said that everyone killed was an "ordinary tribesman."
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center.

Description: Ethiopian soldiers opened fire on a bus full of civilians on August 14, killing 10 people and wounding ten others. Ethiopia denied carrying out the bus attack. There was no other information.

Associated Press reported on 08/15/2007 that "Iraqi police and residents clashed with suspected al-Qaida-linked gunmen early Wednesday northeast of Baghdad, and 14 people were killed in the fighting, police said. The battle began after mortar rounds fell on Buhriz, a suburb of Baqouba, some 60 kilometers (35 miles) northeast of the Iraqi capital, a police officer said on condition of anonymity out of security concerns. 
Residents and local police amassed at the center of town and took up positions in grassy areas on the edge of Buhriz, battling suspected al-Qaida attackers for three hours, the officer said. Eight of those killed were gunmen, and six were civilians, he said. Twenty others were wounded -- all civilians, the officer added. Another officer, Col. Yahya al-Nidawi, said locals succeeded in fighting off the al-Qaida attackers. With the help of almighty God, the brave residents of Buhriz and our gallant police, we were able to repel and eliminate them (the attackers)," al-Nidawi said. By midmorning, several bodies lay scattered on a main street in Buhriz, with residents milling around them. One of the dead men was wearing an ammunition vest, but it was unclear whether he was a resident or one of the attackers. Grieving relatives loaded at least two bodies into wooden coffins covered in blankets."
Comments: The report did not clarify the actual perpetrator of the civilian victims.

Description: In an attack on foreign militants, Pakistani troops reportedly killed 5 civilians. "Two women, two children, and a man--died when their home was bombed in Hurmaz, a village near Mir Ali, an intelligence official in Miran Shah, North Waziristan's main town, said on condition of anonymity." However a military official "told the Associated Press that he had no confirmation of any civilian casualties."

Perp.Non.State.Criminal: members of the Sungu Sungu vigilante group
Description: Five people, three of them brothers, have been killed in Bonyamasicho in Kisii District, by a gang believed to be the dreaded Sungu Sungu vigilante group. The deceased were dragged from their houses and bludgeoned with crude weapons. Residents claim the attackers were accompanied by uniformed gun-wielding police officers. The deceased were suspected criminals believed to have been terrorizing residents for the past two years. They were beaten to death with crude weapons.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center.

Description: Five civilians were killed in the Suuqa Xoolaha neighborhood of Mogadishu on Sunday. Those killed were hit by shots fired by government forces and by bombs targeting government forces.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center.

Description: Government troops resorted to using military aircraft to dislodge a strategic ANC/CNDP position on one of the hills in the Karuba sector to make it possible for its units to move forwards along the Sake-Kimoka-Kabati road. After taking hits from CNDP anti-aircraft guns, the bomber missed its target and ended up spitting fire on civilian habitations, killing 37 and wounding fifties of civilians.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center. The date of the event is unclear from the article. The date the article was published is listed.

Description: At least six people were killed and dozens more were wounded in fierce clashes that erupted inside the main Bakara market in south of the Somalia capital Mogadishu on early Wednesday between the government security forces and the Islamist rebel groups.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center. It is unclear exactly how many of those killed were civilians, but "reliable sources" said that the dead were mainly civilians.

Description: Two police officers were arrested Tuesday in the killings of five youths who were shot repeatedly in the head and dumped in the outskirts of Guatemala City, authorities said. The victims, ages 17 to 22, were playing soccer in a street in a rough Guatemala City neighborhood when they were abducted on September 21. Relatives filed a report with the Human Rights Defender's office saying they had been taken away in patrol cars. Investigators were trying to determine if more officers were involved in the killings. Four of the victims had "sizable" criminal records.

Six civilians were killed when Ugandan soldiers opened fire on a Congolese passenger boat on Lake Albert on September 25, in the latest border flare up between the Great Lakes neighbours, U.N. officials said on Tuesday. In a conflicting version of the shooting incident, Uganda's military reported two soldiers killed, one from each country, in what it said was a gunfight during a dispute over an oil exploration vessel working on the border lake.
Comments: The country in whose territory this incident occurred was unclear. I selected Uganda randomly, but it may have happened in Congo's part of Lake Albert.

Description: Two woman and three children of a family were killed by a stray shell amidst clashes between local Taliban militants and security forces in North Waziristan late on Tuesday. Reports reaching here said two security checkposts were attacked simultaneously east and south of Miranshah and security forces retaliated with artillery fire. The militants have adopted a new strategy, to attack checkposts in dark, to prompt indiscriminate fire from the security forces to cause collateral damage among the civilians in a bid to win local population's support, the local residents said.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center.

Description: On Thursday, at least 9 anti-government demonstrators were killed in Yangon when soldiers and riot police tried to clear the streets by spraying automatic weapons fire into the crowd. Outsiders, however, including the Australian ambassador to Myanmar, say the true death tolls may be much higher than the figures given by the state.

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: militias allied with Sudanese government troops
Description: At least 45 civilians were killed in the town of Muhajiriya in southern Darfur on Oct. 8 after Sudanese army troops stormed the town and bombed it, according to the Sudan Liberation Army. The Sudanese army has denied this charge.
Early Sunday Islamic militants attacked the Mogadishu football stadium, which houses Ethiopian forces. The resulting clashes have killed 23, most of whom were civilians in the area.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center.

Perp.Non.State.Religious: "local militants linked with the ousted Islamic Courts"
Description: On Sunday, thee Ethiopian soldiers and six Somali civilians were killed in heavy fighting between the soldiers and "local militants linked with the ousted Islamic Courts." The fighting occurred in the Suuqa-Xhoola village in Huriwa district north of Mogadishu and began when the militants ambushed an Ethiopian military convoy passing the village.
Comments: This event is the result of a supplemental search utilizing Open Source Center. There are conflicting reports regarding the number of civilians killed.

Description: Eighty people died in 48 hours of fighting Friday that began when Ethiopian troops tried to retrieve the body of a soldier dragged through the streets of Mogadishu. Ethiopian troops fired tank shells in the north of the city, hitting a livestock market seen as a hotbed of insurgent supporters. Mogadishu's mayor accused members of the Islamic militant Shabab fighters of being responsible for the violence.
Comments: The article did not make clear how many of the 80 killed were civilians, nor did it clarify how many were killed by Ethiopian troops and how many by the Shabab fighters. The available information, however, seemed to indicate that most of those killed were in fact civilians. Further, the article did not discuss the death tolls for the individual events that led to the overall death toll for the day.

Description: The Ogaden National Liberation Front is alleging that the Ethiopian government strafed and killed up to a dozen nomads with helicopter gunships near the village of Gurdumi. The government has denied that any fighting is going on in this region, but an American diplomat said that the reports were true but it was unclear whether the helicopter gunships were being used to track down rebels or for reprisals against villages.
Secondary.Source: spokesman for the Ogaden National Liberation Front Abdirahman Mahdi
Contesting.Source: Ethiopian military spokesman Col. Yasaf Adankegn

Description: A rally turned into violence between Adivasi protesters and residents in "Gauhati, the capital of Assam state" according to an article from AP. "Police opened fire on the crowd to quell the violence" of "some of the marchers [who] pelted shops and vehicles with stones, sparking a similar response from ethnic Assamese residents." Six were left dead, and more than 130 were injured.
AP reported that a roadside bomb activated by the Sri Lankan military killed eleven schoolchildren and two others "about 15 miles west of the Tigers' de facto capital of Kilinochchi".

Five people were killed during fighting in the Suga Holaha neighborhood of Mogadishu on Thursday during clashes between Ethiopian troops and pro-Islamist rebels. All of the victims were thought to be civilians, but the army says witnesses mistake insurgents for residents.
A Reuters article reported "ten civilians were killed in the [Swat] valley on Thursday when government artillery shells hit their houses, residents said."

Five people were killed during fighting in the Yaqshid district of Mogadishu Friday during clashes between Ethiopian troops and pro-Islamist rebels. All of the victims were thought to be civilians, but the army says witnesses mistake insurgents for residents.

Seven civilians were killed during a battled between army and rebel forces from the Niger Movement for Justice in the region of Tiguidit, 80 km southeast of Agadez, over the weekend. A rebel fighter was also killed.

Insurgents armed with rocket-propelled grenades and assault rifles attacked an Ethiopian army base in northern Mogadishu, triggering a deadly nighttime clash that sent stray mortar rounds crashing into homes, residents and witnesses said Sunday. At least five Somalis were killed and eight wounded in the crossfire, they said.

The Kenya Medical association announced on Friday that nine people were killed in Mumias in Western province and 16 injured by bullet wounds inflicted by police on unarmed demonstrators in the aftermath of the December presidential election.
Comments: This event came from an article obtained through BBC Monitoring Africa and was recorded as part of a special investigation, at the request of a sponsor, into the violence that followed the December 2007 presidential election in Kenya.

Description: The Kenya Medical association announced on Friday that five people were killed in Bungoma in Western province and 8 injured by bullet wounds inflicted by police on unarmed demonstrators in the aftermath of the December presidential election.
Comments: This event came from an article obtained through BBC Monitoring Africa and was recorded as part of a special investigation, at the request of a sponsor, into the violence that followed the December 2007 presidential election in Kenya.

Description: The Kenya Medical association announced on Friday that five people were killed in Kisumu in Nyanza province and 8 injured by bullet wounds inflicted by police on unarmed demonstrators in the aftermath of the December presidential election.
Comments: This event came from an article obtained through BBC Monitoring Africa and was recorded as part of a special investigation, at the request of a sponsor, into the violence that followed the December 2007 presidential election in Kenya.

Perp.State.Other: Sudanese People's Liberation Movement military wing forces
Description: The Sudan People's Liberation Movement accused Sudanese armed forces of attacking civilian areas in Bahr el-Ghazal Saturday, killing 28 civilians. The group also said that its military wing, the SPLA, had engaged the militias in order to protect the civilians. Sudan's armed forces denied having any role in the clashes.

A mortar round fired during fighting between Somali insurgents and Ethiopian troops killed a mother and her five young children in the capital Mogadishu, a witness and a relative said. Insurgents attacked bases of Ethiopian troops in the south of the capital with mortars and the Ethiopians fired back, said neighbor Mostaf Abdi Ahmed. About 30 mortar rounds were fired, he said.

Congolese soldiers shot and killed at least eight villagers, including three children, in the violence-ravaged North Kivu province last week, witnesses have told U.N. investigators. The villagers were killed on Jan. 2 in Musezero, 50 km (32 miles) north of the provincial capital Goma. Another person is still missing. "Some (witnesses) are saying men in uniform, others were more certain, saying it was a patrol of the (army's) Second Integrated Brigade," Kemal Saiki, spokesman for Congo's U.N. peacekeeping mission, told Reuters on Wednesday. "Some said they fired indiscriminately without warning after mistaking them for CNDP ... But these were unarmed civilians."
Secondary.Source: spokesman for Congo's UN peacekeeping mission Kemal Saiki

Description: Raila Odinga accused police of shooting dead seven people in Nairobi on Thursday during a second day of clashes over President Mwai Kibaki's disputed re-election.
In Kibera on Friday, police opened fire in the slum, killing seven and injuring at least 11.

Six people were killed on the 18th in Nairobi's Kibera slum by police who shot agitated protesters as they toured the slum, cracking down on residents following the vandalism of a nearby railway line.
Comments: This event came from an article obtained through BBC Monitoring Africa and was recorded as part of a special investigation, at the request of a sponsor, into the violence that followed the December 2007 presidential election in Kenya.

Description: Islamic militants firing rockets and mortars clashed with Somali troops and their Ethiopian allies in fighting that killed at least 17 civilians and two Ethiopian soldiers in the capital, witnesses said Tuesday. The fighting occurred late Monday as Somali and Ethiopian troops conducted house-to-house searches in Mogadishu's northern Hiliwa district, traditional elder Mohamud Haji Nur said. Insurgents also fired mortars and rocket-propelled grenades at a former pasta factory where the Ethiopians have a military base. The Ethiopians responded with artillery shells that slammed into nearby residential areas, Nur said.
Comments: Two Ethiopian soldiers died in the clashes as well.

Description: Reuters reported a claim by "a pro-rebel Web site [that] said 8 civilians including children were killed and 35 wounded on Tuesday in a roadside bomb targeting a school bus, which it blamed on the army. A military spokesman denied the report." AP later reported the claim, raising the death toll to "18 civilians, including 11 children".

In Chad's capital N'Djamena a three-day coup attempt led to intense fighting between rebels led by Mahamat Nouri and government forces, with more than 400 civilians killed in the fighting, mostly by bullets.

On Monday, seven civilians were killed in the Maimbung township on Jolo island, allegedly by Philippine soldiers searching for Abu Sayyaf militants who had recently abducted a businesswoman. Victims' families report that the civilians killed were tied up and shot by troops and that two others were also shot as they fled after hearing gunfire.
Comments: There is a corresponding event for the two soldiers and three militants killed in the fighting in the combatant file.

Description: On Friday, the Sudanese military said it bombed three towns in West Darfur--Sirba, Sileia, and Abu Suruj--while striking at rebel forces. Darfur rebels deny that any of their fighters were in the bombed towns and that 200 people were killed in the attacks that included airstrikes and janjaweed.

Reuters relayed information provided by Tamil Tigers; according to the report "Sri Lankan government fighter jets killed eight civilians, including three young children" in an attack on the Kiranchi area. The government asserted that "it had bombed and destroyed an isolated rebel boat yard housing vessels used in suicide missions"; the Tamil Tigers insisted that it was a "coastal civilian settlement". Reportedly, ten civilians were also wounded in the attack and four of the wounded were in critical condition.
At least 30 civilians were killed on February 23 as clashes between Israel and Palestinian militants intensified in the Gaza Strip.

Human rights campaigners in Cameroon accused the government on Wednesday of covering up the true death toll from riots last week, in which one organisation said at least 100 people were killed. Crowds of youths fought police and soldiers in several towns and cities when a strike by taxi drivers over fuel prices turned violent amid anger over President Paul Biya's plan to change the constitution to extend his 25-year rule.Communication Minister Jean-Pierre Biyiti bi Essam told Radio France International on Tuesday that 17 people had died, and accused human rights groups of exaggerating the death toll.But Madeleine Affite, Littoral Province coordinator for Action by Christians for the Abolition of Torture (ACAT), said the true death toll was higher. Littoral Province includes the commercial capital Douala and several other towns hit by riots.Fellow human rights activist Alice Nkom, who is a lawyer in Douala, agreed the official toll was too low. "There are many more than they are saying, and they were killed by bullets," she said. "They don't want people to know."
16 Palestinian civilians -- the youngest a 6-month-old boy -- have been killed in Gaza since clashes between Palestinian militants and the Israeli military escalated Wednesday.

Insurgents fired machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at Somali soldiers on patrol Saturday in the southern part of Mogadishu, said Mumin Mohamed Sahal and Muse Abdulle Hassan, who separately witnessed the fighting. Ethiopian soldiers, who are supporting the Somali government, later joined in. "I saw the dead bodies of five civilians and a government soldier in different places in our village," Hassan told The Associated Press on phone.Doctors at Mogadishu hospitals said they were treating at least 13 civilians wounded in Saturday's violence.

Victim.Noncombatant.Asserted: Noncombatant Status Asserted and Not Disputed
Description: Associated Press reported on 03/02/2008 that "At least 54 Palestinians, about half of them civilians, were killed Saturday [1 March 2008] in the deadliest day in Gaza since the current round of fighting erupted in 2000. Israeli forces went on the offensive to try to stop daily rocket barrages that have reached closer to its populated heartland than ever before. Two Israel soldiers were killed and seven were wounded in the clashes, the military said. Many of the civilians were caught in crossfires, like those in Dardouna's neighborhood, but Palestinians charged the Israelis were firing indiscriminately, labeling the offensive with emotionally charged terms -- "genocide" and "holocaust." At least two dozen Palestinian civilians, including a baby, were among those killed, and militants said 25 fighters died. Health officials said about 200 people were wounded, 14 of them critically."

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: residents of Jabaliya, residents of Jabaliya refugee camp
Description: Sixty-seven people, including 51 who were not identified as Palestinian fighters, were killed on Saturday alone as Israeli tanks backed up by helicopters, pushed into the town and refugee camp of Jabaliya in the northern Gaza Strip, pounding the area throughout the day. Two Israeli soldiers were also killed in clashes with Palestinian resistance fighters. At least 16 of the Palestinians killed were fighters - including 13 from Hamas, two from Islamic Jihad and one from the Popular Resistance Committees.
Comments: This event was obtained through the Open Source Center (OSC) and was recorded at the request of a sponsor.

Description: Five people were killed early Sunday morning in the northern Gaza Strip by Israeli airstrikes. No information on the identities of the victims was given.
Comments: This event was obtained through the Open Source Center (OSC) and was recorded at the request of a sponsor.

Description: Ugandan gunmen killed 20 south Sudanese, kidnapped others and stole thousands of cattle in a cross-border raid on a remote area on 4th March, southern Sudanese officials said.  Officials blamed the attack on the Ugandan People's Defence Force (UPDF).  Details remain unclear.

At least fifty-four people have been killed in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa from March 10 to March 16 as the result of Chinese crackdowns in the capital on protests. No information was given about victims' identities or the circumstances surrounding their deaths.
Secondary.Source: Thubten Samphel, spokesman for the Dalai Lama

Locality: Humera, 373 miles northwest of Addis Ababa
Description: A bomb attached to a bus exploded in northwestern Ethiopia Thursday, killing eight people, government officials said. Ethiopia said rival Eritrea was responsible. The bomb went off in Humera in Tigray State, about 373 miles northwest of the capital, Addis Ababa, Tigray State Vice President Abadi Zemo said. Humera borders Sudan. Eight people died in the explosion and 26 were wounded including an 11-year-old child, police spokesman Demsash Hailu said. Abadi blamed the Eritrean government. Eritrean Information Minister Ali Abdu denied the accusation, telling The Associated Press it was "total rubbish."

Twenty-six people were killed Saturday next to the Drapchi prison in Lhasa. The killings were part of the recent Chinese crackdown on protests. No other information was available about the victims' identity.
Secondary.Source: Tenzin Taklha, senior aide to the Dalai Lama

Description: The Tibetan Centre for Human Rights and Democracy sid on a website that People's Amed Police shot and killed at least 15 Tibetan protesters in Sichuan province's Tibetan-populated Aba county during protests by Tibetans. A police officer denied this claim.
Primary.Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post
Comments: This event was obtained through the Open Source Center (OSC) and was recorded at the request of a sponsor.

Description: At least sixty people were killed in demonstrations and crackdowns by the Chinese government in Tibet over the past week.
Secondary.Source: statement by Tibetan government in exile

Description: The People's Armed Police reportedly shot dead 19 peaceful protesters in Gansu province's Machu county on Monday.
Comments: This event was obtained through the Open Source Center (OSC) and was recorded at the request of a sponsor.

Description: More than 200 people have been killed in week-long clashes between Iraqi security forces and gunmen in the southern oil port of Basra, an Interior Ministry spokesman said. "We have 210 killed, including 42 serious criminals wanted for many crimes, 600 wounded and 155 criminals arrested since the start of the operation in Basra until this moment," spokesman Brigadier Abdul-Karim Khalaf told Reuters from Basra.
Comments: The number killed was arrived at by subtracting the 42 criminals killed from the total number killed of 210. It is assumed that these 168 people killed were noncombatants since they are not identified as either militants or security forces. It is unclear how many of the 600 wounded were noncombatants.

Victim.Identity.Political: Supporters of the opposition party Movement for Democratic Change
Description: More than 50 people have been killed in political violence since Zimbabwe's disputed March 29 elections and 25,000 have fled their homes, opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai said on Tuesday. Tsvangirai's Movement for Democratic Change accuses the ruling ZANU-PF party of launching a violent campaign against its supporters since the March elections to avoid another defeat next month. The ruling party denies the charge, and in turn blames the opposition for the violence. "Over 50 Zimbabweans have been killed in the past six weeks. More than 25,000 people have been displaced. I've been saddened that Zimbabweans are willing to shed the blood of other Zimbabweans over political differences," Tsvangirai said.

Mortar strikes on the Bakara Market killed and injured a number of civilians on Saturday, 30 March, 2008.  Ethiopian soldiers guarding President Abdullah Yusuf and Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin began launching shells into Bakara Market after Islamist insurgents attacked the Presidential Palace where the two men were meeting.  At least 17 people in the market were killed, but a leader of the business community in Bakara Market said 28 had been killed, including traders, customers and porters.
Contesting.Source: Leader of business community in Bakara
Comments: Estimates of numbers killed ranged from at least 17 to 28 persons.

Description: In the Garze Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture in Sichuan province, troops allegedly confronted at a road block Buddhist monks and lay people who were marching on government offices to demand the release of two monks detained for possessing pictures of the Dalai Lama. Troops fired on the crowd, killing eight, including at least three women and one monk, according to the London-based Free Tibet Campaign.
Secondary.Source: spokesman Matt Whitticase of the Free Tibet Campaign

Description: Speaking to the Afghan Islamic Press [AIP], the commander of the 4th battalion of southwest zone border brigade, Gen Rahmatollah Sapi, said: "This morning, a number of Afghans who were on their way to Afghanistan from Iran were attacked by Iranian soldiers, killing 12 of them in the Gandomdara border region of Iran. He said a number of Afghans were also detained by the Iranian soldiers and that some others have gone missing. Gen Rahmatollah Sapi said they were ordinary Afghans not smugglers and they were not doing any subversive activities, but the Iranian soldiers opened fire on them. They were mercilessly killed and treated inhumanly.  Iranian officials claimed the Afghans were smuggling items over the border into Afghanistan.
Comments: The data for this event comes from OSC articles

Description: Nepal was hit by fresh violence Wednesday, the eve of a landmark vote to decide the impoverished country's political destiny and scrap the monarchy. Police shot dead seven Maoists, officials said, and a man protesting the killing of an election candidate was also shot dead by police. "Seven Maoists were killed and 13 injured Tuesday night in police firing," said Balram Yadav, a senior police officer from rural western Dang district. Police shot at the Maoists after fighting with workers from the rival Nepali Congress spiraled out of control, the officer said. Maoists said a candidate from the rival Nepali Congress party ordered police to fire on their cadres.

Reuters reported that arguments between supporters and opponents of Musharraf became violent; mobs gathered after "anti-Musharraf lawyers clashed in court with his supporters." Reportedly, police fired shots to disperse the crowd, killing two men. The other deaths occurred when "lawyers were locked in the building and then the building was burnt." Reportedly, "five charred bodies of lawyers, including a women, were recovered from [the] building housing chambers of lawyers."

At least nine people were killed Monday when members of a banned Kenyan sect staged protests against the killing of their imprisoned leader's wife, police said. "Six were shot by police and three killed by Mungiki," a banned sect, a police commander told AFP. No other information was available.

Associated Press reported on 04/16/2008 that "Israel struck hard against targets in Gaza on Wednesday [16 April 2008], killing at least 20 Palestinians in a day of heavy fighting that also saw three Israeli soldiers killed in a Hamas ambush. Several civilians were among the dead -- including five children and a Reuters cameraman killed while covering the conflict, according to Palestinian officials. In the day's deadliest incident, an Israeli helicopter fired four missiles at targets near the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza, witnesses said. At least 12 Palestinians, including five children ages 12-15, were killed, said Dr. Moaiya Hassanain of the Palestinian Health Ministry."

Militias allied to the Somali government recaptured a southern port from Islamists on Tuesday, as the death toll from an upsurge of fighting in recent days rose to nearly 100, witnesses said. A spokesman for the Islamic Courts, Sheikh Ibrahim Suley, said the real death toll from the weekend violence in Mogadishu was much higher, and talks with the government had consequently been postponed indefinitely. "The Ethiopians killed around 200 people and kidnapped 160 others including 41 Koranic students ... We will continue fighting the Ethiopians and those under the protection of their tanks. We call on them to repent," Suley told Reuters.
Contesting.Source: A spokesman for the Islamic Courts, Sheikh Ibrahim Suley

Victim.Identity.Religious: Several Islamic scholars were among the dead
Description: Ethiopia rejected on Thursday accusations by Amnesty International that its soldiers killed 21 people at a Somali mosque as "lies" and "propaganda". The rights group said on Wednesday the soldiers, stationed in Somalia to bolster the interim government, had also captured dozens of children in a raid on the Al Hidaaya mosque earlier this week during operations against Islamist insurgents. It said an imam and several Islamic scholars were among the dead, and that seven victims had their throats slit. "Amnesty's allegations are unsubstantiated lies and propaganda that they received from Islamic groups in Somalia. Ethiopia has never been involved in such incidents," said Information Ministry spokesman Zemedkun Tekle. Bereket Simon, President Meles Zenawi's special adviser, also criticised the report, noting the human rights group has no presence in Somalia. "It is gathering hearsay and accusing Ethiopia based on false information." In a statement, U.N. humanitarian chief John Holmes urged protection for civilians and criticised the mosque raid. "He also strongly condemned the brutal killings that occurred on 20 April at Al Hidaaya mosque in Heliwaa district of Mogadishu, where women and children were present," said a statement from his New York office.

Prime Minister Ehud Olmert expressed regret on Tuesday over the killing of a Palestinian woman and four of her children in an Israeli raid in the Gaza Strip and said an army investigation was under way. "We still don't know the exact circumstances. They will be investigated by the army and it will publish the exact findings of this incident," he said. Residents of the northern Gaza town of Beit Hanoun said Israeli fire on Monday hit a family home, killing six people, including the woman and the children. The Israeli military disputed the account, describing the deaths as tragic and saying they occurred when an aircraft fired at two militants carrying bags filled with munitions that exploded and destroyed the home. Residents said no gunmen were killed in the explosion during what the Israeli military said was an operation against militants who fire rockets across the border into Israel from the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip. Olmert said Hamas militants were operating in heavily populated areas in the territory and turning Palestinian civilians "into an inseparable part of its war", exposing them to danger.

Ethiopian troops allied to Somalia's shaky government opened fire on civilians in a street in southwestern Somalia, killing 13 on Wednesday after an explosion there killed two soldiers, witnesses said.  Witness Mohamud Ahmed Nur said an explosion apparently caused by a remote-controlled land mine killed the two Ethiopian troops, who were patrolling the town of Baidoa.The soldiers, he said, then opened fire in all directions, killing at least 10 civilian passers-by outright. Mohamed Hussein Diriye, a doctor at the town's main hospital, said three more people died later of their injuries and that seven others were still being treated at the hospital, he said. In the capital Mogadishu, a Ethiopian military commander denied that his troops had opened fire, saying the bomb blast against the Ethiopia water truck was responsible for killing at least 17 civilians and one of his soldiers.
Primary.Source: Associated Press and Agence France Presse

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: Darfuris refusing to take part in the census
Description: Former Darfur rebels accused government militia fighters on Thursday of killing five Darfuris after they refused to take part in Sudan's census. Many in Darfur, where fighting has raged for five years, reject the count because they distrust the Khartoum government. A spokesman for Minni Arcua Minnawi, a former rebel who is now a presidential assistant, said people in camps around Shereia in South Darfur had refused to register when census officials came to take a count on Wednesday. "Because of that the Sudan army sent militias to attack those people," said Mohamed Dirbeen, the military spokesman of Minnawi. It was not possible to independently verify the reports. Sudan's army said it had no links to any militias attacking Minnawi's forces in South Darfur. A spokesman blamed any violence on continued clashes between Minnawi and a breakaway rebel faction.

The peacekeeping force in Darfur said Tuesday it was still trying to evacuate the wounded from airstrikes two days earlier on a school and a market in northern Darfur where 12 civilians, including six children, were reported killed. U.S.-based group Darfur Diaries said a school it funds in the village of Shegeg Karo was bombed Sunday. A statement from the group, released Monday, said villagers had provided names of six children, between the ages of 4 and 11, who were killed during the airstrike. One classroom was completely destroyed. It also said that local residents reported a Sudanese government aircraft had hovered over the area for some time before repeatedly bombing it. There was no immediate government comment on the reported attacks, which couldn't be independently verified. Sudanese forces frequently bomb rebel areas in Darfur, despite a U.N. Security Council ban on military flights over the western region. Darfur Diaries said six additional people were killed when the town's market area was bombed. It provided names for only five killed. Some 35 people were reportedly injured, including two children in critical condition, according to Darfur Diaries.
Secondary.Source: Darfur Diaries, a US-based aid group

Description: At least five demonstrators were killed Monday when Somali security forces fired at crowds protesting rising food prices in the capital Mogadishu, witnesses said.  "Police opened fire at civilians who were closing in on a police station (and) killed two demonstrators, including a young boy in Dharkiley area," Farah Mohamed Abdi told AFP. Another witness, Osman Mukhtar, said police shot two other civilians at a checkpoint in the Waberi area when they responded to grenade attack, bringing the total death toll to five from the demonstrations after another death was reported earlier. "Several people were wounded in Waberi area," Mukhtar added.

Some 23 were killed late Wednesday near the village of Garsani, some 300 kilometres (180 miles) north of Mogadishu, when insurgents ambushed an Ethiopian military convoy. Several witnesses said at least 13 civilians and eight Ethiopian soldiers had been killed in the fighting, while the insurgents admitted to losing two fighters in the battle. "The fighting was so heavy and our holy warriors with the help of Allah won a huge victory," Sheikh Abdirahin Ise, an Islamist spokesman told AFP. "In return they (Ethiopians) killed pastoralists who were near the fighting zone," he added.

Ethiopian forces late Wednesday killed at least 12 nomads in Walaweyne, about 90 kilometres (55 miles) east of Mogadishu, bringing the death toll to 35. Those nomads were setting up their makeshift camp in Almore village when they were killed by Ethiopia forces who had been ambushed by insurgents on a nearby road," Sheikh Mohamed Addow, another elder. "The Ethiopians slit throats of some people," he added. Another elder, Ali Omar confirmed the death toll said the bodies were being prepared for burial.

Dozens of people have been killed or wounded in renewed clashes between the Yemen army and Shiite rebels in the northwest, tribal sources said on Monday. "Fighting killed or wounded dozens of people, including many civilians," on Sunday and Monday in several regions across the Shiite Zaidi rebel stronghold of Saada, one source told AFP.

AP reported that "a pro-rebel web site said 17 civilians were killed Friday in a bomb attack carried out by Sri Lankan government forces". "The TamilNet web site said the attack took place in the Tamil Tiger stronghold of Kilnochchi and the victims included children. It accused elite government special forces soldiers of planting the bomb." A military spokesman denied involvement.

AFP reported that "Sri Lankan government commandos killed six civilians including two children with a roadside mine inside the Tamil Tiger-held north of the island." The attack "took place [in Mankulam village] in the Puliyankulam area, [and] also injured four others." Reportedly, "all the victims were from three families and the injured have been admitted to the Mullaittivu hospital." The Tigers blamed the army's 'Deep Penetration Unit' and said "there could have been no doubt in the attacker's mind that the vehicle belonged to civilians", but "there was no immediate comment from the Sri Lanka defence ministry, which does not comment on operations of its special forces."

Clashes between troops and suspected Islamic insurgents killed at least 12 civilians caught in the crossfire Sunday around the main market in the Somali capital, a merchant said. Both sides exchanged gunfire and mortar fire in and around the market, he said. Twelve civilians were killed. Dr. Dahir Dhere of Medina Hospital said 44 civilians wounded in the clashes were admitted to his hospital.

Islamist insurgents attacked Somali forces in Mogadishu on Thursday, sparking fierce clashes that killed at least five civilians, witnesses said. Rival sides pounded each other with machine guns, rocket propelled grenades and mortars after insurgents ambushed forces patrolling a road near the presidential palace. "The fighting is very heavy in a way we have never experienced in recent months. I have seen three civilians killed, " said Mohamed Younis Ali, a resident of Taleh district. Warsame Hussein saw two civilian bodies killed by a mortar shell in front of his house in the nearby Waberi area, bringing the toll to five.

MOGADISHU, June 18 (Reuters) - Fighting between Islamist-led insurgents and allied Somali-Ethiopian troops has killed at least 17 people, residents said on Wednesday, underlining the lack of impact of a U.N.-brokered peace agreement. One attack on a troop patrol on Tuesday night prompted return fire towards Mogadishu's SOS hospital, killing three people outside, witnesses said. Stray bullets from crossfire killed another three in a separate incident about the same time. Mogadishu resident Fatuma Hussein said a mortar landed on her neighbour's house, also on Tuesday night, killing a woman and two children. Staff at Mogadishu's Madina hospital said they took in 76 wounded people in the last 24 hours, of whom six died there.

Region: Gaza Strip, east of Khan Yunis
Description: Agence France Presse reported on 06/17/2008 that "Six Palestinians, including an Al-Qaeda linked militant, were killed in a string of Israeli air strikes on the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip on Tuesday [17 June 2008], according to medics and witnesses. Five people were killed and several others were wounded in an air strike near Qarara village east of the southern town of Khan Yunis, according to Muawiya Hassanein, the head of Gaza emergency services. "The number of dead has risen to five and a number of civilians have been wounded in an Israeli air strike that targeted a civilian car in the Qarara area," Hassanein said.
